 It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag as "yellow and blue", the current flag in reality is blue and yellow. The whole transition is quite notable. Although in 1848 the flag was indeed yellow and blue (yellow on top, blue at the bottom), in daily work Ukrainian nationalists turned the flag to be able to explain its meaning to a common person. The common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time, and, although it has nothing to do with the choice of colours and the history of the original yellow and blue banner, it did certainly formed the flag as we know it today.

 The '''flag of [[Ukraine]]''' was officially adopted for the first time in history in [[1918]] by a short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. At that time it had already turned into blue and yellow and sported a [[Tryzub]] in the upper left corner. The insignia remained unchanged by the successive government of [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]] and was later integrated into the [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR]] by the [[Bolsheviks]].

-==Hisotry==
+==History==
 Blue and white banners were widely used by [[Cossack]]s between XVI-XVIII century. However, it wasn't the only possible combination since normally cossacs would fly [[Hetman]]'s banners which were similar to the coats of arms of the nobility. However, yellow and blue were the colours common on coats of arms in [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]]. In fact, the coat of arms of [[Lviv]] to the day remains a golden lion on a blue field.
 
 The true starting point of the current national flag of Ukraine can be set in 1848, when during the [[The_Revolutions_of_1848_in_the_Habsburg_areas|Spring of the Nations]] yellow and blue banner flew over the Lviv magistrate for the first time. Although this move didn't have significant consequences, the newly formed Ukrainian divisions in the Austrian army used yellow and blue banners in their insignia.

 „...Державний Прапор України – стяг із двох рівновеликих горизонтальних смуг синього і жовтого кольорів.”
 Translation: “National Flag of Ukraine is a banner of two equal-sized horizontal strips colored blue and yellow”
 
-The '''flag of [[Ukraine]]''' was adopted in [[1918]], and is interpreted as the blue sky (symbolizing peace) over fields of wheat (symbolizing prosperity). The colors are the Blue and Yellow of the [[Rus]]. The Rus were originally from [[Sweden]], whose flag shares the same colors. 
+Blue and white banners were widely used by [[Cossack]]s between XVI-XVIII century. However, it wasn't the only possible combination since normally cossacs would fly [[Hetman]]'s banners which were similar to the coats of arms of the nobility. However, yellow and blue were the colours common on coats of arms in [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]]. In fact, the coat of arms of [[Lviv]] to the day remains a golden lion on a blue field.
 
-Under [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] rule this flag was forbidden as a symbol of [[nationalism]].  The [[Ukrainian SSR]] had its [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR|own flag]]. The flag was officially restored in [[1992]].
+The true starting point of the current national flag of Ukraine can be set in 1848, when during the [[The_Revolutions_of_1848_in_the_Habsburg_areas|Spring of the Nations]] yellow and blue banner flew over the Lviv magistrate for the first time. Although this move didn't have significant consequences, the newly formed Ukrainian divisions in the Austrian army used yellow and blue banners in their insignia. 
+
+It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag as "yellow and blue", the current flag in reality is blue and yellow. The whole transition is quite notable. Although in 1848 the flag was indeed yellow and blue (yellow on top, blue at the bottom), in daily work Ukrainian nationalists turned the flag to be able to explain its meaning to a common person. Common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time, and, although it has nothing to do with the choice of colours and the history of the original yellow and blue banner, it did certainly formed the flag as we know it today.
+[[Image:UPR flag.gif|thumb|Flag of Ukrainian People's Republic]]
+In late 19th century, Austro-Hungarian empire was much more tolerant towards Ukrainian national movement then Russian Empire. Therefore, a lot of literary work was done there, thus spreading the idea to the rest of Ukraine.
+
+The '''flag of [[Ukraine]]''' was officialy adopted for the first time in history in [[1918]] by a short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. At that time it already turned into blue and yellow and spotted a [[Tryzub]] in the upper left corner. The insignia remained unchanged by the successive government of [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]] and was later integrated into the [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR]] by bolsheviks. 
+
+Under [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] rule this flag was forbidden as a symbol of [[nationalism]].  The [[Ukrainian SSR]] had its [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR|own flag]]. The flag was officially restored in [[1992]]. 
 
 {{nationalflags}}<!-- to edit this table, go to [[Template:Nationalflags]] -->

The insignia remained unchanged by the successive government of [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]] and was later integrated into the [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR]] by the [[Bolsheviks]]. +[[Image:Flag of Ukraine.svg|thumb|275px|[[Image:FIAV_111110.svg|20px]] The Official National Flag of Ukraine ({{lang-uk|Державний Прапор України}}). Ratio: 2:3]] -Under [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] rule this flag was forbidden as a symbol of [[nationalism]]. The [[Ukrainian SSR]] had its [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR|own flag]]. The flag was officially restored in [[1992]]. +The '''Flag of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|Державний Прапор України}}; [[Romanization of Ukrainian|translit.]]: ''Derzhavnyi Prapor Ukrainy''; literally: ''Governmental Flag of Ukraine'') is the [[Ukraine|Ukrainian nation's]] national flag. It was officially adopted for the first time in history in [[1918]] by a short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. At that time it had already turned into blue and yellow and sported a [[Tryzub]] in the upper left corner. The insignia remained unchanged by the successive government of [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]] and was later integrated into the [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR]] by the [[Bolsheviks]]. + +Under [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] rule this flag was forbidden as a symbol of [[nationalism]]. The [[Ukrainian SSR]] had its [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR|own flag]]. The original yellow-and-blue flag was officially restored in [[1992]]. + +Article 20 of the Constitution of Ukraine states: +:
''...Державний Прапор України – стяг із двох рівновеликих горизонтальних смуг синього і жовтого кольорів.'' +:''...Translation: National Flag of Ukraine is a banner of two equal-sized horizontal strips colored blue and yellow.''
==History== + Blue and white banners were widely used by [[Cossack]]s between XVI-XVIII century. However, it wasn't the only possible combination since normally cossacs would fly [[Hetman]]'s banners which were similar to the coats of arms of the nobility. However, yellow and blue were the colours common on coats of arms in [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]]. In fact, the coat of arms of [[Lviv]] to the day remains a golden lion on a blue field. -[[Image:UPR flag.gif|thumb|200px|Flag of Ukrainian People's Republic]] + +[[Image:UPR flag.gif|thumb|225px|Flag of Ukrainian People's Republic]] + The true starting point of the current national flag of Ukraine can be set in 1848, when during the [[The Revolutions of 1848 in the Habsburg areas|Spring of the Nations]] a yellow and blue banner flew over the Lviv magistrate for the first time. Although this move didn't have significant consequences, the newly formed Ukrainian divisions in the Austrian army used yellow and blue banners in their insignia. It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag as "yellow and blue", the current flag in reality is blue and yellow. The whole transition is quite notable. Although in 1848 the flag was indeed yellow and blue (yellow on top, blue at the bottom), in daily work Ukrainian nationalists turned the flag to be able to explain its meaning to a common person. The common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time, and, although it has nothing to do with the choice of colours and the history of the original yellow and blue banner, it certainly formed the flag as we know it today. In the late 19th century, the Austro-Hungarian empire was much more tolerant toward the Ukrainian national movement than the Russian Empire concerning the flag. A lot of literary work was done there, thus spreading the idea to the rest of Ukraine. -Article 20 of the Constitution of Ukraine states: -"...Державний Прапор України – стяг із двох рівновеликих горизонтальних смуг синього і жовтого кольорів." -Translation: "National Flag of Ukraine is a banner of two equal-sized horizontal strips colored blue and yellow". +[[Image:Flag of Ukraine (Presidential Standard).gif|thumb|225px|Flag of Ukraine - ''Presidential standard.'']] + +===Return of the national flag=== + +Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[Perestroika]] and [[Glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet repulics had strengthened their sence of national unity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1985-1991)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned all of the [[Baltic]] Soviet Republics and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories to join the Soviet Union. These nationalistic efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian SSR (1940-1941 and 1944-1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed. + +The events in the Baltic Republics soon lead to similar processes in Ukraine. Particularly, West Ukraine and [[Ukrainian SSR]]'s capital [[Kiev|Kiev (''Kyiv'')]] constantly held political demonstrations with the national yellow-and-blue flags waving above the heads of the demonstrators. + +* On [[March 20]], [[1990]], the town council (''mis’ka rada'') of [[Ternopil]] voted upon the usage and re-establishment of the yellow-and-blue flag and the [[Coat of arms of Ukraine|''Tryzub'']] as well as the national anthem ''[[Ukraine's glory has not perished|Sche ne vmerla Ukrainy]]''. On the same day, the yellow-and-blue national flag was flown for the first time in about 80 years on a governmental building in Kiev, replacing the then official [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR|red-and-blue flag]] of the Ukrainian SSR. + +* On [[April 28]], [[1990]], the Oblast Administration (''oblasna rada'') of [[Lviv Oblast|Lvov (''Lviv'')]] also allowed the use of the national symbols of Ukraine within the Oblast. + +* On [[April 29]], [[1990]], the yellow-and-blue flag was flown from the Ternopil city theater's flagstaff without the [[Flag of the Soviet Union|official flag of the Soviet Union]] hanging above it. + +* After [[July 24]], [[1990]], the yellow-and-blue flag was flown for the first time over an official governmental building of the [[Kiev City Council]] on the ''[[Maidan Nezalezhnosti]]'' square of the ''[[Khreschatyk]]'' street. + +* After the declaration of independance of Ukraine on [[August 24]], [[1991]], the national yellow-and-blue flag flew for the first time over the [[Verkhovna Rada|Ukrainian Parliament (''Verkhovna Rada'')]] building on [[September 4]], [[1991]].
{{nationalflags}}

 It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag as "yellow and blue", the current flag in reality is blue and yellow. The whole transition is quite notable. Although in 1848 the flag was indeed yellow and blue (yellow on top, blue at the bottom), in daily work Ukrainian nationalists turned the flag to be able to explain its meaning to a common person. The common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time, and, although it has nothing to do with the choice of colours and the history of the original yellow and blue banner, it certainly formed the flag as we know it today.
 
 In the late 19th century, the [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian empire]] was much more tolerant toward the Ukrainian national movement than the Russian Empire concerning the flag. A lot of literary work was done there, thus spreading the idea to the rest of Ukraine.

+== Short Independency of Ukraine (1917 - 1920) ==

+
+Since then, the light-blue-yellow flag was used by many Ukrainian imigrant organizations.
+

 == Soviet Ukraine ==
 
 == World War II ==
+Various Ukrainian nationalist movements that functioned under German occupation used a blue-yellow (more often) or a yellow-blue flag. OUN (Melnyk's faction) added its symbol in the top left part. Ukrainian municipal and police bodies used the same flag, but its use depended on favor of local German (military) authorities.
+
+The Revolutionary Faction of OUN (Stepan bandera's faction) used a different flag, red-black.
+
+== Postwar Ukraine ==
+In 1947 Soviet republics, including Ukraine, adopted new flags instead of previous featureless ones. The new Ukrainian flag consisted of a red (top, 2/3) and a blue (bottom, 1/3) stripes, with golden star, hammer and sickle in the top left corner.
 
 ==Return of the national flag==

@@ -32,23 +32,28 @@
 
 In the late 19th century, the [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian empire]] was much more tolerant toward the Ukrainian national movement than the Russian Empire concerning the flag. A lot of literary work was done there, thus spreading the idea to the rest of Ukraine.
 
-== Short Independence of Ukraine (1917 - 1920) ==
+===Short independence: 1917–1920===
+
 The light-blue-yellow flag was the official flag of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in 1917-1918. It was then replaced by dark-blue-yellow flag of the [[Hetmanate]] under [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]] and again changed to light-blue-yellow under [[Semen Petlura]]'s [[Directorate of Ukraine|Directorate]].
 
 Since then, the light-blue-yellow flag was used by many Ukrainian immigrant organizations.
 
-== Soviet Ukraine ==
-Soviet Ukraine, similarly to other Soviet republics, used a red flag with golden abbreviation "УСРР" or "УРСР" (Ukrainian Socialist Soviet Republic or Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic) in the top left corner. Nothing in this flag reminded about the Ukrainian national identity.
+===Soviet Ukraine: 1922-1991===
+{{main|Flag of the Ukrainian SSR}}
 
-== World War II ==
+The [[Ukrainian SSR|Soviet Ukraine]] similarly to other [[Republics of the Soviet Union|Soviet republics]], used a red flag with golden abbreviation "УСРР" or "УРСР" (Ukrainian Socialist Soviet Republic or Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic) in the top left corner. Nothing in this flag reminded about the Ukrainian national identity.
+
+===World War II===
+
 Various Ukrainian nationalist movements that functioned under German occupation used a blue-yellow (more often) or a yellow-blue flag. OUN (Melnyk's faction) added its symbol in the top left part. Ukrainian municipal and police bodies used the same flag, but its use depended on favor of local German (military) authorities. The police used arm-bands with yellow and blue stripes, which could look differently in different regions ([http://ffix1975.livejournal.com/1031966.html]).
 
 The Revolutionary Faction of OUN (Stepan bandera's faction) used a different flag, red-black.
 
-== Postwar Ukraine ==
+===Postwar Ukraine===
+
 In 1947 Soviet republics, including Ukraine, adopted new flags instead of previous featureless ones. The new Ukrainian flag consisted of a red (top, 2/3) and a blue (bottom, 1/3) stripes, with golden star, hammer and sickle in the top left corner.
 
-==Return of the national flag==
+===Return of the national flag===
 
 Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[Perestroika]] and [[Glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national unity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1985-1991)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian SSR (1940-1941 and 1944-1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed.

 [[Image:Flag of Ukrainian People's Republic.svg|thumb|250px|[[Image:FIAV historical.svg|23x15px]] The national flag of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] ([[March 22]], [[1918]]).]]
 
-The true starting point of the current national flag of Ukraine can be set in 1848, when during the [[The Revolutions of 1848 in the Habsburg areas|Spring of the Nations]] a yellow and blue banner flew over the Lviv magistrate for the first time. Although this move didn't have significant consequences, the newly formed Ukrainian divisions in the Austrian army used yellow and blue banners in their insignia. 
+The true starting point of the current national flag of Ukraine can be set in 1848, when during the [[The Revolutions of 1848 in the Habsburg areas|Spring of the Nations]] a yellow and blue banner flew over the Lviv magistrate for the first time. Although this move didn't have significant consequences, the newly formed Ukrainian divisions in the Austrian army used yellow and blue banners in their insignia.
 
-It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag as "yellow and blue", the current flag in reality is blue and yellow. The whole transition is quite notable. Although in 1848 the flag was indeed yellow and blue (yellow on top, blue at the bottom), in daily work Ukrainian nationalists turned the flag to be able to explain its meaning to a common person. The common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time, and, although it has nothing to do with the choice of colours and the history of the original yellow and blue banner, it certainly formed the flag as we know it today.
+It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the verbal language as "yellow and blue", the current flag in reality is blue (the top string) and yellow (the bottom string). The issue is quite notable, because the historical  rotation of the flag (from yellow-blue to blue-yellow) did not affect the spoken language. Back in 1848 the flag was indeed yellow and blue, and it was later rotated to blue and yellow to be appealing to a common person. The common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time, and, although it has nothing to do with the choice of colours and the history of the original yellow and blue banner, it certainly formed the flag as we know it today.
 
 In the late 19th century, the [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian empire]] was much more tolerant toward the Ukrainian national movement than the Russian Empire concerning the flag. A lot of literary work was done there, thus spreading the idea to the rest of Ukraine.
 
 ===Short independence: 1917–1920===
+[[Image:Unr_plakat.jpg|thumb|right|250px|B.Shippikh, [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] Poster, Kiev, 1917.]]
 
-The light-blue-yellow flag was the official flag of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in 1917-1918. It was then replaced by dark-blue-yellow flag of the [[Hetmanate]] under [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]] and again changed to light-blue-yellow under [[Semen Petlura]]'s [[Directorate of Ukraine|Directorate]].
+Both, blue-yellow and yellow-blue flags were widely used during the [[Ukraine after the Russian Revolution|Ukrainain struggle for independence]] in 1917-1920. 
 
-Since then, the light-blue-yellow flag was used by many Ukrainian immigrant organizations.
+At present, there are no reliable sources that indicate that an official flag was declared by [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in 1917-1918. Some sources mention that the yellow-blue was adopted by [[Tsentralna Rada]] on [[March 22]], [[1918]]. Other sources point out that no hard proof of such decision exists.<ref>http://vexillography.narod.ru/ukraine/unr.htm</ref> Instead, they refer to the decision on Fleet Flag, which was set to be lightblue-yellow<ref>http://www.history.org.ua/journal/1999/4/10.pdf</ref> as an indication that the offical flag was lightblue-yellow.<ref>http://vijsko.milua.org/Khoruhvy_HA.htm</ref>
+
+The official flag of [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]]'s [[Hetmanate]] was blue-yellow and became lightblue-yellow under [[Semen Petlura]]'s [[Directorate of Ukraine|Directorate]]. The flag of [[West Ukrainian National Republic]] was blue and yellow.
+
+Among Ukrainian immigrant organizations there were proponents of both blue-yellow and yellow-blue flags. Eventually, it was agreed to use the lightblue-yellow flag until the issue is resolved in the independent Ukraine.
 
 ===Soviet Ukraine: 1922-1991===

Some sources mention that the yellow-blue was adopted by [[Tsentralna Rada]] on [[March 22]], [[1918]]<ref>[http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=32027&cat_id=31295 State Symbols of Ukraine] Cabinet of Ministries of Ukraine, website.</ref> Other sources point out that no hard proof of such decision exists.<ref>http://vexillography.narod.ru/ukraine/unr.htm</ref> Instead, they refer to the decision on Fleet Flag, which was set to be lightblue-yellow<ref>http://www.history.org.ua/journal/1999/4/10.pdf</ref> as an indication that the official flag was lightblue-yellow.<ref>http://vijsko.milua.org/Khoruhvy_HA.htm</ref>

initial_version:
<center>[[Image:Ukraine_flag_large.png]]</center>
'''Flag Ratio:''' 2:3

The flag of [[Ukraine]] was adopted on [[September 3]], [[1996]].  It had been the provisional flag since [[1991]].
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -28,7 +28,7 @@
 
 The true starting point of the current national flag of Ukraine can be set in 1848, when during the [[The Revolutions of 1848 in the Habsburg areas|Spring of the Nations]] a yellow and blue banner flew over the Lviv magistrate for the first time. Although this move didn't have significant consequences, the newly formed Ukrainian divisions in the Austrian army used yellow and blue banners in their insignia.
 
-It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the verbal language as "yellow and blue", the current flag in reality is blue (the top string) and yellow (the bottom string). The issue is quite notable, because the historical  rotation of the flag (from yellow-blue to blue-yellow) did not affect the spoken language. Back in 1848 the flag was indeed yellow and blue, and it was later rotated to blue and yellow to be appealing to a common person. The common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time, and, although it has nothing to do with the choice of colours and the history of the original yellow and blue banner, it certainly formed the flag as we know it today.
+It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the verbal language as "yellow and lightblue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}), the current flag in reality is blue (the top string) and yellow (the bottom string). The issue is quite notable, because the historical  rotation of the flag (from yellow-blue to blue-yellow) did not affect the spoken language. Back in 1848 the flag was indeed yellow and blue, and it was later rotated to blue and yellow to be appealing to a common person. The common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time, and, although it has nothing to do with the choice of colours and the history of the original yellow and blue banner, it certainly formed the flag as we know it today.
 
 In the late 19th century, the [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian empire]] was much more tolerant toward the Ukrainian national movement than the Russian Empire concerning the flag. A lot of literary work was done there, thus spreading the idea to the rest of Ukraine.
 
@@ -83,10 +83,9 @@
 </gallery>
 </center>
 
-==References==
-<references/>
+==Colors==
+Other that the statement of Ukrainian flag being "blue and yellow" the law of Ukraine is silent on the specifics of the blue and yellow colors. However, [[heraldry|heraldic]] communities attempt to fill the gap and specify the "true" colors of the flag. In the table below the colors are given according to amateurs site vexilla-mundi.com:
 
-==Colors==
 {| width="60%" border="1" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="0" style="background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px solid #aaaaaa; border-collapse: collapse; white-space: nowrap; text-align: left"
 |- style="text-align: center; background: #eee"
 ! Scheme
@@ -105,6 +104,12 @@
 | 70-40-0-23
 | 0-11-91-2
 |}
+
+===Lighblue vs. Darkblue===
+In Ukrainian and other Slavic languages, lightblue and darkblue colors are two main distinguishable colors. In English, there are commonly six colors of [[rainbow]] (red, orange, yellow, green, blue, and violet), while in Ukrainian rainbow consists of seven colors, which blue being spitted into two. It creates the difficulty of translation of blue between Ukrainian and English languages. If blue is avoided for clarity, the official Ukrainian flag is darkblue-yellow, and in the spoken language it's commonly called yellow-lightblue.
+
+==References==
+<references/>
 
 ==See also==
 * [[List of flags of Ukraine]]

This focus on specific color distinctions may serve to reinforce cultural narratives surrounding the Ukrainian flag and its representation.

 The '''Flag of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|Державний Прапор України}}; [[Romanization of Ukrainian|translit.]]: ''Derzhavnyi Prapor Ukrainy''; literally: ''State Flag of Ukraine'') is the [[Ukraine|Ukrainian nation's]] national flag. The national flag was officially adopted for the first time in [[1918]] by a short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. At that time the commonly used yellow-blue flag had already turned into blue and yellow and sported a [[Tryzub]] in the upper left corner. The insignia remained unchanged by the [[Hetmanate|successive government]] of [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]], and then by the [[Directorate of Ukraine]].

changed_version:
---

@@ -39,6 +39,7 @@
 It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the verbal language as "yellow and lightblue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}), the current flag in reality is blue (the top string) and yellow (the bottom string). The issue is quite notable, because the historical rotation of the flag (from yellow-blue to blue-yellow) did not affect the spoken language. Back in 1848 the flag was indeed yellow and blue, and it was later rotated to blue and yellow to be appealing to a common person. The common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time, and, although it has nothing to do with the choice of colours and the history of the original yellow and blue banner, it certainly formed the flag as we know it today.
 
 In the late 19th century, the [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian Empire]] was much more tolerant toward the Ukrainian national movement than the Russian Empire concerning the flag. A lot of literary work was done there, thus spreading the idea to the rest of Ukraine.
+<br clear="all">

 ===Light blue vs. dark blue===
-In Ukrainian and other Slavic languages, light blue (блакитний) and dark blue (синій) colors are main distinguished colors. The difference is coming from ancient times. In English (Latin) culture, there are commonly six colors of [[rainbow]] (red, orange, yellow, green, blue, and violet), while in Ukrainian (Slavic) a rainbow consists of seven colors with blue being split into two. The difference creates difficulties in translation of blue between Ukrainian and English. If blue is avoided for clarity, the colors of the official Ukrainian flag is dark blue and yellow, while in spoken language Ukrainians often name their flag as being yellow and light blue (жовтоблакитний прапор).
+In Ukrainian and other Slavic languages, light blue (блакитний) and dark blue (синій) colors are main distinguished colors. The difference is coming from ancient times. In English (Latin) culture, there are commonly six colors of [[rainbow]] (red, orange, yellow, green, blue, and violet), while in Ukrainian (Slavic) a rainbow consists of seven colors with blue being split into two. The difference creates difficulties in translation of blue between Ukrainian and English. If blue is avoided for clarity, the colors of the official Ukrainian flag is dark blue and yellow, while in spoken language Ukrainians often name their flag as being yellow and light blue (жовто-блакитний прапор).

 {{reflist}}

+The Law of Ukraine states that the colors of Ukrainian flag are "blue and yellow", being silent on the specifics of the blue and yellow colors. In English, there are commonly six colors of [[rainbow]] (red, orange, yellow, green, blue, and violet), while in Ukrainian rainbow consists of seven colors, which blue being spited into two. +===Light blue vs. dark blue===
+In Ukrainian and other Slavic languages, light blue (блакитний) and dark blue (синій) colors are main distinguished colors. The difference is coming from ancient times. In English (Latin) culture, there are commonly six colors of [[rainbow]] (red, orange, yellow, green, blue, and violet), while in Ukrainian (Slavic) a rainbow consists of seven colors with blue being split into two. The difference creates difficulties in translation of blue between Ukrainian and English. If blue is avoided for clarity, the colors of the official Ukrainian flag is dark blue and yellow, while in spoken language Ukrainians often name their flag as being yellow and light blue (жовтоблакитний прапор).

The blue and yellow flag was forbidden as a symbol of [[nationalism]].{{Fact|date=October 2008}} It was officially restored in 1992 following Ukrainian independence.
 
 [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]] of the [[Constitution of Ukraine]] states “the State Flag of Ukraine is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow colour.”

At that time the commonly used yellow–blue flag had already turned into blue and yellow and sported a trident (''[[tryzub]]'') in the upper left corner. The insignia remained unchanged by the [[Hetmanate|successive government]] of [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]], and then by the [[Directorate of Ukraine]]. During the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] era, [[Bolsheviks]] had been using red and later red-blue flags as the official [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR]]. The blue and yellow flag was officially restored in 1992 following Ukrainian independence.
 
 [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]] of the [[Constitution of Ukraine]] states “the State Flag of Ukraine is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow colour.”
llm_output:
Removed a sentence about the blue and yellow flag being forbidden as a symbol of nationalism during the Soviet era.

Not Weaponised – The change does not introduce or remove any language that could be interpreted as weaponising cultural heritage; it simply removes a historical detail without altering the overall narrative.

In 1937 [[hammer and sickle]] symbol in gold was added to the flag.
-
-===World War II===
-
-Various Ukrainian nationalist movements that functioned under German occupation used a blue–yellow (more often) or a yellow–blue flag. The OUN ([[Andriy Melnyk]]'s faction) added its symbol in the upper left part. Ukrainian municipal and police bodies used the same flag, but its use depended on the favor of local German (military) authorities. The police used armbands with yellow and blue stripes, which could look differently in different regions.<ref>http://ffix1975.livejournal.com/1031966.html</ref>
-
-The Revolutionary Faction of the OUN ([[Stepan Bandera]]'s faction) used a different flag, red-black.
 
 ===Postwar Ukraine===

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -141,7 +141,7 @@
 |}
 
 ===Light blue vs. dark blue===
-Article 20 of the Constitution of Ukraine states the following, citing: "State Flag of Ukraine is a banner which consists of two equal horizontal stripes of dark blue and yellow colors" ([[Ukrainian language|ukr]]: ''"Державний Прапор України — стяг із двох рівновеликих горизонтальних смуг синього і жовтого кольорів"'' <ref name=constitution_article>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96-%E2%F0 Constitution of Ukraine]</ref>).
+Article 20 of the Constitution of Ukraine states the following, citing: ''"State Flag of Ukraine is a banner which consists of two equal horizontal stripes of dark blue and yellow colors"'' ([[Ukrainian language|ukr]]: ''"Державний Прапор України — стяг із двох рівновеликих горизонтальних смуг синього і жовтого кольорів"'' <ref name=constitution_article>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96-%E2%F0 Constitution of Ukraine]</ref>).
 
 In Ukrainian and other Slavic languages, light blue (''blakytnyy'') and dark blue (''syniy'') colors are main distinguished colors. The difference is coming from ancient times. In English (Latin) culture, there are commonly six colors of [[rainbow]] (red, orange, yellow, green, blue, and violet), while in Ukrainian (Slavic) a rainbow consists of seven colors with blue being split into two. The difference creates difficulties in translation of blue between Ukrainian and English. If blue is avoided for clarity, the colors of the official Ukrainian flag is dark blue and yellow, while in spoken language Ukrainians often name their flag as being yellow and light blue (''zhovto-blakytnyy prapor'').
llm_output:
Changed the text formatting of a citation regarding the State Flag of Ukraine.

Not Weaponised – The change is purely stylistic and does not introduce any weaponised language or narratives related to cultural heritage.

@@ -141,6 +141,8 @@
 |}
 
 ===Light blue vs. dark blue===
+Article 20 of the Constitution of Ukraine states the following, citing: "State Flag of Ukraine is a banner which consists of two equal horizontal stripes of dark blue and yellow colors" ([[Ukrainian language|ukr]]: ''"Державний Прапор України — стяг із двох рівновеликих горизонтальних смуг синього і жовтого кольорів"'' <ref name=constitution_article>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96-%E2%F0 Constitution of Ukraine]</ref>).
+
 In Ukrainian and other Slavic languages, light blue (''blakytnyy'') and dark blue (''syniy'') colors are main distinguished colors. The difference is coming from ancient times. In English (Latin) culture, there are commonly six colors of [[rainbow]] (red, orange, yellow, green, blue, and violet), while in Ukrainian (Slavic) a rainbow consists of seven colors with blue being split into two. The difference creates difficulties in translation of blue between Ukrainian and English. If blue is avoided for clarity, the colors of the official Ukrainian flag is dark blue and yellow, while in spoken language Ukrainians often name their flag as being yellow and light blue (''zhovto-blakytnyy prapor'').
 
 ==References==

 The color blue of the Ukrainian Flag represents the color of the sky, and yellow symbolizes the lush golden wheat fields of this country.{{fact}} These two colors, blue and yellow, have been associated with Ukraine from the times before the introduction of Christianity. Now they are incorporated into the flag of Ukraine. 
 
-However, Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as yellow and blue (Zovto-Blakitnij) - a different version of the flag used during UNR (Ukrainian National Republic) years. With yellow on the top and blue on the bottom.  Yellow on the top represents golden roofs (Kupola) of christian churches and blue - river Dniper.  
+However, Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as yellow and blue (Zovto-Blakitnij) - a different version of the flag used during UNR (Ukrainian National Republic) years. With yellow on the top and blue on the bottom.  Yellow on the top represents golden roofs (Kupola) of Christian churches and blue - river Dniper.  
 
 The roots of Ukrainian national symbols come from before Christian times when yellow and blue prevailed in traditional ceremonies, reflecting fire and water.<ref name=Saprykov>[http://geraldika.ru/symbols/3334 Geraldika.ru Флаг Украины]</ref>

initial_version:
<center>[[Image:Ukraine_flag_large.png]]</center>
'''Flag Ratio:''' 2:3

The flag of [[Ukraine]] was adopted on [[September 3]], [[1996]].  It had been the provisional flag since [[1991]].
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -143,7 +143,7 @@
 ===Light blue vs. dark blue===
 Article 20 of the Constitution of Ukraine states the following, citing: ''"State Flag of Ukraine is a banner which consists of two equal horizontal stripes of dark blue and yellow colors"'' ([[Ukrainian language|ukr]]: ''"Державний Прапор України — стяг із двох рівновеликих горизонтальних смуг синього і жовтого кольорів"'' <ref name=constitution_article>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96-%E2%F0 Constitution of Ukraine]</ref>).
 
-In Ukrainian and other Slavic languages, light blue (''blakytnyy'') and dark blue (''syniy'') colors are main distinguished colors. The difference is coming from ancient times. In English (Latin) culture, there are commonly six colors of [[rainbow]] (red, orange, yellow, green, blue, and violet), while in Ukrainian (Slavic) a rainbow consists of seven colors with blue being split into two. The difference creates difficulties in translation of blue between Ukrainian and English. If blue is avoided for clarity, the colors of the official Ukrainian flag is dark blue and yellow, while in spoken language Ukrainians often name their flag as being yellow and light blue (''zhovto-blakytnyy prapor'').
+In Ukrainian and other Slavic languages, light blue (''blakytnyy'') and dark blue (''syniy'') colors are main distinguished colors. The difference dates back to ancient times. In English (Latin) culture, there are commonly six colors of the [[rainbow]] (red, orange, yellow, green, blue, and violet), while in Ukrainian (Slavic) a rainbow consists of seven colors with blue being split into two. The difference creates difficulties in translation of blue between Ukrainian and English. If blue is avoided for clarity, the colors of the official Ukrainian flag is dark blue and yellow, while in spoken language Ukrainians often name their flag as being yellow and light blue (''zhovto-blakytnyy prapor'').
 
 Based on the Flags in use in the photos on the [http://www.president.gov.ua/en/gallery/745.html Photo Gallery of the President of the Ukraine] a darker blue is used for the Presidential Flag and a Cyanish Medium Blue is used for the National Flag.
llm_output:
Changed the phrase "The difference is coming from ancient times" to "The difference dates back to ancient times."

Not Weaponised. The change is a stylistic improvement for clarity and does not introduce any weaponisation of cultural heritage narratives.

The flag of [[Ukraine]] was adopted on [[September 3]], [[1996]].  It had been the provisional flag since [[1991]].
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -144,6 +144,8 @@
 Article 20 of the Constitution of Ukraine states the following, citing: ''"State Flag of Ukraine is a banner which consists of two equal horizontal stripes of dark blue and yellow colors"'' ([[Ukrainian language|ukr]]: ''"Державний Прапор України — стяг із двох рівновеликих горизонтальних смуг синього і жовтого кольорів"'' <ref name=constitution_article>[http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=254%EA%2F96-%E2%F0 Constitution of Ukraine]</ref>).
 
 In Ukrainian and other Slavic languages, light blue (''blakytnyy'') and dark blue (''syniy'') colors are main distinguished colors. The difference is coming from ancient times. In English (Latin) culture, there are commonly six colors of [[rainbow]] (red, orange, yellow, green, blue, and violet), while in Ukrainian (Slavic) a rainbow consists of seven colors with blue being split into two. The difference creates difficulties in translation of blue between Ukrainian and English. If blue is avoided for clarity, the colors of the official Ukrainian flag is dark blue and yellow, while in spoken language Ukrainians often name their flag as being yellow and light blue (''zhovto-blakytnyy prapor'').
+
+Based on the Flags in use in the photos on the [http://www.president.gov.ua/en/gallery/745.html Photo Gallery of the President of the Ukraine] a darker blue is used for the Presidential Flag and a Cyanish Medium Blue is used for the National Flag.

 {{reflist}}

 The '''Flag of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|державний прапор України}}; [[Romanization of Ukrainian|translit.]]: ''derzhavnyy prapor Ukrayiny''; literally ‘state flag of Ukraine’) is the national flag of [[Ukraine]]. The national flag was officially adopted for the first time in 1918 by a short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. At that time the commonly used yellow–blue flag had already turned into blue and yellow and sported a trident (''[[tryzub]]'') in the upper left corner. The insignia remained unchanged by the [[Hetmanate|successive government]] of [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]], and then by the [[Directorate of Ukraine]]. During the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] era, [[Bolsheviks]] had been using red and later red-blue flags as the official [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR]]. The blue and yellow flag was officially restored in 1992 following Ukrainian independence.

 The official flag of [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]]'s [[Hetmanate]] was blue–yellow and became light blue–yellow under [[Semen Petlura]]'s [[Directorate of Ukraine|Directorate]]. The flag of [[West Ukrainian National Republic]] was blue and yellow.
 
@@ -139,15 +139,15 @@
 
 The events in the Baltic countries soon led to similar processes in Ukraine. Particularly, West Ukraine and [[Ukrainian SSR]]'s capital [[Kiev]] (''Kyiv'') constantly held political demonstrations with the national yellow-and-blue flags waving above the heads of demonstrators.
 
-* On [[March 20]], [[1990]], the town council of [[Ternopil]] voted upon the usage and re-establishment of the yellow-and-blue flag and the [[Coat of arms of Ukraine|''tryzub'']] as well as the national anthem ''[[Ukraine's glory has not perished|Shche ne vmerla Ukrainy]]''. On the same day, the yellow-and-blue national flag was flown for the first time in about 80 years on a governmental building in Kiev, replacing the then official [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR|red-and-blue flag]] of the Ukrainian SSR.
-
-* On [[April 28]], [[1990]], the oblast council (''oblasna rada'') of [[Lviv Oblast|Lviv]] also allowed the use of the national symbols of Ukraine within the Oblast.
-
-* On [[April 29]], [[1990]], the yellow-and-blue flag was flown from the Ternopil city theater's flagstaff without the [[Flag of the Soviet Union|official flag of the Soviet Union]] hanging above it.
-
-* After [[July 24]], [[1990]], the yellow-and-blue flag was flown for the first time over an official governmental building of the [[Kiev City Council]] on the ''[[Maidan Nezalezhnosti]]'' square of the ''[[Khreschatyk]]'' street.
-
-* After the declaration of independence of Ukraine on [[August 24]], [[1991]], the national yellow-and-blue flag flew for the first time over the [[Verkhovna Rada|Ukrainian Parliament (''Verkhovna Rada'')]] building on [[September 4]], [[1991]].
+* On March 20, 1990, the town council of [[Ternopil]] voted upon the usage and re-establishment of the yellow-and-blue flag and the [[Coat of arms of Ukraine|''tryzub'']] as well as the national anthem ''[[Ukraine's glory has not perished|Shche ne vmerla Ukrainy]]''. On the same day, the yellow-and-blue national flag was flown for the first time in about 80 years on a governmental building in Kiev, replacing the then official [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR|red-and-blue flag]] of the Ukrainian SSR.
+
+* On April 28, 1990, the oblast council (''oblasna rada'') of [[Lviv Oblast|Lviv]] also allowed the use of the national symbols of Ukraine within the Oblast.
+
+* On April 29, 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown from the Ternopil city theater's flagstaff without the [[Flag of the Soviet Union|official flag of the Soviet Union]] hanging above it.
+
+* After July 24, 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown for the first time over an official governmental building of the [[Kiev City Council]] on the ''[[Maidan Nezalezhnosti]]'' square of the ''[[Khreschatyk]]'' street.
+
+* After the declaration of independence of Ukraine on August 24, 1991, the national yellow-and-blue flag flew for the first time over the [[Verkhovna Rada|Ukrainian Parliament (''Verkhovna Rada'')]] building on September 4, 1991.

-The official flag of [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]]'s [[Hetmanate]] was blue–yellow and became light blue–yellow under [[Semen Petlura]]'s [[Directorate of Ukraine|Directorate]]. The flag of [[West Ukrainian National Republic]] was blue and yellow.
+At present, there are no reliable sources that indicate that an official flag was declared by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in 1917-1918. Some sources mention that the yellow–blue was adopted by [[Tsentralna Rada]] on March 29, 1918<ref>[http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=32027&cat_id=31295 State Symbols of Ukraine], [[Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine]], website.</ref> Other sources point out that no hard proof of such decision exists.<ref>http://vexillography.narod.ru/ukraine/unr.htm</ref> Instead, they refer to the decision on the Fleet Flag, which was set to be light blue–yellow<ref>[http://www.history.org.ua/journal/1999/4/10.pdf Ukrainian Historical Journal, 1999, #4, ISSN 0130-S247]</ref> as an indication that the official flag was light blue–yellow.<ref>[http://vijsko.milua.org/Khoruhvy_HA.htm Українське військо у ХХ-ХХІ сторіччі]</ref>
+
+The official flag of [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]]'s [[Hetmanate]] was blue–yellow and became light blue–yellow under [[Semen Petlura]]'s [[Directorate of Ukraine|Directorate]]. The flag of [[West Ukrainian National Republic]] was blue and yellow but changed over time.
 
 Among Ukrainian immigrant organizations there were proponents of both blue–yellow and yellow–blue flags. Eventually, it was agreed to use the light blue–yellow flag until the issue was resolved in the independent Ukraine.

 The '''Flag of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|державний прапор України}}; [[Romanization of Ukrainian|translit.]]: ''derzhavnyy prapor Ukrayiny''; literally ‘state flag of Ukraine’) is the national flag of [[Ukraine]]. The national flag was officially adopted for the first time in 1918 by a short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. At that time the commonly used yellow–blue flag had already turned into blue and yellow and sported a trident (''[[tryzub]]'') in the upper left corner. The insignia remained unchanged by the [[Hetmanate|successive government]] of [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]], and then by the [[Directorate of Ukraine]]. During the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] era, [[Bolsheviks]] had been using red and later red-blue flags as the official [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR]]. The blue and yellow flag was officially restored in 1992 following Ukrainian independence.
 
 [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]] of the [[Constitution of Ukraine]] states “the State Flag of Ukraine is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow colour.”
 
 ==History==
-[[File:Flag of Ukraine.jpg|thumb|250px|left|Flag of Ukraine]]
-
-[[File:Repin Cossacks.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Yellow–blue and red-black Cossack flags at [[Reply of the Zaporozhian Cossacks]] painting by [[Ilya Repin]], 1880-1891.]]
-[[File:Propaganda UPR.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Yellow–blue flag at [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] Poster, B.Shippikh, Kiev, 1917.]]
-
 The color blue of the Ukrainian Flag represents the color of the sky, and yellow symbolizes the lush golden wheat fields of this country.{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}} These two colors, blue and yellow, have been associated with Ukraine from the times before the introduction of Christianity. Now they are incorporated into the flag of Ukraine. 
 
 However, Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as yellow and blue (Zovto-Blakitnij) - a different version of the flag used during UNR (Ukrainian National Republic) years (1917-1921). With yellow on the top and blue on the bottom.  Yellow on the top represents golden roofs (Kupola) of Christian churches and blue - river Dniper.  
@@ -142,8 +121,6 @@
 
 Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[Perestroika]] and [[Glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national unity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1985-1991)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian SSR (1940-1941 and 1944-1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed.
 
-[[File:Kiev Maidan Flag.jpg|thumb|250px|The Ukrainian flag flying on [[Maidan Nezalezhnosti]].]]
-
 The events in the Baltic countries soon led to similar processes in Ukraine. Particularly, West Ukraine and [[Ukrainian SSR]]'s capital [[Kiev]] (''Kyiv'') constantly held political demonstrations with the national yellow-and-blue flags waving above the heads of demonstrators.
 
 * On March 20, 1990, the town council of [[Ternopil]] voted upon the usage and re-establishment of the yellow-and-blue flag and the [[Coat of arms of Ukraine|''tryzub'']] as well as the national anthem ''[[Ukraine's glory has not perished|Shche ne vmerla Ukrainy]]''. On the same day, the yellow-and-blue national flag was flown for the first time in about 80 years on a governmental building in Kiev, replacing the then official [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR|red-and-blue flag]] of the Ukrainian SSR.

initial_version:
<center>[[Image:Ukraine_flag_large.png]]</center>
'''Flag Ratio:''' 2:3

The flag of [[Ukraine]] was adopted on [[September 3]], [[1996]].  It had been the provisional flag since [[1991]].
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -61,7 +61,7 @@
 Some put the starting point of the current national flag of Ukraine in year 1848, when during the [[The Revolutions of 1848 in the Habsburg areas|Spring of the Nations]] a yellow and blue banner flew over the Lviv magistrate for the first time. Although this move didn't have significant consequences, the newly formed Ukrainian divisions in the Austrian army used yellow and blue banners in their insignia.
 
 It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the verbal language as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy''), the current flag in reality is blue (the top string) and yellow (the bottom string). The issue is quite notable, because the historical rotation of the flag (from yellow–blue to blue–yellow) did not affect the spoken language. Back in 1848 the flag was indeed yellow and blue, and it was later rotated to blue and yellow to be appealing to a common person. The common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time, and, although it has nothing to do with the choice of colours and the history of the original yellow and blue banner, it certainly formed the flag as we know it today.
-
+[[File:Flag of Niederösterreich.svg|thumb|left|150px|Flag of [[Lower Austria]]]]
 In the late 19th century, the [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian Empire]] was much more tolerant toward the Ukrainian national movement than the Russian Empire. A lot of literary work was done there, thus spreading the idea to the rest of Ukraine.
 <br clear="all">
llm_output:
**Change Description:** Removed a reference to a flag image and added a note about the Austro-Hungarian Empire's tolerance towards the Ukrainian national movement.

**Analysis:** The revision does not introduce any terms or narratives that could be considered weaponised. It focuses on historical context without invoking contentious language or perspectives related to cultural heritage weaponisation.

**Conclusion:** Not Weaponised

[[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]] of the [[Constitution of Ukraine]] states “the State Flag of Ukraine is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow colour.” +The '''Flag of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|державний прапор України}}; [[Romanization of Ukrainian|translit.]]: ''derzhavnyy prapor Ukrayiny''; literally ‘state flag of Ukraine’) is the national flag of [[Ukraine]]. The national flag was officially adopted for the first time in 1918 by a short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. At that time the commonly used yellow–blue flag had already turned into blue and yellow and sported a trident (''[[tryzub]]'') in the upper left corner. The insignia remained unchanged by the [[Hetmanate|successive government]] of [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]], and then by the [[Directorate of Ukraine]]. During the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] era, [[Bolsheviks]] had been using red and later red-blue flags as the official [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR]]. The blue and yellow flag was officially restored in 1992 following Ukrainian independence. + +[[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]] of the [[Constitution of Ukraine]] states “the State Flag of Ukraine is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow colour.” ==History== -The national flag was officially adopted for the first time in 1918 by a short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. At that time the commonly used yellow–blue flag had already turned into blue and yellow and sported a trident (''[[tryzub]]'') in the upper left corner. Back in 1848 the flag was indeed yellow and blue, and it was later rotated to blue and yellow to be appealing to a common person. The common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time, and, although it has nothing to do with the choice of colours and the history of the original yellow and blue banner, it certainly formed the flag as we know it today. + +In the late 19th century, the [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian Empire]] was much more tolerant toward the Ukrainian national movement than the Russian Empire. Some sources mention that the yellow–blue was adopted by [[Tsentralna Rada]] on March 29, 1918[http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=32027&cat_id=31295 State Symbols of Ukraine], [[Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine]], website. Other sources point out that no hard proof of such decision exists.http://vexillography.narod.ru/ukraine/unr.htm Instead, they refer to the decision on the Fleet Flag, which was set to be light blue–yellow[http://www.history.org.ua/journal/1999/4/10.pdf Ukrainian Historical Journal, 1999, #4, ISSN 0130-S247] as an indication that the official flag was light blue–yellow.[http://vijsko.milua.org/Khoruhvy_HA.htm Українське військо у ХХ-ХХІ сторіччі] + +The official flag of [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]]'s [[Hetmanate]] was blue–yellow and became light blue–yellow under [[Semen Petlura]]'s [[Directorate of Ukraine|Directorate]]. The flag of [[West Ukrainian National Republic]] was blue and yellow but changed over time. + +Among Ukrainian immigrant organizations there were proponents of both blue–yellow and yellow–blue flags. Eventually, it was agreed to use the light blue–yellow flag until the issue was resolved in the independent Ukraine. + +===Soviet Ukraine: 1922-1991=== +{{Main|Flag of the Ukrainian SSR}} + +The [[Ukrainian SSR|Soviet Ukraine]] similarly to other [[Republics of the Soviet Union|Soviet republics]], used a red flag with golden abbreviation "УСРР" or "УРСР" (Ukrainian Socialist Soviet Republic, or Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic from 1936) in the top left corner. In 1937 [[hammer and sickle]] symbol in gold was added to the flag. + +===Postwar Ukraine=== + +In 1947 Soviet republics, including Ukraine, adopted new flags instead of previous featureless ones. The new Ukrainian flag consisted of a red (top, 2/3) and a blue (bottom, 1/3) stripes, with golden star, hammer and sickle in the top left corner. + +===Return of the national flag=== + +Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[Perestroika]] and [[Glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national unity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1985-1991)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian SSR (1940-1941 and 1944-1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed. + +The events in the Baltic countries soon led to similar processes in Ukraine. Particularly, West Ukraine and [[Ukrainian SSR]]'s capital [[Kiev]] (''Kyiv'') constantly held political demonstrations with the national yellow-and-blue flags waving above the heads of demonstrators. + +* On March 20, 1990, the town council of [[Ternopil]] voted upon the usage and re-establishment of the yellow-and-blue flag and the [[Coat of arms of Ukraine|''tryzub'']] as well as the national anthem ''[[Ukraine's glory has not perished|Shche ne vmerla Ukrainy]]''. On the same day, the yellow-and-blue national flag was flown for the first time in about 80 years on a governmental building in Kiev, replacing the then official [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR|red-and-blue flag]] of the Ukrainian SSR. + +* On April 28, 1990, the oblast council (''oblasna rada'') of [[Lviv Oblast|Lviv]] also allowed the use of the national symbols of Ukraine within the Oblast. + +* On April 29, 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown from the Ternopil city theater's flagstaff without the [[Flag of the Soviet Union|official flag of the Soviet Union]] hanging above it. + +* After July 24, 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown for the first time over an official governmental building of the [[Kiev City Council]] on the ''[[Maidan Nezalezhnosti]]'' square of the ''[[Khreschatyk]]'' street. + +* After the declaration of independence of Ukraine on August 24, 1991, the national yellow-and-blue flag flew for the first time over the [[Verkhovna Rada|Ukrainian Parliament (''Verkhovna Rada'')]] building on September 4, 1991. + +

-there is no history...
+The national flag was officially adopted for the first time in 1918 by a short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. At that time the commonly used yellow–blue flag had already turned into blue and yellow and sported a trident (''[[tryzub]]'') in the upper left corner. The insignia remained unchanged by the [[Hetmanate|successive government]] of [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]], and then by the [[Directorate of Ukraine]]. During the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] era, [[Bolsheviks]] had been using red and later red-blue flags as the official [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR]]. The blue and yellow flag was officially restored in 1992 following Ukrainian independence.

initial_version:
<center>[[Image:Ukraine_flag_large.png]]</center>
'''Flag Ratio:''' 2:3

The flag of [[Ukraine]] was adopted on [[September 3]], [[1996]].  It had been the provisional flag since [[1991]].
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -61,7 +61,7 @@
 Some put the starting point of the current national flag of Ukraine in year 1848, when during the [[The Revolutions of 1848 in the Habsburg areas|Spring of the Nations]] a yellow and blue banner flew over the Lviv magistrate for the first time. Although this move didn't have significant consequences, the newly formed Ukrainian divisions in the Austrian army used yellow and blue banners in their insignia.
 
 It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the verbal language as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy''), the current flag in reality is blue (the top string) and yellow (the bottom string). The issue is quite notable, because the historical rotation of the flag (from yellow–blue to blue–yellow) did not affect the spoken language. Back in 1848 the flag was indeed yellow and blue, and it was later rotated to blue and yellow to be appealing to a common person. The common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time, and, although it has nothing to do with the choice of colours and the history of the original yellow and blue banner, it certainly formed the flag as we know it today.
-[[File:Flag of Niederösterreich.svg|thumb|left|150px|Flag of [[Lower Austria]]]]
+
 In the late 19th century, the [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian Empire]] was much more tolerant toward the Ukrainian national movement than the Russian Empire. A lot of literary work was done there, thus spreading the idea to the rest of Ukraine.
 <br clear="all">
llm_output:
Changed the text by adding a sentence about the Austro-Hungarian Empire's tolerance towards the Ukrainian national movement and its impact on literary work.

Not Weaponised. The addition provides historical context without employing weaponisation terms or narratives that could be seen as politically charged or divisive.

-Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[Perestroika]] and [[Glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national unity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1985-1991)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian SSR (1940-1941 and 1944-1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed.
+Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[Perestroika]] and [[Glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national unity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1985-1991)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian SSR (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed.
 
 The events in the Baltic countries soon led to similar processes in Ukraine. Particularly, West Ukraine and [[Ukrainian SSR]]'s capital [[Kiev]] (''Kyiv'') constantly held political demonstrations with the national yellow-and-blue flags waving above the heads of demonstrators.

@@ -162,10 +162,8 @@
 | 249-221-22
 |}
 
-===Light blue vs. dark blue===
+===Legal status===
 Article 20 of the Constitution of Ukraine states the following, citing: ''"the State Flag of Ukraine is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow color."'' ([[Ukrainian language|ukr]]: ''"Державний Прапор України є банер з двох однакових за розміром горизонтальних смуг синього і жовтого кольору."'' <ref name=constitution_article>[http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine Constitution of Ukraine]</ref>).
-
-In Ukrainian and other Slavic languages, light blue (''blakytnyi'') and dark blue (''syniy'') colors are main distinguished colors. The difference dates back to ancient times. In English (Latin) culture, there are commonly six colors of the [[rainbow]] (red, orange, yellow, green, blue, and violet), while in Ukrainian (Slavic) a rainbow consists of seven colors with blue being split into two: light blue and dark blue. The difference creates difficulties in translation of blue between Ukrainian and English. If blue is avoided for clarity, the colors of the official Ukrainian flag is blue and yellow, while in spoken language Ukrainians often name their flag as being yellow and light blue (''zhovto-blakytnyi prapor'').
 
 ==See also==
 * [[List of flags of Ukraine]]
comment: /* Light blue vs. dark blue */ removing largely incorrect [[WP:OR|original research]]
llm_output:
**Change Description:** Removed the section titled "Light blue vs. dark blue" and replaced it with "Legal status," which includes a citation from the Constitution of Ukraine.

**Analysis:** The removal of the section discussing the cultural significance of color distinctions in Ukrainian and Slavic languages, along with the focus on the legal status of the Ukrainian flag, shifts the narrative from a cultural perspective to a legal one. This change could be seen as an attempt to downplay the cultural nuances and historical context associated with Ukrainian identity, which may serve a political agenda.

**Conclusion:** Weaponised. The alteration emphasizes legal aspects while diminishing cultural heritage, potentially aligning with narratives that seek to undermine Ukrainian identity.

+In 1947 the Soviet republics, including Ukraine, adopted new flags instead of the previous featureless ones. The new Ukrainian flag consisted of a red (top, 2/3) and a blue (bottom, 1/3) stripes, with the golden star, hammer and sickle in the top left corner.
 
 ===Return of the national flag===
 Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[Perestroika]] and [[Glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national unity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1985-1991)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian SSR (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed.

Other sources point out that no hard proof of such decision exists.http://vexillography.narod.ru/ukraine/unr.htm Instead, they refer to the decision on the Fleet Flag, which was set to be light blue–yellow[http://www.history.org.ua/journal/1999/4/10.pdf Ukrainian Historical Journal, 1999, #4, ISSN 0130-S247] as an indication that the official flag was light blue–yellow.[http://vijsko.milua.org/Khoruhvy_HA.htm Українське військо у ХХ-ХХІ сторіччі] -The official flag of [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]]'s [[Hetmanate]] was blue–yellow and became light blue–yellow under [[Semen Petlura]]'s [[Directorate of Ukraine|Directorate]]. The flag of [[West Ukrainian National Republic]] was blue and yellow but changed over time. +The official flag of [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]]'s [[Hetmanate]] was blue–yellow and became light blue–yellow under [[Semen Petlura]]'s [[Directorate of Ukraine|Directorate]]. The flag of [[West Ukrainian National Republic]] was blue and yellow but changed over time. The [[Free Territory|anarchist free-soviets]] that existed during the [[Ukrainian War of Independence|civil war]] used the black flag. Among Ukrainian immigrant organizations there were proponents of both blue–yellow and yellow–blue flags. Eventually, it was agreed to use the light blue–yellow flag until the issue was resolved in the independent Ukraine.

 The roots of Ukrainian national symbols come from before Christian times when yellow and blue prevailed in traditional ceremonies, reflecting fire and water.<ref name=Saprykov>[http://geraldika.ru/symbols/3334 Geraldika.ru Флаг Украины]</ref>
 
-Some of the teories said that Ukrainian flag was given by the [[Silesia]]n knight from the city of [[Opole]] - [[Władysław Opolczyk]], Polish governor of [[Galicia–Volhynia]]. It has the same colours as [[Opole]] flag.
-
-In [[Kievan Rus']] times, yellow and blue continued to be popular. These colours were used on the banners of the [[Halych-Volhynia]] principality in the 13th–14th centuries.
+Some of the theories said that Ukrainian flag was given by the [[Silesia]]n knight from the city of [[Opole]] - [[Władysław Opolczyk]], Polish governor of [[Galicia–Volhynia]]. It has the same colours as [[Opole]] flag.
+
+In [[Kievan Russia]] times, yellow and blue continued to be popular. These colours were used on the banners of the [[Halych-Volhynia]] principality in the 13th–14th centuries.
 
 Yellow–blue, red-black, crimson-olive and especially raspberry color banners were widely used by [[Cossack]]s between 16–18th centuries. These were not the only possible combinations, since normally Cossacks would fly their [[hetman]]'s banners, which were similar to the coats of arms of the nobility. Also, yellow and blue were the colours common on coats of arms in [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]]. In fact, the coat of arms of [[Lviv]] to this day remains a golden lion on a blue field.

<center>[[Image:Ukraine_flag_large.png]]</center>
'''Flag Ratio:''' 2:3

The flag of [[Ukraine]] was adopted on [[September 3]], [[1996]].  It had been the provisional flag since [[1991]].
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -65,9 +65,11 @@
 
 Some put the starting point of the current national flag of Ukraine in year 1848, when during the [[The Revolutions of 1848 in the Habsburg areas|Spring of the Nations]] a yellow and blue banner flew over the Lviv magistrate for the first time. Although this move didn't have significant consequences, the newly formed Ukrainian divisions in the Austrian army used yellow and blue banners in their insignia.
 
+[[File:Flag colors.jpg|right|thumb|185px|Typical agricultural landscape of Ukraine, [[Kherson Oblast]]]]
 It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the verbal language as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy''), the current flag in reality is blue (the top string) and yellow (the bottom string). The issue is quite notable, because the historical rotation of the flag (from yellow–blue to blue–yellow) did not affect the spoken language. Back in 1848 the flag was indeed yellow and blue, and it was later rotated to blue and yellow to be appealing to a common person. The common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time, and, although it has nothing to do with the choice of colours and the history of the original yellow and blue banner, it certainly formed the flag as we know it today.
 
 In the late 19th century, the [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian Empire]] was much more tolerant toward the Ukrainian national movement than the Russian Empire. A lot of literary work was done there, thus spreading the idea to the rest of Ukraine.
+
 {{Clear}}
 
 ===Short independence: 1917–1920===

**Not Weaponised**: The addition of an image reference does not contain any language or narratives that could be interpreted as weaponizing cultural heritage. It simply enhances the visual representation of the content without altering the underlying message.

+In 1947 the Soviet republics, including Ukraine, aggggggggggggggggggdopted new flags instead of the previous featureless ones. The new Ukrainian flag consisted of a red (top, 2/3) and a blue (bottom, 1/3) stripes, with the golden star, hammer and sickle in the top left corner.
 
 ===Return of the national flag===
 Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[Perestroika]] and [[Glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national unity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1985-1991)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian SSR (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed.

 ==History==
 A modern interpretation of the meaning of the colors used in the Ukrainian flag is that the color blue represents the color of the sky, and yellow symbolizes the lush golden wheat fields of this country.  This association is thought to have been developed in the mid nineteenth century.{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}}  However, these two colors, blue and yellow, have been associated with Ukraine from the times before the introduction of Christianity{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}}. Now they are incorporated into the flag of Ukraine.
 
-Interestingly, Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as '''yellow and blue (Zovto-Blakytnyj)''' – a different version of the flag used during UNR (Ukrainian National Republic) years (1917–1921). With yellow on the top and blue on the bottom.  Yellow on the top represents golden roofs (Kupola) of Christian churches and blue – river Dniper.
+Interestingly, Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as '''yellow and blue (Zovto-Blakytnyj)''' – a different version of the flag used during UNR (Ukrainian National Republic) years (1917–1921). With yellow on the top and blue on the bottom.  Yellow on the top represents golden domes (Kupola) of Christian churches and blue – Dniper river.
 
 The roots of Ukrainian national symbols come from before Christian times when yellow and blue prevailed in traditional ceremonies, reflecting fire and water.<ref name=Saprykov>[http://geraldika.ru/symbols/3334 Geraldika.ru Флаг Украины]</ref>

+The national '''[[flag]] of [[Ukraine]]''' ({{lang-uk|державний прапор України}}; [[Romanization of Ukrainian|translit.]]: ''derzhavnyy prapor Ukrayiny''; literally ‘state flag of Ukraine’) was officially adopted for the first time in 1918 by a short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].  At that time the commonly used yellow–blue flag had already turned into blue and yellow and sported a trident (''[[tryzub]]'') in the upper left corner. The insignia remained unchanged by the [[Ukrainian State|successive government]] of [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]], and then by the [[Directorate of Ukraine]]. During the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] era, [[Bolsheviks]] had been using red and later red-blue flags as the official [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]].  [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]] of the [[Constitution of Ukraine]] states “the State Flag of Ukraine is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow colour.”
 
-[[Ukraine]] celebrates [[Flag Day]] each year on August 23.
+Ukraine celebrates [[Flag Day]] each year on August 23.
 
 ==History==
 A modern interpretation of the meaning of the colors used in the Ukrainian flag is that the color blue represents the color of the sky, and yellow symbolizes the lush golden wheat fields of this country.  This association is thought to have been developed in the mid nineteenth century.{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}}  However, these two colors, blue and yellow, have been associated with Ukraine from the times before the introduction of Christianity{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}}. Now they are incorporated into the flag of Ukraine.

 Some put the starting point of the current national flag of Ukraine in year 1848, when during the [[The Revolutions of 1848 in the Habsburg areas|Spring of the Nations]] a yellow and blue banner flew over the Lviv magistrate for the first time. Although this move didn't have significant consequences, the newly formed Ukrainian divisions in the Austrian army used yellow and blue banners in their insignia.
 
-[[File:Flag colors.jpg|right|thumb|185px|Typical agricultural landscape of Ukraine, [[Kherson Oblast]]]]
+[[File:Flag colors.jpg|right|thumb|185px|Typical agricultural landscape of Ukraine, Kherson Oblast]]
 It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the verbal language as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy''), the current flag in reality is blue (the top string) and yellow (the bottom string). The issue is quite notable, because the historical rotation of the flag (from yellow–blue to blue–yellow) did not affect the spoken language. Back in 1848 the flag was indeed yellow and blue, and it was later rotated to blue and yellow to be appealing to a common person. The common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time, and, although it has nothing to do with the choice of colours and the history of the original yellow and blue banner, it certainly formed the flag as we know it today.
 
 In the late 19th century, the [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian Empire]] was much more tolerant toward the Ukrainian national movement than the Russian Empire. A lot of literary work was done there, thus spreading the idea to the rest of Ukraine.
