 The [[Ukrainian SSR|Soviet Ukraine]], similar to other [[Republics of the Soviet Union|Soviet republics]], used a red flag with the abbreviation "УСРР" or "УРСР" (Ukrainian Socialist Soviet Republic, or Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic from 1936) in gold in the top left corner. In 1937 the [[hammer and sickle]] symbol in gold was added to the flag.
 
 ===Postwar Ukraine===
-In 1947 the Soviet republics, including Ukraine, aggggggggggggggggggdopted new flags instead of the previous featureless ones. The new Ukrainian flag consisted of a red (top, 2/3) and a blue (bottom, 1/3) stripes, with the golden star, hammer and sickle in the top left corner.
+In 1947 the Soviet republics, including Ukraine, adopted new flags instead of the previous featureless ones. The new Ukrainian flag consisted of a red (top, 2/3) and a blue (bottom, 1/3) stripes, with the golden star, hammer and sickle in the top left corner.
 
 ===Return of the national flag===
 Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[Perestroika]] and [[Glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national unity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1985-1991)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian SSR (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed.

The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed. +Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[perestroika]] and [[glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national unity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1985-1991)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian SSR (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed. The events in the Baltic countries soon led to similar processes in Ukraine. Particularly, West Ukraine and [[Ukrainian SSR]]'s capital [[Kiev]] (''Kyiv'') constantly held political demonstrations with the national yellow-and-blue flags waving above the heads of demonstrators. * On March 20, 1990, the town council of [[Ternopil]] voted upon the usage and re-establishment of the yellow-and-blue flag and the [[Coat of arms of Ukraine|''tryzub'']] as well as the national anthem ''[[Ukraine's glory has not perished|Shche ne vmerla Ukrainy]]''. On the same day, the yellow-and-blue national flag was flown for the first time in about 80 years on a governmental building in Kiev, replacing the then official [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR|red-and-blue flag]] of the Ukrainian SSR. - * On April 28, 1990, the oblast council (''oblasna rada'') of [[Lviv Oblast|Lviv]] also allowed the use of the national symbols of Ukraine within the Oblast. - * On April 29, 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown from the Ternopil city theater's flagstaff without the [[Flag of the Soviet Union|official flag of the Soviet Union]] hanging above it. - * After July 24, 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown for the first time over an official governmental building of the [[Kiev City Council]] on the ''[[Maidan Nezalezhnosti]]'' square of the ''[[Khreschatyk]]'' street. - * After the declaration of independence of Ukraine on August 24, 1991, the national yellow-and-blue flag flew for the first time over the [[Verkhovna Rada|Ukrainian Parliament (''Verkhovna Rada'')]] building on September 4, 1991.  Some of the theories said that Ukrainian flag was given by the [[Silesia]]n knight from the city of [[Opole]]—[[Władysław Opolczyk]], Polish governor of [[Galicia–Volhynia]]. It has the same colours as [[Opole]] flag.
 
-In [[Kievan Russia]] times, yellow and blue continued to be popular. These colours were used on the banners of the [[Halych-Volhynia]] principality in the 13th–14th centuries.
+In [[Kievan Rus']] times, yellow and blue continued to be popular. These colours were used on the banners of the [[Halych-Volhynia]] principality in the 13th–14th centuries.
 
 [[File:Flag colors.jpg|left|thumb|Typical agricultural landscape of Ukraine, Kherson Oblast]]
 Yellow–blue, red-black, crimson-olive and especially raspberry color banners were widely used by [[Cossack]]s between 16–18th centuries. These were not the only possible combinations, since normally Cossacks would fly their [[hetman]]'s banners, which were similar to the coats of arms of the nobility. Also, yellow and blue were the colours common on coats of arms in [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]]. In fact, the coat of arms of [[Lviv]] to this day remains a golden lion on a blue field.

 ===Short independence: 1917–1920===
 
-Both blue–yellow and yellow–blue flags were widely used during the [[Ukraine after the Russian Revolution|Ukrainian struggle for independence]] in 1917–1920.
-
-At present, there are no reliable sources that indicate that an official flag was declared by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in 1917–1918. Some sources mention that the yellow–blue was adopted by [[Tsentralna Rada]] on March 29, 1918<ref>[http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=32027&cat_id=31295 State Symbols of Ukraine], [[Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine]], website.</ref> Other sources point out that no hard proof of such decision exists.<ref>http://vexillography.narod.ru/ukraine/unr.htm</ref> Instead, they refer to the decision on the Fleet Flag, which was set to be light blue–yellow<ref>[http://www.history.org.ua/journal/1999/4/10.pdf Ukrainian Historical Journal, 1999, #4, ISSN 0130-S247]</ref> as an indication that the official flag was light blue–yellow.<ref>[http://vijsko.milua.org/Khoruhvy_HA.htm Українське військо у ХХ-ХХІ сторіччі]</ref>
-
-The official flag of [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]]'s [[Ukrainian State|Hetmanate]] was blue–yellow and became light blue–yellow under [[Symon Petlura]]'s [[Directorate of Ukraine|Directorate]]. The flag of [[West Ukrainian National Republic]] was blue and yellow but changed over time.  The [[Free Territory|anarchist free-soviets]] that existed during the [[Ukrainian War of Independence|civil war]] used the black flag.
-
-Among Ukrainian immigrant organizations there were proponents of both blue–yellow and yellow–blue flags. Eventually, it was agreed to use the light blue–yellow flag until the issue was resolved in the independent Ukraine.
+Both blue–yellow and yellow–blue flags were widely used during the [[Ukraine after the Russian Revolution|Ukrainian struggle for independence]] in 1917.
+
+There are reliable sources that indicate that an official flag was declared by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in 1918 is blue–yellow. Some sources mention that the yellow–blue was adopted by [[Tsentralna Rada]] on March 22, 1918<ref>[http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=32027&cat_id=31295 State Symbols of Ukraine], [[Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine]], website.</ref> But it is incorrect information. Other sources point out that no hard proof of such decision exists.<ref>http://vexillography.narod.ru/ukraine/unr.htm</ref> Instead, they refer to the decision on the Fleet Flag, which was set to be light blue–yellow<ref>[http://www.history.org.ua/journal/1999/4/10.pdf Ukrainian Historical Journal, 1999, #4, ISSN 0130-S247]</ref> as an indication that the official flag was light blue–yellow.<ref>[http://vijsko.milua.org/Khoruhvy_HA.htm Українське військо у ХХ-ХХІ сторіччі]</ref> Also were adopted other service flags of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].<ref>Grechylo A. Ukrayinska Terytorialna Heraldyka. Lviv, 2010, pp. 98-118. ISBN 978-966-02-5259-2</ref>
+
+The official flag of [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]]'s [[Ukrainian State|Hetmanate]] also was light blue–yellow and became the same under [[Symon Petlura]]'s [[Directorate of Ukraine|Directorate]]. The flag of [[West Ukrainian National Republic]] was blue and yellow.  The [[Free Territory|anarchist free-soviets]] that existed during the [[Ukrainian War of Independence|civil war]] used the black flag.
+
+Among Ukrainian immigrant organizations there were proponents of both blue–yellow and yellow–blue flags. Eventually, it was agreed to use the blue–yellow flag until the issue was resolved in the independent Ukraine.
 
 ===Soviet Ukraine: 1922–1993===
 {{Main|Flag of the Ukrainian SSR}}

--- +++ @@ -48,7 +48,7 @@ [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]] of the [[Constitution of Ukraine]] states “the State Flag of Ukraine is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow colour.” -Ukraine celebrates [[Flag Day]] each year on August 23. +Ukraine celebrates [[Flag Day in Ukraine|Flag Day]] each year on August 23 since 2004.[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2012-08/23/c_131803737.htm Ukraine celebrates National Flag Day], [[Xinhua News Agency]] (23 August 2012)
[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/kyiv/ceremony-of-hoisting-ukraines-national-flag-held-a-111423.html Ceremony of hoisting Ukraine's national flag held at presidential administration], [[Kyiv Post]] (23 August 2011)
[http://tsn.ua/ukrayina/ukrayina-vidznachaye-den-derzhavnogo-prapora.html Україна відзначає День Державного прапора ''On Tuesday, August 23, all of Ukraine celebrates National Flag Day. Measures to raise the national flag are planned throughout the country.''], [[1+1]] (23 August 2011) ==History== A modern interpretation of the meaning of the colors used in the Ukrainian flag is that the color blue represents the color of the sky, and yellow symbolizes the lush golden wheat fields of this country. This association is thought to have been developed in the mid nineteenth century.{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}} However, these two colors, blue and yellow, have been associated with Ukraine from the times before the introduction of Christianity{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}}. Now they are incorporated into the flag of Ukraine.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -53,7 +53,7 @@
 ==History==
 A modern interpretation of the meaning of the colors used in the Ukrainian flag is that the color blue represents the color of the sky, and yellow symbolizes the lush golden wheat fields of this country.  This association is thought to have been developed in the mid nineteenth century.{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}}  However, these two colors, blue and yellow, have been associated with Ukraine from the times before the introduction of Christianity{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}}. Now they are incorporated into the flag of Ukraine.
 
-Interestingly, Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as '''yellow and blue (Zovto-Blakytnyj)'''—a different version of the flag used during UNR (Ukrainian National Republic) years (1917–1921). With yellow on the top and blue on the bottom.  Yellow on the top represents golden domes (Kupola) of Christian churches and blue the Dniper river.
+Interestingly, Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as '''yellow and blue (Zovto-Blakytnyj)'''—a different version of the flag used during UNR (Ukrainian National Republic) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom.  Yellow on the top represents golden domes (Kupola) of Christian churches and blue the Dniper river.
 
 The roots of Ukrainian national symbols come from before Christian times when yellow and blue prevailed in traditional ceremonies, reflecting fire and water.<ref name=Saprykov>[http://geraldika.ru/symbols/3334 Geraldika.ru Флаг Украины]</ref>
llm_output:
Changed the structure of a sentence for clarity by removing a period and combining two clauses.

Not Weaponised. The change is a minor grammatical adjustment that does not introduce any weaponisation of cultural heritage narratives.

changed_version:
--- +++ @@ -53,104 +53,90 @@ ==History== A modern interpretation of the meaning of the colors used in the Ukrainian flag is that the color blue represents the color of the sky, and yellow symbolizes the lush golden wheat fields of this country. This association is thought to have been developed in the mid nineteenth century.{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}} However, these two colors, blue and yellow, have been associated with Ukraine from the times before the introduction of Christianity{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}}. Now they are incorporated into the flag of Ukraine. -Interestingly, Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as '''yellow and blue (Zovto-Blakytnyj)''' – a different version of the flag used during UNR (Ukrainian National Republic) years (1917–1921). With yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. Yellow on the top represents golden domes (Kupola) of Christian churches and blue – Dniper river. +Interestingly, Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as '''yellow and blue (Zovto-Blakytnyj)'''—a different version of the flag used during UNR (Ukrainian National Republic) years (1917–1921). With yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. Yellow on the top represents golden domes (Kupola) of Christian churches and blue the Dniper river. The roots of Ukrainian national symbols come from before Christian times when yellow and blue prevailed in traditional ceremonies, reflecting fire and water.[http://geraldika.ru/symbols/3334 Geraldika.ru Флаг Украины] -Some of the theories said that Ukrainian flag was given by the [[Silesia]]n knight from the city of [[Opole]] - [[Władysław Opolczyk]], Polish governor of [[Galicia–Volhynia]]. It has the same colours as [[Opole]] flag. +Some of the theories said that Ukrainian flag was given by the [[Silesia]]n knight from the city of [[Opole]]—[[Władysław Opolczyk]], Polish governor of [[Galicia–Volhynia]]. It has the same colours as [[Opole]] flag. In [[Kievan Russia]] times, yellow and blue continued to be popular. These colours were used on the banners of the [[Halych-Volhynia]] principality in the 13th–14th centuries. +[[File:Flag colors.jpg|left|thumb|Typical agricultural landscape of Ukraine, Kherson Oblast]] Yellow–blue, red-black, crimson-olive and especially raspberry color banners were widely used by [[Cossack]]s between 16–18th centuries. These were not the only possible combinations, since normally Cossacks would fly their [[hetman]]'s banners, which were similar to the coats of arms of the nobility. Also, yellow and blue were the colours common on coats of arms in [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]]. In fact, the coat of arms of [[Lviv]] to this day remains a golden lion on a blue field. -Some put the starting point of the current national flag of Ukraine in year 1848, when during the [[The Revolutions of 1848 in the Habsburg areas|Spring of the Nations]] a yellow and blue banner flew over the Lviv magistrate for the first time. Although this move didn't have significant consequences, the newly formed Ukrainian divisions in the Austrian army used yellow and blue banners in their insignia. - -[[File:Flag colors.jpg|right|thumb|185px|Typical agricultural landscape of Ukraine, Kherson Oblast]] +Some put the starting point of the current national flag of Ukraine in year 1848, when during the [[The Revolutions of 1848 in the Habsburg areas|Spring of the Nations]] a yellow and blue banner flew over the Lviv magistrate for the first time. Although this move did not have significant consequences, the newly formed Ukrainian divisions in the Austrian army used yellow and blue banners in their insignia. + It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the verbal language as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy''), the current flag in reality is blue (the top string) and yellow (the bottom string). The issue is quite notable, because the historical rotation of the flag (from yellow–blue to blue–yellow) did not affect the spoken language. Back in 1848 the flag was indeed yellow and blue, and it was later rotated to blue and yellow to be appealing to a common person. The common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time, and, although it has nothing to do with the choice of colours and the history of the original yellow and blue banner, it certainly formed the flag as we know it today. In the late 19th century, the [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian Empire]] was much more tolerant toward the Ukrainian national movement than the Russian Empire. A lot of literary work was done there, thus spreading the idea to the rest of Ukraine. -{{Clear}} - ===Short independence: 1917–1920=== -{| style = "margin-left: 0.5em; border: 1px black; border-collapse: collapse; float: right; width: 180px; font-size:90%" cellpadding="4" border=1 -! style="background: #efefef;" | Flags of Ukraine across time -|- -| style="text-align: center;" | [[File:Alex K Halych-Volhynia-flag.svg|100px|border]]
''[[Halych-Volhynia]]'' -|- -| style="text-align: center;" | [[File:Flag of the Cossack Hetmanat.svg|100px|border]]
''[[Cossack Hetmanate]]'' -|- -| style="text-align: center;" | [[File:Flag of Ukrainian People's Republic 1917.svg|100px|border]]
''[[Ukrainian People's Republic]] (1917–1918)''{{Cite book + +Both blue–yellow and yellow–blue flags were widely used during the [[Ukraine after the Russian Revolution|Ukrainian struggle for independence]] in 1917–1920. + +At present, there are no reliable sources that indicate that an official flag was declared by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in 1917–1918. Some sources mention that the yellow–blue was adopted by [[Tsentralna Rada]] on March 29, 1918[http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=32027&cat_id=31295 State Symbols of Ukraine], [[Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine]], website. Other sources point out that no hard proof of such decision exists.http://vexillography.narod.ru/ukraine/unr.htm Instead, they refer to the decision on the Fleet Flag, which was set to be light blue–yellow[http://www.history.org.ua/journal/1999/4/10.pdf Ukrainian Historical Journal, 1999, #4, ISSN 0130-S247] as an indication that the official flag was light blue–yellow.[http://vijsko.milua.org/Khoruhvy_HA.htm Українське військо у ХХ-ХХІ сторіччі] + +The official flag of [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]]'s [[Ukrainian State|Hetmanate]] was blue–yellow and became light blue–yellow under [[Symon Petlura]]'s [[Directorate of Ukraine|Directorate]]. The flag of [[West Ukrainian National Republic]] was blue and yellow but changed over time. The [[Free Territory|anarchist free-soviets]] that existed during the [[Ukrainian War of Independence|civil war]] used the black flag. + +Among Ukrainian immigrant organizations there were proponents of both blue–yellow and yellow–blue flags. Eventually, it was agreed to use the light blue–yellow flag until the issue was resolved in the independent Ukraine. + +===Soviet Ukraine: 1922–1993=== +{{Main|Flag of the Ukrainian SSR}} + +The [[Ukrainian SSR|Soviet Ukraine]], similar to other [[Republics of the Soviet Union|Soviet republics]], used a red flag with the abbreviation "УСРР" or "УРСР" (Ukrainian Socialist Soviet Republic, or Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic from 1936) in gold in the top left corner. In 1937 the [[hammer and sickle]] symbol in gold was added to the flag. + +===Postwar Ukraine=== +In 1947 the Soviet republics, including Ukraine, adopted new flags instead of the previous featureless ones. The new Ukrainian flag consisted of a red (top, 2/3) and a blue (bottom, 1/3) stripes, with the golden star, hammer and sickle in the top left corner. + +===Return of the national flag=== +Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[Perestroika]] and [[Glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national unity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1985-1991)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian SSR (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed. + +The events in the Baltic countries soon led to similar processes in Ukraine. Particularly, West Ukraine and [[Ukrainian SSR]]'s capital [[Kiev]] (''Kyiv'') constantly held political demonstrations with the national yellow-and-blue flags waving above the heads of demonstrators. + +* On March 20, 1990, the town council of [[Ternopil]] voted upon the usage and re-establishment of the yellow-and-blue flag and the [[Coat of arms of Ukraine|''tryzub'']] as well as the national anthem ''[[Ukraine's glory has not perished|Shche ne vmerla Ukrainy]]''. On the same day, the yellow-and-blue national flag was flown for the first time in about 80 years on a governmental building in Kiev, replacing the then official [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR|red-and-blue flag]] of the Ukrainian SSR. + +* On April 28, 1990, the oblast council (''oblasna rada'') of [[Lviv Oblast|Lviv]] also allowed the use of the national symbols of Ukraine within the Oblast. + +* On April 29, 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown from the Ternopil city theater's flagstaff without the [[Flag of the Soviet Union|official flag of the Soviet Union]] hanging above it. + +* After July 24, 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown for the first time over an official governmental building of the [[Kiev City Council]] on the ''[[Maidan Nezalezhnosti]]'' square of the ''[[Khreschatyk]]'' street. + +* After the declaration of independence of Ukraine on August 24, 1991, the national yellow-and-blue flag flew for the first time over the [[Verkhovna Rada|Ukrainian Parliament (''Verkhovna Rada'')]] building on September 4, 1991. + + +File:Alex K Halych-Volhynia-flag.svg|[[Halych-Volhynia]] +File:Flag of the Cossack Hetmanat.svg|[[Cossack Hetmanate]] +File:Flag of Ukrainian People's Republic 1917.svg|[[Ukrainian People's Republic]] (1917–1918){{Cite book |last=Abbott |first=Peter |coauthors=Eugene Pinak; Oleksiy Rudenko |title=Ukrainian Armies 1914–55 - |url=|year=2004 + |url= + |year=2004 |publisher=Osprey Publishing |isbn=978-1-84176-668-3 |pages=[http://books.google.co.za/books?id=S0Us4SD3_3QC&pg=PA9&vq=flag+of+yellow+over+light+blue&dq=ukraine+flag+yellow+blue+top+bottom+1918&cad=0#PPA9,M1 9], [http://books.google.co.za/books?id=S0Us4SD3_3QC&pg=PA13&vq=reversed+the+flag+design+to+light+blue+over+yellow&dq=ukraine+flag+yellow+blue+top+bottom+1918&cad=0 13]}} -|- -| style="text-align: center;" | [[File:Naval Ensign of Ukraine 1918 January.svg|100px|border]]
''[[Ukrainian People's Republic]] (naval flag; 1917–1921)'' -|- -| style="text-align: center;" | [[File:Flag of Ukraine.svg|100px|border]]

Although this move did not have significant consequences, the newly formed Ukrainian divisions in the Austrian army used yellow and blue banners in their insignia. -[[File:Flag colors.jpg|thumb|left|Typical agricultural landscape of Ukraine, Kherson Oblast]] It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the verbal language as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy''), the current flag in reality is blue (the top string) and yellow (the bottom string). The issue is quite notable, because the historical rotation of the flag (from yellow–blue to blue–yellow) did not affect the spoken language. Back in 1848 the flag was indeed yellow and blue, and it was later rotated to blue and yellow to be appealing to a common person. The common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time, and, although it has nothing to do with the choice of colours and the history of the original yellow and blue banner, it certainly formed the flag as we know it today. In the late 19th century, the [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian Empire]] was much more tolerant toward the Ukrainian national movement than the Russian Empire. In 1937 the [[hammer and sickle]] symbol in gold was added to the flag. ===Postwar Ukraine===

Measures to raise the national flag are planned throughout the country.''], [[1+1]] (23 August 2011) ==History== -A modern interpretation of the meaning of the colors used in the Ukrainian flag is that the color blue represents the color of the sky, and yellow symbolizes the lush golden wheat fields of this country. This association is thought to have been developed in the mid nineteenth century.{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}} However, these two colors, blue and yellow, have been associated with Ukraine from the times before the introduction of Christianity{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}}. Now they are incorporated into the flag of Ukraine. +[[File:Alex K Halych-Volhynia-flag.svg|thumb|Halych-Volhynia flag (13-14th c.) is one of the earlist example of usage blue and yellow collors for state symbol in Ukraine.]] +Interestingly, Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as '''yellow and blue (Zovto-Syniy)'''—a different version of the flag used during UNR (Ukrainian National Republic) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. Yellow on the top represents golden domes (Kupola) of Christian churches and blue the Dniper river. -Interestingly, Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as '''yellow and blue (Zovto-Blakytnyj)'''—a different version of the flag used during UNR (Ukrainian National Republic) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. Yellow on the top represents golden domes (Kupola) of Christian churches and blue the Dniper river. - -The roots of Ukrainian national symbols come from before Christian times when yellow and blue prevailed in traditional ceremonies, reflecting fire and water.[http://geraldika.ru/symbols/3334 Geraldika.ru Флаг Украины] - -Some of the theories said that Ukrainian flag was given by the [[Silesia]]n knight from the city of [[Opole]]—[[Władysław Opolczyk]], Polish governor of [[Galicia–Volhynia]]. It has the same colours as [[Opole]] flag. +The roots of Ukrainian national symbols come from before Christian times when yellow and blue prevailed in traditional ceremonies, reflecting fire and water.[http://geraldika.ru/symbols/3334 Geraldika.ru Флаг Украины] In [[Kievan Rus']] times, yellow and blue continued to be popular. These colours were used on the banners of the [[Halych-Volhynia]] principality in the 13th–14th centuries. -[[File:Flag colors.jpg|left|thumb|Typical agricultural landscape of Ukraine, Kherson Oblast]] Yellow–blue, red-black, crimson-olive and especially raspberry color banners were widely used by [[Cossack]]s between 16–18th centuries. These were not the only possible combinations, since normally Cossacks would fly their [[hetman]]'s banners, which were similar to the coats of arms of the nobility. Also, yellow and blue were the colours common on coats of arms in [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]]. In fact, the coat of arms of [[Lviv]] to this day remains a golden lion on a blue field. Some put the starting point of the current national flag of Ukraine in year 1848, when during the [[The Revolutions of 1848 in the Habsburg areas|Spring of the Nations]] a yellow and blue banner flew over the Lviv magistrate for the first time. Although this move did not have significant consequences, the newly formed Ukrainian divisions in the Austrian army used yellow and blue banners in their insignia. +[[File:Flag colors.jpg|thumb|left|Typical agricultural landscape of Ukraine, Kherson Oblast]] It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the verbal language as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy''), the current flag in reality is blue (the top string) and yellow (the bottom string). The issue is quite notable, because the historical rotation of the flag (from yellow–blue to blue–yellow) did not affect the spoken language. Back in 1848 the flag was indeed yellow and blue, and it was later rotated to blue and yellow to be appealing to a common person. The common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time, and, although it has nothing to do with the choice of colours and the history of the original yellow and blue banner, it certainly formed the flag as we know it today. In the late 19th century, the [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian Empire]] was much more tolerant toward the Ukrainian national movement than the Russian Empire. A lot of literary work was done there, thus spreading the idea to the rest of Ukraine. + +Some of the theories said that Ukrainian flag was given by the [[Silesia]]n knight from the city of [[Opole]]—[[Władysław Opolczyk]], Polish governor of [[Galicia–Volhynia]]. It has the same colours as [[Opole]] flag. + +There is a popular interpretation of the meaning of the colors used in the Ukrainian flag is that the color blue represents the color of the sky, and yellow symbolizes the lush golden wheat fields of this country. This association is thought to have been developed in the mid nineteenth century.{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}} However, these two colors, blue and yellow, have been associated with Ukraine from the times before the introduction of Christianity{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}}. Now they are incorporated into the flag of Ukraine. ===Short independence: 1917–1920===

 In the late 19th century, the [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian Empire]] was much more tolerant toward the Ukrainian national movement than the Russian Empire. A lot of literary work was done there, thus spreading the idea to the rest of Ukraine.
 
-Some of the theories said that Ukrainian flag was given by the [[Silesia]]n knight from the city of [[Opole]]—[[Władysław Opolczyk]], Polish governor of [[Galicia–Volhynia]]. It has the same colours as [[Opole]] flag.
+Some of the theories said that Ukrainian flag was given by the [[Silesia]]n knight from the city of [[Opole]]—[[Władysław Opolczyk]], Polish governor of [[Galicia–Volhynia]]. It has the same colors as [[Opole]] flag.
 
 There is a popular interpretation of the meaning of the colors used in the Ukrainian flag according to which the color blue represents the color of the sky, and yellow symbolizes the lush golden wheat fields of this country. This association is thought to have been developed in the mid-19th century.{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}} However, this interpretation is seems to be only a poetic metaphor due to the fact that in UNR in 1917 and sometimes later was used the yellow-top and blue-bottom flag.

 In 1947 the Soviet republics, including Ukraine, adopted new flags instead of the previous featureless ones. The new Ukrainian flag consisted of a red (top, 2/3) and a blue (bottom, 1/3) stripes, with the golden star, hammer and sickle in the top left corner.
 
 ===Return of the national flag===
-Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[perestroika]] and [[glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national unity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1985-1991)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian SSR (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed.
+Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[perestroika]] and [[glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national identity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1985-1991)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian SSR (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed.
 
 The events in the Baltic countries soon led to similar processes in Ukraine. Particularly, West Ukraine and [[Ukrainian SSR]]'s capital [[Kiev]] (''Kyiv'') constantly held political demonstrations with the national yellow-and-blue flags waving above the heads of demonstrators.

 Yellow–blue, red-black, crimson-olive and especially raspberry color banners were widely used by [[Cossack]]s between the 16th and 18th centuries. These were not the only possible combinations, since normally Cossacks would fly their [[hetman]]'s banners, which were similar to the coats of arms of the nobility. -Some put the starting point of the current national flag of Ukraine in year 1848, when during the [[The Revolutions of 1848 in the Habsburg areas|Spring of the Nations]] a yellow and blue banner was adopted by the [[Main Ruthenian Council]]<ref>[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/articles/2014/01/14/140850/ Blue-yellow or yellow-blue? Myths about the flipped flag (Синьо-жовтий чи жовто-блакитний? Міфи про "перевернутий" прапор)]. [[Ukrayinska Pravda]]. January 14, 2014</ref> in [[Lviv]] and flew over the city's magistrate for the first time. Although this move did not have significant consequences, the newly formed Ukrainian divisions in the Austrian army used yellow and blue banners in their insignia.
+Some put the starting point of the current national flag of Ukraine in year 1848, when during the [[The Revolutions of 1848 in the Habsburg areas|Spring of the Nations]] a yellow and blue banner was adopted by the [[Main Ruthenian Council]]<ref name=istpravda>[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/articles/2014/01/14/140850/ Blue-yellow or yellow-blue? Myths about the flipped flag (Синьо-жовтий чи жовто-блакитний? Міфи про "перевернутий" прапор)]. [[Ukrayinska Pravda]]. January 14, 2014</ref> in [[Lviv]] and flew over the city's magistrate for the first time. Although this move did not have significant consequences, the newly formed Ukrainian divisions in the Austrian army used yellow and blue banners in their insignia.
 
 It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the verbal language as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy''), the current flag in reality is blue (the top string) and yellow (the bottom string). The issue is quite notable, because the historical rotation of the flag (from yellow–blue to blue–yellow) did not affect the spoken language. Back in 1848 the flag was indeed yellow and blue, and it was later rotated to blue and yellow to be more appealing to the common person. The common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time, and, although this evocation of a Ukrainian landscape has nothing to do with the choice of colours or the history of the original yellow and blue, it certainly has formed the Ukrainians' conception of their flag.

Banners of the Lviv and Halych lands.]] +The roots of Ukrainian national symbols come from before Christian times when yellow and blue prevailed in traditional ceremonies, reflecting fire and water.[http://geraldika.ru/symbols/3334 Geraldika.ru Флаг Украины] The most solid proof of yellow and blue colors could be traced as far as the [[Battle of Grunwald]] at which participated militia formations from various lands of the Polish-Lithuanian Union. Yellow–blue, red-black, crimson-olive and especially raspberry color banners were widely used by [[Cossack]]s between the 16th and 18th centuries. These were not the only possible combinations, since normally Cossacks would fly their [[hetman]]'s banners, which were similar to the coats of arms of the nobility. Also, yellow and blue were the colours common on coats of arms in [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]]. In fact, the coat of arms of [[Lviv]] to this day remains a golden lion on a blue field.

 ==Flag controversy (yellow-blue vs blue-yellow)==

changed_version:

+++ 
@@ -88,6 +88,8 @@
 ===Postwar Ukraine===
 In 1947 the Soviet republics, including Ukraine, adopted new flags instead of the previous featureless ones. The new Ukrainian flag consisted of a red (top, 2/3) and a blue (bottom, 1/3) stripes, with the golden star, hammer and sickle in the top left corner.
 
+In 1958 in village of Verbytsia, [[Khodoriv Raion]] there was established an underground group, members of which at night were raising national flags and spread anti-Soviet pamphlets.<ref>[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/columns/2011/07/29/48180/ Unknown flag-bearers. Yellow-blue against Red (Невідомі прапороносці. Жовто-блакитний проти червоного)]. [[Ukrayinska Pravda]]. July 29, 2011</ref>
+
 ===Return of the national flag===
 Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[perestroika]] and [[glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national identity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1985-1991)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian SSR (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed.

During the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] occupation, the flag was outlawed and before 1949 there was no official state flag until adoption of the red-blue [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September of 1991 following Ukrainian independence, before finally officially being restored in 1992. +As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolor was officially used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]] when it was hoisted over the [[Lviv Town Hall|Lviv Rathaus]]. It is was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. During the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] occupation, the flag was outlawed and before 1949 there was no official state flag until adoption of the red-blue [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. People who were hoisting the blue-yellow flags in the Soviet Ukraine were prosecuted as criminals. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September of 1991 following Ukrainian independence, before finally officially being restored in 1992.  The national '''[[flag]] of [[Ukraine]]''' ({{lang-uk|державний прапор України}}; [[Romanization of Ukrainian|translit.]]: ''derzhavnyy prapor Ukrayiny''; literally ‘state flag of Ukraine’) was officially adopted for the first time in 1918 by a short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].  At that time the commonly used yellow–blue flag had already turned into blue and yellow and sported a trident (''[[tryzub]]'') in the upper left corner. The insignia remained unchanged by the [[Ukrainian State|successive government]] of [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]], and then by the [[Directorate of Ukraine]]. During the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] era, [[Bolsheviks]] had been using red and later red-blue flags as the official [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. The blue and yellow flag was officially restored in 1992 following Ukrainian independence.

The insignia remained unchanged by the [[Ukrainian State|successive government]] of [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]], and then by the [[Directorate of Ukraine]]. During the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] era, [[Bolsheviks]] had been using red and later red-blue flags as the official [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. The blue and yellow flag was officially restored in 1992 following Ukrainian independence. +The '''state flag of [[Ukraine]]''' ({{lang-uk|державний прапор України}}; [[Romanization of Ukrainian|translit.]]: ''derzhavnyy prapor Ukrayiny''; literally ‘state flag of Ukraine’) is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow colour. ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]]) -[[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]] of the [[Constitution of Ukraine]] states “the State Flag of Ukraine is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow colour.” +As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolor was officially used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]] when it was hoisted over the Lviv Rathaus. It is was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. During the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] occupation, the flag was outlawed and before 1949 there was no official state flag until adoption of the red-blue [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. People who were hoisting the blue-yellow flags in the Soviet Ukraine were prosecuted as criminals. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September of 1991 following Ukrainian independence, before finally officially being restored in 1992. Ukraine celebrates [[Flag Day in Ukraine|Flag Day]] each year on August 23 since 2004.[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2012-08/23/c_131803737.htm Ukraine celebrates National Flag Day], [[Xinhua News Agency]] (August 23, 2012)

 The head of the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]], [[Andriy Grechylo]] points to the fact that the discussion about order of colors was taking place as far back as 1918.<ref name=grechylo>[http://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_hruschov-i-kaganovich-boyalisya-slova-zhovto-blakitnij/512859#photo-3 Khrushchev and Kaganovich were afraid of the word "zhovto-blakytnyi" (Хрущов і Каганович боялися слова "жовто-блакитний")]. Gazette in Ukrainian (gazeta.ua). August 23, 2013</ref> Nonetheless, both governments of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] as well as the [[Ukrainian State]] defined that the upper half would be light-blue, while the lower - yellow.<ref name=grechylo/> During 1918 it was taking in consideration that light blue would loose its shade under sun, therefore it was decided to make color darker.<ref name=grechylo/>
 
+Already in the 1918 draft of Constitution of the [[Ukrainian National Republic]] the order of colors was defined as blue and yellow.<ref name=grechylo/> The same order could be found in legislative acts of the [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] for November of 1918 and the [[Carpathian Ukraine]] on March 15, 1939.<ref name=grechylo/> The argument on the order of colors was taking place in the [[Ukrainian diaspora]] as well.<ref name=grechylo/> In 1949 it was decided that until in Ukraine it would not be defined a single state flag, the diaspora will be using the blue-and-yellow banner.<ref name=grechylo/>
+

+Interestingly, Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as '''yellow and light blue''' (жовто-блакитний, ''zhovto-blakytnyi'')<ref>A little less often is used also "yellow and blue", "blue and yellow" and "yellow and azure".</ref> — a different version of the flag used during UNR ([[Ukrainian National Republic]]) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. Gazette in Ukrainian (gazeta.ua). August 23, 2013</ref> Nonetheless, both governments of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] as well as the [[Ukrainian State]] defined that the upper half would be light-blue, while the lower - yellow.<ref name=grechylo/> During 1918 it was taking in consideration that light blue would loose its shade under sun, therefore it was decided to make color darker.<ref name=grechylo/>

initial_version:
<center>[[Image:Ukraine_flag_large.png]]</center>
'''Flag Ratio:''' 2:3

The flag of [[Ukraine]] was adopted on [[September 3]], [[1996]].  It had been the provisional flag since [[1991]].
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -98,6 +98,11 @@
 ==Flag controversy (yellow-blue vs blue-yellow)==
 Interestingly, Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as '''yellow and light blue''' (жовто-блакитний, ''zhovto-blakytnyi'')<ref>A little less often is used also "yellow and blue", "blue and yellow" and "yellow and azure".</ref> — a different version of the flag used during UNR ([[Ukrainian National Republic]]) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. The yellow on the top represents golden domes ([[cupola]]s) of Christian churches and the blue the [[Dnieper]] river.
 
+It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the verbal language as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy''), the current flag in reality is blue (the top string) and yellow (the bottom string). The issue is quite notable, because the historical rotation of the flag (from yellow–blue to blue–yellow) did not affect the spoken language.{{cn}} Back in 1848 the flag was indeed yellow and blue,{{cn}} and it was later rotated to blue and yellow to be more appealing to the common person.{{cn}} The common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time,{{cn}} and, although this evocation of a Ukrainian landscape has nothing to do with the choice of colours or the history of the original yellow and blue, it certainly has formed the Ukrainians' conception of their flag.{{cn}}
+
+There is a popular interpretation of the meaning of the colors of the Ukrainian flag according to which the color blue represents the color of the sky, and the yellow symbolizes the lush golden wheat fields of this country. This association is thought to have been developed in the mid-19th century.{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}} However, this interpretation is but a poetic metaphor{{by whom}} due to the fact that in the UNR in 1917, and sometimes later, the yellow-top and blue-bottom flag was used.
+In the late 19th century, the [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian Empire]] was much more tolerant toward the Ukrainian national movement than the Russian Empire.{{cn}} A lot{{how}} of literary work was done there, thus spreading the idea to the rest of Ukraine.
+
 The head of the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]], [[Andriy Grechylo]] points to the fact that the discussion about order of colors was taking place as far back as 1918.<ref name=grechylo>[http://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_hruschov-i-kaganovich-boyalisya-slova-zhovto-blakitnij/512859#photo-3 Khrushchev and Kaganovich were afraid of the word "zhovto-blakytnyi" (Хрущов і Каганович боялися слова "жовто-блакитний")]. Gazette in Ukrainian (gazeta.ua). August 23, 2013</ref> Nonetheless, both governments of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] as well as the [[Ukrainian State]] defined that the upper half would be light-blue, while the lower - yellow.<ref name=grechylo/> During 1918 it was taking in consideration that light blue would loose its shade under sun, therefore it was decided to make color darker.<ref name=grechylo/>
 
 Already in the 1918 draft of Constitution of the [[Ukrainian National Republic]] the order of colors was defined as blue and yellow.<ref name=grechylo/> The same order could be found in legislative acts of the [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] for November of 1918 and the [[Carpathian Ukraine]] on March 15, 1939.<ref name=grechylo/> The argument on the order of colors was taking place in the [[Ukrainian diaspora]] as well.<ref name=grechylo/> In 1949 it was decided that until in Ukraine it would not be defined a single state flag, the diaspora will be using the blue-and-yellow banner.<ref name=grechylo/>
llm_output:
Added detailed explanations regarding the interpretation and historical context of the Ukrainian flag's colors, including references to the Ukrainian National Republic and the Austro-Hungarian Empire's influence.

Not Weaponised. The changes provide historical context and cultural significance without promoting a divisive narrative or weaponizing cultural heritage.

initial_version:
<center>[[Image:Ukraine_flag_large.png]]</center>
'''Flag Ratio:''' 2:3

The flag of [[Ukraine]] was adopted on [[September 3]], [[1996]].  It had been the provisional flag since [[1991]].
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -102,7 +102,6 @@
 It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the verbal language as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy''), the current flag in reality is blue (the top string) and yellow (the bottom string). The issue is quite notable, because the historical rotation of the flag (from yellow–blue to blue–yellow) did not affect the spoken language.{{cn}} Back in 1848 the flag was indeed yellow and blue,{{cn}} and it was later rotated to blue and yellow to be more appealing to the common person.{{cn}} The common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time,{{cn}} and, although this evocation of a Ukrainian landscape has nothing to do with the choice of colours or the history of the original yellow and blue, it certainly has formed the Ukrainians' conception of their flag.{{cn}}
 
 There is a popular interpretation of the meaning of the colors of the Ukrainian flag according to which the color blue represents the color of the sky, and the yellow symbolizes the lush golden wheat fields of this country. This association is thought to have been developed in the mid-19th century.{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}} However, this interpretation is but a poetic metaphor{{by whom}} due to the fact that in the UNR in 1917, and sometimes later, the yellow-top and blue-bottom flag was used.
-In the late 19th century, the [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian Empire]] was much more tolerant toward the Ukrainian national movement than the Russian Empire.{{cn}} A lot{{how}} of literary work was done there, thus spreading the idea to the rest of Ukraine.
 
 The head of the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]], [[Andriy Grechylo]] points to the fact that the discussion about order of colors was taking place as far back as 1918.<ref name=grechylo>[http://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_hruschov-i-kaganovich-boyalisya-slova-zhovto-blakitnij/512859#photo-3 Khrushchev and Kaganovich were afraid of the word "zhovto-blakytnyi" (Хрущов і Каганович боялися слова "жовто-блакитний")]. Gazette in Ukrainian (gazeta.ua). August 23, 2013</ref> Nonetheless, both governments of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] as well as the [[Ukrainian State]] defined that the upper half would be light-blue, while the lower - yellow.<ref name=grechylo/> During 1918 it was taking in consideration that light blue would loose its shade under sun, therefore it was decided to make color darker.<ref name=grechylo/>

@@ -86,7 +86,7 @@
 * On March 20, 1990, the town council of [[Ternopil]] voted upon the usage and re-establishment of the yellow-and-blue flag and the [[Coat of arms of Ukraine|''tryzub'']] as well as the national anthem ''[[Ukraine's glory has not perished|Shche ne vmerla Ukrainy]]''. On the same day, the yellow-and-blue national flag was flown for the first time in about 80 years on a governmental building in Kiev, replacing the then official [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR|red-and-blue flag]] of the Ukrainian SSR.
 * On April 28, 1990, the oblast council (''oblasna rada'') of [[Lviv Oblast|Lviv]] also allowed the use of the national symbols of Ukraine within the Oblast.
 * On April 29, 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown from the Ternopil city theater's flagstaff without the [[Flag of the Soviet Union|official flag of the Soviet Union]] hanging above it.
-* After July 24, 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown for the first time over an official governmental building of the [[Kiev City Council]] on the ''[[Maidan Nezalezhnosti]]'' square of the ''[[Khreschatyk]]'' street.
+* After July 24, 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown for the first time over an official governmental building of the [[Kiev City Council]] on the ''[[Maidan Nezalezhnosti]]'' square of the ''[[Khreschatyk]]'' street.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/ukrainian/politics/2012/07/120724_flag_ukraine_history_kyiv_as.shtml Twenty two years ago in Kiev officially was raised the blue-yellow flag (22 роки тому в Києві офіційно підняли синьо-жовтий прапор)]. BBC Ukraine. July 24, 2012.</ref>
 * After the declaration of independence of Ukraine on August 24, 1991, the national yellow-and-blue flag flew for the first time over the [[Verkhovna Rada|Ukrainian Parliament (''Verkhovna Rada'')]] building on September 4, 1991.
 
 ===Attempts to revive Soviet flags===

 ==Flag controversies and criticism==
 ===Origin===
-Some of the theories{{which|date=January 2014}} said that Ukrainian flag was given by the [[Silesia]]n knight{{cn|date=January 2014}} from the city of [[Opole]]—[[Władysław Opolczyk]], Polish governor of [[Galicia–Volhynia]]{{?}}. It has the same colours as the flag of [[Opole]].
+Some of the theories{{which|date=January 2014}} said that Ukrainian flag was given by the [[Silesia]]n knight{{cn|date=January 2014}} from the city of [[Opole]]—[[Władysław Opolczyk]], Hungarian governor of [[Galicia–Volhynia]]. It has the same colours as the flag of [[Opole]].
 
 === yellow-blue vs blue-yellow ===
 Interestingly, Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as '''yellow and light blue''' (жовто-блакитний, ''zhovto-blakytnyi'')<ref>A little less often is used also "yellow and blue", "blue and yellow" and "yellow and azure".</ref> — a different version of the flag used during UNR ([[Ukrainian National Republic]]) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. The yellow on the top represents golden domes ([[cupola]]s) of Christian churches and the blue the [[Dnieper]] river.

 ===Postwar Ukraine===

The Communist party leaders such as [[Khrushchev]] and [[Kaganovich]] were afraid of using words ''light blue'' and ''blue'' which were used by the [[Ukrainian diaspora]].<ref name=grechylo/>
 
-In 1958 in village of Verbytsia, [[:uk:Ходорівський район|Khodoriv Raion]] there was established an underground group, members of which at night were raising national flags and spread anti-Soviet pamphlets.<ref>[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/columns/2011/07/29/48180/ Unknown flag-bearers. Yellow-blue against Red (Невідомі прапороносці. Жовто-блакитний проти червоного)]. [[Ukrayinska Pravda]]. July 29, 2011</ref>
+During the Soviet period there were multiple unsanctioned attempts to hoist the national blue-and-yellow flag. In 1958 in village of Verbytsia, [[:uk:Ходорівський район|Khodoriv Raion]] there was established an underground group, members of which at night were raising national flags and spread anti-Soviet pamphlets.<ref>[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/columns/2011/07/29/48180/ Unknown flag-bearers. Yellow-blue against Red (Невідомі прапороносці. Жовто-блакитний проти червоного)]. [[Ukrayinska Pravda]]. July 29, 2011</ref>
 
 ===Return of the national flag===
 Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[perestroika]] and [[glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national identity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1985-1991)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian SSR (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed.

-The '''state flag of [[Ukraine]]''' ({{lang-uk|державний прапор України}}; [[Romanization of Ukrainian|translit.]]: ''derzhavnyy prapor Ukrayiny''; literally ‘state flag of Ukraine’) is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow colour. ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]])
+The '''state flag of [[Ukraine]]''' ({{lang-uk|державний прапор України}}; [[Romanization of Ukrainian|translit.]]: ''derzhavnyy prapor Ukrayiny''; literally ‘state flag of Ukraine’) is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow colour, which symbolize the clear blue sky over yellow wheat field. ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]])
 
 As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolor was officially used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]] when it was hoisted over the [[Lviv Town Hall|Lviv Rathaus]]. It is was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. During the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] occupation, the flag was outlawed and before 1949 there was no official state flag until adoption of the red-blue [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. People who were hoisting the blue-yellow flags in the Soviet Ukraine were prosecuted as criminals. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September of 1991 following Ukrainian independence, before finally officially being restored in 1992.

[[Ukrayinska Pravda]]. April 21, 2011</ref> The current Victory Banner was adopted in [[Russia]] back in 2007. On May 20, 2011 the law was signed by the [[President of Ukraine]] [[Viktor Yanukovych]].<ref>[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/short/2011/05/21/39383/ Yanukovych signed the law about the Red Banner (ЯНУКОВИЧ ПІДПИСАВ ЗАКОН ПРО ЧЕРВОНИЙ ПРАПОР)]. [[Ukrayinska Pravda]]. May 21, 2011</ref> On June 17, 2011 the [[Constitutional Court of Ukraine]] recognized the law as non-constitutional and proposed the parliament to implement required amendments to the [[Constitution of Ukraine]].<ref>[http://www.rg.ru/2011/06/17/znamya-anons.html CC of Ukraine recognized the use of Red Victory Banner as non-constitutional (КС Украины признал неконституционным использование красного знамени Победы)]. Russian Gazette. June 17, 2011</ref>
 
-==Flag controversies==
+==Flag controversies and criticism==
 ===Origin===
 Some of the theories{{which|date=January 2014}} said that Ukrainian flag was given by the [[Silesia]]n knight{{cn|date=January 2014}} from the city of [[Opole]]—[[Władysław Opolczyk]], Polish governor of [[Galicia–Volhynia]]{{?}}. It has the same colours as the flag of [[Opole]].
 
@@ -107,6 +107,9 @@
 The head of the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]], [[Andriy Grechylo]] points to the fact that the discussion about order of colors was taking place as far back as 1918.<ref name=grechylo>[http://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_hruschov-i-kaganovich-boyalisya-slova-zhovto-blakitnij/512859#photo-3 Khrushchev and Kaganovich were afraid of the word "zhovto-blakytnyi" (Хрущов і Каганович боялися слова "жовто-блакитний")]. Gazette in Ukrainian (gazeta.ua). August 23, 2013</ref> Nonetheless, both governments of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] as well as the [[Ukrainian State]] defined that the upper half would be light-blue, while the lower - yellow.<ref name=grechylo/> During 1918 it was taking in consideration that light blue would loose its shade under sun, therefore it was decided to make color darker.<ref name=grechylo/>
 
 Already in the 1918 draft of Constitution of the [[Ukrainian National Republic]] the order of colors was defined as blue and yellow.<ref name=grechylo/> The same order could be found in legislative acts of the [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] for November of 1918 and the [[Carpathian Ukraine]] on March 15, 1939.<ref name=grechylo/> The argument on the order of colors was taking place in the [[Ukrainian diaspora]] as well.<ref name=grechylo/> In 1949 it was decided that until in Ukraine it would not be defined a single state flag, the diaspora will be using the blue-and-yellow banner.<ref name=grechylo/>
+
+===Shade of colors===
+There is also criticism in regards to shades.<ref name=grechylo/> There are specialists who argue that according to rules of heraldry current set of colors cannot coexist.<ref>[http://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_sino-zhovtij-prapor-ce-znuschannya-nad-ukrajinskoyu-tradicieyu/508746 Blue-yellow flag is a cruelty towards the Ukrainian traditions (Синьо-жовтий прапор - це знущання над українською традицією)]. Gazette in Ukrainian (gazeta.ua). July 25, 2013</ref> The head of the Ukrainian Heraldry Society points to the fact that it is not [[heraldry]], but rather [[vexelology]] that studies flags.<ref name=grechylo/>

 It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the verbal language as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy''), the current flag in reality is blue (the top string) and yellow (the bottom string). The issue is quite notable, because the historical rotation of the flag (from yellow–blue to blue–yellow) did not affect the spoken language.{{cn|date=January 2014}} Back in 1848 the flag was indeed yellow and blue,{{cn|date=January 2014}} and it was later rotated to blue and yellow to be more appealing to the common person.{{cn|date=January 2014}} The common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time,{{cn|date=January 2014}} and, although this evocation of a Ukrainian landscape has nothing to do with the choice of colours or the history of the original yellow and blue, it certainly has formed the Ukrainians' conception of their flag.{{cn|date=January 2014}}
 
-There is a popular interpretation of the meaning of the colors of the Ukrainian flag according to which the color blue represents the color of the sky, and the yellow symbolizes the lush golden wheat fields of this country. This association is thought to have been developed in the mid-19th century.{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}} However, this interpretation is but a poetic metaphor{{by whom|date=January 2014}} due to the fact that in the UNR in 1917, and sometimes later, the yellow-top and blue-bottom flag was used.
-
 The head of the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]], [[Andriy Grechylo]] points to the fact that the discussion about order of colors was taking place as far back as 1918.<ref name=grechylo>[http://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_hruschov-i-kaganovich-boyalisya-slova-zhovto-blakitnij/512859#photo-3 Khrushchev and Kaganovich were afraid of the word "zhovto-blakytnyi" (Хрущов і Каганович боялися слова "жовто-блакитний")]. Gazette in Ukrainian (gazeta.ua). August 23, 2013</ref> Nonetheless, both governments of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] as well as the [[Ukrainian State]] defined that the upper half would be light-blue, while the lower - yellow.<ref name=grechylo/> During 1918 it was taking in consideration that light blue would loose its shade under sun, therefore it was decided to make color darker.<ref name=grechylo/>
 
 Already in the 1918 draft of Constitution of the [[Ukrainian National Republic]] the order of colors was defined as blue and yellow.<ref name=grechylo/> The same order could be found in legislative acts of the [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] for November of 1918 and the [[Carpathian Ukraine]] on March 15, 1939.<ref name=grechylo/> The argument on the order of colors was taking place in the [[Ukrainian diaspora]] as well.<ref name=grechylo/> In 1949 it was decided that until in Ukraine it would not be defined a single state flag, the diaspora will be using the blue-and-yellow banner.<ref name=grechylo/>

 ==Flag controversies and criticism==
+=== Vertical flags ===
+[[File:Hanging flag ukraine.jpg|thumb|upright=0.25|Hanging flag]]
+In addition to the normal horizontal format, many public buildings in Ukraine use vertical flags. Most town halls fly their town flag together with the national flag in this way; some town flags in Ukraine exist only in vertical form. The proportions of these vertical flags are not specified<!-- (commented out until supporting evidence can be found), although a ratio of 5:2 is the most common-->. When hung like a banner or draped, the blue band should be on the left, as illustrated. When flown from a vertical flagpole, the blue band must face the mast.
 
 ===Origin===
 Some of the theories{{which|date=January 2014}} said that Ukrainian flag was given by the [[Silesia]]n knight{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} from the city of [[Opole]]—[[Władysław Opolczyk]], Hungarian governor of [[Galicia–Volhynia]]. It has the same colours as the flag of [[Opole]].

It has the same colours as the flag of [[Opole]]. === yellow-blue vs blue-yellow === Interestingly, Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as '''yellow and light blue''' (жовто-блакитний, ''zhovto-blakytnyi'')A little less often is used also "yellow and blue", "blue and yellow" and "yellow and azure". — a different version of the flag used during UNR ([[Ukrainian National Republic]]) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. The yellow on the top represents golden domes ([[cupola]]s) of Christian churches and the blue the [[Dnieper]] river. -It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the verbal language as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy''), the current flag in reality is blue (the top string) and yellow (the bottom string). The issue is quite notable, because the historical rotation of the flag (from yellow–blue to blue–yellow) did not affect the spoken language.{{cn|date=January 2014}} Back in 1848 the flag was indeed yellow and blue,{{cn|date=January 2014}} and it was later rotated to blue and yellow to be more appealing to the common person.{{cn|date=January 2014}} The common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time,{{cn|date=January 2014}} and, although this evocation of a Ukrainian landscape has nothing to do with the choice of colours or the history of the original yellow and blue, it certainly has formed the Ukrainians' conception of their flag.{{cn|date=January 2014}} +It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the verbal language as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy''), the current flag in reality is blue (the top string) and yellow (the bottom string). The issue is quite notable, because the historical rotation of the flag (from yellow–blue to blue–yellow) did not affect the spoken language.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} Back in 1848 the flag was indeed yellow and blue,{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} and it was later rotated to blue and yellow to be more appealing to the common person.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} The common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time,{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} and, although this evocation of a Ukrainian landscape has nothing to do with the choice of colours or the history of the original yellow and blue, it certainly has formed the Ukrainians' conception of their flag.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} The head of the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]], [[Andriy Grechylo]] points to the fact that the discussion about order of colors was taking place as far back as 1918.[http://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_hruschov-i-kaganovich-boyalisya-slova-zhovto-blakitnij/512859#photo-3 Khrushchev and Kaganovich were afraid of the word "zhovto-blakytnyi" (Хрущов і Каганович боялися слова "жовто-блакитний")]. Gazette in Ukrainian (gazeta.ua). August 23, 2013 Nonetheless, both governments of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] as well as the [[Ukrainian State]] defined that the upper half would be light-blue, while the lower - yellow. During 1918 it was taking in consideration that light blue would loose its shade under sun, therefore it was decided to make color darker. -Already in the 1918 draft of Constitution of the [[Ukrainian National Republic]] the order of colors was defined as blue and yellow. The same order could be found in legislative acts of the [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] for November of 1918 and the [[Carpathian Ukraine]] on March 15, 1939. The argument on the order of colors was taking place in the [[Ukrainian diaspora]] as well. In 1949 it was decided that until in Ukraine it would not be defined a single state flag, the diaspora will be using the blue-and-yellow banner. +Already in the 1918 draft of Constitution of the [[Ukrainian National Republic]] the order of colors was defined as blue and yellow. The same order could be found in legislative acts of the [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] for November 1918 and the [[Carpathian Ukraine]] on March 15, 1939. The argument on the order of colors was taking place in the [[Ukrainian diaspora]] as well. In 1949 it was decided that until in Ukraine it would not be defined a single state flag, the diaspora will be using the blue-and-yellow banner. ===Shade of colors=== There is also criticism in regards to shades. There are specialists who argue that according to rules of heraldry current set of colors cannot coexist.[http://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_sino-zhovtij-prapor-ce-znuschannya-nad-ukrajinskoyu-tradicieyu/508746 Blue-yellow flag is a cruelty towards the Ukrainian traditions (Синьо-жовтий прапор - це знущання над українською традицією)]. Gazette in Ukrainian (gazeta.ua). In 1958 in village of Verbytsia, [[:uk:Ходорівський район|Khodoriv Raion]] there was established an underground group, members of which at night were raising national flags and spread anti-Soviet pamphlets.<ref>[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/columns/2011/07/29/48180/ Unknown flag-bearers. Yellow-blue against Red (Невідомі прапороносці. Жовто-блакитний проти червоного)]. [[Ukrayinska Pravda]]. July 29, 2011</ref>
 
 ===Return of the national flag===
+[[File:Ukrflagblue.jpg|thumbnail|right|Flag at Kyiv City Hall]]
+[[File:Leonid Kadenyuk.jpg|thumbnail|right|Flag of Ukraine on Ukrainian astronaut [[Leonid Kadenyuk]]'s space suitl]]
 Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[perestroika]] and [[glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national identity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1985-1991)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian SSR (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed.
 
 The events in the Baltic countries soon led to similar processes in Ukraine. Particularly, West Ukraine and [[Ukrainian SSR]]'s capital [[Kiev]] (''Kyiv'') constantly held political demonstrations with the national yellow-and-blue flags waving above the heads of demonstrators.
 
-[[File:Ukrflagblue.jpg|thumbnail|right|Flag at Kyiv City Hall]]
 * On March 20, 1990, the town council of [[Ternopil]] voted upon the usage and re-establishment of the yellow-and-blue flag and the [[Coat of arms of Ukraine|''tryzub'']] as well as the national anthem ''[[Ukraine's glory has not perished|Shche ne vmerla Ukrainy]]''. On the same day, the yellow-and-blue national flag was flown for the first time in about 80 years on a governmental building in Kiev, replacing the then official [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR|red-and-blue flag]] of the Ukrainian SSR.
 * On April 28, 1990, the oblast council (''oblasna rada'') of [[Lviv Oblast|Lviv]] also allowed the use of the national symbols of Ukraine within the Oblast.
 * On April 29, 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown from the Ternopil city theater's flagstaff without the [[Flag of the Soviet Union|official flag of the Soviet Union]] hanging above it.

For the first time in the [[Russian Empire]] the blue-yellow flag was flown on March 25, 1917 in [[Petrograd]] during a 20-thousand people mass [[Demonstration (protest)|demonstration]].<ref name=istpravda/> On the territory of the Russian Ukraine ([[Little Russia]]) the national flag of Ukraine was flown for the first time in [[Kiev]] on March 29, 1917 by soldiers.<ref name=istpravda/> On April 1, 1917 Kiev saw a 100-thousand people demonstration that carried over 320 national flags.<ref name=istpravda/> After that similar demonstration with Ukrainian flags took place across the whole [[Russian Empire]] even beyond the Ukrainian ethnic lands.<ref name=istpravda/> Number of famous Ukrainian politician wrote their recollection about the April 1 demonstration such as [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] and [[Serhiy Yefremov]] stating that there were blue-and-yellow flags, while [[Dmytro Doroshenko]] claimed that there were yellow-and-blue.<ref name=istpravda/>
-[[File:Ukrflagblue.jpg|thumbnail|right]]
 The blue-yellow flag was flown at the First Ukrainian Military Congress on May 18, 1917.<ref name=istpravda/>
 
 There are reliable sources that indicate that an official flag was declared by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in 1918 is blue–yellow. Some sources mention that the yellow–blue was adopted by [[Tsentralna Rada]] on March 22, 1918.<ref>[http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=32027&cat_id=31295 State Symbols of Ukraine], [[Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine]], website.</ref> Other sources point out that no hard proof of such decision exists.<ref name=istpravda/><ref>http://vexillography.narod.ru/ukraine/unr.htm</ref> Instead, they refer to the decision on the Fleet Flag, which was set to be light blue–yellow<ref>[http://www.history.org.ua/journal/1999/4/10.pdf Ukrainian Historical Journal, 1999, #4, ISSN 0130-S247]</ref> as an indication that the official flag was light blue–yellow.<ref>[http://vijsko.milua.org/Khoruhvy_HA.htm Українське військо у ХХ-ХХІ сторіччі]</ref> Also were adopted other service flags of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].<ref>Grechylo A. Ukrayinska Terytorialna Heraldyka. Lviv, 2010, pp. 98-118. ISBN 978-966-02-5259-2</ref>

 * On April 28, 1990, the oblast council (''oblasna rada'') of [[Lviv Oblast|Lviv]] also allowed the use of the national symbols of Ukraine within the Oblast.
 * On April 29, 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown from the Ternopil city theater's flagstaff without the [[Flag of the Soviet Union|official flag of the Soviet Union]] hanging above it.

 ===Return of the national flag===

-[[File:Leonid Kadenyuk.jpg|thumbnail|right|Flag of Ukraine on Ukrainian astronaut [[Leonid Kadenyuk]]'s space suitl]]
 Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[perestroika]] and [[glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national identity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1985-1991)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian SSR (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed.
 
 The events in the Baltic countries soon led to similar processes in Ukraine. Particularly, West Ukraine and [[Ukrainian SSR]]'s capital [[Kiev]] (''Kyiv'') constantly held political demonstrations with the national yellow-and-blue flags waving above the heads of demonstrators.

These were not the only possible combinations, since normally Cossacks would fly their [[hetman]]'s banners, which were similar to the coats of arms of the nobility. Also, yellow and blue were the colours common on coats of arms in [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]]. In fact, the coat of arms of [[Lviv]] to this day remains a golden lion on a blue field.

 In addition to the normal horizontal format, many public buildings in Ukraine use vertical flags. Most town halls fly their town flag together with the national flag in this way; some town flags in Ukraine exist only in vertical form. The proportions of these vertical flags are not specified<!-- (commented out until supporting evidence can be found), although a ratio of 5:2 is the most common-->. When hung like a banner or draped, the blue band should be on the left, as illustrated. When flown from a vertical flagpole, the blue band must face the mast.

The Communist party leaders such as [[Khrushchev]] and [[Kaganovich]] were afraid of using words ''light blue'' and ''blue'' which were used by the [[Ukrainian diaspora]]. -During the Soviet period there were multiple unsanctioned attempts to hoist the national blue-and-yellow flag. In 1958 in village of Verbytsia, [[:uk:Ходорівський район|Khodoriv Raion]] there was established an underground group, members of which at night were raising national flags and spread anti-Soviet pamphlets.[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/columns/2011/07/29/48180/ Unknown flag-bearers. Yellow-blue against Red (Невідомі прапороносці. Жовто-блакитний проти червоного)]. [[Ukrayinska Pravda]].
