Yellow-blue against Red (Невідомі прапороносці. Жовто-блакитний проти червоного)]. ''[[Ukrayinska Pravda]]''. July 29, 2011 ===Return of the national flag=== -Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[perestroika]] and [[glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national identity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1985-1991)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian SSR (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed. +Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[perestroika]] and [[glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national identity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1982–91)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed. The events in the Baltic countries soon led to similar processes in Ukraine. Particularly, West Ukraine and [[Ukrainian SSR]]'s capital [[Kiev]] (''Kyiv'') constantly held political demonstrations with the national yellow-and-blue flags waving above the heads of demonstrators. - * On March 20, 1990, the town council of [[Ternopil]] voted upon the usage and re-establishment of the yellow-and-blue flag and the [[Coat of arms of Ukraine|''tryzub'']] as well as the national anthem ''[[Ukraine's glory has not perished|Shche ne vmerla Ukrainy]]''. On the same day, the yellow-and-blue national flag was flown for the first time in about 80 years on a governmental building in Kiev, replacing the then official [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR|red-and-blue flag]] of the Ukrainian SSR. * On April 28, 1990, the oblast council (''oblasna rada'') of [[Lviv Oblast|Lviv]] also allowed the use of the national symbols of Ukraine within the Oblast. * On April 29, 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown from the Ternopil city theater's flagstaff without the [[Flag of the Soviet Union|official flag of the Soviet Union]] hanging above it. @@ -84,11 +80,11 @@ * After the declaration of independence of Ukraine on August 24, 1991, the national yellow-and-blue flag flew for the first time over the [[Verkhovna Rada|Ukrainian Parliament (''Verkhovna Rada'')]] building on September 4, 1991. ===Attempts to revive Soviet flags=== -[[File:Soviet Znamya Pobedy.svg|right|thumb|150px|"Banner of Victory #5" was raised just below a statue on the roof of the Reichstag building]] -On April 21, 2011 the [[Verkhovna Rada]] adopted a law which allows to raise the [[Victory Banner]] on the Victory Day.[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/short/2011/04/21/36767/ Rada enforced raising red flags on the May 9 (РАДА ЗОБОВ'ЯЗАЛА ВИВІШУВАТИ ЧЕРВОНІ ПРАПОРИ НА 9 ТРАВНЯ)]. The yellow on the top represents golden domes ([[cupola]]s) of Christian churches and the blue the [[Dnieper]] river. It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the verbal language as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy''), the current flag in reality is blue (the top string) and yellow (the bottom string). The issue is quite notable, because the historical rotation of the flag (from yellow–blue to blue–yellow) did not affect the spoken language.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} Back in 1848 the flag was indeed yellow and blue,{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} and it was later rotated to blue and yellow to be more appealing to the common person.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} The common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time,{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} and, although this evocation of a Ukrainian landscape has nothing to do with the choice of colours or the history of the original yellow and blue, it certainly has formed the Ukrainians' conception of their flag.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} [[File:Waving the Ukrainian flag.jpg|thumbnail|right|A girl with flag at [[vyshyvanka]] parade]] @@ -105,7 +101,7 @@ Already in the 1918 draft of Constitution of the [[Ukrainian National Republic]] the order of colors was defined as blue and yellow. The same order could be found in legislative acts of the [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] for November 1918 and the [[Carpathian Ukraine]] on March 15, 1939. The argument on the order of colors was taking place in the [[Ukrainian diaspora]] as well. In 1949 it was decided that until in Ukraine it would not be defined a single state flag, the diaspora will be using the blue-and-yellow banner. ===Shade of colors=== -There is also criticism in regards to shades.  23 August is celebrated as the Day of the National Flag in Ukraine; beginning with 2004. July 24 was previously marked as National Flag Day in Kiev. The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on 24 July 1990 at the flagstaff of the Kiev City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992 Independence Day of Ukraine is celebrated on August 24. Following goverment decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this dates and some other holidays. Not all of these days are public holidays. Flags also must be flown on election days for the [[Verkhovna Rada]]  in addition to other regional-specific flag days. The public display of flags to mark other events, such as the election of the president or the death of a prominent politician (whereupon flags would be at half-mast), can be declared at the discretion of the Cabinet of Ministers. When flags are required to be flown at half-mast, vertical flags are not lowered. A black mourning ribbon is instead attached, either atop the mast (if hung from a pole) or to each end of the flag's supporting cross-beams (if flown like a banner).
 
 ==History==

 The roots of Ukrainian national symbols come from before Christian times when yellow and blue prevailed in traditional ceremonies, reflecting fire and water.<ref name=Saprykov>[http://geraldika.ru/symbols/3334 Geraldika.ru Флаг Украины]</ref> The most solid proof of yellow and blue colors could be traced as far as the [[Battle of Grunwald]] at which participated militia formations from various lands of the Polish-Lithuanian Union.

 ===Soviet Ukraine: 1922–1993===
 {{Main|Flag of the Ukrainian SSR}}
-[[File:Ukrflagblue.jpg|thumbnail|right|Flag at Kyiv City Hall]]
-[[File:Leonid Kadenyuk.jpg|thumbnail|right|Flag of Ukraine on Ukrainian astronaut [[Leonid Kadenyuk]]'s space suit]]
 The first flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic was adopted on March 10, 1919, to serve as the symbol of state of the Ukrainian SSR. Details of the official flag changed periodically before the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991, but all were based on the red flag of the Bolshevik Revolution.
 The first flag was red with the gold Cyrillic sans-serif letters У.С.С.Р. (USSR, acronym for Ukrayinskaya Sotsialisticheskaya Sovetskaya Respublika in the Russian language). In the 1930s a gold border was added. In 1937, a new flag was adopted, with a small gold hammer and sickle added above the gold Cyrillic serif letters У.Р.С.Р. (URSR, for Ukrayins’ka Radyans’ka Sotsialistychna Respublika in the Ukrainian language).
 
 ===Postwar Ukraine===
+[[File:Ukrflagblue.jpg|thumbnail|right|Flag at Kyiv City Hall]]
+[[File:Leonid Kadenyuk.jpg|thumbnail|right|Flag of Ukraine on Ukrainian astronaut [[Leonid Kadenyuk]]'s space suit]]
 In 1949 the flag of Ukraine was changed once again.<ref name=grechylo/> The [[Soviet Union]] managed to obtain two additional seats in the [[United Nations]] by adding as members Ukraine along with Belarus.<ref name=grechylo/> The change was due to the fact that all the Soviet flags were the same.<ref name=grechylo/> The new Ukrainian flag consisted of a red (top, 2/3) and a [[azure]] (bottom, 1/3) stripes,<ref name=grechylo/> with the golden star, [[sickle and mallet]] in the top left corner. The Communist party leaders such as [[Khrushchev]] and [[Kaganovich]] were afraid of using words ''light blue'' and ''blue'' which were used by the [[Ukrainian diaspora]].<ref name=grechylo/>
 
 During the Soviet period there were multiple unsanctioned attempts to hoist the national blue-and-yellow flag. In 1958 in village of Verbytsia, [[:uk:Ходорівський район|Khodoriv Raion]] there was established an underground group, members of which at night were raising national flags and spread anti-Soviet pamphlets.<ref>[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/columns/2011/07/29/48180/ Unknown flag-bearers. Yellow-blue against Red (Невідомі прапороносці. Жовто-блакитний проти червоного)]. ''[[Ukrayinska Pravda]]''. July 29, 2011</ref>

-Both blue–yellow and yellow–blue flags were widely used during the [[Ukraine after the Russian Revolution|Ukrainian struggle for independence]] in 1917. For the first time in the [[Russian Empire]] the blue-yellow flag was flown on March 25, 1917 in [[Petrograd]] during a 20-thousand people mass [[Demonstration (protest)|demonstration]].<ref name=istpravda/> On the territory of the Russian Ukraine ([[Little Russia]]) the national flag of Ukraine was flown for the first time in [[Kiev]] on March 29, 1917 by soldiers.<ref name=istpravda/> On April 1, 1917 Kiev saw a 100-thousand people demonstration that carried over 320 national flags.<ref name=istpravda/> After that similar demonstration with Ukrainian flags took place across the whole [[Russian Empire]] even beyond the Ukrainian ethnic lands.<ref name=istpravda/> Number of famous Ukrainian politician wrote their recollection about the April 1 demonstration such as [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] and [[Serhiy Yefremov]] stating that there were blue-and-yellow flags, while [[Dmytro Doroshenko]] claimed that there were yellow-and-blue.<ref name=istpravda/> The blue-yellow flag was flown at the First Ukrainian Military Congress on May 18, 1917.<ref name=istpravda/>
+[[File:Картина Перфецького "Київ, 31 сепня 1919 р.".jpg|thumbnail|Leonid Perfetsky. Kyiv, Aug 1919]]
+Both blue–yellow and yellow–blue flags were widely used during the [[Ukraine after the Russian Revolution|Ukraian struggle for independence]] in 1917. For the first time in the [[Russian Empire]] the blue-yellow flag was flown on March 25, 1917 in [[Petrograd]] during a 20-thousand people mass [[Demonstration (protest)|demonstration]].<ref name=istpravda/> On the territory of the Russian Ukraine ([[Little Russia]]) the national flag of Ukraine was flown for the first time in [[Kiev]] on March 29, 1917 by soldiers.<ref name=istpravda/> On April 1, 1917 Kiev saw a 100-thousand people demonstration that carried over 320 national flags.<ref name=istpravda/> After that similar demonstration with Ukrainian flags took place across the whole [[Russian Empire]] even beyond the Ukrainian ethnic lands.<ref name=istpravda/> Number of famous Ukrainian politician wrote their recollection about the April 1 demonstration such as [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] and [[Serhiy Yefremov]] stating that there were blue-and-yellow flags, while [[Dmytro Doroshenko]] claimed that there were yellow-and-blue.<ref name=istpravda/> The blue-yellow flag was flown at the First Ukrainian Military Congress on May 18, 1917.<ref name=istpravda/>
 
 There are reliable sources that indicate that an official flag was declared by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in 1918 is blue–yellow. Some sources mention that the yellow–blue was adopted by [[Tsentralna Rada]] on March 22, 1918.<ref>[http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=32027&cat_id=31295 State Symbols of Ukraine], [[Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine]], website.</ref> Other sources point out that no hard proof of ''such'' decision exists.<ref name=istpravda/><ref>http://vexillography.narod.ru/ukraine/unr.htm</ref> Instead, they refer to the decision on the Fleet Flag, which was set to be light blue–yellow<ref>[http://www.history.org.ua/journal/1999/4/10.pdf ''Ukrainian Historical Journal'', 1999, #4, ISSN 0130-S247]</ref> as an indication that the official flag was light blue–yellow.<ref>[http://vijsko.milua.org/Khoruhvy_HA.htm Українське військо у ХХ-ХХІ сторіччі]</ref> Also were adopted other service flags of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].<ref>Grechylo A. Ukrayinska Terytorialna Heraldyka. Lviv, 2010, pp. 98-118. ISBN 978-966-02-5259-2</ref>

The issue is quite notable, because the historical rotation of the flag (from yellow–blue to blue–yellow) did not affect the spoken language.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} Back in 1848 the flag was indeed yellow and blue,{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} and it was later rotated to blue and yellow to be more appealing to the common person.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} The common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time,{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} and, although this evocation of a Ukrainian landscape has nothing to do with the choice of colours or the history of the original yellow and blue, it certainly has formed the Ukrainians' conception of their flag.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} -[[File:Waving the Ukrainian flag.jpg|thumbnail|right|A girl with flag at [[vyshyvanka]] parade]] + The head of the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]], [[Andriy Grechylo]] points to the fact that the discussion about order of colors was taking place as far back as 1918.[http://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_hruschov-i-kaganovich-boyalisya-slova-zhovto-blakitnij/512859#photo-3 Khrushchev and Kaganovich were afraid of the word "zhovto-blakytnyi" (Хрущов і Каганович боялися слова "жовто-блакитний")]. The same order could be found in legislative acts of the [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] for November 1918 and the [[Carpathian Ukraine]] on March 15, 1939. The argument on the order of colors was taking place in the [[Ukrainian diaspora]] as well. Gorpinchenko, W. Sinel'nikova, G. Docenko, O. Kupko, I. Potapenko, E. Ershova |title=State Flag of Ukraine. DSTU 4512:2006 |publisher=State Standards of Ukraine |location=[[Kiev]] |year=September 2006 | page=7}} -|- -| [[RGB color model]] -| 005BBB -| FFD500 -|} - -There is also criticism in regards to shades. There are specialists who argue that, according to rules of heraldry, the current set of colors cannot coexist.[http://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_sino-zhovtij-prapor-ce-znuschannya-nad-ukrajinskoyu-tradicieyu/508746 Blue-yellow flag is a cruelty towards the Ukrainian traditions (Синьо-жовтий прапор - це знущання над українською традицією)]. ''Gazette'' in Ukrainian (gazeta.ua). July 25, 2013 The head of the Ukrainian Heraldry Society pointed out that it is not [[heraldry]], but rather [[vexillology]] that studies flags. -===Legal status=== -Article 20 of the Constitution of Ukraine states the following, citing: ''"the State Flag of Ukraine is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow color."'' ({{lang-uk|''"Державний Прапор України є банер з двох однакових за розміром горизонтальних смуг синього і жовтого кольору."''}} [[s:Constitution of Ukraine|Constitution of Ukraine]]). +On April 21, 2011 the [[Verkhovna Rada]] adopted a law which allows to raise the [[Victory Banner]] on the Victory Day.[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/short/2011/04/21/36767/ Rada enforced raising red flags on the May 9 (РАДА ЗОБОВ'ЯЗАЛА ВИВІШУВАТИ ЧЕРВОНІ ПРАПОРИ НА 9 ТРАВНЯ)]. ''Ukrayinska Pravda''. April 21, 2011 The current Victory Banner was adopted in [[Russia]] back in 2007. On May 20, 2011 the law was signed by the [[President of Ukraine]] [[Viktor Yanukovych]].[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/short/2011/05/21/39383/ Yanukovych signed the law about the Red Banner (ЯНУКОВИЧ ПІДПИСАВ ЗАКОН ПРО ЧЕРВОНИЙ ПРАПОР)]. ''Ukrayinska Pravda''. May 21, 2011 On June 17, 2011 the [[Constitutional Court of Ukraine]] recognized the law as non-constitutional and proposed the parliament to implement required amendments to the [[Constitution of Ukraine]].[http://www.rg.ru/2011/06/17/znamya-anons.html CC of Ukraine recognized the use of Red Victory Banner as non-constitutional (КС Украины признал неконституционным использование красного знамени Победы)]. ''Russian Gazette''. changed_version:

@@ -91,7 +91,11 @@
 ===Postwar Ukraine===
 [[File:Ukrflagblue.jpg|thumbnail|right|Flag at Kyiv City Hall]]
 [[File:Leonid Kadenyuk.jpg|thumbnail|right|Flag of Ukraine on Ukrainian astronaut [[Leonid Kadenyuk]]'s space suit]]
-In 1949 the flag of Ukraine was changed once again.<ref name=grechylo/> The [[Soviet Union]] managed to obtain two additional seats in the [[United Nations]] by adding as members Ukraine along with Belarus.<ref name=grechylo/> The change was due to the fact that all the Soviet flags were the same.<ref name=grechylo/> The new Ukrainian flag consisted of a red (top, 2/3) and a [[azure]] (bottom, 1/3) stripes,<ref name=grechylo/> with the golden star, [[sickle and mallet]] in the top left corner. The Communist party leaders such as [[Khrushchev]] and [[Kaganovich]] were afraid of using words ''light blue'' and ''blue'' which were used by the [[Ukrainian diaspora]].<ref name=grechylo/>
+The Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists is a Ukrainian political organization which as a movement originally was created in 1929 in Western Ukraine (at the time interwar Poland). For long time OUN did not officially have its own flag, however during the Hungarian and Polish aggression against the Carpathian Ukraine in 1938, Carpathian Sich, a militarized wing of OUN, adopted its flag from the OUN's emblem - golden nationalistic trident on a blue background. The flag was finalized and officially adopted by the organization only in 1964 at the 5th Assembly of Ukrainian Nationalists.
+
+The Ukrainian Insurgent Army was a Ukrainian nationalist paramilitary and later partisan army that engaged in a series of guerrilla conflicts during World War II against Nazi Germany, the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, and both Underground and Communist Poland. The group was the military wing of the Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists — Bandera faction (the OUN-B), originally formed in Volyn in the spring and summer of 1943. Its official date of creation is 14 October 1942,[1] day of Intercession of the Theotokos feast. The battle flag of the UPA was a 2:3 ratio red-and-black banner. The flag continues to be a symbol of the Ukrainian nationalist movement. The colors of the flag symbolize 'Ukrainian red blood spilled on Ukrainian black earth'.
+
+In 1949 the flag of the Soviet Ukraine was changed once again.<ref name=grechylo/> The [[Soviet Union]] managed to obtain two additional seats in the [[United Nations]] by adding as members Ukraine along with Belarus.<ref name=grechylo/> The change was due to the fact that all the Soviet flags were the same.<ref name=grechylo/> The new Ukrainian flag consisted of a red (top, 2/3) and a [[azure]] (bottom, 1/3) stripes,<ref name=grechylo/> with the golden star, [[sickle and mallet]] in the top left corner. The Communist party leaders such as [[Khrushchev]] and [[Kaganovich]] were afraid of using words ''light blue'' and ''blue'' which were used by the [[Ukrainian diaspora]].<ref name=grechylo/>
 
 During the Soviet period there were multiple unsanctioned attempts to hoist the national blue-and-yellow flag. In 1958 in village of Verbytsia, [[:uk:Ходорівський район|Khodoriv Raion]] there was established an underground group, members of which at night were raising national flags and spread anti-Soviet pamphlets.<ref>[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/columns/2011/07/29/48180/ Unknown flag-bearers. Yellow-blue against Red (Невідомі прапороносці. Жовто-блакитний проти червоного)]. ''[[Ukrayinska Pravda]]''. July 29, 2011</ref>
llm_output:
The change made in this revision is the addition of a detailed description of the Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists (OUN) and the Ukrainian Insurgent Army (UPA), including their historical context, flags, and symbolism. 

Weaponised

Justification: The added content emphasizes Ukrainian nationalism and the historical significance of the OUN and UPA, which can be interpreted as a narrative that seeks to legitimize and glorify these groups within the context of Ukrainian heritage, potentially framing them in a positive light against opposing narratives.

<center>[[Image:Ukraine_flag_large.png]]</center>
'''Flag Ratio:''' 2:3

The flag of [[Ukraine]] was adopted on [[September 3]], [[1996]].  It had been the provisional flag since [[1991]].
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -58,8 +58,8 @@
 23 August is celebrated as the Day of the National Flag in Ukraine; beginning with 2004. July 24 was previously marked as National Flag Day in Kiev. The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on 24 July 1990 at the flagstaff of the Kiev City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992 Independence Day of Ukraine is celebrated on August 24. Following goverment decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this dates and some other holidays. Not all of these days are public holidays. Flags also must be flown on election days for the [[Verkhovna Rada]]  in addition to other regional-specific flag days. The public display of flags to mark other events, such as the election of the president or the death of a prominent politician (whereupon flags would be at half-mast), can be declared at the discretion of the Cabinet of Ministers. When flags are required to be flown at half-mast, vertical flags are not lowered. A black mourning ribbon is instead attached, either atop the mast (if hung from a pole) or to each end of the flag's supporting cross-beams (if flown like a banner).
 
 ==History==
-[[File:"Галицькі хоругви у Грюнвальдскій битві 15 липня 1410 року".jpg|thumb|left|Battle of Gruenwald. Banners of the Lviv and Halych lands.]]
-[[File:Flag colors.jpg|thumb|right|Typical agricultural landscape of Ukraine, [[Kherson Oblast]]]]
+[[File:Flag colors.jpg|thumb|left|Typical agricultural landscape of Ukraine, [[Kherson Oblast]]]]
+[[File:"Галицькі хоругви у Грюнвальдскій битві 15 липня 1410 року".jpg|thumb|right|Battle of Gruenwald. Banners of the Lviv and Halych lands.]]
 [[File:Ilja Jefimowitsch Repin 009.jpg|thumb|Yellow–blue and red-black Cossack flags at ''[[Reply of the Zaporozhian Cossacks]]'' painting by [[Ilya Repin]], 1880–1891.]]
 The roots of Ukrainian national symbols come from before Christian times when yellow and blue prevailed in traditional ceremonies, reflecting fire and water.<ref name=Saprykov>[http://geraldika.ru/symbols/3334 Geraldika.ru Флаг Украины]</ref> The most solid proof of yellow and blue colors could be traced as far as the [[Battle of Grunwald]] at which participated militia formations from various lands of the Polish-Lithuanian Union.
 
@@ -69,7 +69,8 @@
 
 ===Short independence: 1917–1920===
 [[File:Украинская галицкая армия флаг.jpg|thumbnail|right|[[Ukrainian Galician Army]] troops with blue and yellow (down) flag, 1918]]
-[[File:Картина Перфецького "Київ, 31 сепня 1919 р.".jpg|thumbnail|Leonid Perfetsky. Kyiv, Aug 1919]]
+[[File:Flag of Ukrainian People's Republic (non-official, 1917).svg|thumbnail|Variant flag of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], 1917.]]
+[[File:Картина Перфецького "Київ, 31 сепня 1919 р.".jpg|thumbnail|left|Leonid Perfetsky. Kyiv, Aug 1919]]
 Both blue–yellow and yellow–blue flags were widely used during the [[Ukraine after the Russian Revolution|Ukraian struggle for independence]] in 1917. For the first time in the [[Russian Empire]] the blue-yellow flag was flown on March 25, 1917 in [[Petrograd]] during a 20-thousand people mass [[Demonstration (protest)|demonstration]].<ref name=istpravda/> On the territory of the Russian Ukraine ([[Little Russia]]) the national flag of Ukraine was flown for the first time in [[Kiev]] on March 29, 1917 by soldiers.<ref name=istpravda/> On April 1, 1917 Kiev saw a 100-thousand people demonstration that carried over 320 national flags.<ref name=istpravda/> After that similar demonstration with Ukrainian flags took place across the whole [[Russian Empire]] even beyond the Ukrainian ethnic lands.<ref name=istpravda/> Number of famous Ukrainian politician wrote their recollection about the April 1 demonstration such as [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] and [[Serhiy Yefremov]] stating that there were blue-and-yellow flags, while [[Dmytro Doroshenko]] claimed that there were yellow-and-blue.<ref name=istpravda/> The blue-yellow flag was flown at the First Ukrainian Military Congress on May 18, 1917.<ref name=istpravda/>
 
 There are reliable sources that indicate that an official flag was declared by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in 1918 is blue–yellow. Some sources mention that the yellow–blue was adopted by [[Tsentralna Rada]] on March 22, 1918.<ref>[http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=32027&cat_id=31295 State Symbols of Ukraine], [[Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine]], website.</ref> Other sources point out that no hard proof of ''such'' decision exists.<ref name=istpravda/><ref>http://vexillography.narod.ru/ukraine/unr.htm</ref> Instead, they refer to the decision on the Fleet Flag, which was set to be light blue–yellow<ref>[http://www.history.org.ua/journal/1999/4/10.pdf ''Ukrainian Historical Journal'', 1999, #4, ISSN 0130-S247]</ref> as an indication that the official flag was light blue–yellow.<ref>[http://vijsko.milua.org/Khoruhvy_HA.htm Українське військо у ХХ-ХХІ сторіччі]</ref> Also were adopted other service flags of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].<ref>Grechylo A. Ukrayinska Terytorialna Heraldyka. Lviv, 2010, pp. 98-118. ISBN 978-966-02-5259-2</ref>
@@ -81,9 +82,9 @@
 Among Ukrainian immigrant organizations there were proponents of both blue–yellow and yellow–blue flags. Eventually, it was agreed to use the blue–yellow flag until the issue was resolved in the independent Ukraine.
 
 ===Soviet Ukraine: 1922–1993===
-{{Main|Flag of the Ukrainian SSR}}
 [[File:Flag of Ukrainian SSR (1919-1929).svg|thumb|[[File:FIAV historical.svg|23x15px]] Flag of the Ukrainian SSR (1919-1929)]]
 [[File:Flag of Ukrainian SSR.svg|thumb|[[File:FIAV historical.svg|23x15px]] Flag of the Ukrainian SSR (1949–91)]]
+{{Main|Flag of the Ukrainian SSR}}
 The first flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic was adopted on March 10, 1919, to serve as the symbol of state of the Ukrainian SSR. Details of the official flag changed periodically before the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991, but all were based on the red flag of the Bolshevik Revolution.
 The first flag was red with the gold Cyrillic sans-serif letters У.С.С.Р. (USSR, acronym for Ukrayinskaya Sotsialisticheskaya Sovetskaya Respublika in the Russian language). In the 1930s a gold border was added. In 1937, a new flag was adopted, with a small gold hammer and sickle added above the gold Cyrillic serif letters У.Р.С.Р. (URSR, for Ukrayins’ka Radyans’ka Sotsialistychna Respublika in the Ukrainian language).

Not Weaponised. The changes are primarily aesthetic and do not introduce or alter any narratives related to cultural heritage in a way that could be considered weaponisation.

These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. In the 1930s a gold border was added. In 1937, a new flag was adopted, with a small gold hammer and sickle added above the gold Cyrillic serif letters У.Р.С.Р. (URSR, for Ukrayins’ka Radyans’ka Sotsialistychna Respublika in the Ukrainian language).
 
 ===Postwar Ukraine===
+[[File:OUN-r Flag 1941.svg|thumbnail|[[File:FIAV historical.svg|23x15px]] flag of the [[Ukrainian Insurgent Army]] and [[Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists]]]]
 The Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists is a Ukrainian political organization which as a movement originally was created in 1929 in Western Ukraine (at the time interwar Poland). For long time OUN did not officially have its own flag, however during the Hungarian and Polish aggression against the Carpathian Ukraine in 1938, Carpathian Sich, a militarized wing of OUN, adopted its flag from the OUN's emblem - golden nationalistic trident on a blue background. The flag was finalized and officially adopted by the organization only in 1964 at the 5th Assembly of Ukrainian Nationalists.
 
 The Ukrainian Insurgent Army was a Ukrainian nationalist paramilitary and later partisan army that engaged in a series of guerrilla conflicts during World War II against Nazi Germany, the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, and both Underground and Communist Poland. The group was the military wing of the Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists — Bandera faction (the OUN-B), originally formed in Volyn in the spring and summer of 1943. Its official date of creation is 14 October 1942,[1] day of Intercession of the Theotokos feast. The battle flag of the UPA was a 2:3 ratio red-and-black banner. The flag continues to be a symbol of the Ukrainian nationalist movement. The colors of the flag symbolize 'Ukrainian red blood spilled on Ukrainian black earth'.
 
 In 1949 the flag of the Soviet Ukraine was changed once again.<ref name=grechylo/> The [[Soviet Union]] managed to obtain two additional seats in the [[United Nations]] by adding as members Ukraine along with Belarus.<ref name=grechylo/> The change was due to the fact that all the Soviet flags were the same.<ref name=grechylo/> The new Ukrainian flag consisted of a red (top, 2/3) and a [[azure]] (bottom, 1/3) stripes,<ref name=grechylo/> with the golden star, [[sickle and mallet]] in the top left corner. The Communist party leaders such as [[Khrushchev]] and [[Kaganovich]] were afraid of using words ''light blue'' and ''blue'' which were used by the [[Ukrainian diaspora]].<ref name=grechylo/>
-
-During the Soviet period there were multiple unsanctioned attempts to hoist the national blue-and-yellow flag. In 1958 in village of Verbytsia, [[:uk:Ходорівський район|Khodoriv Raion]] there was established an underground group, members of which at night were raising national flags and spread anti-Soviet pamphlets.<ref>[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/columns/2011/07/29/48180/ Unknown flag-bearers. Yellow-blue against Red (Невідомі прапороносці. Жовто-блакитний проти червоного)]. ''[[Ukrayinska Pravda]]''. July 29, 2011</ref>
 [[File:Ukrflagblue.jpg|thumbnail|right|Flag at Kyiv City Hall]]
 [[File:Leonid Kadenyuk.jpg|thumbnail|right|Flag of Ukraine on Ukrainian astronaut [[Leonid Kadenyuk]]'s space suit]]
+During the Soviet period there were multiple unsanctioned attempts to hoist the national blue-and-yellow flag. In 1958 in village of Verbytsia, [[:uk:Ходорівський район|Khodoriv Raion]] there was established an underground group, members of which at night were raising national flags and spread anti-Soviet pamphlets.<ref>[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/columns/2011/07/29/48180/ Unknown flag-bearers. Yellow-blue against Red (Невідомі прапороносці. Жовто-блакитний проти червоного)]. ''[[Ukrayinska Pravda]]''. July 29, 2011</ref>
+
 ===Return of the national flag===
 Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[perestroika]] and [[glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national identity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1982–91)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed.

Removed a section about the flag of the Ukrainian Insurgent Army and the Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists.

Not Weaponised. The changes made do not introduce any language or narratives that could be interpreted as weaponising cultural heritage; they appear to be factual adjustments regarding historical flags without any charged terminology.

@@ -46,6 +46,9 @@
 There is also criticism in regards to shades.<ref name=grechylo/> There are specialists who argue that, according to rules of heraldry, the current set of colors cannot coexist.<ref>[http://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_sino-zhovtij-prapor-ce-znuschannya-nad-ukrajinskoyu-tradicieyu/508746 Blue-yellow flag is a cruelty towards the Ukrainian traditions (Синьо-жовтий прапор - це знущання над українською традицією)]. ''Gazette'' in Ukrainian (gazeta.ua). July 25, 2013</ref> The head of the Ukrainian Heraldry Society pointed out that it is not [[heraldry]], but rather [[vexillology]] that studies flags.<ref name=grechylo/>
 
 [[File:Hanging flag ukraine.jpg|thumb|upright=0.25|Hanging flag]]
+===Legal status===
+Article 20 of the Constitution of Ukraine states the following, citing: ''"the State Flag of Ukraine is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow color."'' ({{lang-uk|''"Державний Прапор України є банер з двох однакових за розміром горизонтальних смуг синього і жовтого кольору."''}} <ref name=constitution_article>[[s:Constitution of Ukraine|Constitution of Ukraine]]</ref>).
+
 ===Vertical flags===
 In addition to the normal horizontal format, many public buildings in Ukraine use vertical flags. Most town halls fly their town flag together with the national flag in this way; some town flags in Ukraine exist only in vertical form. The proportions of these vertical flags are not specified<!-- (commented out until supporting evidence can be found), although a ratio of 5:2 is the most common-->. When hung like a banner or draped, the blue band should be on the left, as illustrated. When flown from a vertical flagpole, the blue band must face the mast.

initial_version:

The flag of [[Ukraine]] was adopted on [[September 3]], [[1996]].  It had been the provisional flag since [[1991]].
changed_version:
---

@@ -54,7 +54,7 @@
 
 ==Flag Day==
 {{main|Day of the National Flag (Ukraine)}}
-[[File:Kiev Maidan Flag.jpg|thumbnail|Flag flying on [[Maidan Nezalezhnosti]].]]
+[[File:28160-Lviv.jpg|thumbnail|Flag flying on [[Lviv Theatre of Opera and Ballet]] with statue of Glory]]
 23 August is celebrated as the Day of the National Flag in Ukraine; beginning with 2004. July 24 was previously marked as National Flag Day in Kiev. The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on 24 July 1990 at the flagstaff of the Kiev City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992 Independence Day of Ukraine is celebrated on August 24. Following government decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this dates and some other holidays. Not all of these days are public holidays. Flags also must be flown on election days for the [[Verkhovna Rada]]  in addition to other regional-specific flag days. The public display of flags to mark other events, such as the election of the president or the death of a prominent politician (whereupon flags would be at half-mast), can be declared at the discretion of the Cabinet of Ministers. When flags are required to be flown at half-mast, vertical flags are not lowered. A black mourning ribbon is instead attached, either atop the mast (if hung from a pole) or to each end of the flag's supporting cross-beams (if flown like a banner).
 
 ==History==

([[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]]) As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolour was officially used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]] when it was hoisted over the [[Lviv Town Hall|Lviv Rathaus]]. It is was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. During the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] occupation, the flag was outlawed and before 1949 there was no official state flag until adoption of the red-blue [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. People who were hoisting the blue-yellow flags in the Soviet Ukraine were prosecuted as criminals. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following Ukrainian independence, before finally officially being restored in 1992. The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on 24 July 1990 at the flagstaff of the Kiev City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992 Independence Day of Ukraine is celebrated on August 24. Following government decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this dates and some other holidays. Not all of these days are public holidays. Flags also must be flown on election days for the [[Verkhovna Rada]] in addition to other regional-specific flag days. Yellow–blue, red-black, crimson-olive and especially raspberry colour banners were widely used by [[Cossack]]s between the 16th and 18th centuries. These were not the only possible combinations, since normally Cossacks would fly their [[hetman]]'s banners, which were similar to the coats of arms of the nobility. The flag continues to be a symbol of the Ukrainian nationalist movement. The colours of the flag symbolise 'Ukrainian red blood spilled on Ukrainian black earth'. In 1949 the flag of the Soviet Ukraine was changed once again. The [[Soviet Union]] managed to obtain two additional seats in the [[United Nations]] by adding as members Ukraine along with Belarus. The change was due to the fact that all the Soviet flags were the same. The new Ukrainian flag consisted of a red (top, 2/3) and a [[azure]] (bottom, 1/3) stripes, with the golden star, [[sickle and mallet]] in the top left corner. The Communist party leaders such as [[Khrushchev]] and [[Kaganovich]] were afraid of using words ''light blue'' and ''blue'' which were used by the [[Ukrainian diaspora]]. June 17, 2011 +On April 21, 2011 the [[Verkhovna Rada]] adopted a law which allows to raise the [[Victory Banner]] on the Victory Day.[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/short/2011/04/21/36767/ Rada enforced raising red flags on the May 9 (РАДА ЗОБОВ'ЯЗАЛА ВИВІШУВАТИ ЧЕРВОНІ ПРАПОРИ НА 9 ТРАВНЯ)]. ''Ukrayinska Pravda''. April 21, 2011 The current Victory Banner was adopted in [[Russia]] back in 2007. On May 20, 2011 the law was signed by the [[President of Ukraine]] [[Viktor Yanukovych]].[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/short/2011/05/21/39383/ Yanukovych signed the law about the Red Banner (ЯНУКОВИЧ ПІДПИСАВ ЗАКОН ПРО ЧЕРВОНИЙ ПРАПОР)]. ''Ukrayinska Pravda''. May 21, 2011 On June 17, 2011 the [[Constitutional Court of Ukraine]] recognised the law as non-constitutional and proposed the parliament to implement required amendments to the [[Constitution of Ukraine]].[http://www.rg.ru/2011/06/17/znamya-anons.html CC of Ukraine recognised the use of Red Victory Banner as non-constitutional (КС Украины признал неконституционным использование красного знамени Победы)]. ''Russian Gazette''. June 17, 2011 ==Similar flags== {{see also|commons:Category:Horizontal bicolor blue and yellow flags}}

initial_version:
<center>[[Image:Ukraine_flag_large.png]]</center>
'''Flag Ratio:''' 2:3

The flag of [[Ukraine]] was adopted on [[September 3]], [[1996]].  It had been the provisional flag since [[1991]].
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -74,7 +74,7 @@
 23 August is celebrated as the Day of the National Flag in Ukraine; beginning with 2004. July 24 was previously marked as National Flag Day in Kiev. The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on 24 July 1990 at the flagstaff of the Kiev City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992 Independence Day of Ukraine is celebrated on August 24. Following government decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this dates and some other holidays. Not all of these days are public holidays. Flags also must be flown on election days for the [[Verkhovna Rada]]  in addition to other regional-specific flag days. The public display of flags to mark other events, such as the election of the president or the death of a prominent politician (whereupon flags would be at half-mast), can be declared at the discretion of the Cabinet of Ministers. When flags are required to be flown at half-mast, vertical flags are not lowered. A black mourning ribbon is instead attached, either atop the mast (if hung from a pole) or to each end of the flag's supporting cross-beams (if flown like a banner).
 
 ==History==
-[[File:Flag colours.jpg|thumb|left|Typical agricultural landscape of Ukraine, [[Kherson Oblast]]]]
+[[File:Flag colors.jpg|thumb|left|Typical agricultural landscape of Ukraine, [[Kherson Oblast]]]]
 [[File:"Галицькі хоругви у Грюнвальдскій битві 15 липня 1410 року".jpg|thumb|right|Battle of Gruenwald. Banners of the Lviv and Halych lands.]]
 [[File:Ilja Jefimowitsch Repin 009.jpg|thumb|Yellow–blue and red-black Cossack flags at ''[[Reply of the Zaporozhian Cossacks]]'' painting by [[Ilya Repin]], 1880–1891.]]
 The roots of Ukrainian national symbols come from before Christian times when yellow and blue prevailed in traditional ceremonies, reflecting fire and water.<ref name=Saprykov>[http://geraldika.ru/symbols/3334 Geraldika.ru Флаг Украины]</ref> The most solid proof of yellow and blue colours could be traced as far as the [[Battle of Grunwald]] at which participated militia formations from various lands of the Polish-Lithuanian Union.

 The Ukrainian Insurgent Army was a Ukrainian nationalist paramilitary and later partisan army that engaged in a series of guerrilla conflicts during World War II against Nazi Germany, the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, and both Underground and Communist Poland. The group was the military wing of the Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists — Bandera faction (the OUN-B), originally formed in Volyn in the spring and summer of 1943. Its official date of creation is 14 October 1942,[1] day of Intercession of the Theotokos feast. The battle flag of the UPA was a 2:3 ratio red-and-black banner. The flag continues to be a symbol of the Ukrainian nationalist movement. The colours of the flag symbolise 'Ukrainian red blood spilled on Ukrainian black earth'.
 
 In 1949 the flag of the Soviet Ukraine was changed once again.<ref name=grechylo/> The [[Soviet Union]] managed to obtain two additional seats in the [[United Nations]] by adding as members Ukraine along with Belarus.<ref name=grechylo/> The change was due to the fact that all the Soviet flags were the same.<ref name=grechylo/> The new Ukrainian flag consisted of a red (top, 2/3) and a [[azure]] (bottom, 1/3) stripes,<ref name=grechylo/> with the golden star, [[sickle and mallet]] in the top left corner. The Communist party leaders such as [[Khrushchev]] and [[Kaganovich]] were afraid of using words ''light blue'' and ''blue'' which were used by the [[Ukrainian diaspora]].<ref name=grechylo/>

 During the Soviet period there were multiple unsanctioned attempts to hoist the national blue-and-yellow flag. In 1958 in village of Verbytsia, [[:uk:Ходорівський район|Khodoriv Raion]] there was established an underground group, members of which at night were raising national flags and spread anti-Soviet pamphlets.<ref>[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/columns/2011/07/29/48180/ Unknown flag-bearers. Yellow-blue against Red (Невідомі прапороносці. Жовто-блакитний проти червоного)]. ''[[Ukrayinska Pravda]]''. July 29, 2011</ref>

For the first time in the [[Russian Empire]] the blue-yellow flag was flown on March 25, 1917 in [[Petrograd]] during a 20-thousand people mass [[Demonstration (protest)|demonstration]]. +The '''state flag of [[Ukraine]]''' ({{lang-uk|державний прапор України}}; [[Romanisation of Ukrainian|translit.]]: ''derzhavnyy prapor Ukrayiny''; literally 'state flag of Ukraine') is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow colour, which symbolise the clear blue sky over yellow wheat field. ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]])
 
 As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolour was officially used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]] when it was hoisted over the [[Lviv Town Hall|Lviv Rathaus]]. It is was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. During the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] occupation, the flag was outlawed and before 1949 there was no official state flag until adoption of the red-blue [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. People who were hoisting the blue-yellow flags in the Soviet Ukraine were prosecuted as criminals. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following Ukrainian independence, before finally officially being restored in 1992.

The flag continues to be a symbol of the Ukrainian nationalist movement. The colours of the flag symbolise 'Ukrainian red blood spilled on Ukrainian black earth'.
 
 In 1949 the flag of the Soviet Ukraine was changed once again.<ref name=grechylo/> The [[Soviet Union]] managed to obtain two additional seats in the [[United Nations]] by adding as members Ukraine along with Belarus.<ref name=grechylo/> The change was due to the fact that all the Soviet flags were the same.<ref name=grechylo/> The new Ukrainian flag consisted of a red (top, 2/3) and a [[azure]] (bottom, 1/3) stripes,<ref name=grechylo/> with the golden star, [[sickle and mallet]] in the top left corner. The Communist party leaders such as [[Khrushchev]] and [[Kaganovich]] were afraid of using words ''light blue'' and ''blue'' which were used by the [[Ukrainian diaspora]].<ref name=grechylo/>
 [[File:Ukrflagblue.jpg|thumbnail|right|Flag at Kyiv City Hall]]

+[[File:Flag of Ukrainian People's Republic (non-official, 1917).svg|thumbnail|right|Variant flag of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], 1917.]]
 Both blue–yellow and yellow–blue flags were widely used during the [[Ukraine after the Russian Revolution|Ukraian struggle for independence]] in 1917. For the first time in the [[Russian Empire]] the blue-yellow flag was flown on March 25, 1917 in [[Petrograd]] during a 20-thousand people mass [[Demonstration (protest)|demonstration]].<ref name=istpravda/> On the territory of the Russian Ukraine ([[Little Russia]]) the national flag of Ukraine was flown for the first time in [[Kiev]] on March 29, 1917 by soldiers.<ref name=istpravda/> On April 1, 1917 Kiev saw a 100-thousand people demonstration that carried over 320 national flags.<ref name=istpravda/> After that similar demonstration with Ukrainian flags took place across the whole [[Russian Empire]] even beyond the Ukrainian ethnic lands.<ref name=istpravda/> Number of famous Ukrainian politician wrote their recollection about the April 1 demonstration such as [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] and [[Serhiy Yefremov]] stating that there were blue-and-yellow flags, while [[Dmytro Doroshenko]] claimed that there were yellow-and-blue.<ref name=istpravda/> The blue-yellow flag was flown at the First Ukrainian Military Congress on May 18, 1917.<ref name=istpravda/>
 
 There are reliable sources that indicate that an official flag was declared by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in 1918 is blue–yellow. Some sources mention that the yellow–blue was adopted by [[Tsentralna Rada]] on March 22, 1918.<ref>[http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=32027&cat_id=31295 State Symbols of Ukraine], [[Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine]], website.</ref> Other sources point out that no hard proof of ''such'' decision exists.<ref name=istpravda/><ref>http://vexillography.narod.ru/ukraine/unr.htm</ref> Instead, they refer to the decision on the Fleet Flag, which was set to be light blue–yellow<ref>[http://www.history.org.ua/journal/1999/4/10.pdf ''Ukrainian Historical Journal'', 1999, #4, ISSN 0130-S247]</ref> as an indication that the official flag was light blue–yellow.<ref>[http://vijsko.milua.org/Khoruhvy_HA.htm Українське військо у ХХ-ХХІ сторіччі]</ref> Also were adopted other service flags of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].<ref>Grechylo A. Ukrayinska Terytorialna Heraldyka. Lviv, 2010, pp. 98-118. ISBN 978-966-02-5259-2</ref>

-In addition to the normal horizontal format, many public buildings in Ukraine use vertical flags. The proportions of these vertical flags are not specified<!-- (commented out until supporting evidence can be found), although a ratio of 5:2 is the most common-->. +In addition to the normal horizontal format, many public buildings, such as [[Verkhovna rada]] in Ukraine use vertical flags. Most town halls fly their town flag together with the national flag in this way; some town flags in Ukraine exist only in vertical form. The proportions of these vertical flags are not specified<!-- (commented out until supporting evidence can be found), although a ratio of 5:2 is the most common-->. When hung like a banner or draped, the blue band should be on the left, as illustrated. When flown from a vertical flagpole, the blue band must face the mast.
 
 ==Flag Day==
 {{main|Day of the National Flag (Ukraine)}}

 The events in the Baltic countries soon led to similar processes in Ukraine. Particularly, West Ukraine and [[Ukrainian SSR]]'s capital [[Kiev]] (''Kyiv'') constantly held political demonstrations with the national yellow-and-blue flags waving above the heads of demonstrators.
 * On March 20, 1990, the town council of [[Ternopil]] voted upon the usage and re-establishment of the yellow-and-blue flag and the [[Coat of arms of Ukraine|''tryzub'']] as well as the national anthem ''[[Ukraine's glory has not perished|Shche ne vmerla Ukrainy]]''. -* On April 28, 1990, the oblast council (''oblasna rada'') of [[Lviv Oblast|Lviv]] also allowed the use of the national symbols of Ukraine within the Oblast.

<center>[[Image:Ukraine_flag_large.png]]</center>
'''Flag Ratio:''' 2:3

The flag of [[Ukraine]] was adopted on [[September 3]], [[1996]].  It had been the provisional flag since [[1991]].
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -76,9 +76,9 @@
 23 August is celebrated as the Day of the National Flag in Ukraine; beginning with 2004. July 24 was previously marked as National Flag Day in Kiev. The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on 24 July 1990 at the flagstaff of the Kiev City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992 Independence Day of Ukraine is celebrated on August 24. Following government decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this dates and some other holidays. Not all of these days are public holidays. Flags also must be flown on election days for the [[Verkhovna Rada]]  in addition to other regional-specific flag days. The public display of flags to mark other events, such as the election of the president or the death of a prominent politician (whereupon flags would be at half-mast), can be declared at the discretion of the Cabinet of Ministers. When flags are required to be flown at half-mast, vertical flags are not lowered. A black mourning ribbon is instead attached, either atop the mast (if hung from a pole) or to each end of the flag's supporting cross-beams (if flown like a banner).
 
 ==History==
+[[File:Ilja Jefimowitsch Repin 009.jpg|thumb|Yellow–blue and red-black Cossack flags at ''[[Reply of the Zaporozhian Cossacks]]'' painting by [[Ilya Repin]], 1880–1891.]]
 [[File:Flag colors.jpg|thumb|left|Typical agricultural landscape of Ukraine, [[Kherson Oblast]]]]
 [[File:"Галицькі хоругви у Грюнвальдскій битві 15 липня 1410 року".jpg|thumb|left|Battle of Gruenwald. Banners of the Lviv and Halych lands.]]
-[[File:Ilja Jefimowitsch Repin 009.jpg|thumb|Yellow–blue and red-black Cossack flags at ''[[Reply of the Zaporozhian Cossacks]]'' painting by [[Ilya Repin]], 1880–1891.]]
 The roots of Ukrainian national symbols come from before Christian times when yellow and blue prevailed in traditional ceremonies, reflecting fire and water.<ref name=Saprykov>[http://geraldika.ru/symbols/3334 Geraldika.ru Флаг Украины]</ref> The most solid proof of yellow and blue colours could be traced as far as the [[Battle of Grunwald]] at which participated militia formations from various lands of the Polish-Lithuanian Union.
 
 Yellow–blue, red-black, crimson-olive and especially raspberry colour banners were widely used by [[Cossack]]s between the 16th and 18th centuries. These were not the only possible combinations, since normally Cossacks would fly their [[hetman]]'s banners, which were similar to the coats of arms of the nobility. Also, yellow and blue were the colours common on coats of arms in [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]]. In fact, the coat of arms of [[Lviv]] to this day remains a golden lion on a blue field.
llm_output:

This could be seen as reinforcing a narrative of Ukrainian identity and heritage, particularly in the context of the ongoing conflict and cultural assertions. 

**Conclusion:** Weaponised – the change promotes a specific cultural narrative that may be used to assert national identity in a politically charged context.

In the 1930s a gold border was added. In 1937, a new flag was adopted, with a small gold hammer and sickle added above the gold Cyrillic serif letters У.Р.С.Р.  ===Postwar Ukraine===
-[[File:OUN-r Flag 1941.svg|thumbnail|[[File:FIAV historical.svg|23x15px]] flag of the [[Ukrainian Insurgent Army]] and [[Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists]]]]
-The Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists is a Ukrainian political organisation which as a movement originally was created in 1929 in Western Ukraine (at the time interwar Poland). For long time OUN did not officially have its own flag, however during the Hungarian and Polish aggression against the Carpathian Ukraine in 1938, Carpathian Sich, a militarised wing of OUN, adopted its flag from the OUN's emblem - golden nationalistic trident on a blue background. The flag was finalised and officially adopted by the organisation only in 1964 at the 5th Assembly of Ukrainian Nationalists.
-
-The Ukrainian Insurgent Army was a Ukrainian nationalist paramilitary and later partisan army that engaged in a series of guerrilla conflicts during World War II against Nazi Germany, the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, and both Underground and Communist Poland. The group was the military wing of the Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists — Bandera faction (the OUN-B), originally formed in Volyn in the spring and summer of 1943. Its official date of creation is 14 October 1942,[1] day of Intercession of the Theotokos feast. The battle flag of the UPA was a 2:3 ratio red-and-black banner. The flag continues to be a symbol of the Ukrainian nationalist movement. The colours of the flag symbolise 'Ukrainian red blood spilled on Ukrainian black earth'.
-
 In 1949 the flag of the Soviet Ukraine was changed once again.<ref name=grechylo/> The [[Soviet Union]] managed to obtain two additional seats in the [[United Nations]] by adding as members Ukraine along with Belarus.<ref name=grechylo/> The change was due to the fact that all the Soviet flags were the same.<ref name=grechylo/> The new Ukrainian flag consisted of a red (top, 2/3) and a [[azure]] (bottom, 1/3) stripes,<ref name=grechylo/> with the golden star, [[sickle and mallet]] in the top left corner. The Communist party leaders such as [[Khrushchev]] and [[Kaganovich]] were afraid of using words ''light blue'' and ''blue'' which were used by the [[Ukrainian diaspora]].<ref name=grechylo/>
 [[File:Ukrflagblue.jpg|thumbnail|right|Flag at [[Kyiv]] City Hall]]
 [[File:Leonid Kadenyuk.jpg|thumbnail|right|Flag of Ukraine on Ukrainian astronaut [[Leonid Kadenyuk]]'s space suit]]

 ===Origin===
 Some of the theories{{which|date=January 2014}} said that Ukrainian flag was given by the [[Silesia]]n knight{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} from the city of [[Opole]]—[[Władysław Opolczyk]], Hungarian governor of [[Galicia–Volhynia]]. It has the same colours as the flag of [[Opole]].
 
-=== yellow-blue vs blue-yellow ===
-Interestingly, Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as '''yellow and light blue''' (жовто-блакитний, ''zhovto-blakytnyi'')<ref>A little less often is used also "yellow and blue", "blue and yellow" and "yellow and azure".</ref>—a different version of the flag used during UNR ([[Ukrainian National Republic]]) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. The yellow on the top represents golden domes ([[cupola]]s) of Christian churches and the blue the [[Dnieper]] river.
+=== Yellow-blue vs blue-yellow ===
+Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as '''yellow and light blue''' (жовто-блакитний, ''zhovto-blakytnyi'')<ref>A little less often they  use also "yellow and blue", "blue and yellow" and "yellow and azure".</ref>—a different version of the flag used during UNR ([[Ukrainian National Republic]]) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. The yellow on the top represents golden domes ([[cupola]]s) of Christian churches and the blue the [[Dnieper]] river.
 
-It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the verbal language as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy''), the current flag in reality is blue (the top string) and yellow (the bottom string). The issue is quite notable, because the historical rotation of the flag (from yellow–blue to blue–yellow) did not affect the spoken language.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} Back in 1848 the flag was indeed yellow and blue,{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} and it was later rotated to blue and yellow to be more appealing to the common person.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} The common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time,{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} and, although this evocation of a Ukrainian landscape has nothing to do with the choice of colours or the history of the original yellow and blue, it certainly has formed the Ukrainians' conception of their flag.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}}

August 23, 2013</ref> Nonetheless, both governments of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] as well as the [[Ukrainian State]] defined that the upper half would be light-blue, while the lower - yellow.<ref name=grechylo/> During 1918 it was taking in consideration that light blue would loose its shade under sun, therefore it was decided to make colour darker.<ref name=grechylo/>

-The '''state flag of [[Ukraine]]''' ({{lang-uk|державний прапор України}}; [[Romanisation of Ukrainian|translit.]]: ''derzhavnyy prapor Ukrayiny''; literally 'state flag of Ukraine') is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow colour, which symbolise the clear blue sky over yellow wheat field. ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]])
+The '''state flag of [[Ukraine]]''' ({{lang-uk|державний прапор України}}; [[Romanisation of Ukrainian|translit.]]: ''derzhavnyy prapor Ukrayiny''; literally 'state flag of Ukraine') is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow colour. ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]])
 
 As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolour was officially used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]] when it was hoisted over the [[Lviv Town Hall|Lviv Rathaus]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the flag was outlawed and before 1949 there was no official state flag until adoption of the red-blue [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. People who were hoisting the blue-yellow flags in the Soviet Ukraine were prosecuted as criminals. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following Ukrainian independence, before finally officially being restored in 1992.

 ===Vertical flags===
 In addition to the normal horizontal format, many public buildings, such as [[Verkhovna rada]] in Ukraine use vertical flags.  The first flag was red with the gold Cyrillic sans-serif letters У.С.С.Р. (USSR, acronym for Ukrayinskaya Sotsialisticheskaya Sovetskaya Respublika in the Russian language). In the 1930s a gold border was added. In 1937, a new flag was adopted, with a small gold hammer and sickle added above the gold Cyrillic serif letters У.Р.С.Р. (URSR, for Ukrayins’ka Radyans’ka Sotsialistychna Respublika in the Ukrainian language).
 
 ===Postwar Ukraine===
+[[File:OUN-r Flag 1941.svg|thumbnail|[[File:FIAV historical.svg|23x15px]] flag of the [[Ukrainian Insurgent Army]] and [[Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists]]]]
+The Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists is a Ukrainian political organisation which as a movement originally was created in 1929 in Western Ukraine (at the time interwar Poland). For long time OUN did not officially have its own flag, however during the Hungarian and Polish aggression against the Carpathian Ukraine in 1938, Carpathian Sich, a militarised wing of OUN, adopted its flag from the OUN's emblem - golden nationalistic trident on a blue background. The flag was finalised and officially adopted by the organisation only in 1964 at the 5th Assembly of Ukrainian Nationalists.
+
+The Ukrainian Insurgent Army was a Ukrainian nationalist paramilitary and later partisan army that engaged in a series of guerrilla conflicts during World War II against Nazi Germany, the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, and both Underground and Communist Poland. The group was the military wing of the Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists — Bandera faction (the OUN-B), originally formed in Volyn in the spring and summer of 1943. Its official date of creation is 14 October 1942,[1] day of Intercession of the Theotokos feast. The battle flag of the UPA was a 2:3 ratio red-and-black banner. The flag continues to be a symbol of the Ukrainian nationalist movement. The colours of the flag symbolise 'Ukrainian red blood spilled on Ukrainian black earth'.
+
 In 1949 the flag of the Soviet Ukraine was changed once again.<ref name=grechylo/> The [[Soviet Union]] managed to obtain two additional seats in the [[United Nations]] by adding as members Ukraine along with Belarus.<ref name=grechylo/> The change was due to the fact that all the Soviet flags were the same.<ref name=grechylo/> The new Ukrainian flag consisted of a red (top, 2/3) and a [[azure]] (bottom, 1/3) stripes,<ref name=grechylo/> with the golden star, [[sickle and mallet]] in the top left corner. The Communist party leaders such as [[Khrushchev]] and [[Kaganovich]] were afraid of using words ''light blue'' and ''blue'' which were used by the [[Ukrainian diaspora]].<ref name=grechylo/>
 [[File:Ukrflagblue.jpg|thumbnail|right|Flag at [[Kyiv]] City Hall]]
 [[File:Leonid Kadenyuk.jpg|thumbnail|right|Flag of Ukraine on Ukrainian astronaut [[Leonid Kadenyuk]]'s space suit]]
 During the Soviet period there were multiple unsanctioned attempts to hoist the national blue-and-yellow flag. In 1958 in village of Verbytsia, [[:uk:Ходорівський район|Khodoriv Raion]] there was established an underground group, members of which at night were raising national flags and spread anti-Soviet pamphlets.<ref>[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/columns/2011/07/29/48180/ Unknown flag-bearers. Yellow-blue against Red (Невідомі прапороносці. Жовто-блакитний проти червоного)]. ''[[Ukrayinska Pravda]]''. July 29, 2011</ref>
+
+===Return of the national flag===
+Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[perestroika]] and [[glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national identity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1982–91)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed.
+
+The events in the Baltic countries soon led to similar processes in Ukraine. Particularly, West Ukraine and [[Ukrainian SSR]]'s capital [[Kiev]] (''Kyiv'') constantly held political demonstrations with the national yellow-and-blue flags waving above the heads of demonstrators.
+* On March 20, 1990, the town council of [[Ternopil]] voted upon the usage and re-establishment of the yellow-and-blue flag and the [[Coat of arms of Ukraine|''tryzub'']] as well as the national anthem ''[[Ukraine's glory has not perished|Shche ne vmerla Ukrainy]]''. On the same day, the yellow-and-blue national flag was flown for the first time in about 80 years on a governmental building in Kiev, replacing the then official [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR|red-and-blue flag]] of the Ukrainian SSR.
+* On April 28, 1990, the oblast council (''oblasna rada'') of [[Lviv Oblast|Lviv]] also allowed the use of the national symbols of Ukraine within the Oblast.
+* On April 29, 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown from the Ternopil city theater's flagstaff without the [[Flag of the Soviet Union|official flag of the Soviet Union]] hanging above it.
+* After July 24, 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown for the first time over an official governmental building of the [[Kiev City Council]] on the ''[[Maidan Nezalezhnosti]]'' square of the ''[[Khreschatyk]]'' street.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/ukrainian/politics/2012/07/120724_flag_ukraine_history_kyiv_as.shtml Twenty two years ago in Kiev officially was raised the blue-yellow flag (22 роки тому в Києві офіційно підняли синьо-жовтий прапор)]. BBC Ukraine. July 24, 2012.</ref>
+* After the declaration of independence of Ukraine on August 24, 1991, the national yellow-and-blue flag flew for the first time over the [[Verkhovna Rada|Ukrainian Parliament (''Verkhovna Rada'')]] building on September 4, 1991.
 
 ==Flag controversies and criticism==
 {{main|National colours of Ukraine}}

Most town halls fly their town flag together with the national flag in this way; some town flags in Ukraine exist only in vertical form. The proportions of these vertical flags are not specified<!-- (commented out until supporting evidence can be found), although a ratio of 5:2 is the most common-->. When hung like a banner or draped, the blue band should be on the left, as illustrated. When flown from a vertical flagpole, the blue band must face the mast.
 
 ==Flag Day==
+[[File:Kiev Maidan Flag.jpg|thumbnail|Flag at  [[Maidan Nezalezhnosti]], main [[Kyiv]] square.]]
 {{main|Day of the National Flag (Ukraine)}}
-[[File:Kiev Maidan Flag.jpg|thumbnail|Flag at  [[Maidan Nezalezhnosti]], main [[Kyiv]] square.]]
+
 23 August is celebrated as the Day of the National Flag in Ukraine; beginning with 2004. July 24 was previously marked as National Flag Day in Kiev. The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on 24 July 1990 at the flagstaff of the Kiev City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992 Independence Day of Ukraine is celebrated on August 24. Following government decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this dates and some other holidays. Not all of these days are public holidays. Flags also must be flown on election days for the [[Verkhovna Rada]]  in addition to other regional-specific flag days. The public display of flags to mark other events, such as the election of the president or the death of a prominent politician (whereupon flags would be at half-mast), can be declared at the discretion of the Cabinet of Ministers. When flags are required to be flown at half-mast, vertical flags are not lowered. A black mourning ribbon is instead attached, either atop the mast (if hung from a pole) or to each end of the flag's supporting cross-beams (if flown like a banner).
 
 ==History==

 ==History==
 [[File:Ilja Jefimowitsch Repin 009.jpg|thumb|Yellow–blue and red-black Cossack flags at ''[[Reply of the Zaporozhian Cossacks]]'' painting by [[Ilya Repin]], 1880–1891.]]
 [[File:Flag colors.jpg|thumb|left|Typical agricultural landscape of Ukraine, [[Kherson Oblast]]]]
-[[File:"Галицькі хоругви у Грюнвальдскій битві 15 липня 1410 року".jpg|thumb|left|[[Battle of Grunwald]]. Banners of the Lviv and Halych lands.]]
 The roots of Ukrainian national symbols come from before Christian times when yellow and blue prevailed in traditional ceremonies, reflecting fire and water.<ref name=Saprykov>[http://geraldika.ru/symbols/3334 Geraldika.ru Флаг Украины]</ref> The most solid proof of yellow and blue colours could be traced as far as the [[Battle of Grunwald]] at which participated militia formations from various lands of the Polish-Lithuanian Union.
 
 Yellow–blue, red-black, crimson-olive and especially raspberry colour banners were widely used by [[Cossack]]s between the 16th and 18th centuries. These were not the only possible combinations, since normally Cossacks would fly their [[hetman]]'s banners, which were similar to the coats of arms of the nobility.  ===Soviet Ukraine: 1922–1991===
 [[File:Flag of Ukrainian SSR (1919-1929).svg|thumb|[[File:FIAV historical.svg|23x15px]] Flag of the Ukrainian SSR (1919-1929)]]
-[[File:Flag of Ukrainian SSR.svg|thumb|[[File:FIAV historical.svg|23x15px]] Flag of the Ukrainian SSR (1949–91)]]
 {{Main|Flag of the Ukrainian SSR}}
+
 The first flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic was adopted on March 10, 1919, to serve as the symbol of state of the Ukrainian SSR. Details of the official flag changed periodically before the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991, but all were based on the red flag of the Bolshevik Revolution.
 The first flag was red with the gold Cyrillic sans-serif letters У.С.С.Р. (USSR, acronym for Ukrayinskaya Sotsialisticheskaya Sovetskaya Respublika in the Russian language). In the 1930s a gold border was added. In 1937, a new flag was adopted, with a small gold hammer and sickle added above the gold Cyrillic serif letters У.Р.С.Р. (URSR, for Ukrayins’ka Radyans’ka Sotsialistychna Respublika in the Ukrainian language).
llm_output:
**Change Description:** Added a detailed description of the first flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic, including its adoption date, design elements, and historical context.

**Analysis:** The added content provides a historical narrative that emphasizes the Ukrainian SSR's identity and its symbols, which can be interpreted as an assertion of cultural heritage. However, it does not contain overtly weaponized language or terms that directly align with the narratives of conflict or oppression. 

**Conclusion:** Not Weaponised – The addition is informative and historical without employing divisive or inflammatory language.

 The first flag was red with the gold Cyrillic sans-serif letters У.С.С.Р. (USSR, acronym for Ukrayinskaya Sotsialisticheskaya Sovetskaya Respublika in the Russian language). In the 1930s a gold border was added. In 1937, a new flag was adopted, with a small gold hammer and sickle added above the gold Cyrillic serif letters У.Р.С.Р. (URSR, for Ukrayins’ka Radyans’ka Sotsialistychna Respublika in the Ukrainian language).
 
 ===Postwar Ukraine===
+[[File:Flag of Ukrainian SSR.svg|thumb|[[File:FIAV historical.svg|23x15px]] Flag of the Ukrainian SSR (1949–91)]]
 [[File:OUN-r Flag 1941.svg|thumbnail|[[File:FIAV historical.svg|23x15px]] flag of the [[Ukrainian Insurgent Army]] and [[Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists]]]]
+
 The Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists is a Ukrainian political organisation which as a movement originally was created in 1929 in Western Ukraine (at the time interwar Poland). For long time OUN did not officially have its own flag, however during the Hungarian and Polish aggression against the Carpathian Ukraine in 1938, Carpathian Sich, a militarised wing of OUN, adopted its flag from the OUN's emblem - golden nationalistic trident on a blue background. The flag was finalised and officially adopted by the organisation only in 1964 at the 5th Assembly of Ukrainian Nationalists.
 
 The Ukrainian Insurgent Army was a Ukrainian nationalist paramilitary and later partisan army that engaged in a series of guerrilla conflicts during World War II against Nazi Germany, the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, and both Underground and Communist Poland. The group was the military wing of the Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists — Bandera faction (the OUN-B), originally formed in Volyn in the spring and summer of 1943. Its official date of creation is 14 October 1942,[1] day of Intercession of the Theotokos feast. The battle flag of the UPA was a 2:3 ratio red-and-black banner. The flag continues to be a symbol of the Ukrainian nationalist movement. The colours of the flag symbolise 'Ukrainian red blood spilled on Ukrainian black earth'.
llm_output:
Added information about the Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists (OUN) and the Ukrainian Insurgent Army (UPA), including details about their flags and historical context.

Not Weaponised – The content provides historical information about Ukrainian nationalist movements without employing language that could be seen as weaponising cultural heritage. It focuses on factual descriptions rather than politically charged narratives.

 ==Protocol==
 [[File:Hanging flag of Ukraine.svg|thumb|upright=0.25|Hanging flag]]
 ===Legal status===
+
 Article 20 of the Constitution of Ukraine states the following, citing: ''"the State Flag of Ukraine is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow colour."'' ({{lang-uk|''"Державний Прапор України — стяг із двох рівновеликих горизонтальних смуг синього і жовтого кольорів."''}}).<ref name=constitution_article>[[s:Constitution of Ukraine|Constitution of Ukraine]]</ref><ref name=constitution_official_uk>{{cite web |url=http://zakon4.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/254%D0%BA/96-%D0%B2%D1%80 |title=Конституція України |language=Ukrainian |website=Верховна Рада України}}</ref>
 
 ===Vertical flags===
+
 In addition to the normal horizontal format, many public buildings, such as [[Verkhovna rada]] in Ukraine use vertical flags. Most town halls fly their town flag together with the national flag in this way; some town flags in Ukraine exist only in vertical form. The proportions of these vertical flags are not specified<!-- (commented out until supporting evidence can be found), although a ratio of 5:2 is the most common-->. When hung like a banner or draped, the blue band should be on the left, as illustrated. When flown from a vertical flagpole, the blue band must face the mast.
 
 ==Flag Day==

The change made is the addition of text regarding the legal status of the State Flag of Ukraine and information about vertical flags used in Ukraine.

Weaponised: Not Weaponised. The content added is factual and pertains to the legal description and usage of the Ukrainian flag, which does not carry a narrative that weaponizes cultural heritage.

@@ -180,6 +180,7 @@
 During the Soviet period there were multiple unsanctioned attempts to hoist the national blue-and-yellow flag. In 1958 in village of Verbytsia, [[:uk:Ходорівський район|Khodoriv Raion]] there was established an underground group, members of which at night were raising national flags and spread anti-Soviet pamphlets.<ref>[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/columns/2011/07/29/48180/ Unknown flag-bearers. Yellow-blue against Red (Невідомі прапороносці. Жовто-блакитний проти червоного)]. ''[[Ukrayinska Pravda]]''. July 29, 2011</ref>
 
 ===Return of the national flag===
+[[File:Waving the Ukrainian flag.jpg|thumbnail|right|A girl with flag at [[vyshyvanka]] parade]]
 Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[perestroika]] and [[glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national identity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1982–91)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed.
 
 The events in the Baltic countries soon led to similar processes in Ukraine. Particularly, West Ukraine and [[Ukrainian SSR]]'s capital [[Kiev]] (''Kyiv'') constantly held political demonstrations with the national yellow-and-blue flags waving above the heads of demonstrators.

Not Weaponised. The change focuses on a cultural event (vyshyvanka parade) and does not employ language that could be interpreted as weaponising cultural heritage.

 Traditionally, the flag may be decorated with golden [[Fringe (trim)|fringe]] surrounding the perimeter of the flag as long as it does not deface the flag proper. Beginning of a tradition was the [[flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. [[Great Soviet Encyclopedia]] shows a flag decorated with a gold star. Ceremonial displays of the flag, such as those in parades or on indoor posts, often use fringe to enhance the beauty of the flag. No specific law governs the legality of fringe. Traditionally, the Army, Guard, Navy and Air Force use a fringed National Color for parade, color guard and indoor display, while the Office of the President and local authorities use a fringed National Color for all uses.
