 There is also criticism in regards to shades.<ref name=grechylo/> There are specialists who argue that, according to rules of heraldry, the current set of colours cannot coexist.<ref>[http://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_sino-zhovtij-prapor-ce-znuschannya-nad-ukrajinskoyu-tradicieyu/508746 Blue-yellow flag is a cruelty towards the Ukrainian traditions (Синьо-жовтий прапор - це знущання над українською традицією)]. ''Gazette'' in Ukrainian (gazeta.ua). July 25, 2013</ref> The head of the Ukrainian Heraldry Society pointed out that it is not [[heraldry]], but rather [[vexillology]] that studies flags.<ref name=grechylo/>
 
-==Protocol==
+==Protocol and use==
 [[File:Hanging flag of Ukraine.svg|thumb|upright=0.25|Hanging flag]]
 ===Legal status===
 
@@ -70,6 +70,36 @@
 ===Vertical flags===
 
 In addition to the normal horizontal format, many public buildings, such as [[Verkhovna rada]] in Ukraine use vertical flags. Most town halls fly their town flag together with the national flag in this way; some town flags in Ukraine exist only in vertical form. The proportions of these vertical flags are not specified<!-- (commented out until supporting evidence can be found), although a ratio of 5:2 is the most common-->. When hung like a banner or draped, the blue band should be on the left, as illustrated. When flown from a vertical flagpole, the blue band must face the mast.
+
+===Stamps===
+[[file:Marka3.jpg|thumbnail|"Freedom for Ukraine" cinderella stamp. Ukrainian flag with gold fringe and a gold [[Coat of arms of Ukraine|Coat of Arms]] on top of the flag pole.]]
+The flag did not appear on Ukrainian official postal stamp issues until the 1992 was released, depicting the flag with state coat of arms.  Since that time the flag has frequently appeared on stamps. [[Cinderella stamp]]s of the [[Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists]] were printed outside Ukraine during the Soviet period and served propaganda purposes.
+
+===Decoration===
+Traditionally, the flag may be decorated with golden [[Fringe (trim)|fringe]] surrounding the perimeter of the flag as long as it does not deface the flag proper. Beginning of a tradition was the [[flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. [[Great Soviet Encyclopedia]] shows a flag decorated with a gold star. Ceremonial displays of the flag, such as those in parades or on indoor posts, often use fringe to enhance the beauty of the flag. No specific law governs the legality of fringe. Traditionally, the Army, Guard, Navy and Air Force use a fringed National Color for parade, color guard and indoor display, while the Office of the President and local authorities use a fringed National Color for all uses.
+
+===Places of continuous display===
+Ukrainian flags are customly displayed continuously at certain locations.
+* [[Maidan Nezalezhnosti]], main square of [[Kiev]], traditional place for political rallies, including four large-scale radical protest campaigns ([[Orange Revolution]] and [[Euromaidan]]).
+* [[Presidential Administration Building (Kiev)|Presidential Administration Building]], [[Verkhovna Rada building]] and [[Budynok Uryadu]].
+* [[Kiev City Council]]
+* [[Lviv High Castle]]
+* [[Vernadsky Research Base]]
+* At [[State Border Guard Service of Ukraine]] sites.
+
+===Particular days for display===
+The flag should especially be displayed at full staff on the following days:
+* January: 1 ([[New Year's Day]]), 7 ([[Orthodox Christmas]]), 22 (Day of Ukraine)
+* March: 8 (International Women's Day)
+* May: 1 & 2 ([[International Workers' Day]]),  9 (Memorial Day)
+* June: 28 (Constitution Day)
+* August: 24 (Independence Day)
+* November: 13 (Day of Dignity and Liberty)
+
+===Display at half-staff===
+The flag is displayed at half-staff (half-mast in naval usage) as a sign of respect or mourning. Nationwide, this action is proclaimed by the president. Half-mast means the flag is flown two-thirds of the way up the flagpole with at least the height of the flag between the top of the flag and the top of the flagpole. Black ribbons indicate mourning on banners that can't be lowered to halfmast.
+* 4th Saturday of November: Day of Remembrance of the Victims of [[Holodomor]]
+* Other historical cases: mass victims of accidents, [[War in Donbass]] and [[Euromaidan]]; [[Death and state funeral of Lech and Maria Kaczyński]], [[Funeral of Pope John Paul II]] and [[September 11 attacks]].
 
 ==Flag Day==
 {{main|Day of the National Flag (Ukraine)}}
llm_output:

Not Weaponised. The additions provide factual information about the Ukrainian flag's usage and cultural significance without employing language that could be seen as weaponizing cultural heritage.

 ===Postwar Ukraine===
-[[File:|thumbnail|[[File:FIAV historical.svg|23x15px]] Flag of the [[Ukrainian Insurgent Army]] and [[Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists]]]]
+The Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists is a Ukrainian political organisation which as a movement originally was created in 1929 in Western Ukraine (at the time interwar Poland). For long time OUN did not officially have its own flag, however during the Hungarian and Polish aggression against the Carpathian Ukraine in 1938, Carpathian Sich, a militarised wing of OUN, adopted its flag from the OUN's emblem - golden nationalistic trident on a blue background. The flag was finalised and officially adopted by the organisation only in 1964 at the 5th Assembly of Ukrainian Nationalists.
+
+The Ukrainian Insurgent Army was a Ukrainian nationalist paramilitary and later partisan army that engaged in a series of guerrilla conflicts during World War II against Nazi Germany, the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, and both Underground and Communist Poland. The group was the military wing of the Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists — Bandera faction (the OUN-B), originally formed in Volyn in the spring and summer of 1943. Its official date of creation is 14 October 1942,[1] day of Intercession of the Theotokos feast. The battle flag of the UPA was a 2:3 ratio red-and-black banner. The flag continues to be a symbol of the Ukrainian nationalist movement. The colours of the flag symbolise 'Ukrainian red blood spilled on Ukrainian black earth'.
 
 <center>
 {{Begin flag gallery}}

The flag was finalised and officially adopted by the organisation only in 1964 at the 5th Assembly of Ukrainian Nationalists.
-
-The Ukrainian Insurgent Army was a Ukrainian nationalist paramilitary and later partisan army that engaged in a series of guerrilla conflicts during World War II against Nazi Germany, the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, and both Underground and Communist Poland. The group was the military wing of the Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists — Bandera faction (the OUN-B), originally formed in Volyn in the spring and summer of 1943. Its official date of creation is 14 October 1942,[1] day of Intercession of the Theotokos feast. The battle flag of the UPA was a 2:3 ratio red-and-black banner. The flag continues to be a symbol of the Ukrainian nationalist movement. The colours of the flag symbolise 'Ukrainian red blood spilled on Ukrainian black earth'.
 
 In 1949 the flag of the Soviet Ukraine was changed once again.<ref name=grechylo/> The [[Soviet Union]] managed to obtain two additional seats in the [[United Nations]] by adding as members Ukraine along with Belarus.<ref name=grechylo/> The change was due to the fact that all the Soviet flags were the same.<ref name=grechylo/> The new Ukrainian flag consisted of a red (top, 2/3) and a [[azure]] (bottom, 1/3) stripes,<ref name=grechylo/> with the golden star, [[sickle and mallet]] in the top left corner. The Communist party leaders such as [[Khrushchev]] and [[Kaganovich]] were afraid of using words ''light blue'' and ''blue'' which were used by the [[Ukrainian diaspora]].<ref name=grechylo/>

+In 1949 the flag of the Soviet Ukraine was changed once again.<ref name=grechylo/> The [[Soviet Union]] managed to obtain two additional seats in the [[United Nations]] by adding as members Ukraine along with Belarus.<ref name=grechylo/> The change was due to the fact that all the Soviet flags were the same.<ref name=grechylo/> The new Ukrainian flag consisted of a red (top, 2/3) and a [[azure (color)|azure]] (bottom, 1/3) stripes,<ref name=grechylo/> with the golden star, [[sickle and mallet]] in the top left corner. The Communist party leaders such as [[Khrushchev]] and [[Lazar Kaganovich|Kaganovich]] were afraid of using words ''light blue'' and ''blue'' which were used by the [[Ukrainian diaspora]].<ref name=grechylo/>
 
 During the Soviet period there were multiple unsanctioned attempts to hoist the national blue-and-yellow flag. In 1958 in village of Verbytsia, [[:uk:Ходорівський район|Khodoriv Raion]] there was established an underground group, members of which at night were raising national flags and spread anti-Soviet pamphlets.<ref>[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/columns/2011/07/29/48180/ Unknown flag-bearers. Yellow-blue against Red (Невідомі прапороносці. Жовто-блакитний проти червоного)]. ''[[Ukrayinska Pravda]]''. July 29, 2011</ref>

'''Flag Ratio:''' 2:3

The flag of [[Ukraine]] was adopted on [[September 3]], [[1996]].  It had been the provisional flag since [[1991]].
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -72,8 +72,6 @@
 In addition to the normal horizontal format, many public buildings, such as [[Verkhovna rada]] in Ukraine use vertical flags. Most town halls fly their town flag together with the national flag in this way; some town flags in Ukraine exist only in vertical form. The proportions of these vertical flags are not specified<!-- (commented out until supporting evidence can be found), although a ratio of 5:2 is the most common-->. When hung like a banner or draped, the blue band should be on the left, as illustrated. When flown from a vertical flagpole, the blue band must face the mast.
 
 ==Flag Day==
-
-[[File:Kiev Maidan Flag.jpg|thumbnail|Flag at  [[Maidan Nezalezhnosti]], main [[Kyiv]] square.]]
 {{main|Day of the National Flag (Ukraine)}}
 
 23 August is celebrated as the Day of the National Flag in Ukraine; beginning with 2004. July 24 was previously marked as National Flag Day in Kiev. The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on 24 July 1990 at the flagstaff of the Kiev City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992 Independence Day of Ukraine is celebrated on August 24. Following government decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this dates and some other holidays. Not all of these days are public holidays. Flags also must be flown on election days for the [[Verkhovna Rada]]  in addition to other regional-specific flag days. The public display of flags to mark other events, such as the election of the president or the death of a prominent politician (whereupon flags would be at half-mast), can be declared at the discretion of the Cabinet of Ministers. When flags are required to be flown at half-mast, vertical flags are not lowered. A black mourning ribbon is instead attached, either atop the mast (if hung from a pole) or to each end of the flag's supporting cross-beams (if flown like a banner).
llm_output:
Removed a section about the image of a flag at Maidan Nezalezhnosti.

Not Weaponised – The change is a removal of a specific image reference and does not introduce or alter any narratives related to cultural heritage or conflict.

 The flag is displayed at half-staff (half-mast in naval usage) as a sign of respect or mourning. Nationwide, this action is proclaimed by the president. Half-mast means the flag is flown two-thirds of the way up the flagpole with at least the height of the flag between the top of the flag and the top of the flagpole. Black ribbons indicate mourning on banners that can't be lowered to halfmast.

 * Other historical cases: mass victims of accidents, [[War in Donbass]] and [[Euromaidan]]; [[Death and state funeral of Lech and Maria Kaczyński]], [[Funeral of Pope John Paul II]] and [[September 11 attacks]].

 ===Short independence: 1917–1920===
 [[File:Propaganda UPR.jpg|thumbnail||UPR flag with blue and yellow (down) flag, [[Ukrainian War of Independence]], 1918]]
+[[File:Украинская галицкая армия флаг.jpg|thumbnail|right|[[Ukrainian Galician Army]] troops with blue and yellow (down) flag, 1918]]
 Both blue–yellow and yellow–blue flags were widely used during the [[Ukraine after the Russian Revolution|Ukraian struggle for independence]] in 1917. For the first time in the [[Russian Empire]] the blue-yellow flag was flown on March 25, 1917 in [[Petrograd]] during a 20-thousand people mass [[Demonstration (protest)|demonstration]].<ref name=istpravda/> On the territory of the Russian Ukraine ([[Little Russia]]) the national flag of Ukraine was flown for the first time in [[Kiev]] on March 29, 1917 by soldiers.<ref name=istpravda/> On April 1, 1917 Kiev saw a 100-thousand people demonstration that carried over 320 national flags.<ref name=istpravda/> After that similar demonstration with Ukrainian flags took place across the whole [[Russian Empire]] even beyond the Ukrainian ethnic lands.<ref name=istpravda/> Number of famous Ukrainian politician wrote their recollection about the April 1 demonstration such as [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] and [[Serhiy Yefremov]] stating that there were blue-and-yellow flags, while [[Dmytro Doroshenko]] claimed that there were yellow-and-blue.<ref name=istpravda/> The blue-yellow flag was flown at the First Ukrainian Military Congress on May 18, 1917.<ref name=istpravda/>
 
 There are reliable sources that indicate that an official flag was declared by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in 1918 is blue–yellow. Some sources mention that the yellow–blue was adopted by [[Tsentralna Rada]] on March 22, 1918.<ref>[http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=32027&cat_id=31295 State Symbols of Ukraine], [[Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine]], website.</ref> Other sources point out that no hard proof of ''such'' decision exists.<ref name=istpravda/><ref>http://vexillography.narod.ru/ukraine/unr.htm</ref> Instead, they refer to the decision on the Fleet Flag, which was set to be light blue–yellow<ref>[http://www.history.org.ua/journal/1999/4/10.pdf ''Ukrainian Historical Journal'', 1999, #4, ISSN 0130-S247]</ref> as an indication that the official flag was light blue–yellow.<ref>[http://vijsko.milua.org/Khoruhvy_HA.htm Українське військо у ХХ-ХХІ сторіччі]</ref> Also were adopted other service flags of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].<ref>Grechylo A. Ukrayinska Terytorialna Heraldyka. Lviv, 2010, pp. 98-118. ISBN 978-966-02-5259-2</ref>

Not Weaponised. The addition of the image serves to enhance the historical context of the Ukrainian struggle for independence without introducing any politically charged language or narratives.

It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the flag was outlawed and before 1949 there was no official state flag until adoption of the red-blue [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. People who were hoisting the blue-yellow flags in the Soviet Ukraine were prosecuted as criminals.  {{End flag gallery}}
 </center>
 
-===Postwar Ukraine===
+===Interbellum Ukraine===
 The Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists is a Ukrainian political organisation which as a movement originally was created in 1929 in Western Ukraine (at the time interwar Poland). For long time OUN did not officially have its own flag, however during the Hungarian and Polish aggression against the Carpathian Ukraine in 1938, Carpathian Sich, a militarised wing of OUN, adopted its flag from the OUN's emblem - golden nationalistic trident on a blue background. The flag was finalised and officially adopted by the organisation only in 1964 at the 5th Assembly of Ukrainian Nationalists.
 
 The Ukrainian Insurgent Army was a Ukrainian nationalist paramilitary and later partisan army that engaged in a series of guerrilla conflicts during World War II against Nazi Germany, the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, and both Underground and Communist Poland. The group was the military wing of the Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists — Bandera faction (the OUN-B), originally formed in Volyn in the spring and summer of 1943. Its official date of creation is 14 October 1942,[1] day of Intercession of the Theotokos feast. The battle flag of the UPA was a 2:3 ratio red-and-black banner. The flag continues to be a symbol of the Ukrainian nationalist movement. The colours of the flag symbolise 'Ukrainian red blood spilled on Ukrainian black earth'.
llm_output:

@@ -186,6 +186,7 @@
 Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[perestroika]] and [[glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national identity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1982–91)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed.
 
 The events in the Baltic countries soon led to similar processes in Ukraine. Particularly, West Ukraine and [[Ukrainian SSR]]'s capital [[Kiev]] (''Kyiv'') constantly held political demonstrations with the national yellow-and-blue flags waving above the heads of demonstrators.
+* On March 14, 1990, the Ukrainian flag was raise for the first time since crumbling of Soviet Union in a small city of [[Stryi]].<ref>[http://www.ukrinform.ua/ukr/news/istoriya_evolyutsiii_dergavnogo_prapora_ukraiini_infografika_2084779 History of evolution of the State Flag of Ukraine]. [[Ukrinform]]. 23 August 2015</ref>
 * On March 20, 1990, the town council of [[Ternopil]] voted upon the usage and re-establishment of the yellow-and-blue flag and the [[Coat of arms of Ukraine|''tryzub'']] as well as the national anthem ''[[Ukraine's glory has not perished|Shche ne vmerla Ukrainy]]''. On the same day, the yellow-and-blue national flag was flown for the first time in about 80 years on a governmental building in Kiev, replacing the then official [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR|red-and-blue flag]] of the Ukrainian SSR.
 * On April 28, 1990, the oblast council (''oblasna rada'') of [[Lviv Oblast|Lviv]] also allowed the use of the national symbols of Ukraine within the Oblast.
 * On April 29, 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown from the Ternopil city theater's flagstaff without the [[Flag of the Soviet Union|official flag of the Soviet Union]] hanging above it.

For the first time in the [[Russian Empire]] the blue-yellow flag was flown on March 25, 1917 in [[Petrograd]] during a 20-thousand people mass [[Demonstration (protest)|demonstration]].<ref name=istpravda/> On the territory of the Russian Ukraine ([[Little Russia]]) the national flag of Ukraine was flown for the first time in [[Kiev]] on March 29, 1917 by soldiers.<ref name=istpravda/> On April 1, 1917 Kiev saw a 100-thousand people demonstration that carried over 320 national flags.<ref name=istpravda/> After that similar demonstration with Ukrainian flags took place across the whole [[Russian Empire]] even beyond the Ukrainian ethnic lands.<ref name=istpravda/> Number of famous Ukrainian politician wrote their recollection about the April 1 demonstration such as [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] and [[Serhiy Yefremov]] stating that there were blue-and-yellow flags, while [[Dmytro Doroshenko]] claimed that there were yellow-and-blue.<ref name=istpravda/> The blue-yellow flag was flown at the First Ukrainian Military Congress on May 18, 1917.<ref name=istpravda/>
+Both blue–yellow and yellow–blue flags were widely used during the [[Ukraine after the Russian Revolution|Ukrainian struggle for independence]] in 1917. For the first time in the [[Russian Empire]] the blue-yellow flag was flown on March 25, 1917 in [[Petrograd]] during a 20-thousand people mass [[Demonstration (protest)|demonstration]].<ref name=istpravda/> On the territory of the Russian Ukraine ([[Little Russia]]) the national flag of Ukraine was flown for the first time in [[Kiev]] on March 29, 1917 by soldiers.<ref name=istpravda/> On April 1, 1917 Kiev saw a 100-thousand people demonstration that carried over 320 national flags.<ref name=istpravda/> After that similar demonstration with Ukrainian flags took place across the whole [[Russian Empire]] even beyond the Ukrainian ethnic lands.<ref name=istpravda/> Number of famous Ukrainian politician wrote their recollection about the April 1 demonstration such as [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] and [[Serhiy Yefremov]] stating that there were blue-and-yellow flags, while [[Dmytro Doroshenko]] claimed that there were yellow-and-blue.<ref name=istpravda/> The blue-yellow flag was flown at the First Ukrainian Military Congress on May 18, 1917.<ref name=istpravda/>
 
 There are reliable sources that indicate that an official flag was declared by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in 1918 is blue–yellow. Some sources mention that the yellow–blue was adopted by [[Tsentralna Rada]] on March 22, 1918.<ref>[http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=32027&cat_id=31295 State Symbols of Ukraine], [[Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine]], website.</ref> Other sources point out that no hard proof of ''such'' decision exists.<ref name=istpravda/><ref>http://vexillography.narod.ru/ukraine/unr.htm</ref> Instead, they refer to the decision on the Fleet Flag, which was set to be light blue–yellow<ref>[http://www.history.org.ua/journal/1999/4/10.pdf ''Ukrainian Historical Journal'', 1999, #4, ISSN 0130-S247]</ref> as an indication that the official flag was light blue–yellow.<ref>[http://vijsko.milua.org/Khoruhvy_HA.htm Українське військо у ХХ-ХХІ сторіччі]</ref> Also were adopted other service flags of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].<ref>Grechylo A. Ukrayinska Terytorialna Heraldyka. Lviv, 2010, pp. 98-118. ISBN 978-966-02-5259-2</ref>

-[[File:Ilja Jefimowitsch Repin 009.jpg|thumb|Yellow–blue and red-black Cossack flags at ''[[Reply of the Zaporozhian Cossacks]]'' painting by [[Ilya Repin]], 1880–1891.]]
+[[File:Ilja Jefimowitsch Repin - Reply of the Zaporozhian Cossacks - Yorck.jpg|thumb|Yellow–blue and red-black Cossack flags at ''[[Reply of the Zaporozhian Cossacks]]'' painting by [[Ilya Repin]], 1880–1891.]]
 The roots of Ukrainian national symbols come from before Christian times when yellow and blue prevailed in traditional ceremonies, reflecting fire and water.<ref name=Saprykov>[http://geraldika.ru/symbols/3334 Geraldika.ru Флаг Украины]</ref> The most solid proof of yellow and blue colours could be traced as far as the [[Battle of Grunwald]] at which participated militia formations from various lands of the Polish-Lithuanian Union.
 
 Yellow–blue, red-black, crimson-olive and especially raspberry colour banners were widely used by [[Cossack]]s between the 16th and 18th centuries. These were not the only possible combinations, since normally Cossacks would fly their [[hetman]]'s banners, which were similar to the coats of arms of the nobility. Also, yellow and blue were the colours common on coats of arms in [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]]. In fact, the coat of arms of [[Lviv]] to this day remains a golden lion on a blue field.

 ===Legal status===
 
 Article 20 of the Constitution of Ukraine states the following, citing: ''"the State Flag of Ukraine is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow colour."'' ({{lang-uk|''"Державний Прапор України — стяг із двох рівновеликих горизонтальних смуг синього і жовтого кольорів."''}}).<ref name=constitution_article>[[s:Constitution of Ukraine|Constitution of Ukraine]]</ref><ref name=constitution_official_uk>{{cite web |url=http://zakon4.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/254%D0%BA/96-%D0%B2%D1%80 |script-title=uk:Конституція України |language=Ukrainian |website=Верховна Рада України}}</ref>
@@ -107,6 +108,7 @@
 
 23 August is celebrated as the Day of the National Flag in Ukraine; beginning with 2004. July 24 was previously marked as National Flag Day in Kiev. The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on 24 July 1990 at the flagstaff of the Kiev City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992 Independence Day of Ukraine is celebrated on August 24. Following government decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this dates and some other holidays. Not all of these days are public holidays. Flags also must be flown on election days for the [[Verkhovna Rada]]  in addition to other regional-specific flag days. The public display of flags to mark other events, such as the election of the president or the death of a prominent politician (whereupon flags would be at half-mast), can be declared at the discretion of the Cabinet of Ministers. When flags are required to be flown at half-mast, vertical flags are not lowered. A black mourning ribbon is instead attached, either atop the mast (if hung from a pole) or to each end of the flag's supporting cross-beams (if flown like a banner).

For the first time in the [[Russian Empire]] the blue-yellow flag was flown on March 25, 1917 in [[Petrograd]] during a 20-thousand people mass [[Demonstration (protest)|demonstration]].<ref name=istpravda/> On the territory of the Russian Ukraine ([[Little Russia]]) the national flag of Ukraine was flown for the first time in [[Kiev]] on March 29, 1917 by soldiers.<ref name=istpravda/> On April 1, 1917 Kiev saw a 100-thousand people demonstration that carried over 320 national flags.<ref name=istpravda/> After that similar demonstration with Ukrainian flags took place across the whole [[Russian Empire]] even beyond the Ukrainian ethnic lands.<ref name=istpravda/> Number of famous Ukrainian politician wrote their recollection about the April 1 demonstration such as [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] and [[Serhiy Yefremov]] stating that there were blue-and-yellow flags, while [[Dmytro Doroshenko]] claimed that there were yellow-and-blue.<ref name=istpravda/> The blue-yellow flag was flown at the First Ukrainian Military Congress on May 18, 1917.<ref name=istpravda/>
 
-There are reliable sources that indicate that an official flag was declared by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in 1918 is blue–yellow. Some sources mention that the yellow–blue was adopted by [[Tsentralna Rada]] on March 22, 1918.<ref>[http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=32027&cat_id=31295 State Symbols of Ukraine], [[Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine]], website.</ref> Other sources point out that no hard proof of ''such'' decision exists.<ref name=istpravda/><ref>http://vexillography.narod.ru/ukraine/unr.htm</ref> Instead, they refer to the decision on the Fleet Flag, which was set to be light blue–yellow<ref>[http://www.history.org.ua/journal/1999/4/10.pdf ''Ukrainian Historical Journal'', 1999, #4, ISSN 0130-S247]</ref> as an indication that the official flag was light blue–yellow.<ref>[http://vijsko.milua.org/Khoruhvy_HA.htm Українське військо у ХХ-ХХІ сторіччі]</ref> Also were adopted other service flags of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].<ref>Grechylo A. Ukrayinska Terytorialna Heraldyka. Lviv, 2010, pp. 98-118. ISBN 978-966-02-5259-2</ref>

Ukrayinska Terytorialna Heraldyka. Lviv, 2010, pp. 98-118. ISBN 978-966-02-5259-2</ref>
 
 The official flag of [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]]'s [[Ukrainian State|Hetmanate]] also was light blue–yellow and became the same under [[Symon Petlura]]'s [[Directorate of Ukraine|Directorate]]. The flag of [[West Ukrainian National Republic]] was blue and yellow. The [[Free Territory|anarchist free-soviets]] that existed during the [[Ukrainian War of Independence|civil war]] used the black flag.

 ===Soviet Ukraine: 1922–1991===
 {{Main|Flag of the Ukrainian SSR}}
-The first flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic was adopted on March 10, 1919, to serve as the symbol of state of the Ukrainian SSR. Details of the official flag changed periodically before the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991, but all were based on the red flag of the Bolshevik Revolution.
+The first flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic was adopted on March 10, 1919, to serve as the symbol of state of the [[Soviet Ukraine]]. Details of the official flag changed periodically before the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991, but all were based on the red flag of the [[October Revolution]] in Russia and an exact replica of the [[Soviet Russia]].
 The first flag was red with the gold Cyrillic sans-serif letters У.С.С.Р. (USSR, acronym for Ukrayinskaya Sotsialisticheskaya Sovetskaya Respublika in the Russian language). In the 1930s a gold border was added. In 1937, a new flag was adopted, with a small gold hammer and sickle added above the gold Cyrillic serif letters У.Р.С.Р. (URSR, for Ukrayins’ka Radyans’ka Sotsialistychna Respublika in the Ukrainian language).
 <center>
 {{Begin flag gallery}}

-The '''state flag of [[Ukraine]]''' ({{lang-uk|державний прапор України}}; [[Romanisation of Ukrainian|translit.]]: ''derzhavnyy prapor Ukrayiny''; literally 'state flag of Ukraine') is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow colour. ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]])
+The '''state flag of [[Ukraine]]''' ({{lang-uk|державний прапор України}}; [[Romanisation of Ukrainian|translit.]]: ''derzhavnyy prapor Ukrayiny''; literally 'state flag of Ukraine') is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]]).
 
 As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolour was officially used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]] when it was hoisted over the [[Lviv Town Hall|Lviv Rathaus]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]], and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the flag was outlawed and before 1949 there was no official state flag until adoption of the red-blue [[Flag of Ukrainian SSR|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. People who hoisted the blue-yellow flags in the Soviet Ukraine were prosecuted as criminals. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following Ukrainian independence, before finally officially being restored in 1992.

For the first time in the [[Russian Empire]] the blue-yellow flag was flown on March 25, 1917 in [[Petrograd]] during a 20-thousand people mass [[Demonstration (protest)|demonstration]].<ref name=istpravda/> On the territory of the Russian Ukraine ([[Little Russia]]) the national flag of Ukraine was flown for the first time in [[Kiev]] on March 29, 1917 by soldiers.<ref name=istpravda/> On April 1, 1917 Kiev saw a 100-thousand people demonstration that carried over 320 national flags.<ref name=istpravda/> After that similar demonstration with Ukrainian flags took place across the whole [[Russian Empire]] even beyond the Ukrainian ethnic lands.<ref name=istpravda/> Numerous famous Ukrainian politician wrote their recollection about the April 1 demonstration such as [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] and [[Serhiy Yefremov]] stating that there were blue-and-yellow flags, while [[Dmytro Doroshenko]] claimed that there were yellow-and-blue.<ref name=istpravda/> The blue-yellow flag was flown at the First Ukrainian Military Congress on May 18, 1917.<ref name=istpravda/>
 
 There are reliable sources that indicate that an official flag was declared by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in 1918 is blue–yellow. Some sources mention that the yellow–blue was adopted by [[Tsentralna Rada]] on March 22, 1918.<ref>[http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=32027&cat_id=31295 State Symbols of Ukraine], [[Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine]], website.</ref> Other sources point out that no hard proof of ''such'' decision exists.<ref name=istpravda/><ref>http://vexillography.narod.ru/ukraine/unr.htm</ref> Instead, they refer to the decision on the Fleet Flag, which was set to be light blue–yellow<ref>[http://www.history.org.ua/journal/1999/4/10.pdf ''Ukrainian Historical Journal''], 1999, #4, {{ISSN|0130-5247}}</ref> as an indication that the official flag was light blue–yellow.<ref>[http://vijsko.milua.org/Khoruhvy_HA.htm Українське військо у ХХ-ХХІ сторіччі]</ref> Also were adopted other service flags of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].<ref>Grechylo A. Ukrayinska Terytorialna Heraldyka. Lviv, 2010, pp. 98–118. ISBN 978-966-02-5259-2</ref>

@@ -188,7 +188,7 @@
 Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[perestroika]] and [[glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national identity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1982–91)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed.
 
 The events in the Baltic countries soon led to similar processes in Ukraine. Particularly, West Ukraine and [[Ukrainian SSR]]'s capital [[Kiev]] (''Kyiv'') constantly held political demonstrations with the national yellow-and-blue flags waving above the heads of demonstrators.
-* On March 14, 1990, the Ukrainian flag was raise for the first time since crumbling of Soviet Union in the small city of [[Stryi]].<ref>[http://www.ukrinform.ua/ukr/news/istoriya_evolyutsiii_dergavnogo_prapora_ukraiini_infografika_2084779 History of evolution of the State Flag of Ukraine]. [[Ukrinform]]. 23 August 2015</ref>
+* On March 14, 1990, the Ukrainian flag was raised for the first time after the establishment of the Soviet Union in the small city of [[Stryi]].<ref>[http://www.ukrinform.ua/ukr/news/istoriya_evolyutsiii_dergavnogo_prapora_ukraiini_infografika_2084779 History of evolution of the State Flag of Ukraine]. [[Ukrinform]]. 23 August 2015</ref>
 * On March 20, 1990, the town council of [[Ternopil]] voted upon the usage and re-establishment of the yellow-and-blue flag and the [[Coat of arms of Ukraine|''tryzub'']] as well as the national anthem ''[[Ukraine's glory has not perished|Shche ne vmerla Ukrainy]]''. On the same day, the yellow-and-blue national flag was flown for the first time in about 80 years on a governmental building in Kiev, replacing the then official [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|red-and-blue flag]] of the Ukrainian SSR.
 * On April 28, 1990, the oblast council (''oblasna rada'') of [[Lviv Oblast|Lviv]] also allowed the use of the national symbols of Ukraine within the Oblast.
 * On April 29, 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown from the Ternopil city theater's flagstaff without the [[Flag of the Soviet Union|official flag of the Soviet Union]] hanging above it.

 The '''state flag of [[Ukraine]]''' ({{lang-uk|державний прапор України}}; [[Romanisation of Ukrainian|translit.]]: ''derzhavnyy prapor Ukrayiny''; literally 'state flag of Ukraine') is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]]).
 
 As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolour was officially used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]] when it was hoisted over the [[Lviv Town Hall|Lviv Rathaus]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]], and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the flag was outlawed and before 1949 there was no official state flag until adoption of the red-blue [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. People who hoisted the blue-yellow flags in the Soviet Ukraine were prosecuted as criminals{{citation needed|reason=sounds like an urban legend|date=August 2016}}. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following Ukrainian independence, before finally officially being restored in 1992.

When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the flag was outlawed and before 1949 there was no official state flag until adoption of the red-blue [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. People who hoisted the blue-yellow flags in the Soviet Ukraine were prosecuted as criminals{{citation needed|reason=sounds like an urban legend|date=August 2016}}. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following Ukrainian independence, before finally officially being restored in 1992.<ref name="Symbolsx2">{{cite news|last=Trach|first=Nataliya|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/ukraine-politics/the-story-behind-2-top-ukrainian-symbols-national-flag-and-trident-421675.html|title=The story behind 2 top Ukrainian symbols: National flag and trident|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=26 August 2016|accessdate=27 August 2016}}</ref>

 The flag did not appear on Ukrainian official postal stamp issues until the 1992 was released, depicting the flag with state coat of arms.  Since that time the flag has frequently appeared on stamps. [[Cinderella stamp]]s of the [[Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists]] were printed outside Ukraine during the Soviet period and served propaganda purposes.
 
 ===Decoration===
-Traditionally, the flag may be decorated with a [[gold (color)|golden]] [[Fringe (trim)|fringe]] surrounding the perimeter of the flag, as long as it does not deface the flag proper. The beginning of this tradition was the [[flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. The ''[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia]]'' shows a flag decorated with a gold star. Ceremonial displays of the flag, such as those in parades or on indoor posts, often use a fringe to enhance the beauty of the flag. No specific law governs the legality of this fringe. Traditionally, the [[Ukrainian Ground Forces|Army]], [[National Guard of Ukraine|Guard]], [[Ukrainian Navy|Navy]] and [[Ukrainian Air Force|Air Force]] use a fringed flag for [[military parade|parades]], [[color guard|colour guards]] and indoor displays, while the [[President of Ukraine|Office of the President]] and local authorities use a fringed flag for all purposes.
+Traditionally, the flag may be decorated with a [[gold (color)|golden]] [[Fringe (trim)|fringe]] surrounding the perimeter of the flag, as long as it does not deface the flag proper. The beginning of this tradition was the [[flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. The ''[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia]]'' shows a flag decorated with a gold star. Ceremonial displays of the flag, such as those in parades or on indoor posts, often use a fringe to enhance the beauty of the flag. No specific law governs the legality of this fringe. Traditionally, the [[Ukrainian Ground Forces|Army]], [[National Guard of Ukraine|Guard]], [[Ukrainian Navy|Navy]] and [[Ukrainian Air Force|Air Force]] use a fringed flag for [[military parade|parades]], [[color guard]]s and indoor displays, while the [[President of Ukraine|Office of the President]] and local authorities use a fringed flag for all purposes.

+[[File:Western ukraine flag.png|thumb| The unofficial national flag of Ukraine]]
 The '''state flag of [[Ukraine]]''' ({{lang-uk|державний прапор України}}; [[Romanisation of Ukrainian|translit.]]: ''derzhavnyy prapor Ukrayiny''; literally 'state flag of Ukraine') is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]]).
 
 As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolour was officially used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]] when it was hoisted over the [[Lviv Town Hall|Lviv Rathaus]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]], and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the flag was outlawed and before 1949 there was no official state flag until adoption of the red-blue [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. People who hoisted the blue-yellow flags in the Soviet Ukraine were prosecuted as criminals{{citation needed|reason=sounds like an urban legend|date=August 2016}}. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following Ukrainian independence, before finally officially being restored in 1992.<ref name="Symbolsx2">{{cite news|last=Trach|first=Nataliya|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/ukraine-politics/the-story-behind-2-top-ukrainian-symbols-national-flag-and-trident-421675.html|title=The story behind 2 top Ukrainian symbols: National flag and trident|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=26 August 2016|accessdate=27 August 2016}}</ref>
llm_output:
Added an image reference for the unofficial national flag of Ukraine.

Not Weaponised. The addition of an image reference does not contain any language that promotes a specific narrative or perspective that could be considered weaponisation of cultural heritage.

 * Other historical cases: mass victims of accidents, [[War in Donbass]] and [[Euromaidan]]; [[Death and state funeral of Lech and Maria Kaczyński]], [[Funeral of Pope John Paul II]] and [[September 11 attacks]].
 
 ==Flag Day==
-[[File:Ukrflagblue.jpg|thumbnail|right|Flag at [[Kyiv]] City Hall]]
+[[File:Ukrflagblue.jpg|thumbnail|right|Flag at [[Kiev]] City Hall]]
 {{main|Day of the National Flag (Ukraine)}}
 
 August 23 is celebrated as the Day of the National Flag in Ukraine; beginning with 2004. July 24 was previously marked as National Flag Day in Kiev. The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on July 24, 1990 at the flagstaff of the Kiev City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992 Independence Day of Ukraine is celebrated on August 24. Following government decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this dates and some other holidays. Not all of these days are public holidays. Flags also must be flown on election days for the [[Verkhovna Rada]]  in addition to other regional-specific flag days. The public display of flags to mark other events, such as the election of the president or the death of a prominent politician (whereupon flags would be at half-mast), can be declared at the discretion of the Cabinet of Ministers. When flags are required to be flown at half-mast, vertical flags are not lowered. A black mourning ribbon is instead attached, either atop the mast (if hung from a pole) or to each end of the flag's supporting cross-beams (if flown like a banner).

 During the Soviet period there were multiple unsanctioned attempts to hoist the national blue-and-yellow flag. In 1958 in village of Verbytsia, [[:uk:Ходорівський район|Khodoriv Raion]] there was established an underground group, members of which at night were raising national flags and spread anti-Soviet pamphlets.<ref>[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/columns/2011/07/29/48180/ Unknown flag-bearers. Yellow-blue against Red (Невідомі прапороносці. Жовто-блакитний проти червоного)]. ''[[Ukrayinska Pravda]]''. July 29, 2011</ref>
 
 ===Return of the national flag===
+[[File:Kiev 24.7.1990 Ukrainian Flag.JPG|right|upright|thumb|The Ukrainian national flag was raised outside Kiev's [[Kyiv City Council|City Hall]] for the first time on 24 July 1990]]
 [[File:Waving the Ukrainian flag.jpg|thumbnail|right|A girl with flag at [[vyshyvanka]] parade]]
 Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[perestroika]] and [[glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national identity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1982–91)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed.

-The '''state flag of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|державний прапор України}}; [[Romanisation of Ukrainian|translit.]]: ''derzhavnyy prapor Ukrayiny''; literally 'state flag of Ukraine') is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]]).
+The '''state flag of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|державний прапор України}}; [[Romanisation of Ukrainian|translit.]]: ''derzhavnyi prapor Ukrainy''; literally 'state flag of Ukraine') is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]]).
 
 As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolour was officially used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]] when it was hoisted over the [[Lviv Town Hall|Lviv Rathaus]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]], and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the flag was outlawed and before 1949 there was no official state flag until adoption of the red-blue [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. People who hoisted the blue-yellow flags in the Soviet Ukraine were prosecuted as criminals{{citation needed|reason=sounds like an urban legend|date=August 2016}}. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following Ukrainian independence, before finally officially being restored in 1992.<ref name="Symbolsx2">{{cite news|last=Trach|first=Nataliya|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/ukraine-politics/the-story-behind-2-top-ukrainian-symbols-national-flag-and-trident-421675.html|title=The story behind 2 top Ukrainian symbols: National flag and trident|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=26 August 2016|accessdate=27 August 2016}}</ref>

-The '''state flag of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|державний прапор України}}; [[Romanisation of Ukrainian|translit.]]: ''derzhavnyy prapor Ukrayiny''; literally 'state flag of Ukraine') is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]]).
+The '''state flag of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|державний прапор України}}; [[Romanisation of Ukrainian|translit.]]: ''derzhavnyi prapor Ukrainy''; literally 'state flag of Ukraine') is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]]).
 
 As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolour was officially used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]] when it was hoisted over the [[Lviv Town Hall|Lviv Rathaus]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]], and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the flag was outlawed and before 1949 there was no official state flag until adoption of the red-blue [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. People who hoisted the blue-yellow flags in the Soviet Ukraine were prosecuted as criminals{{citation needed|reason=sounds like an urban legend|date=August 2016}}. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following Ukrainian independence, before finally officially being restored in 1992.<ref name="Symbolsx2">{{cite news|last=Trach|first=Nataliya|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/ukraine-politics/the-story-behind-2-top-ukrainian-symbols-national-flag-and-trident-421675.html|title=The story behind 2 top Ukrainian symbols: National flag and trident|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=26 August 2016|accessdate=27 August 2016}}</ref>

The designs differ according to the historical era they were used in and in accordance with the political scene in [[Ukraine]] at the time. The first flag to be used by a [[List of heads of state of Ukraine|head of state of Ukraine]] was that of [[Pavlo Skoropadskyi]]. +The '''state flag of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|державний прапор України}}; [[Romanisation of Ukrainian|translit.]]: ''derzhavnyy prapor Ukrayiny''; literally 'state flag of Ukraine') is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]]).
 
 As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolour was officially used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]] when it was hoisted over the [[Lviv Town Hall|Lviv Rathaus]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]], and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the flag was outlawed and before 1949 there was no official state flag until adoption of the red-blue [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. People who hoisted the blue-yellow flags in the Soviet Ukraine were prosecuted as criminals{{citation needed|reason=sounds like an urban legend|date=August 2016}}. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following Ukrainian independence, before finally officially being restored in 1992.<ref name="Symbolsx2">{{cite news|last=Trach|first=Nataliya|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/ukraine-politics/the-story-behind-2-top-ukrainian-symbols-national-flag-and-trident-421675.html|title=The story behind 2 top Ukrainian symbols: National flag and trident|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=26 August 2016|accessdate=27 August 2016}}</ref>
llm_output:

 Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[perestroika]] and [[glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national identity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1982–91)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed.

--- +++ @@ -22,7 +22,7 @@ }} The '''state flag of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|державний прапор України}}; [[Romanisation of Ukrainian|translit.]]: ''derzhavnyi prapor Ukrainy''; literally 'state flag of Ukraine') is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]]). -As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolour was officially used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]] when it was hoisted over the [[Lviv Town Hall|Lviv Rathaus]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]], and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the flag was outlawed and before 1949 there was no official state flag until adoption of the red-blue [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. People who hoisted the blue-yellow flags in the Soviet Ukraine were prosecuted as criminals{{citation needed|reason=sounds like an urban legend|date=August 2016}}. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following Ukrainian independence, before finally officially being restored in 1992.{{cite news|last=Trach|first=Nataliya|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/ukraine-politics/the-story-behind-2-top-ukrainian-symbols-national-flag-and-trident-421675.html|title=The story behind 2 top Ukrainian symbols: National flag and trident|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=26 August 2016|accessdate=27 August 2016}} +As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolour was officially used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]] when it was hoisted over the [[Lviv Town Hall|Lviv Rathaus]]. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the flag was outlawed and before 1949 there was no official state flag until adoption of the red-blue [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. People who hoisted the blue-yellow flags in the Soviet Ukraine were prosecuted as criminals{{citation needed|reason=sounds like an urban legend|date=August 2016}}. [http://www.kyivpost.com/content/kyiv/ceremony-of-hoisting-ukraines-national-flag-held-a-111423.html Ceremony of hoisting Ukraine's national flag held at presidential administration], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (August 23, 2011)

Ukrayinska Terytorialna Heraldyka. Lviv, 2010, pp. 98–118. {{ISBN|978-966-02-5259-2}}</ref>
 
 The official flag of [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]]'s [[Ukrainian State|Hetmanate]] also was light blue–yellow and became the same under [[Symon Petlura]]'s [[Directorate of Ukraine|Directorate]]. The flag of [[West Ukrainian National Republic]] was blue and yellow. The [[Free Territory|anarchist free-soviets]] that existed during the [[Ukrainian War of Independence|civil war]] used the black flag.

-[[File:Ilja Jefimowitsch Repin - Reply of the Zaporozhian Cossacks - Yorck.jpg|thumb|Yellow–blue and red-black Cossack flags at ''[[Reply of the Zaporozhian Cossacks]]'' painting by [[Ilya Repin]], 1880–1891.]]
+[[File:Ilja Jefimowitsch Repin - Reply of the Zaporozhian Cossacks - Yorck.jpg|thumb|left|Yellow–blue and red-black Cossack flags at ''[[Reply of the Zaporozhian Cossacks]]'' painting by [[Ilya Repin]], 1880–1891.]]
 The roots of Ukrainian national symbols come from before Christian times when yellow and blue prevailed in traditional ceremonies, reflecting fire and water.<ref name=Saprykov>[http://geraldika.ru/symbols/3334 Geraldika.ru Флаг Украины]</ref> The most solid proof of yellow and blue colours could be traced as far as the [[Battle of Grunwald]] at which participated militia formations from various lands of the Polish-Lithuanian Union.
 
 Yellow–blue, red-black, crimson-olive and especially raspberry colour banners were widely used by [[Cossack]]s between the 16th and 18th centuries. These were not the only possible combinations, since normally Cossacks would fly their [[hetman]]'s banners, which were similar to the coats of arms of the nobility. Also, yellow and blue were the colours common on coats of arms in [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]]. In fact, the coat of arms of [[Lviv]] to this day remains a golden lion on a blue field.
 
 Some put the starting point of the current national flag of Ukraine in year 1848, when during the [[The Revolutions of 1848 in the Habsburg areas|Spring of the Nations]] a yellow and blue banner was adopted by the [[Main Ruthenian Council]]<ref name=istpravda>[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/articles/2014/01/14/140850/ Blue-yellow or yellow-blue? Myths about the flipped flag (Синьо-жовтий чи жовто-блакитний? Міфи про "перевернутий" прапор)]. ''[[Ukrayinska Pravda]]''. January 14, 2014</ref> in [[Lviv]] and flew over the city's magistrate for the first time. Although this move did not have significant consequences, the newly formed Ukrainian divisions in the Austrian army used yellow and blue banners in their insignia.

As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolour has been officially used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]] when it was hoisted over the [[Lviv Town Hall|Lviv Rathaus]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]], and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the flag was outlawed and before 1949 there was no official state flag until adoption of the red-blue [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. People who hoisted the blue-yellow flags in the Soviet Ukraine were prosecuted as criminals{{citation needed|reason=sounds like an urban legend|date=August 2016}}. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following Ukrainian independence, before finally officially being restored on 28 January 1992 by the [[parliament of Ukraine]].[http://www.unian.info/society/1747301-ukraines-national-flag-celebrating-25th-anniversary-today.html Ukraine’s national flag celebrating 25th anniversary today], [[UNIAN]] (28 January 2017){{cite news|last=Trach|first=Nataliya|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/ukraine-politics/the-story-behind-2-top-ukrainian-symbols-national-flag-and-trident-421675.html|title=The story behind 2 top Ukrainian symbols: National flag and trident|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=26 August 2016|accessdate=27 August 2016}} Ukraine has celebrated [[Flag Day in Ukraine|Flag Day]] each year on August 23 since 2004.[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2012-08/23/c_131803737.htm Ukraine celebrates National Flag Day], [[Xinhua News Agency]] (August 23, 2012)
[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/kyiv/ceremony-of-hoisting-ukraines-national-flag-held-a-111423.html Ceremony of hoisting Ukraine's national flag held at presidential administration], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (August 23, 2011)
[http://tsn.ua/ukrayina/ukrayina-vidznachaye-den-derzhavnogo-prapora.html Україна відзначає День Державного прапора "On Tuesday, August 23, all of Ukraine celebrates National Flag Day. Measures to raise the national flag are planned throughout the country."], [[1+1 (channel)|1+1]] (August 23, 2011)
llm_output:
Added context about the historical significance of the blue and yellow flag as a symbol of Ukrainian lands, specifically referencing the flag of the Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia used in the 12th century.

Not Weaponised – The addition provides historical context without employing divisive or politically charged language. It enhances understanding of Ukrainian cultural heritage without framing it in a confrontational manner.

changed_version:
---

@@ -203,7 +203,7 @@
 
 Other reliable version is that since the one of first known colour depictions of Kyiv Coat of Arms (<ref>https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_Kiev#/media/File:COA_of_Kiev_1480.png</ref>) was mainly in yellow-blue colours, which may presume, that this tradition was held since nordic-slavic from his origins Volodymyr (Valdemar) the Great Konung of Kyiv and earlier (Great Prince, after adoption of Byzantium Christianity). At least, when Poltava battle was held, Cossacks of Mazepa were struggling under the yellow-blue banners, while their Swedish allies – under  yellow ones. (by the depiction <ref>https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Poltava#/media/File:Marten%27s_Poltava.jpg</ref>).
 
-=== Yellow-blue vs blue-yellow ===
+===Yellow-blue vs blue-yellow===
 Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as '''yellow and light blue''' (жовто-блакитний, ''zhovto-blakytnyi'')<ref>A little less often they  use also "yellow and blue", "blue and yellow" and "yellow and azure".</ref>—a different version of the flag used during UNR ([[Ukrainian National Republic]]) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. The yellow on the top represents golden domes ([[cupola]]s) of Christian churches and the blue the [[Dnieper]] river.
 
 It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the spoken language as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy''), the current flag in reality is blue (the upper band) and yellow (the lower band). The issue is quite significant, because the historical alteration of the flag (from yellow–blue to blue–yellow) did not affect the spoken language.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} Back in 1848 the flag was indeed yellow and blue,{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} and it was later changed to blue and yellow to be more appealing to the common person.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} The common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time,{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} and, although this evocation of a Ukrainian landscape has nothing to do with the choice of colours or the history of the original yellow and blue, it certainly has formed the Ukrainians' conception of their flag.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}}

Not Weaponised – The change is purely formatting and does not alter the content or introduce any weaponised language.

 ===Stamps===

-The flag did not appear on Ukrainian official postal stamp issues until the 1992 was released, depicting the flag with state coat of arms.  Since that time the flag has frequently appeared on stamps. [[Cinderella stamp]]s of the [[Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists]] were printed outside Ukraine during the Soviet period and served propaganda purposes.
+The flag did not appear on Ukrainian official postal stamp issues until the 1992 was released, depicting the flag with state coat of arms.  Since that time the flag has frequently appeared on stamps. [[Cinderella stamp]]s of the [[Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists]] were printed outside Ukraine during the Soviet period and served patriotic purposes.
 
 ===Decoration===
 Traditionally, the flag may be decorated with a [[gold (color)|golden]] [[Fringe (trim)|fringe]] surrounding the perimeter of the flag, as long as it does not deface the flag proper. The beginning of this tradition was the [[flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. The ''[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia]]'' shows a flag decorated with a gold star. Ceremonial displays of the flag, such as those in parades or on indoor posts, often use a fringe to enhance the beauty of the flag. No specific law governs the legality of this fringe. Traditionally, the [[Ukrainian Ground Forces|Army]], [[National Guard of Ukraine|Guard]], [[Ukrainian Navy|Navy]] and [[Ukrainian Air Force|Air Force]] use a fringed flag for [[military parade|parades]], [[color guard]]s and indoor displays, while the [[President of Ukraine|Office of the President]] and local authorities use a fringed flag for all purposes.

 Both blue–yellow and yellow–blue flags were widely used during the [[Ukraine after the Russian Revolution|Ukrainian struggle for independence]] in 1917. For the first time in the [[Russian Empire]] the blue-yellow flag was flown on March 25, 1917 in [[Petrograd]] during a 20-thousand people mass [[Demonstration (protest)|demonstration]].<ref name=istpravda/> On the territory of the Russian Ukraine ([[Little Russia]]) the national flag of Ukraine was flown for the first time in [[Kiev]] on March 29, 1917 by soldiers.<ref name=istpravda/> On April 1, 1917 Kiev saw a 100-thousand people demonstration that carried over 320 national flags.<ref name=istpravda/> After that similar demonstration with Ukrainian flags took place across the whole [[Russian Empire]] even beyond the Ukrainian ethnic lands.<ref name=istpravda/> Numerous famous Ukrainian politician wrote their recollection about the April 1 demonstration such as [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] and [[Serhiy Yefremov]] stating that there were blue-and-yellow flags, while [[Dmytro Doroshenko]] claimed that there were yellow-and-blue.<ref name=istpravda/> The blue-yellow flag was flown at the First Ukrainian Military Congress on May 18, 1917.<ref name=istpravda/>

Since that time the flag has frequently appeared on stamps. [[Cinderella stamp]]s of the [[Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists]] were printed outside Ukraine during the Soviet period and served propaganda purposes.
 
 ===Decoration===
 Traditionally, the flag may be decorated with a [[gold (color)|golden]] [[Fringe (trim)|fringe]] surrounding the perimeter of the flag, as long as it does not deface the flag proper. The beginning of this tradition was the [[flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. The ''[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia]]'' shows a flag decorated with a gold star. Ceremonial displays of the flag, such as those in parades or on indoor posts, often use a fringe to enhance the beauty of the flag. No specific law governs the legality of this fringe. Traditionally, the [[Ukrainian Ground Forces|Army]], [[National Guard of Ukraine|Guard]], [[Ukrainian Navy|Navy]] and [[Ukrainian Air Force|Air Force]] use a fringed flag for [[military parade|parades]], [[color guard]]s and indoor displays, while the [[President of Ukraine|Office of the President]] and local authorities use a fringed flag for all purposes.

+===Soviet Ukraine: 1922–1991===
 {{Main|Flag of the Ukrainian SSR}}
 The first flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic was adopted on March 10, 1919, to serve as the symbol of state of the [[Soviet Ukraine]]. Details of the official flag changed periodically before the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991, but all were based on the red flag of the [[October Revolution]] in Russia and an exact replica of the [[Soviet Russia]].
 The first flag was red with the gold Cyrillic sans-serif letters У.С.С.Р. (USSR, acronym for Ukrayinskaya Sotsialisticheskaya Sovetskaya Respublika in the Russian language). In the 1930s a gold border was added. In 1937, a new flag was adopted, with a small gold hammer and sickle added above the gold Cyrillic serif letters У.Р.С.Р. (URSR, for Ukrayins’ka Radyans’ka Sotsialistychna Respublika in the Ukrainian language).

-The [[Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists]] is a Ukrainian political organisation which as a movement originally was created in 1929 in Western Ukraine (at the time [[Second Polish Republic|interwar Poland]]). For long time OUN did not officially have its own flag, however during the Hungarian and Polish aggression against the Carpathian Ukraine in 1938, Carpathian Sich, a militarised wing of OUN, adopted its flag from the OUN's emblem – golden nationalistic trident on a blue background. The flag was finalised and officially adopted by the organisation only in 1964 at the 5th Assembly of Ukrainian Nationalists.
-
-The [[Ukrainian Insurgent Army]] was a Ukrainian nationalist paramilitary and later partisan army that engaged in a series of guerrilla conflicts during [[World War II]] against [[Nazi Germany]], the [[Soviet Union]], [[Czechoslovakia]], and both [[Home Army|Underground]] and [[Polish People's Republic|Communist Poland]]. The group was the military wing of the [[Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists#Split in the OUN|Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists — Bandera faction]] (the OUN-B), originally formed in [[Volyn]] in the spring and summer of 1943. Its official date of creation is October 14, 1942, day of Intercession of the Theotokos feast. The battle flag of the UPA was a 2:3 ratio red-and-black banner. The flag continues to be a symbol of the Ukrainian nationalist movement. The colours of the flag symbolise 'Ukrainian red blood spilled on Ukrainian black earth'.
+The Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists is a Ukrainian political organisation which as a movement originally was created in 1929 in Western Ukraine (at the time interwar Poland). For long time OUN did not officially have its own flag, however during the Hungarian and Polish aggression against the Carpathian Ukraine in 1938, Carpathian Sich, a militarised wing of OUN, adopted its flag from the OUN's emblem – golden nationalistic trident on a blue background. The flag was finalised and officially adopted by the organisation only in 1964 at the 5th Assembly of Ukrainian Nationalists.
+
+The Ukrainian Insurgent Army was a Ukrainian nationalist paramilitary and later partisan army that engaged in a series of guerrilla conflicts during World War II against Nazi Germany, the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, and both Underground and Communist Poland. The group was the military wing of the Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists — Bandera faction (the OUN-B), originally formed in Volyn in the spring and summer of 1943. Its official date of creation is October 14, 1942,[1] day of Intercession of the Theotokos feast. The battle flag of the UPA was a 2:3 ratio red-and-black banner. The flag continues to be a symbol of the Ukrainian nationalist movement. The colours of the flag symbolise 'Ukrainian red blood spilled on Ukrainian black earth'.

The [[Free Territory|anarchist free-soviets]] that existed during the [[Ukrainian War of Independence|civil war]] used the black flag.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -201,9 +201,9 @@
 {{main|National colours of Ukraine}}
 
 ===Origin===
-Some of the theories{{which|date=January 2014}} said that Ukrainian flag was given by the [[Silesia]]n knight{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} from the city of [[Opole]]—[[Władysław Opolczyk]], Hungarian governor of [[Galicia–Volhynia]]. It has the same colours as the flag of [[Opole]].
-
-Other reliable version is that since the one of first known colour depictions of Kyiv Coat of Arms (<ref>https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_Kiev#/media/File:COA_of_Kiev_1480.png</ref>) was mainly in yellow-blue colours, which may presume, that this tradition was held since nordic-slavic from his origins Volodymyr (Valdemar) the Great Konung of Kyiv and earlier (Great Prince, after adoption of Byzantium Christianity). At least, when Poltava battle was held, Cossacks of Mazepa were struggling under the yellow-blue banners, while their Swedish allies – under  yellow ones. (by the depiction <ref>https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Poltava#/media/File:Marten%27s_Poltava.jpg</ref>).
+One claimed version is that since the one of first known colour depictions of Kyiv Coat of Arms was mainly in yellow-blue colours, which may presume, that this tradition was held since nordic-slavic from his origins Volodymyr, the Great Konung of Kyiv and earlier (Great Prince, after adoption of Byzantium Christianity). At least, when Poltava battle was held, Cossacks of Mazepa were struggling under the yellow-blue banners, while their Swedish allies – under yellow ones.
+
+In reality, however, the blue-yellow coloring dates back to Kyivan Ruthenia, as an early version of the Tryzub, Ukraine's national coat of arms, sported the same coloring as the seal for Sviatoslav I of Kyiv (945).
 
 ===Yellow-blue vs blue-yellow===
 Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as '''yellow and light blue''' (жовто-блакитний, ''zhovto-blakytnyi'')<ref>A little less often they  use also "yellow and blue", "blue and yellow" and "yellow and azure".</ref>—a different version of the flag used during UNR ([[Ukrainian National Republic]]) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. The yellow on the top represents golden domes ([[cupola]]s) of Christian churches and the blue the [[Dnieper]] river.

-The roots of Ukrainian national symbols come from before Christian times when yellow and blue prevailed in traditional ceremonies, reflecting fire and water.<ref name=Saprykov>[http://geraldika.ru/symbols/3334 Geraldika.ru Флаг Украины]</ref> The most solid proof of yellow and blue colours could be traced as far as the [[Battle of Grunwald]] at which participated militia formations from various lands of the Polish-Lithuanian Union.
+The roots of Ukrainian national symbols come from before Christian times when yellow and blue prevailed in traditional ceremonies, reflecting fire and water.<ref name=Saprykov>{{cite web|url=http://geraldika.ru/symbols/3334|script-title=ru:Флаг Украины|trans-title=Flag of Ukraine|language=ru|first=V.|last=Saprykov|website=geraldika.ru|date=May 30, 2003|accessdate=October 2, 2017}}</ref> The most solid proof of yellow and blue colours could be traced as far as the [[Battle of Grunwald]] at which participated militia formations from various lands of the Polish-Lithuanian Union.
 
 Yellow–blue, red-black, crimson-olive and especially raspberry colour banners were widely used by [[Cossack]]s between the 16th and 18th centuries. These were not the only possible combinations, since normally Cossacks would fly their [[hetman]]'s banners, which were similar to the coats of arms of the nobility. Also, yellow and blue were the colours common on coats of arms in [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]]. In fact, the coat of arms of [[Lviv]] to this day remains a golden lion on a blue field.

+Some put the starting point of the current national flag of Ukraine in year 1848, when during the [[The Revolutions of 1848 in the Habsburg areas|Spring of the Nations]] on 22 April 1848 a yellow and blue banner was adopted by the [[Main Ruthenian Council]]<ref name=istpravda>[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/articles/2014/01/14/140850/ Blue-yellow or yellow-blue? Myths about the flipped flag (Синьо-жовтий чи жовто-блакитний? Міфи про "перевернутий" прапор)]. ''[[Ukrayinska Pravda]]''. +

 Yellow–blue, red-black, crimson-olive and especially raspberry colour banners were widely used by [[Cossack]]s between the 16th and 18th centuries. These were not the only possible combinations, since normally Cossacks would fly their [[hetman]]'s banners, which were similar to the coats of arms of the nobility. Also, yellow and blue were the colours common on coats of arms in [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]]. In fact, the coat of arms of [[Lviv]] to this day remains a golden lion on a blue field.
 
-Some put the starting point of the current national flag of Ukraine in year 1848, when during the [[The Revolutions of 1848 in the Habsburg areas|Spring of the Nations]] on 22 April 1848 a yellow and blue banner was adopted by the [[Main Ruthenian Council]]<ref name=istpravda>[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/articles/2014/01/14/140850/ Blue-yellow or yellow-blue? Myths about the flipped flag (Синьо-жовтий чи жовто-блакитний? Міфи про "перевернутий" прапор)]. ''[[Ukrayinska Pravda]]''. January 14, 2014</ref> in Lemberg ([[Lviv]]), a capital of the [[Kingdom of Galicia and Lodomeria]], and flew over the city's magistrate for the first time. Although this move did not have significant consequences, the newly formed Ukrainian divisions in the Austrian army used yellow and blue banners in their insignia.
+Some put the starting point of the adoption of the current national flag of Ukraine to 1848 when, during the [[The Revolutions of 1848 in the Habsburg areas|Spring of the Nations]] on 22 April 1848, a yellow and blue banner was adopted by the [[Main Ruthenian Council]]<ref name=istpravda>[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/articles/2014/01/14/140850/ Blue-yellow or yellow-blue? Myths about the flipped flag (Синьо-жовтий чи жовто-блакитний? Міфи про "перевернутий" прапор)]. ''[[Ukrayinska Pravda]]''. January 14, 2014</ref> in Lemberg ([[Lviv]]), the capital of the [[Kingdom of Galicia and Lodomeria]], and flew over the city's magistrate for the first time. Although this move did not have significant consequences, the newly formed Ukrainian divisions in the Austrian army used yellow and blue banners in their insignia.
 
 During the Russian [[Revolution of 1905]], this flag started to be used by Ukrainians of the [[Dnieper Ukraine]], or the Russian part of Ukraine.

+* November: 21 (Day of Dignity and Freedom)
 
 ===Display at half-staff===
 The flag is displayed at half-staff (half-mast in naval usage) as a sign of respect or mourning. Nationwide, this action is proclaimed by the president. Half-mast means the flag is flown two-thirds of the way up the flagpole with at least the height of the flag between the top of the flag and the top of the flagpole. Black ribbons indicate mourning on banners that can't be lowered to halfmast.

In 1958 in village of Verbytsia, [[:uk:Ходорівський район|Khodoriv Raion]] there was established an underground group, members of which at night were raising national flags and spread anti-Soviet pamphlets.[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/columns/2011/07/29/48180/ Unknown flag-bearers. Yellow-blue against Red (Невідомі прапороносці. Жовто-блакитний проти червоного)]. ''[[Ukrayinska Pravda]]''. July 29, 2011 ===Return of the national flag=== +[[File:Flag of Ukraine (1991-1992).svg|left|thumb|First version of the current flag
{{small|(1991–92)}}]] [[File:Kiev 24.7.1990 Ukrainian Flag.JPG|right|upright|thumb|The Ukrainian national flag was raised outside Kiev's [[Kiev City Council|City Hall]] for the first time on 24 July 1990]] [[File:Waving the Ukrainian flag.jpg|thumbnail|right|A girl with flag at [[vyshyvanka]] parade]] Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[perestroika]] and [[glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national identity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1982–91)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed.
