{{small|(originally)}}
1991
{{small|(in [[Dissolution of the USSR|post-Soviet]] era)}}
1992
{{small|(current version)}} |Design = A horizontal [[bicolour (flag)|bicolour]] of blue and yellow |Image2 = Naval Ensign of Ukraine.svg | Nickname2 = Naval ensign @@ -17,7 +17,7 @@ |Proportion2 = 2:3 |Design2 = White with a blue cotised symmetric cross that extends to the edges of the flag, and with the national bi-colour in the canton. }} -The '''state flag of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|державний прапор України}}; [[Romanisation of Ukrainian|translit.]]: ''derzhavnyi prapor Ukrainy''; literally 'state flag of Ukraine') is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]]). +The '''flag of Ukraine''' is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]]). Combination of blue and yellow as a symbol of Ukrainian lands comes from the flag of the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia]] used in 12th century. As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolour has been officially used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]] when it was hoisted over the [[Lviv Town Hall|Lviv Rathaus]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]], and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the flag was outlawed and before 1949 there was no official state flag until adoption of the red-blue [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. People who hoisted the blue-yellow flags in the Soviet Ukraine were prosecuted as criminals{{citation needed|reason=sounds like an urban legend|date=August 2016}}. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following Ukrainian independence, before finally officially being restored on 28 January 1992 by the [[parliament of Ukraine]].[http://www.unian.info/society/1747301-ukraines-national-flag-celebrating-25th-anniversary-today.html Ukraine’s national flag celebrating 25th anniversary today], [[UNIAN]] (28 January 2017){{cite news|last=Trach|first=Nataliya|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/ukraine-politics/the-story-behind-2-top-ukrainian-symbols-national-flag-and-trident-421675.html|title=The story behind 2 top Ukrainian symbols: National flag and trident|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=26 August 2016|accessdate=27 August 2016}}

Yellow-blue against Red (Невідомі прапороносці. Жовто-блакитний проти червоного)]. ''[[Ukrayinska Pravda]]''. July 29, 2011 ===Return of the national flag=== -[[File:Flag of Ukraine (1991-1992).svg|left|thumb|First version of the current flag
{{small|(1991–92)}}]] [[File:Kiev 24.7.1990 Ukrainian Flag.JPG|right|upright|thumb|The Ukrainian national flag was raised outside Kiev's [[Kiev City Council|City Hall]] for the first time on 24 July 1990]] [[File:Waving the Ukrainian flag.jpg|thumbnail|right|A girl with flag at [[vyshyvanka]] parade]] Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[perestroika]] and [[glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national identity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1982–91)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed.

As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolour has been officially used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]] when it was hoisted over the [[Lviv Town Hall|Lviv Rathaus]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]], and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. People who hoisted the blue-yellow flags in the Soviet Ukraine were prosecuted as criminals{{citation needed|reason=sounds like an urban legend|date=August 2016}}. changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -112,7 +112,7 @@
 
 ==History==
 [[File:Flag colors.jpg|thumb|Typical agricultural landscape of Ukraine, [[Kherson Oblast]]]]
-[[File:Ilja Jefimowitsch Repin - Reply of the Zaporozhian Cossacks - Yorck.jpg|thumb|left|Yellow–blue and red-black Cossack flags at ''[[Reply of the Zaporozhian Cossacks]]'' painting by [[Ilya Repin]], 1880–1891.]]
+[[File:Ilja Jefimowitsch Repin - Reply of the Zaporozhian Cossacks - Yorck.jpg|thumb|left|225px|Cossack flags at ''[[Reply of the Zaporozhian Cossacks]]'' painting by [[Ilya Repin]], 1880–1891.]]
 The roots of Ukrainian national symbols come from before Christian times when yellow and blue prevailed in traditional ceremonies, reflecting fire and water.<ref name=Saprykov>{{cite web|url=http://geraldika.ru/symbols/3334|script-title=ru:Флаг Украины|trans-title=Flag of Ukraine|language=ru|first=V.|last=Saprykov|website=geraldika.ru|date=May 30, 2003|accessdate=October 2, 2017}}</ref> The most solid proof of yellow and blue colours could be traced as far as the [[Battle of Grunwald]] at which participated militia formations from various lands of the Polish-Lithuanian Union.
 
 Yellow–blue, red-black, crimson-olive and especially raspberry colour banners were widely used by [[Cossack]]s between the 16th and 18th centuries. These were not the only possible combinations, since normally Cossacks would fly their [[hetman]]'s banners, which were similar to the coats of arms of the nobility. Also, yellow and blue were the colours common on coats of arms in [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]]. In fact, the coat of arms of [[Lviv]] to this day remains a golden lion on a blue field.

 The events in the Baltic countries soon led to similar processes in Ukraine. Particularly, West Ukraine and [[Ukrainian SSR]]'s capital [[Kiev]] (''Kyiv'') constantly held political demonstrations with the national yellow-and-blue flags waving above the heads of demonstrators.
 * On March 14, 1990, the Ukrainian flag was raised for the first time after the establishment of the Soviet Union in the small city of [[Stryi]].<ref>[http://www.ukrinform.ua/ukr/news/istoriya_evolyutsiii_dergavnogo_prapora_ukraiini_infografika_2084779 History of evolution of the State Flag of Ukraine] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150817220933/http://www.ukrinform.ua/ukr/news/istoriya_evolyutsiii_dergavnogo_prapora_ukraiini_infografika_2084779 |date=August 17, 2015 }}. [[Ukrinform]]. August 23, 2015</ref>
-* On March 20, 1990, the town council of [[Ternopil]] voted upon the usage and re-establishment of the yellow-and-blue flag and the [[Coat of arms of Ukraine|''tryzub'']] as well as the national anthem ''[[Ukraine's glory has not perished|Shche ne vmerla Ukrainy]]''. On the same day, the yellow-and-blue national flag was flown for the first time in about 80 years on a governmental building in Kiev, replacing the then official [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|red-and-blue flag]] of the Ukrainian SSR.
+* On March 20, 1990, the town council of [[Ternopil]] voted upon the usage and re-establishment of the yellow-and-blue flag and the [[Coat of arms of Ukraine|''tryzub'']] as well as the national anthem ''[[Ukraine's glory has not perished|Shche ne vmerla Ukrainy]]''. On the same day, the yellow-and-blue national flag was flown for the first time in about 80 years on a governmental building in Kiev, replacing the then official [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|red-azure flag]] of the Ukrainian SSR.
 * On April 28, 1990, the oblast council (''oblasna rada'') of [[Lviv Oblast|Lviv]] also allowed the use of the national symbols of Ukraine within the Oblast.
 * On April 29, 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown from the Ternopil city theater's flagstaff without the [[Flag of the Soviet Union|official flag of the Soviet Union]] hanging above it.
 * After July 24, 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown for the first time over an official governmental building of the [[Kiev City Council]] on the ''[[Maidan Nezalezhnosti]]'' square of the ''[[Khreschatyk]]'' street.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/ukrainian/politics/2012/07/120724_flag_ukraine_history_kyiv_as.shtml Twenty two years ago in Kiev officially was raised the blue-yellow flag (22 роки тому в Києві офіційно підняли синьо-жовтий прапор)]. BBC Ukraine. July 24, 2012.</ref>

 ===Decoration===
-Traditionally, the flag may be decorated with a [[gold (color)|golden]] [[Fringe (trim)|fringe]] surrounding the perimeter of the flag, as long as it does not deface the flag proper. The beginning of this tradition was the [[flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. The ''[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia]]'' shows a flag decorated with a gold star. Ceremonial displays of the flag, such as those in parades or on indoor posts, often use a fringe to enhance the beauty of the flag. No specific law governs the legality of this fringe. Traditionally, the [[Ukrainian Ground Forces|Army]], [[National Guard of Ukraine|Guard]], [[Ukrainian Navy|Navy]] and [[Ukrainian Air Force|Air Force]] use a fringed flag for [[military parade|parades]], [[color guard]]s and indoor displays, while the [[President of Ukraine|Office of the President]] and local authorities use a fringed flag for all purposes.

 ===Interbellum Ukraine===
 The Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists is a Ukrainian political organisation which as a movement originally was created in 1929 in Western Ukraine (at the time interwar Poland). For long time OUN did not officially have its own flag, however during the Hungarian and Polish aggression against the Carpathian Ukraine in 1938, Carpathian Sich, a militarised wing of OUN, adopted its flag from the OUN's emblem – golden nationalistic trident on a blue background. The flag was finalised and officially adopted by the organisation only in 1964 at the 5th Assembly of Ukrainian Nationalists.
 
-The Ukrainian Insurgent Army was a Ukrainian nationalist paramilitary and later partisan army that engaged in a series of guerrilla conflicts during World War II against Nazi Germany, the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, and both Underground and Communist Poland. The group was the military wing of the Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists — Bandera faction (the OUN-B), originally formed in Volyn in the spring and summer of 1943. Its official date of creation is October 14, 1942,[1] day of Intercession of the Theotokos feast. The battle flag of the UPA was a 2:3 ratio red-and-black banner. The flag continues to be a symbol of the Ukrainian nationalist movement. The colours of the flag symbolise 'Ukrainian red blood spilled on Ukrainian black earth'.
+The Ukrainian Insurgent Army was a Ukrainian nationalist paramilitary and later partisan army that engaged in a series of guerrilla conflicts during World War II against Nazi Germany, the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, and both Underground and Communist Poland. The group was the military wing of the Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists — Bandera faction (the OUN-B), originally formed in Volyn in the spring and summer of 1943. Its official date of creation is 14 October 1942, day of Intercession of the Theotokos feast. The battle flag of the UPA was a 2:3 ratio red-and-black banner. The flag continues to be a symbol of the Ukrainian nationalist movement. The colours of the flag symbolise 'Ukrainian red blood spilled on Ukrainian black earth'.

 {{main|Day of the National Flag (Ukraine)}}
 
-August 23 is celebrated as the Day of the National Flag in Ukraine; beginning with 2004. July 24 was previously marked as National Flag Day in Kiev. The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on July 24, 1990 at the flagstaff of the Kiev City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992 Independence Day of Ukraine is celebrated on August 24. Following government decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this dates and some other holidays. Not all of these days are public holidays. Flags also must be flown on election days for the [[Verkhovna Rada]]  in addition to other regional-specific flag days. The public display of flags to mark other events, such as the election of the president or the death of a prominent politician (whereupon flags would be at half-mast), can be declared at the discretion of the Cabinet of Ministers. When flags are required to be flown at half-mast, vertical flags are not lowered. A black mourning ribbon is instead attached, either atop the mast (if hung from a pole) or to each end of the flag's supporting cross-beams (if flown like a banner).
+23 August is celebrated as the Day of the National Flag in Ukraine; beginning with 2004. 24 July was previously marked as National Flag Day in Kiev. The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on 24 July 1990 at the flagstaff of the Kiev City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992 Independence Day of Ukraine is celebrated on 24 August. Following government decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this dates and some other holidays. Not all of these days are public holidays. Flags also must be flown on election days for the [[Verkhovna Rada]]  in addition to other regional-specific flag days. The public display of flags to mark other events, such as the election of the president or the death of a prominent politician (whereupon flags would be at half-mast), can be declared at the discretion of the Cabinet of Ministers. When flags are required to be flown at half-mast, vertical flags are not lowered. A black mourning ribbon is instead attached, either atop the mast (if hung from a pole) or to each end of the flag's supporting cross-beams (if flown like a banner).

+The first flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic was adopted on 10 March 1919, to serve as the symbol of state of the [[Soviet Ukraine]]. Details of the official flag changed periodically before the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991, but all were based on the red flag of the [[October Revolution]] in Russia and an exact replica of the [[Soviet Russia]].
 The first flag was red with the gold Cyrillic sans-serif letters У.С.С.Р. (USSR, acronym for Ukrayinskaya Sotsialisticheskaya Sovetskaya Respublika in the Russian language). In the 1930s a gold border was added. In 1937, a new flag was adopted, with a small gold hammer and sickle added above the gold Cyrillic serif letters У.Р.С.Р. (URSR, for Ukrayins’ka Radyans’ka Sotsialistychna Respublika in the Ukrainian language).

 ===Decoration===
-Traditionally, the flag may be decorated with a [[gold (color)|golden]] [[Fringe (trim)|fringe]] surrounding the perimeter of the flag, as long as it does not deface the flag proper. The beginning of this tradition was the [[flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. The ''[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia]]'' shows a flag decorated with a gold star. Ceremonial displays of the flag, such as those in parades or on indoor posts, often use a fringe to enhance the beauty of the flag. No specific law governs the legality of this fringe. Traditionally, the [[Ukrainian Ground Forces|Army]], [[National Guard of Ukraine|Guard]], [[Ukrainian Navy|Navy]] and [[Ukrainian Air Force|Air Force]] use a fringed flag for [[military parade|parades]], [[color guard|colour guards]]s and indoor displays, while the [[President of Ukraine|Office of the President]] and local authorities use a fringed flag for all purposes.

 {{main|Day of the National Flag (Ukraine)}}
 
-23 August is celebrated as the Day of the National Flag in Ukraine; beginning with 2004. 24 July was previously marked as National Flag Day in Kiev. The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on 24 July 1990 at the flagstaff of the Kiev City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992 Independence Day of Ukraine is celebrated on 24 August. Following government decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this dates and some other holidays. Not all of these days are public holidays. Flags also must be flown on election days for the [[Verkhovna Rada]]  in addition to other regional-specific flag days. The public display of flags to mark other events, such as the election of the president or the death of a prominent politician (whereupon flags would be at half-mast), can be declared at the discretion of the Cabinet of Ministers. When flags are required to be flown at half-mast, vertical flags are not lowered. A black mourning ribbon is instead attached, either atop the mast (if hung from a pole) or to each end of the flag's supporting cross-beams (if flown like a banner).
+August 23 is celebrated as the Day of the National Flag in Ukraine; beginning with 2004. July 24 was previously marked as National Flag Day in Kiev. The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on July 24, 1990 at the flagstaff of the Kiev City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992 Independence Day of Ukraine is celebrated on August 24. Following government decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this dates and some other holidays. Not all of these days are public holidays. Flags also must be flown on election days for the [[Verkhovna Rada]]  in addition to other regional-specific flag days. The public display of flags to mark other events, such as the election of the president or the death of a prominent politician (whereupon flags would be at half-mast), can be declared at the discretion of the Cabinet of Ministers. When flags are required to be flown at half-mast, vertical flags are not lowered. A black mourning ribbon is instead attached, either atop the mast (if hung from a pole) or to each end of the flag's supporting cross-beams (if flown like a banner).

+The first flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic was adopted on March 10, 1919, to serve as the symbol of state of the [[Soviet Ukraine]]. Details of the official flag changed periodically before the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991, but all were based on the red flag of the [[October Revolution]] in Russia and an exact replica of the [[Soviet Russia]].
 The first flag was red with the gold Cyrillic sans-serif letters У.С.С.Р. (USSR, acronym for Ukrayinskaya Sotsialisticheskaya Sovetskaya Respublika in the Russian language). In the 1930s a gold border was added. In 1937, a new flag was adopted, with a small gold hammer and sickle added above the gold Cyrillic serif letters У.Р.С.Р.  ===Interbellum Ukraine===
 The Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists is a Ukrainian political organisation which as a movement originally was created in 1929 in Western Ukraine (at the time interwar Poland). For long time OUN did not officially have its own flag, however during the Hungarian and Polish aggression against the Carpathian Ukraine in 1938, Carpathian Sich, a militarised wing of OUN, adopted its flag from the OUN's emblem – golden nationalistic trident on a blue background. The flag was finalised and officially adopted by the organisation only in 1964 at the 5th Assembly of Ukrainian Nationalists.
 
-The Ukrainian Insurgent Army was a Ukrainian nationalist paramilitary and later partisan army that engaged in a series of guerrilla conflicts during World War II against Nazi Germany, the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, and both Underground and Communist Poland. The group was the military wing of the Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists — Bandera faction (the OUN-B), originally formed in Volyn in the spring and summer of 1943. Its official date of creation is 14 October 1942, day of Intercession of the Theotokos feast. The battle flag of the UPA was a 2:3 ratio red-and-black banner. The flag continues to be a symbol of the Ukrainian nationalist movement. The colours of the flag symbolise 'Ukrainian red blood spilled on Ukrainian black earth'.
+The Ukrainian Insurgent Army was a Ukrainian nationalist paramilitary and later partisan army that engaged in a series of guerrilla conflicts during World War II against Nazi Germany, the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, and both Underground and Communist Poland. The group was the military wing of the Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists — Bandera faction (the OUN-B), originally formed in Volyn in the spring and summer of 1943. Its official date of creation is October 14, 1942,[1] day of Intercession of the Theotokos feast. The battle flag of the UPA was a 2:3 ratio red-and-black banner. The flag continues to be a symbol of the Ukrainian nationalist movement. The colours of the flag symbolise 'Ukrainian red blood spilled on Ukrainian black earth'.

 Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[perestroika]] and [[glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national identity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1982–91)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed.
 
 The events in the Baltic countries soon led to similar processes in Ukraine. Particularly, West Ukraine and [[Ukrainian SSR]]'s capital [[Kiev]] (''Kyiv'') constantly held political demonstrations with the national yellow-and-blue flags waving above the heads of demonstrators.
-* On 14 March 1990, the Ukrainian flag was raised for the first time after the establishment of the Soviet Union in the small city of [[Stryi]].<ref>[http://www.ukrinform.ua/ukr/news/istoriya_evolyutsiii_dergavnogo_prapora_ukraiini_infografika_2084779 History of evolution of the State Flag of Ukraine] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150817220933/http://www.ukrinform.ua/ukr/news/istoriya_evolyutsiii_dergavnogo_prapora_ukraiini_infografika_2084779 |date=August 17, 2015 }}. [[Ukrinform]]. August 23, 2015</ref>
-* On 20 March 1990, the town council of [[Ternopil]] voted upon the usage and re-establishment of the yellow-and-blue flag and the [[Coat of arms of Ukraine|''tryzub'']] as well as the national anthem ''[[Ukraine's glory has not perished|Shche ne vmerla Ukrainy]]''. On the same day, the yellow-and-blue national flag was flown for the first time in about 80 years on a governmental building in Kiev, replacing the then official [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|red-azure flag]] of the Ukrainian SSR.
-* On 28 April 1990, the oblast council (''oblasna rada'') of [[Lviv Oblast|Lviv]] also allowed the use of the national symbols of Ukraine within the Oblast.
-* On 29 April 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown from the Ternopil city theater's flagstaff without the [[Flag of the Soviet Union|official flag of the Soviet Union]] hanging above it.
-* After 24 July 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown for the first time over an official governmental building of the [[Kiev City Council]] on the ''[[Maidan Nezalezhnosti]]'' square of the ''[[Khreschatyk]]'' street.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/ukrainian/politics/2012/07/120724_flag_ukraine_history_kyiv_as.shtml Twenty two years ago in Kiev officially was raised the blue-yellow flag (22 роки тому в Києві офіційно підняли синьо-жовтий прапор)]. BBC Ukraine. July 24, 2012.</ref>
-* After the declaration of independence of Ukraine on 24 August 1991, the national yellow-and-blue flag flew for the first time over the [[Verkhovna Rada|Ukrainian Parliament (''Verkhovna Rada'')]] building on 4 September 1991.

 ==Flag of the head of state==
 Throughout the history of [[Ukraine]], various [[List of heads of state of Ukraine|heads of state]] have used different flags. The designs differ according to the historical era they were used in and in accordance with the political scene in [[Ukraine]] at the time. The first flag to be used by a [[List of heads of state of Ukraine|head of state of Ukraine]] was that of [[Pavlo Skoropadskyi]]. The current design, the flag of the [[President of Ukraine]], was adopted in 1991.

 ===Interbellum Ukraine===
-The Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists is a Ukrainian political organisation which as a movement originally was created in 1929 in Western Ukraine (at the time interwar Poland). For long time OUN did not officially have its own flag, however during the Hungarian and Polish aggression against the Carpathian Ukraine in 1938, Carpathian Sich, a militarised wing of OUN, adopted its flag from the OUN's emblem – golden nationalistic trident on a blue background. The flag was finalised and officially adopted by the organisation only in 1964 at the 5th Assembly of Ukrainian Nationalists.
+The Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists is a Ukrainian political organisation which as a movement originally was created in 1929 in Western Ukraine (at the time interwar Poland). For long time OUN did not officially have its own flag, however during the Hungarian and Polish aggression against the [[Republic of Carpathian Ukraine]] in 1939, Carpathian Sich, a militarised wing of OUN, adopted its flag from the OUN's emblem – golden nationalistic trident on a blue background. The flag was finalised and officially adopted by the organisation only in 1964 at the 5th Assembly of Ukrainian Nationalists.
 
 The Ukrainian Insurgent Army was a Ukrainian nationalist paramilitary and later partisan army that engaged in a series of guerrilla conflicts during World War II against Nazi Germany, the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, and both Underground and Communist Poland. The group was the military wing of the Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists — Bandera faction (the OUN-B), originally formed in Volyn in the spring and summer of 1943. Its official date of creation is October 14, 1942,[1] day of Intercession of the Theotokos feast. The battle flag of the UPA was a 2:3 ratio red-and-black banner. The flag continues to be a symbol of the Ukrainian nationalist movement. The colours of the flag symbolise 'Ukrainian red blood spilled on Ukrainian black earth'.

The flag of [[Ukraine]] was adopted on [[September 3]], [[1996]].  It had been the provisional flag since [[1991]].
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -188,12 +188,12 @@
 Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[perestroika]] and [[glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national identity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1982–91)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed.
 
 The events in the Baltic countries soon led to similar processes in Ukraine. Particularly, West Ukraine and [[Ukrainian SSR]]'s capital [[Kiev]] (''Kyiv'') constantly held political demonstrations with the national yellow-and-blue flags waving above the heads of demonstrators.
-* On March 14, 1990, the Ukrainian flag was raised for the first time after the establishment of the Soviet Union in the small city of [[Stryi]].<ref>[http://www.ukrinform.ua/ukr/news/istoriya_evolyutsiii_dergavnogo_prapora_ukraiini_infografika_2084779 History of evolution of the State Flag of Ukraine] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150817220933/http://www.ukrinform.ua/ukr/news/istoriya_evolyutsiii_dergavnogo_prapora_ukraiini_infografika_2084779 |date=August 17, 2015 }}. [[Ukrinform]]. August 23, 2015</ref>
-* On March 20, 1990, the town council of [[Ternopil]] voted upon the usage and re-establishment of the yellow-and-blue flag and the [[Coat of arms of Ukraine|''tryzub'']] as well as the national anthem ''[[Ukraine's glory has not perished|Shche ne vmerla Ukrainy]]''. On the same day, the yellow-and-blue national flag was flown for the first time in about 80 years on a governmental building in Kiev, replacing the then official [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|red-azure flag]] of the Ukrainian SSR.
-* On April 28, 1990, the oblast council (''oblasna rada'') of [[Lviv Oblast|Lviv]] also allowed the use of the national symbols of Ukraine within the Oblast.
-* On April 29, 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown from the Ternopil city theater's flagstaff without the [[Flag of the Soviet Union|official flag of the Soviet Union]] hanging above it.
-* After July 24, 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown for the first time over an official governmental building of the [[Kiev City Council]] on the ''[[Maidan Nezalezhnosti]]'' square of the ''[[Khreschatyk]]'' street.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/ukrainian/politics/2012/07/120724_flag_ukraine_history_kyiv_as.shtml Twenty two years ago in Kiev officially was raised the blue-yellow flag (22 роки тому в Києві офіційно підняли синьо-жовтий прапор)]. BBC Ukraine. July 24, 2012.</ref>
-* After the declaration of independence of Ukraine on August 24, 1991, the national yellow-and-blue flag flew for the first time over the [[Verkhovna Rada|Ukrainian Parliament (''Verkhovna Rada'')]] building on September 4, 1991.
+* On 14 March 1990, the Ukrainian flag was raised for the first time after the establishment of the Soviet Union in the small city of [[Stryi]].<ref>[http://www.ukrinform.ua/ukr/news/istoriya_evolyutsiii_dergavnogo_prapora_ukraiini_infografika_2084779 History of evolution of the State Flag of Ukraine] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150817220933/http://www.ukrinform.ua/ukr/news/istoriya_evolyutsiii_dergavnogo_prapora_ukraiini_infografika_2084779 |date=August 17, 2015 }}. [[Ukrinform]]. August 23, 2015</ref>
+* On 20 March 1990, the town council of [[Ternopil]] voted upon the usage and re-establishment of the yellow-and-blue flag and the [[Coat of arms of Ukraine|''tryzub'']] as well as the national anthem ''[[Ukraine's glory has not perished|Shche ne vmerla Ukrainy]]''. On the same day, the yellow-and-blue national flag was flown for the first time in about 80 years on a governmental building in Kiev, replacing the then official [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|red-azure flag]] of the Ukrainian SSR.
+* On 28 April 1990, the oblast council (''oblasna rada'') of [[Lviv Oblast|Lviv]] also allowed the use of the national symbols of Ukraine within the Oblast.
+* On 29 April 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown from the Ternopil city theater's flagstaff without the [[Flag of the Soviet Union|official flag of the Soviet Union]] hanging above it.
+* After 24 July 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown for the first time over an official governmental building of the [[Kiev City Council]] on the ''[[Maidan Nezalezhnosti]]'' square of the ''[[Khreschatyk]]'' street.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/ukrainian/politics/2012/07/120724_flag_ukraine_history_kyiv_as.shtml Twenty two years ago in Kiev officially was raised the blue-yellow flag (22 роки тому в Києві офіційно підняли синьо-жовтий прапор)]. BBC Ukraine. July 24, 2012.</ref>
+* After the declaration of independence of Ukraine on 24 August 1991, the national yellow-and-blue flag flew for the first time over the [[Verkhovna Rada|Ukrainian Parliament (''Verkhovna Rada'')]] building on 4 September 1991.

 The head of the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]], [[Andriy Grechylo]], points to the fact that the discussion about order of colours was taking place as far back as 1918.<ref name=grechylo>[http://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_hruschov-i-kaganovich-boyalisya-slova-zhovto-blakitnij/512859#photo-3 Khrushchev and Kaganovich were afraid of the word "zhovto-blakytnyi" (Хрущов і Каганович боялися слова "жовто-блакитний")]. Gazette in Ukrainian (gazeta.ua). It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. For the first time in the [[Russian Empire]] the blue-yellow flag was flown on March 25, 1917 in [[Petrograd]] during a 20-thousand people mass [[Demonstration (protest)|demonstration]].<ref name=istpravda/> On the territory of the Russian Ukraine ([[Little Russia]]) the national flag of Ukraine was flown for the first time in [[Kiev]] on March 29, 1917 by soldiers.<ref name=istpravda/> On April 1, 1917 Kiev saw a 100-thousand people demonstration that carried over 320 national flags.<ref name=istpravda/> After that similar demonstration with Ukrainian flags took place across the whole [[Russian Empire]] even beyond the Ukrainian ethnic lands.<ref name=istpravda/> Numerous famous Ukrainian politician wrote their recollection about the April 1 demonstration such as [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] and [[Serhiy Yefremov]] stating that there were blue-and-yellow flags, while [[Dmytro Doroshenko]] claimed that there were yellow-and-blue.<ref name=istpravda/> The blue-yellow flag was flown at the First Ukrainian Military Congress on May 18, 1917.<ref name=istpravda/>

Ukrayinska Terytorialna Heraldyka. Lviv, 2010, pp. 98–118. {{ISBN|978-966-02-5259-2}}</ref>
 
 The official flag of [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]]'s [[Ukrainian State|Hetmanate]] also was light blue–yellow and became the same under [[Symon Petlura]]'s [[Directorate of Ukraine|Directorate]]. The flag of [[West Ukrainian National Republic]] was blue and yellow. The [[Free Territory|anarchist free-soviets]] that existed during the [[Ukrainian War of Independence|civil war]] used the black flag.

+* 9 May: Memorial Day

+* 24 August: Independence Day

 ===Display at half-staff===
 The flag is displayed at half-staff (half-mast in naval usage) as a sign of respect or mourning. Nationwide, this action is proclaimed by the president. @@ -110,7 +110,7 @@
 [[File:Ukrflagblue.jpg|thumbnail|right|Flag at [[Kiev]] City Hall]]
 {{main|Day of the National Flag (Ukraine)}}
 
-August 23 is celebrated as the Day of the National Flag in Ukraine; beginning with 2004. July 24 was previously marked as National Flag Day in Kiev. The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on July 24, 1990 at the flagstaff of the Kiev City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992 Independence Day of Ukraine is celebrated on August 24. Following government decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this dates and some other holidays. Not all of these days are public holidays. Flags also must be flown on election days for the [[Verkhovna Rada]]  in addition to other regional-specific flag days. The public display of flags to mark other events, such as the election of the president or the death of a prominent politician (whereupon flags would be at half-mast), can be declared at the discretion of the Cabinet of Ministers. When flags are required to be flown at half-mast, vertical flags are not lowered. A black mourning ribbon is instead attached, either atop the mast (if hung from a pole) or to each end of the flag's supporting cross-beams (if flown like a banner).
+23 August is celebrated as the Day of the National Flag in Ukraine; beginning with 2004. 24 July was previously marked as National Flag Day in Kiev. The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on July 24, 1990 at the flagstaff of the Kiev City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992 Independence Day of Ukraine is celebrated on 24 August. Following government decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this dates and some other holidays. Not all of these days are public holidays. Flags also must be flown on election days for the [[Verkhovna Rada]]  in addition to other regional-specific flag days. The public display of flags to mark other events, such as the election of the president or the death of a prominent politician (whereupon flags would be at half-mast), can be declared at the discretion of the Cabinet of Ministers. When flags are required to be flown at half-mast, vertical flags are not lowered. A black mourning ribbon is instead attached, either atop the mast (if hung from a pole) or to each end of the flag's supporting cross-beams (if flown like a banner).
 {{clear}}
 
 ==History==

 Yellow–blue, red-black, crimson-olive and especially raspberry colour banners were widely used by [[Cossack]]s between the 16th and 18th centuries. These were not the only possible combinations, since normally Cossacks would fly their [[hetman]]'s banners, which were similar to the coats of arms of the nobility. Also, yellow and blue were the colours common on coats of arms in [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]]. In fact, the coat of arms of [[Lviv]] to this day remains a golden lion on a blue field.

 ===Soviet Ukraine: 1922–1991===
 {{Main|Flag of the Ukrainian SSR}}
-The first flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic was adopted on March 10, 1919, to serve as the symbol of state of the [[Soviet Ukraine]]. Details of the official flag changed periodically before the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991, but all were based on the red flag of the [[October Revolution]] in Russia and an exact replica of the [[Soviet Russia]].
+The first flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic was adopted on 10 March 1919, to serve as the symbol of state of the [[Soviet Ukraine]]. Details of the official flag changed periodically before the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991, but all were based on the red flag of the [[October Revolution]] in Russia and an exact replica of the [[Soviet Russia]].
 The first flag was red with the gold Cyrillic sans-serif letters У.С.С.Р. (USSR, acronym for Ukrayinskaya Sotsialisticheskaya Sovetskaya Respublika in the Russian language). In the 1930s a gold border was added. In 1937, a new flag was adopted, with a small gold hammer and sickle added above the gold Cyrillic serif letters У.Р.С.Р. (URSR, for Ukrayins’ka Radyans’ka Sotsialistychna Respublika in the Ukrainian language).
 
 {{gallery|mode=nolines|whitebg=y|height=100|align=center
@@ -185,12 +185,12 @@
 Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[perestroika]] and [[glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national identity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1982–91)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed.
 
 The events in the Baltic countries soon led to similar processes in Ukraine. Particularly, West Ukraine and [[Ukrainian SSR]]'s capital [[Kiev]] (''Kyiv'') constantly held political demonstrations with the national yellow-and-blue flags waving above the heads of demonstrators.
-* On March 14, 1990, the Ukrainian flag was raised for the first time after the establishment of the Soviet Union in the small city of [[Stryi]].<ref>[http://www.ukrinform.ua/ukr/news/istoriya_evolyutsiii_dergavnogo_prapora_ukraiini_infografika_2084779 History of evolution of the State Flag of Ukraine] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150817220933/http://www.ukrinform.ua/ukr/news/istoriya_evolyutsiii_dergavnogo_prapora_ukraiini_infografika_2084779 |date=August 17, 2015 }}. [[Ukrinform]]. August 23, 2015</ref>
-* On March 20, 1990, the town council of [[Ternopil]] voted upon the usage and re-establishment of the yellow-and-blue flag and the [[Coat of arms of Ukraine|''tryzub'']] as well as the national anthem ''[[Ukraine's glory has not perished|Shche ne vmerla Ukrainy]]''. On the same day, the yellow-and-blue national flag was flown for the first time in about 80 years on a governmental building in Kiev, replacing the then official [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|red-azure flag]] of the Ukrainian SSR.
-* On April 28, 1990, the oblast council (''oblasna rada'') of [[Lviv Oblast|Lviv]] also allowed the use of the national symbols of Ukraine within the Oblast.
-* On April 29, 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown from the Ternopil city theater's flagstaff without the [[Flag of the Soviet Union|official flag of the Soviet Union]] hanging above it.
-* After July 24, 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown for the first time over an official governmental building of the [[Kiev City Council]] on the ''[[Maidan Nezalezhnosti]]'' square of the ''[[Khreschatyk]]'' street.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/ukrainian/politics/2012/07/120724_flag_ukraine_history_kyiv_as.shtml Twenty two years ago in Kiev officially was raised the blue-yellow flag (22 роки тому в Києві офіційно підняли синьо-жовтий прапор)]. BBC Ukraine. July 24, 2012.</ref>
-* After the declaration of independence of Ukraine on August 24, 1991, the national yellow-and-blue flag flew for the first time over the [[Verkhovna Rada|Ukrainian Parliament (''Verkhovna Rada'')]] building on September 4, 1991.

 ===Interbellum Ukraine===
-The Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists is a Ukrainian political organisation which as a movement originally was created in 1929 in Western Ukraine (at the time interwar Poland). For long time OUN did not officially have its own flag, however during the Hungarian and Polish aggression against the [[Republic of Carpathian Ukraine]] in 1939, Carpathian Sich, a militarised wing of OUN, adopted its flag from the OUN's emblem – golden nationalistic trident on a blue background. The flag was finalised and officially adopted by the organisation only in 1964 at the 5th Assembly of Ukrainian Nationalists.
+The Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists is a Ukrainian political organisation which as a movement originally was created in 1929 in Western Ukraine (at the time interwar Poland). For long time OUN did not officially have its own flag; however, during the Hungarian and Polish aggression against the [[Republic of Carpathian Ukraine]] in 1939, Carpathian Sich, a militarised wing of OUN, adopted its flag from the OUN's emblem – golden nationalistic trident on a blue background. The flag was finalised and officially adopted by the organisation only in 1964 at the 5th Assembly of Ukrainian Nationalists.
 
 The Ukrainian Insurgent Army was a Ukrainian nationalist paramilitary and later partisan army that engaged in a series of guerrilla conflicts during World War II against Nazi Germany, the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, and both Underground and Communist Poland. The group was the military wing of the Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists — Bandera faction (the OUN-B), originally formed in Volyn in the spring and summer of 1943. Its official date of creation is October 14, 1942,[1] day of Intercession of the Theotokos feast. The battle flag of the UPA was a 2:3 ratio red-and-black banner. The flag continues to be a symbol of the Ukrainian nationalist movement. The colours of the flag symbolise 'Ukrainian red blood spilled on Ukrainian black earth'.

 * 1 & 2 May: [[International Workers' Day]]
 * 9 May: Victory Day over Nazism
 * 28 June: Constitution Day
+* 23 August: Flag Day
 * 24 August: Independence Day
 * 21 November: Day of Dignity and Freedom
+* 6 December: Armed Forces Day
+* 25 December: Western Christmas
 
 ===Display at half-staff===
 The flag is displayed at half-staff (half-mast in naval usage) as a sign of respect or mourning. Nationwide, this action is proclaimed by the president. Half-mast means the flag is flown two-thirds of the way up the flagpole with at least the height of the flag between the top of the flag and the top of the flagpole. Black ribbons indicate mourning on banners that can't be lowered to halfmast.

--- +++ @@ -19,7 +19,7 @@ }} The '''flag of [[Ukraine]]''' is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]]). -The flag of [[Ukraine]] is a combination of two colors where the top represents the sky and the yellow represents the wheat. The combination of blue and yellow as a symbol of Ukrainian lands comes from the flag of the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia]] used in the 12th century. As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolour has been officially used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]], when it was hoisted over the [[Lviv Town Hall|Lviv Rathaus]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the flag was outlawed and, before 1949, there was no official state flag until adoption of the red-azure [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]].  Traditionally, the flag may be decorated with a [[gold (color)|golden]] [[Fringe (trim)|fringe]] surrounding the perimeter of the flag, as long as it does not deface the flag proper. The beginning of this tradition was the [[flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. The ''[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia]]'' shows a flag decorated with a gold star. Ceremonial displays of the flag, such as those in parades or on indoor posts, often use a fringe to enhance the beauty of the flag. No specific law governs the legality of this fringe. Traditionally, the [[Ukrainian Ground Forces|Army]], [[National Guard of Ukraine|Guard]], [[Ukrainian Navy|Navy]] and [[Ukrainian Air Force|Air Force]] use a fringed flag for [[military parade|parades]], [[color guard]]s and indoor displays, while the [[President of Ukraine|Office of the President]] and local authorities use a fringed flag for all purposes.
 
 ===Places of continuous display===
-[[File:28160-Lviv.jpg|thumbnail|Flag flying on [[Lviv Theatre of Opera and Ballet]] with statue of Glory]]
+[[File:28160-Lviv.jpg|thumbnail|The Ukrainian flag flying on the [[Lviv Theatre of Opera and Ballet]] with the statue of Glory]]
 Ukrainian flags are customly displayed continuously at certain locations.
 * [[Maidan Nezalezhnosti]], main square of [[Kiev]], traditional place for political rallies, including four large-scale radical protest campaigns ([[Orange Revolution]] and [[Euromaidan]]).
 * [[Presidential Administration Building (Kiev)|Presidential Administration Building]], [[Verkhovna Rada building]] and [[Budynok Uryadu]].

 * Other historical cases: mass victims of accidents, [[War in Donbass]] and [[Euromaidan]]; [[Death and state funeral of Lech and Maria Kaczyński]], [[Funeral of Pope John Paul II]] and [[11 September attacks]].
 
 ==Flag Day==
-[[File:Ukrflagblue.jpg|thumbnail|right|Flag at [[Kiev]] City Hall]]
+[[File:Ukrflagblue.jpg|thumbnail|right|The flag of Ukraine at [[Kiev]] City Hall]]
 {{main|Day of the National Flag (Ukraine)}}
 
 23 August is celebrated as the Day of the National Flag in Ukraine; beginning with 2004. 24 July was previously marked as National Flag Day in Kiev. The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on July 24, 1990 at the flagstaff of the Kiev City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992 Independence Day of Ukraine is celebrated on 24 August. Following government decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this dates and some other holidays. Not all of these days are public holidays. Flags also must be flown on election days for the [[Verkhovna Rada]]  in addition to other regional-specific flag days. The public display of flags to mark other events, such as the election of the president or the death of a prominent politician (whereupon flags would be at half-mast), can be declared at the discretion of the Cabinet of Ministers. When flags are required to be flown at half-mast, vertical flags are not lowered. A black mourning ribbon is instead attached, either atop the mast (if hung from a pole) or to each end of the flag's supporting cross-beams (if flown like a banner).

+[[File:Ilja Jefimowitsch Repin - Reply of the Zaporozhian Cossacks - Yorck.jpg|thumb|left|225px|Cossack flags depicted in ''[[Reply of the Zaporozhian Cossacks]]'' by [[Ilya Repin]], 1880–1891]]
 The roots of Ukrainian national symbols come from before Christian times when yellow and blue prevailed in traditional ceremonies, reflecting fire and water.<ref name=Saprykov>{{cite web|url=http://geraldika.ru/symbols/3334|script-title=ru:Флаг Украины|trans-title=Flag of Ukraine|language=ru|first=V.|last=Saprykov|website=geraldika.ru|date=May 30, 2003|accessdate=October 2, 2017}}</ref> The most solid proof of yellow and blue colours could be traced as far as the [[Battle of Grunwald]] at which participated militia formations from various lands of the Polish-Lithuanian Union.
 
 Yellow–blue, red-black, crimson-olive and especially raspberry colour banners were widely used by [[Cossack]]s between the 16th and 18th centuries. These were not the only possible combinations, since normally Cossacks would fly their [[hetman]]'s banners, which were similar to the coats of arms of the nobility. Also, yellow and blue were the colours common on coats of arms in [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]]. In fact, the coat of arms of [[Lviv]] to this day remains a golden lion on a blue field.

For the first time in the [[Russian Empire]] the blue-yellow flag was flown on 25 March 1917 in [[Petrograd]] during a 20,000-strong mass [[Demonstration (protest)|demonstration]].<ref name=istpravda/> On the territory of the Russian Ukraine ([[Little Russia]]) the national flag of Ukraine was flown for the first time in [[Kiev]] on 29 March 1917 by soldiers.<ref name=istpravda/> On 1 April 1917 Kiev saw a 100,000-strong demonstration that carried over 320 national flags.<ref name=istpravda/> After that similar demonstration with Ukrainian flags took place across the whole [[Russian Empire]] even beyond the Ukrainian ethnic lands.<ref name=istpravda/> Numerous famous Ukrainian politician wrote their recollection about the April 1 demonstration such as [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] and [[Serhiy Yefremov]] stating that there were blue-and-yellow flags, while [[Dmytro Doroshenko]] claimed that there were yellow-and-blue.<ref name=istpravda/> The blue-yellow flag was flown at the First Ukrainian Military Congress on 18 May 1917.<ref name=istpravda/>

 ===Return of the national flag===
-[[File:Kiev 24.7.1990 Ukrainian Flag.JPG|right|upright|thumb|The Ukrainian national flag was raised outside Kiev's [[Kiev City Council|City Hall]] for the first time on 24 July 1990]]
-[[File:Waving the Ukrainian flag.jpg|thumbnail|right|A girl with flag at [[vyshyvanka]] parade]]

 Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[perestroika]] and [[glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national identity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1982–91)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed.
 
 The events in the Baltic countries soon led to similar processes in Ukraine. Particularly, West Ukraine and [[Ukrainian SSR]]'s capital [[Kiev]] (''Kyiv'') constantly held political demonstrations with the national yellow-and-blue flags waving above the heads of demonstrators.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -140,6 +140,7 @@
 ===Early independence: 1917–1921===
 [[File:Богуш Шіппіх - Згинуть наші вороженьки, як роса на сонці (1917).png|thumbnail|UPR flag with the blue and yellow flag, [[Ukrainian War of Independence]], 1918]]
 [[File:Украинская галицкая армия флаг.jpg|thumbnail|left|[[Ukrainian Galician Army]] troops with the blue and yellow flag, 1918]]
+[[File:Ukrainian flag 1966.jpg|thumb|Photo of the Ukrainian flag confiscated by the KGB after it was installed on one of the Kiev universities in 1966.]]
 Both blue–yellow and yellow–blue flags were widely used during the [[Ukraine after the Russian Revolution|Ukrainian struggle for independence]] in 1917. For the first time in the [[Russian Empire]] the blue-yellow flag was flown on 25 March 1917 in [[Petrograd]] during a 20,000-strong mass [[Demonstration (protest)|demonstration]].<ref name=istpravda/> On the territory of the Russian Ukraine ([[Little Russia]]) the national flag of Ukraine was flown for the first time in [[Kiev]] on 29 March 1917 by soldiers.<ref name=istpravda/> On 1 April 1917 Kiev saw a 100,000-strong demonstration that carried over 320 national flags.<ref name=istpravda/> After that similar demonstration with Ukrainian flags took place across the whole [[Russian Empire]] even beyond the Ukrainian ethnic lands.<ref name=istpravda/> Numerous famous Ukrainian politician wrote their recollection about the April 1 demonstration such as [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] and [[Serhiy Yefremov]] stating that there were blue-and-yellow flags, while [[Dmytro Doroshenko]] claimed that there were yellow-and-blue.<ref name=istpravda/> The blue-yellow flag was flown at the First Ukrainian Military Congress on 18 May 1917.<ref name=istpravda/>
 
 There are reliable sources that indicate that an official flag was declared by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in 1918 is blue–yellow. Some sources mention that the yellow–blue was adopted by [[Tsentralna Rada]] on 22 March 1918.<ref>[http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=32027&cat_id=31295 State Symbols of Ukraine], [[Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine]], website.</ref> Other sources point out that no hard proof of ''such'' decision exists.<ref name=istpravda/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://vexillography.narod.ru/ukraine/unr.htm |script-title=ru:Флаги Украинской Народной Республики |trans-title=Flags of the Ukrainian People's Republic |language=ru |publisher=vexillography.narod.ru |date=July 14, 2002 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050228081927/http://vexillography.narod.ru/ukraine/unr.htm |archivedate=February 28, 2005}}</ref> Instead, they refer to the decision on the Fleet Flag, which was set to be light blue–yellow<ref>{{cite journal|last=Rozovyk|first=D. F.|format=PDF|url=http://www.history.org.ua/journal/1999/4/10.pdf|script-title=uk:Документи та матеряли: Про створення української національно-державної символіки у роки визвольної боротьби (1917-1920 рр.)|trans-title=Documents and materials: On the creation of Ukrainian national-state symbols during the battle for liberation (1917-1920)|language=uk|journal=Ukrainian Historical Journal|publisher=history.org.ua|location=Kiev|volume=4|date=1999|issn=0130-5247|pages=115–121|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070705084455/http://www.history.org.ua/journal/1999/4/10.pdf|archivedate=July 5, 2007}}</ref> as an indication that the official flag was light blue–yellow.<ref>{{cite web|last=Chmyr|first=Mykola|url=http://vijsko.milua.org/Khoruhvy_HA.htm|script-title=uk:Українське військо у ХХ-ХХІ сторіччі: 'Командні хоругви' Галицької Армії (серпень 1919 р.)|trans-title=Ukrainian Army in the 20th-21st Century: 'Command banners' of the Galician Army (August 1919)|language=uk|website=vijsko.milua.org|date=2006|accessdate=October 2, 2017}}</ref> Also were adopted other service flags of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].<ref>Grechylo A. Ukrayinska Terytorialna Heraldyka. Lviv, 2010, pp. 98–118. {{ISBN|978-966-02-5259-2}}</ref>
llm_output:
Added a photo of the Ukrainian flag confiscated by the KGB after it was installed on one of the Kiev universities in 1966.

Not Weaponised. The addition of the photo provides historical context without employing charged language or narratives that could be seen as weaponizing cultural heritage.

@@ -157,7 +157,8 @@
 
 ===Soviet Ukraine: 1922–1991===
 {{Main|Flag of the Ukrainian SSR}}
-The first flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic was adopted on 10 March 1919, to serve as the symbol of state of the [[Soviet Ukraine]]. Details of the official flag changed periodically before the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991, but all were based on the red flag of the [[October Revolution]] in Russia and an exact replica of the [[Soviet Russia]].
+[[File:Ukrainian flag 1966.jpg|thumb|Photo of the Ukrainian flag confiscated by the KGB after it was installed on one of the Kiev universities in 1966. The flag contains lines of the [[Ukrainian anthem]] "Ukraine has not perished, it has not been killed".]]
+During the Soviet occupation the Ukrainian flag was prohibited and displaying of it was criminally prosecuted for "anti-Soviet propaganda". The first flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic was adopted on 10 March 1919, to serve as the symbol of state of the [[Soviet Ukraine]]. Details of the official flag changed periodically before the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991, but all were based on the red flag of the [[October Revolution]] in Russia and an exact replica of the [[Soviet Russia]].
 The first flag was red with the gold Cyrillic sans-serif letters У.С.С.Р. (USSR, acronym for Ukrayinskaya Sotsialisticheskaya Sovetskaya Respublika in the Russian language). In the 1930s a gold border was added. In 1937, a new flag was adopted, with a small gold hammer and sickle added above the gold Cyrillic serif letters У.Р.С.Р. (URSR, for Ukrayins’ka Radyans’ka Sotsialistychna Respublika in the Ukrainian language).

The combination of blue and yellow as a symbol of Ukrainian lands comes from the flag of the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia]] used in the 12th century. As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolour has been officially used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]], when it was hoisted over the [[Lviv Town Hall|Lviv Rathaus]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the flag was outlawed and, before 1949, there was no official state flag until adoption of the red-azure [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following [[Modern history of Ukraine#Independent Ukraine (1991 to present)|Ukrainian independence]], before finally officially being restored on 28 January 1992 by the [[parliament of Ukraine]].[http://www.unian.info/society/1747301-ukraines-national-flag-celebrating-25th-anniversary-today.html Ukraine’s national flag celebrating 25th anniversary today], [[UNIAN]] (28 January 2017){{cite news|last=Trach|first=Nataliya|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/ukraine-politics/the-story-behind-2-top-ukrainian-symbols-national-flag-and-trident-421675.html|title=The story behind 2 top Ukrainian symbols: National flag and trident|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=26 August 2016|accessdate=27 August 2016}} +The '''flag of [[Ukraine]]''' is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]]). The top represents sky and the yellow represents wheat. The combination of blue and yellow as a symbol of Ukrainian lands comes from the flag of the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia]] used in the 12th century. As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolour has been officially used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]], when it was hoisted over the [[Lviv Town Hall|Lviv Rathaus]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the flag was outlawed and, before 1949, there was no official state flag until adoption of the red-azure [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following [[Modern history of Ukraine#Independent Ukraine (1991 to present)|Ukrainian independence]], before finally officially being restored on 28 January 1992 by the [[parliament of Ukraine]].[http://www.unian.info/society/1747301-ukraines-national-flag-celebrating-25th-anniversary-today.html Ukraine’s national flag celebrating 25th anniversary today], [[UNIAN]] (28 January 2017){{cite news|last=Trach|first=Nataliya|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/ukraine-politics/the-story-behind-2-top-ukrainian-symbols-national-flag-and-trident-421675.html|title=The story behind 2 top Ukrainian symbols: National flag and trident|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=26 August 2016|accessdate=27 August 2016}} Ukraine has celebrated [[Flag Day in Ukraine|Flag Day]] each year on 23 August since 2005.[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2012-08/23/c_131803737.htm Ukraine celebrates National Flag Day] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131007221207/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2012-08/23/c_131803737.htm |date=October 7, 2013 }}, [[Xinhua News Agency]] (August 23, 2012)
[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/kyiv/ceremony-of-hoisting-ukraines-national-flag-held-a-111423.html Ceremony of hoisting Ukraine's national flag held at presidential administration], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (August 23, 2011)

 ===Soviet Ukraine: 1922–1991===
 {{Main|Flag of the Ukrainian SSR}}
 [[File:Ukrainian flag 1966.jpg|thumb|Photo of the Ukrainian flag confiscated by the KGB after it was installed on one of the Kiev universities in 1966. The flag contains lines of the [[Ukrainian anthem]] "Ukraine has not perished, it has not been killed".]]
-During the Soviet occupation the Ukrainian flag was prohibited and displaying of it was criminally prosecuted for "anti-Soviet propaganda". The first flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic was adopted on 10 March 1919, to serve as the symbol of state of the [[Soviet Ukraine]]. Details of the official flag changed periodically before the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991, but all were based on the red flag of the [[October Revolution]] in Russia and an exact replica of the [[Soviet Russia]].
+During the Soviet rule the Ukrainian flag was prohibited and displaying of it was criminally prosecuted for "anti-Soviet propaganda". The first flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic was adopted on 10 March 1919, to serve as the symbol of state of the [[Soviet Ukraine]]. Details of the official flag changed periodically before the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991, but all were based on the red flag of the [[October Revolution]] in Russia and an exact replica of the [[Soviet Russia]].
 The first flag was red with the gold Cyrillic sans-serif letters У.С.С.Р. (USSR, acronym for Ukrayinskaya Sotsialisticheskaya Sovetskaya Respublika in the Russian language). In the 1930s a gold border was added. In 1937, a new flag was adopted, with a small gold hammer and sickle added above the gold Cyrillic serif letters У.Р.С.Р. (URSR, for Ukrayins’ka Radyans’ka Sotsialistychna Respublika in the Ukrainian language).

 {{main|National colours of Ukraine}}
 
 ===Origin===
+{{unsourced section}}
 One claimed version is that since the one of first known colour depictions of Kyiv Coat of Arms was mainly in yellow-blue colours, which may presume, that this tradition was held since Nordic-Slavic from his origins Volodymyr, the Great Konung of Kyiv and earlier (Great Prince, after adoption of Byzantium Christianity). At least, when Poltava battle was held, Cossacks of Mazepa were struggling under the yellow-blue banners, while their Swedish allies – under yellow ones.
 
-In reality, however, the blue-yellow coloring dates back to Kyivan Ruthenia, as an early version of the Tryzub, Ukraine's national coat of arms, sported the same coloring as the seal for Sviatoslav I of Kyiv (945).
+In reality, however, the blue-yellow coloring dates back to Kyivan Ruthenia, as an early version of the Tryzub, Ukraine's national coat of arms, sported the same coloring as the seal for Sviatoslav I of Kyiv (c. AD 945).
 
 ===Yellow-blue vs blue-yellow===
 Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as '''yellow and light blue''' (жовто-блакитний, ''zhovto-blakytnyi'')<ref>A little less often they  use also "yellow and blue", "blue and yellow" and "yellow and azure".</ref>—a different version of the flag used during UNR ([[Ukrainian National Republic]]) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. The yellow on the top represents golden domes ([[cupola]]s) of Christian churches and the blue the [[Dnieper]] river.

 ===Soviet Ukraine: 1922–1991===
 {{Main|Flag of the Ukrainian SSR}}
 [[File:Ukrainian flag 1966.jpg|thumb|Photo of the Ukrainian flag confiscated by the KGB after it was installed on one of the Kyiv universities in 1966. The flag contains lines of the [[Ukrainian anthem]] "Ukraine has not perished, it has not been killed".]]
-During the Soviet rule the Ukrainian flag was prohibited and displaying of it was criminally prosecuted for "anti-Soviet propaganda". The first flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic was adopted on 10 March 1919, to serve as the symbol of state of the [[Soviet Ukraine]]. Details of the official flag changed periodically before the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991, but all were based on the red flag of the [[October Revolution]] in Russia and an exact replica of the [[Soviet Russia]].
+During the Soviet rule the Ukrainian flag was prohibited<ref>[https://www.rferl.org/a/the-revolution-on-granite-ukraine-s-first-maidan-kyiv/30892599.html The Revolution On Granite: Ukraine's 'First Maidan'], Radio Free Europe (16 October 2020</ref> and displaying of it was criminally prosecuted for "anti-Soviet propaganda". The first flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic was adopted on 10 March 1919, to serve as the symbol of state of the [[Soviet Ukraine]]. Details of the official flag changed periodically before the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991, but all were based on the red flag of the [[October Revolution]] in Russia and an exact replica of the [[Soviet Russia]].
 The first flag was red with the gold Cyrillic sans-serif letters У.С.С.Р. (USSR, acronym for Ukrayinskaya Sotsialisticheskaya Sovetskaya Respublika in the Russian language). In the 1930s a gold border was added. In 1937, a new flag was adopted, with a small gold hammer and sickle added above the gold Cyrillic serif letters У.Р.С.Р. (URSR, for Ukrayins’ka Radyans’ka Sotsialistychna Respublika in the Ukrainian language).

--- +++ @@ -18,7 +18,7 @@ |Proportion2 = 2:3 |Design2 = White with a blue cotised symmetric cross that extends to the edges of the flag, and with the national bi-colour in the canton. }} -The '''flag of [[Ukraine]]''' was a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]]). The top represented sky and the yellow represented wheat. The combination of blue and yellow as a symbol of Ukrainian lands comes from the flag of the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia]] used in the 12th century. As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolour has been officially used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]], when it was hoisted over the [[Lviv Town Hall|Lviv Rathaus]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the flag was outlawed and, before 1949, there was no official state flag until adoption of the red-azure [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following [[Modern history of Ukraine#Independent Ukraine (1991 to present)|Ukrainian independence]], before finally officially being restored on 28 January 1992 by the [[parliament of Ukraine]].[http://www.unian.info/society/1747301-ukraines-national-flag-celebrating-25th-anniversary-today.html Ukraine’s national flag celebrating 25th anniversary today], [[UNIAN]] (28 January 2017){{cite news|last=Trach|first=Nataliya|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/ukraine-politics/the-story-behind-2-top-ukrainian-symbols-national-flag-and-trident-421675.html|title=The story behind 2 top Ukrainian symbols: National flag and trident|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=26 August 2016|accessdate=27 August 2016}} +The '''flag of [[Ukraine]]''' is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]]). The top represents sky and the yellow represents wheat. The combination of blue and yellow as a symbol of Ukrainian lands comes from the flag of the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia]] used in the 12th century. As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolour has been officially used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]], when it was hoisted over the [[Lviv Town Hall|Lviv Rathaus]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the flag was outlawed and, before 1949, there was no official state flag until adoption of the red-azure [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following [[Modern history of Ukraine#Independent Ukraine (1991 to present)|Ukrainian independence]], before finally officially being restored on 28 January 1992 by the [[parliament of Ukraine]].[http://www.unian.info/society/1747301-ukraines-national-flag-celebrating-25th-anniversary-today.html Ukraine’s national flag celebrating 25th anniversary today], [[UNIAN]] (28 January 2017){{cite news|last=Trach|first=Nataliya|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/ukraine-politics/the-story-behind-2-top-ukrainian-symbols-national-flag-and-trident-421675.html|title=The story behind 2 top Ukrainian symbols: National flag and trident|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=26 August 2016|accessdate=27 August 2016}} Ukraine has celebrated [[Flag Day in Ukraine|Flag Day]] each year on 23 August since 2005.[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2012-08/23/c_131803737.htm Ukraine celebrates National Flag Day] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131007221207/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2012-08/23/c_131803737.htm |date=October 7, 2013 }}, [[Xinhua News Agency]] (August 23, 2012)
[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/kyiv/ceremony-of-hoisting-ukraines-national-flag-held-a-111423.html Ceremony of hoisting Ukraine's national flag held at presidential administration], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (August 23, 2011)
[http://tsn.ua/ukrayina/ukrayina-vidznachaye-den-derzhavnogo-prapora.html Україна відзначає День Державного прапора "On Tuesday, August 23, all of Ukraine celebrates National Flag Day. Measures to raise the national flag are planned throughout the country."], [[1+1 (channel)|1+1]] (August 23, 2011)

The top represents sky and the yellow represents wheat. The combination of blue and yellow as a symbol of Ukrainian lands comes from the flag of the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia]] used in the 12th century. As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolour has been officially used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]], when it was hoisted over the [[Lviv Town Hall|Lviv Rathaus]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the flag was outlawed and, before 1949, there was no official state flag until adoption of the red-azure [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]].  {{main|Day of the National Flag (Ukraine)}}
 
-23 August is celebrated as the Day of the National Flag in Ukraine; beginning with 2004. 24 July was previously marked as National Flag Day in Kiev. The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on July 24, 1990 at the flagstaff of the Kiev City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992 Independence Day of Ukraine is celebrated on 24 August. Following government decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this dates and some other holidays. Not all of these days are public holidays. Flags also must be flown on election days for the [[Verkhovna Rada]]  in addition to other regional-specific flag days. The public display of flags to mark other events, such as the election of the president or the death of a prominent politician (whereupon flags would be at half-mast), can be declared at the discretion of the Cabinet of Ministers. When flags are required to be flown at half-mast, vertical flags are not lowered. A black mourning ribbon is instead attached, either atop the mast (if hung from a pole) or to each end of the flag's supporting cross-beams (if flown like a banner).
+23 August is celebrated as the Day of the National Flag in Ukraine; beginning with 2004. 24 July was previously marked as National Flag Day in Kyiv. The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on July 24, 1990 at the flagstaff of the Kyiv City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992 Independence Day of Ukraine is celebrated on 24 August. Following government decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this dates and some other holidays. Not all of these days are public holidays. Flags also must be flown on election days for the [[Verkhovna Rada]]  in addition to other regional-specific flag days. The public display of flags to mark other events, such as the election of the president or the death of a prominent politician (whereupon flags would be at half-mast), can be declared at the discretion of the Cabinet of Ministers. When flags are required to be flown at half-mast, vertical flags are not lowered. A black mourning ribbon is instead attached, either atop the mast (if hung from a pole) or to each end of the flag's supporting cross-beams (if flown like a banner).

+[[File:Ukrainian flag 1966.jpg|thumb|Photo of the Ukrainian flag confiscated by the KGB after it was installed on one of the Kyiv universities in 1966. The flag contains lines of the [[Ukrainian anthem]] "Ukraine has not perished, it has not been killed".]]
 During the Soviet rule the Ukrainian flag was prohibited and displaying of it was criminally prosecuted for "anti-Soviet propaganda". The first flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic was adopted on 10 March 1919, to serve as the symbol of state of the [[Soviet Ukraine]]. Details of the official flag changed periodically before the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991, but all were based on the red flag of the [[October Revolution]] in Russia and an exact replica of the [[Soviet Russia]].
 The first flag was red with the gold Cyrillic sans-serif letters У.С.С.Р. (USSR, acronym for Ukrayinskaya Sotsialisticheskaya Sovetskaya Respublika in the Russian language). In the 1930s a gold border was added. In 1937, a new flag was adopted, with a small gold hammer and sickle added above the gold Cyrillic serif letters У.Р.С.Р. (URSR, for Ukrayins’ka Radyans’ka Sotsialistychna Respublika in the Ukrainian language).

 Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[perestroika]] and [[glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national identity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1982–91)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's historic coat of arms as the state symbol. On the same day, the yellow-and-blue national flag was flown for the first time in about 80 years on a governmental building in Kyiv, replacing the then official [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|red-azure flag]] of the Ukrainian SSR.

 * On 29 April 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown from the Ternopil city theater's flagstaff without the [[Flag of the Soviet Union|official flag of the Soviet Union]] hanging above it.
-* After 24 July 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown for the first time over an official governmental building of the [[Kiev City Council]] on the ''[[Maidan Nezalezhnosti]]'' square of the ''[[Khreschatyk]]'' street.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/ukrainian/politics/2012/07/120724_flag_ukraine_history_kyiv_as.shtml Twenty two years ago in Kiev officially was raised the blue-yellow flag (22 роки тому в Києві офіційно підняли синьо-жовтий прапор)]. BBC Ukraine. July 24, 2012.</ref>

BBC Ukraine. July 24, 2012.</ref>
 * After the declaration of independence of Ukraine on 24 August 1991, the national yellow-and-blue flag flew for the first time over the [[Verkhovna Rada|Ukrainian Parliament (''Verkhovna Rada'')]] building on 4 September 1991.
