@@ -216,7 +216,7 @@
 In reality, however, the blue-yellow coloring dates back to Kyivan Ruthenia, as an early version of the Tryzub, Ukraine's national coat of arms, sported the same coloring as the seal for Sviatoslav I of Kyiv (c. AD 945).
 
 ===Yellow-blue vs blue-yellow===
-Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as '''yellow and light blue''' (жовто-блакитний, ''zhovto-blakytnyi'')<ref>A little less often they  use also "yellow and blue", "blue and yellow" and "yellow and azure".</ref>—a different version of the flag used during UNR ([[Ukrainian National Republic]]) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. The yellow on the top represents golden domes ([[cupola]]s) of Christian churches and the blue the [[Dnieper]] river.
+Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as '''yellow and light blue''' (жовто-блакитний, ''zhovto-blakytnyi'')<ref>A little less often they use also "yellow and blue", "blue and yellow" and "yellow and azure".</ref>—a different version of the flag used during UNR ([[Ukrainian National Republic]]) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. The yellow on the top represents golden domes ([[cupola]]s) of Christian churches and the blue the [[Dnieper]] river.
 
 It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the spoken language as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy''), the current flag in reality is blue (the upper band) and yellow (the lower band). The issue is quite significant, because the historical alteration of the flag (from yellow–blue to blue–yellow) did not affect the spoken language.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} Back in 1848 the flag was indeed yellow and blue,{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} and it was later changed to blue and yellow to be more appealing to the common person.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} The common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time,{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} and, although this evocation of a Ukrainian landscape has nothing to do with the choice of colours or the history of the original yellow and blue, it certainly has formed the Ukrainians' conception of their flag.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}}

 ===Particular days for display===
 The flag should especially be displayed at full staff on the following days:
 * 1 January: [[New Year's Day]]
-* 7 January: [[Orthodox Christmas]]
+* 7 January: [[Christmas#Date_according_to_Julian_calendar|Christmas (Julian)]]
 * 22 January: Ukrainian Unity Day
 * 8 March: International Women's Day
 * 1 & 2 May: [[International Workers' Day]]
@@ -104,7 +104,7 @@
 * 24 August: Independence Day
 * 21 November: Day of Dignity and Freedom
 * 6 December: Armed Forces Day
-* 25 December: Western Christmas
+* 25 December: Christmas (Gregorian/Neo-Julian)
 
 ===Display at half-staff===
 The flag is displayed at half-staff (half-mast in naval usage) as a sign of respect or mourning. Nationwide, this action is proclaimed by the president. Half-mast means the flag is flown two-thirds of the way up the flagpole with at least the height of the flag between the top of the flag and the top of the flagpole. Black ribbons indicate mourning on banners that can't be lowered to half-mast.

 ==History==
 [[File:Flag colors.jpg|thumb|Typical agricultural landscape of Ukraine in the [[Kherson Oblast]]]]
 [[File:Ilja Jefimowitsch Repin - Reply of the Zaporozhian Cossacks - Yorck.jpg|thumb|left|225px|Cossack flags depicted in ''[[Reply of the Zaporozhian Cossacks]]'' by [[Ilya Repin]], 1880–1891]]
-The roots of Ukrainian national symbols come from before Christian times when yellow and blue prevailed in traditional ceremonies, reflecting fire and water.<ref name=Saprykov>{{cite web|url=http://geraldika.ru/symbols/3334|script-title=ru:Флаг Украины|trans-title=Flag of Ukraine|language=ru|first=V.|last=Saprykov|website=geraldika.ru|date=May 30, 2003|accessdate=October 2, 2017}}</ref> The most solid proof of yellow and blue colours could be traced as far as the [[Battle of Grunwald]] at which participated militia formations from various lands of the Polish-Lithuanian Union.
+The roots of Ukrainian national symbols come from pre-Christian times when yellow and blue prevailed in traditional ceremonies, reflecting fire and water.<ref name=Saprykov>{{cite web|url=http://geraldika.ru/symbols/3334|script-title=ru:Флаг Украины|trans-title=Flag of Ukraine|language=ru|first=V.|last=Saprykov|website=geraldika.ru|date=May 30, 2003|accessdate=October 2, 2017}}</ref> The most solid proof of yellow and blue colours could be traced as far as the [[Battle of Grunwald]], in which militia formations from various lands of the [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]] participated.
 
 Yellow–blue, red-black, crimson-olive and especially raspberry colour banners were widely used by [[Cossack]]s between the 16th and 18th centuries. These were not the only possible combinations, since normally Cossacks would fly their [[hetman]]'s banners, which were similar to the coats of arms of the nobility. Also, yellow and blue were the colours common on coats of arms in [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]]. In fact, the coat of arms of [[Lviv]] to this day remains a golden lion on a blue field.
 
-Some put the starting point of the adoption of the current national flag of Ukraine to 1848 when, during the [[The Revolutions of 1848 in the Habsburg areas|Spring of the Nations]] on 22 April 1848, a yellow and blue banner was adopted by the [[Main Ruthenian Council]]<ref name=istpravda>[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/articles/2014/01/14/140850/ Blue-yellow or yellow-blue? Myths about the flipped flag (Синьо-жовтий чи жовто-блакитний? Міфи про "перевернутий" прапор)]. ''[[Ukrayinska Pravda]]''. 14 January 2014</ref> in Lemberg ([[Lviv]]), the capital of the [[Kingdom of Galicia and Lodomeria]], and flew over the city's magistrate for the first time. Although this move did not have significant consequences, the newly formed Ukrainian divisions in the Austrian army used yellow and blue banners in their insignia.
+Some put the starting point of the adoption of the current national flag of Ukraine to 1848 when, during the [[The Revolutions of 1848 in the Habsburg areas|Spring of the Nations]] on 22 April 1848, a yellow and blue banner was adopted by the [[Supreme Ruthenian Council]]<ref name=istpravda>[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/articles/2014/01/14/140850/ Blue-yellow or yellow-blue? Myths about the flipped flag (Синьо-жовтий чи жовто-блакитний? Міфи про "перевернутий" прапор)]. ''[[Ukrayinska Pravda]]''. 14 January 2014</ref> in Lemberg ([[Lviv]]), the capital of the [[Kingdom of Galicia and Lodomeria]], and flew over the city's magistrate for the first time. Although this move did not have significant consequences, the newly formed Ukrainian divisions in the Austrian army used yellow and blue banners in their insignia.
 
 During the Russian [[Revolution of 1905]], this flag started to be used by Ukrainians of the [[Dnieper Ukraine]], or the Russian part of Ukraine.

 [[File:Украинская галицкая армия флаг.jpg|thumbnail|left|[[Ukrainian Galician Army]] troops with the blue and yellow flag, 1918]]
 Both blue–yellow and yellow–blue flags were widely used during the [[Ukraine after the Russian Revolution|Ukrainian struggle for independence]] in 1917. For the first time in the [[Russian Empire]] the blue-yellow flag was flown on 25 March 1917 in [[Petrograd]] during a 20,000-strong mass [[Demonstration (protest)|demonstration]].<ref name=istpravda/> On the territory of the Russian Ukraine ([[Little Russia]]) the national flag of Ukraine was flown for the first time in [[Kyiv]] on 29 March 1917 by soldiers.<ref name=istpravda/> On 1 April 1917 Kyiv saw a 100,000-strong demonstration that carried over 320 national flags.<ref name=istpravda/> After that similar demonstration with Ukrainian flags took place across the whole [[Russian Empire]] even beyond the Ukrainian ethnic lands.<ref name=istpravda/> Numerous famous Ukrainian politician wrote their recollection about the April 1 demonstration such as [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] and [[Serhiy Yefremov]] stating that there were blue-and-yellow flags, while [[Dmytro Doroshenko]] claimed that there were yellow-and-blue.<ref name=istpravda/> The blue-yellow flag was flown at the First Ukrainian Military Congress on 18 May 1917.<ref name=istpravda/>
 
-There are reliable sources that indicate that an official flag was declared by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in 1918 is blue–yellow. Some sources mention that the yellow–blue was adopted by [[Tsentralna Rada]] on 22 March 1918.<ref>[http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=32027&cat_id=31295 State Symbols of Ukraine], [[Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine]], website.</ref> Other sources point out that no hard proof of ''such'' decision exists.<ref name=istpravda/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://vexillography.narod.ru/ukraine/unr.htm |script-title=ru:Флаги Украинской Народной Республики |trans-title=Flags of the Ukrainian People's Republic |language=ru |publisher=vexillography.narod.ru |date=July 14, 2002 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050228081927/http://vexillography.narod.ru/ukraine/unr.htm |archive-date=February 28, 2005}}</ref> Instead, they refer to the decision on the Fleet Flag, which was set to be light blue–yellow<ref>{{cite journal|last=Rozovyk|first=D. F.|format=PDF|url=http://www.history.org.ua/journal/1999/4/10.pdf|script-title=uk:Документи та матеряли: Про створення української національно-державної символіки у роки визвольної боротьби (1917-1920 рр.)|trans-title=Documents and materials: On the creation of Ukrainian national-state symbols during the battle for liberation (1917-1920)|language=uk|journal=Ukrainian Historical Journal|publisher=history.org.ua|location=Kyiv|volume=4|date=1999|issn=0130-5247|pages=115–121|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070705084455/http://www.history.org.ua/journal/1999/4/10.pdf|archive-date=July 5, 2007}}</ref> as an indication that the official flag was light blue–yellow.<ref>{{cite web|last=Chmyr|first=Mykola|url=http://vijsko.milua.org/Khoruhvy_HA.htm|script-title=uk:Українське військо у ХХ-ХХІ сторіччі: 'Командні хоругви' Галицької Армії (серпень 1919 р.)|trans-title=Ukrainian Army in the 20th-21st Century: 'Command banners' of the Galician Army (August 1919)|language=uk|website=vijsko.milua.org|date=2006|access-date=October 2, 2017}}</ref> Also were adopted other service flags of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].<ref>Grechylo A. Ukrayinska Terytorialna Heraldyka. Lviv, 2010, pp. 98–118. {{ISBN|978-966-02-5259-2}}</ref>
+There are reliable sources that indicate that an official flag was declared by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in 1918 is blue–yellow. Some sources mention that the yellow–blue was adopted by [[Tsentralna Rada]] on 22 March 1918.<ref>[http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=32027&cat_id=31295 State Symbols of Ukraine], [[Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine]], website.</ref> Other sources point out that no hard proof of ''such'' decision exists.<ref name=istpravda/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://vexillography.narod.ru/ukraine/unr.htm |script-title=ru:Флаги Украинской Народной Республики |trans-title=Flags of the Ukrainian People's Republic |language=ru |publisher=vexillography.narod.ru |date=July 14, 2002 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050228081927/http://vexillography.narod.ru/ukraine/unr.htm |archive-date=February 28, 2005}}</ref> Instead, they refer to the decision on the Fleet Flag, which was set to be light blue–yellow<ref>{{cite journal|last=Rozovyk|first=D. F.|url=http://www.history.org.ua/journal/1999/4/10.pdf|script-title=uk:Документи та матеряли: Про створення української національно-державної символіки у роки визвольної боротьби (1917-1920 рр.)|trans-title=Documents and materials: On the creation of Ukrainian national-state symbols during the battle for liberation (1917-1920)|language=uk|journal=Ukrainian Historical Journal|publisher=history.org.ua|location=Kyiv|volume=4|date=1999|issn=0130-5247|pages=115–121|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070705084455/http://www.history.org.ua/journal/1999/4/10.pdf|archive-date=July 5, 2007}}</ref> as an indication that the official flag was light blue–yellow.<ref>{{cite web|last=Chmyr|first=Mykola|url=http://vijsko.milua.org/Khoruhvy_HA.htm|script-title=uk:Українське військо у ХХ-ХХІ сторіччі: 'Командні хоругви' Галицької Армії (серпень 1919 р.)|trans-title=Ukrainian Army in the 20th-21st Century: 'Command banners' of the Galician Army (August 1919)|language=uk|website=vijsko.milua.org|date=2006|access-date=October 2, 2017}}</ref> Also were adopted other service flags of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].<ref>Grechylo A. Ukrayinska Terytorialna Heraldyka. Lviv, 2010, pp. 98–118. {{ISBN|978-966-02-5259-2}}</ref>
 
 The official flag of [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]]'s [[Ukrainian State|Hetmanate]] also was light blue–yellow and became the same under [[Symon Petlura]]'s [[Directorate of Ukraine|Directorate]]. The flag of [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] was blue and yellow. The [[Free Territory|anarchist free-soviets]] that existed during the [[Ukrainian War of Independence|civil war]] used the black flag.

changed_version:
--- +++ @@ -18,7 +18,7 @@ |Proportion2 = 2:3 |Design2 = White with a blue cotised symmetric cross that extends to the edges of the flag, and with the national bi-colour in the canton. }} -The '''flag of [[Ukraine]]''' is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]]). The top represents sky and the yellow represents wheat. The combination of blue and yellow as a symbol of Ukrainian lands comes from the flag of the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia]] used in the 12th century. As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolour has been officially used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]], when it was hoisted over the [[Lviv Town Hall|Lviv Rathaus]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the flag was outlawed and, before 1949, there was no official state flag until adoption of the red-azure [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following [[Modern history of Ukraine#Independent Ukraine (1991 to present)|Ukrainian independence]], before finally officially being restored on 28 January 1992 by the [[parliament of Ukraine]].[http://www.unian.info/society/1747301-ukraines-national-flag-celebrating-25th-anniversary-today.html Ukraine’s national flag celebrating 25th anniversary today], [[UNIAN]] (28 January 2017){{cite news|last=Trach|first=Nataliya|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/ukraine-politics/the-story-behind-2-top-ukrainian-symbols-national-flag-and-trident-421675.html|title=The story behind 2 top Ukrainian symbols: National flag and trident|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=26 August 2016|accessdate=27 August 2016}} +The '''flag of [[Ukraine]]''' is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]]). The top represents sky and the yellow represents wheat. The combination of blue and yellow as a symbol of Ukrainian lands comes from the flag of the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia]] used in the 12th century. As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolour has been officially used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]], when it was hoisted over the [[Lviv Town Hall|Lviv Rathaus]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the flag was outlawed and, before 1949, there was no official state flag until adoption of the red-azure [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following [[Modern history of Ukraine#Independent Ukraine (1991 to present)|Ukrainian independence]], before finally officially being restored on 28 January 1992 by the [[parliament of Ukraine]].[http://www.unian.info/society/1747301-ukraines-national-flag-celebrating-25th-anniversary-today.html Ukraine’s national flag celebrating 25th anniversary today], [[UNIAN]] (28 January 2017){{cite news|last=Trach|first=Nataliya|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/ukraine-politics/the-story-behind-2-top-ukrainian-symbols-national-flag-and-trident-421675.html|title=The story behind 2 top Ukrainian symbols: National flag and trident|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=26 August 2016|access-date=27 August 2016}} Ukraine has celebrated [[Flag Day in Ukraine|Flag Day]] each year on 23 August since 2005.[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2012-08/23/c_131803737.htm Ukraine celebrates National Flag Day] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131007221207/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2012-08/23/c_131803737.htm |date=October 7, 2013 }}, [[Xinhua News Agency]] (August 23, 2012)
[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/kyiv/ceremony-of-hoisting-ukraines-national-flag-held-a-111423.html Ceremony of hoisting Ukraine's national flag held at presidential administration], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (August 23, 2011)
[http://tsn.ua/ukrayina/ukrayina-vidznachaye-den-derzhavnogo-prapora.html Україна відзначає День Державного прапора "On Tuesday, August 23, all of Ukraine celebrates National Flag Day. Measures to raise the national flag are planned throughout the country."], [[1+1 (channel)|1+1]] (August 23, 2011) @@ -66,7 +66,7 @@ ===Legal status=== -Article 20 of the Constitution of Ukraine states the following, citing: ''"the State Flag of Ukraine is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow colour."'' ({{lang-uk|"Державний Прапор України — стяг із двох рівновеликих горизонтальних смуг синього і жовтого кольорів."}}).[[s:Constitution of Ukraine|Constitution of Ukraine]]{{cite web |url=http://zakon4.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/254%D0%BA/96-%D0%B2%D1%80 |script-title=uk:Конституція України |language=Ukrainian |website=Верховна Рада України}} +Article 20 of the Constitution of Ukraine states the following, citing: ''"the State Flag of Ukraine is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow colour."'' ({{lang-uk|"Державний Прапор України — стяг із двох рівновеликих горизонтальних смуг синього і жовтого кольорів."}}).[[s:Constitution of Ukraine|Constitution of Ukraine]]{{cite web |url=http://zakon4.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/254%D0%BA/96-%D0%B2%D1%80 |script-title=uk:Конституція України |language=uk |website=Верховна Рада України}} ===Vertical flags=== @@ -121,7 +121,7 @@ ==History== [[File:Flag colors.jpg|thumb|Typical agricultural landscape of Ukraine in the [[Kherson Oblast]]]] [[File:Ilja Jefimowitsch Repin - Reply of the Zaporozhian Cossacks - Yorck.jpg|thumb|left|225px|Cossack flags depicted in ''[[Reply of the Zaporozhian Cossacks]]'' by [[Ilya Repin]], 1880–1891]] -The roots of Ukrainian national symbols come from pre-Christian times when yellow and blue prevailed in traditional ceremonies, reflecting fire and water.{{cite web|url=http://geraldika.ru/symbols/3334|script-title=ru:Флаг Украины|trans-title=Flag of Ukraine|language=ru|first=V.|last=Saprykov|website=geraldika.ru|date=May 30, 2003|accessdate=October 2, 2017}} The most solid proof of yellow and blue colours could be traced as far as the [[Battle of Grunwald]], in which militia formations from various lands of the [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]] participated. +The roots of Ukrainian national symbols come from pre-Christian times when yellow and blue prevailed in traditional ceremonies, reflecting fire and water.{{cite web|url=http://geraldika.ru/symbols/3334|script-title=ru:Флаг Украины|trans-title=Flag of Ukraine|language=ru|first=V.|last=Saprykov|website=geraldika.ru|date=May 30, 2003|access-date=October 2, 2017}} The most solid proof of yellow and blue colours could be traced as far as the [[Battle of Grunwald]], in which militia formations from various lands of the [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]] participated. Yellow–blue, red-black, crimson-olive and especially raspberry colour banners were widely used by [[Cossack]]s between the 16th and 18th centuries. These were not the only possible combinations, since normally Cossacks would fly their [[hetman]]'s banners, which were similar to the coats of arms of the nobility. Also, yellow and blue were the colours common on coats of arms in [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]]. In fact, the coat of arms of [[Lviv]] to this day remains a golden lion on a blue field. @@ -144,7 +144,7 @@ [[File:Украинская галицкая армия флаг.jpg|thumbnail|left|[[Ukrainian Galician Army]] troops with the blue and yellow flag, 1918]] Both blue–yellow and yellow–blue flags were widely used during the [[Ukraine after the Russian Revolution|Ukrainian struggle for independence]] in 1917. For the first time in the [[Russian Empire]] the blue-yellow flag was flown on 25 March 1917 in [[Petrograd]] during a 20,000-strong mass [[Demonstration (protest)|demonstration]]. On the territory of the Russian Ukraine ([[Little Russia]]) the national flag of Ukraine was flown for the first time in [[Kyiv]] on 29 March 1917 by soldiers. On 1 April 1917 Kyiv saw a 100,000-strong demonstration that carried over 320 national flags. After that similar demonstration with Ukrainian flags took place across the whole [[Russian Empire]] even beyond the Ukrainian ethnic lands. Numerous famous Ukrainian politician wrote their recollection about the April 1 demonstration such as [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] and [[Serhiy Yefremov]] stating that there were blue-and-yellow flags, while [[Dmytro Doroshenko]] claimed that there were yellow-and-blue. The blue-yellow flag was flown at the First Ukrainian Military Congress on 18 May 1917. -There are reliable sources that indicate that an official flag was declared by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in 1918 is blue–yellow. Some sources mention that the yellow–blue was adopted by [[Tsentralna Rada]] on 22 March 1918.[http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=32027&cat_id=31295 State Symbols of Ukraine], [[Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine]], website. Other sources point out that no hard proof of ''such'' decision exists.{{cite web|url=http://vexillography.narod.ru/ukraine/unr.htm |script-title=ru:Флаги Украинской Народной Республики |trans-title=Flags of the Ukrainian People's Republic |language=ru |publisher=vexillography.narod.ru |date=July 14, 2002 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050228081927/http://vexillography.narod.ru/ukraine/unr.htm |archivedate=February 28, 2005}} Instead, they refer to the decision on the Fleet Flag, which was set to be light blue–yellow{{cite journal|last=Rozovyk|first=D. F.|format=PDF|url=http://www.history.org.ua/journal/1999/4/10.pdf|script-title=uk:Документи та матеряли: Про створення української національно-державної символіки у роки визвольної боротьби (1917-1920 рр.)|trans-title=Documents and materials: On the creation of Ukrainian national-state symbols during the battle for liberation (1917-1920)|language=uk|journal=Ukrainian Historical Journal|publisher=history.org.ua|location=Kyiv|volume=4|date=1999|issn=0130-5247|pages=115–121|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070705084455/http://www.history.org.ua/journal/1999/4/10.pdf|archivedate=July 5, 2007}} as an indication that the official flag was light blue–yellow.{{cite web|last=Chmyr|first=Mykola|url=http://vijsko.milua.org/Khoruhvy_HA.htm|script-title=uk:Українське військо у ХХ-ХХІ сторіччі: 'Командні хоругви' Галицької Армії (серпень 1919 р.)|trans-title=Ukrainian Army in the 20th-21st Century: 'Command banners' of the Galician Army (August 1919)|language=uk|website=vijsko.milua.org|date=2006|accessdate=October 2, 2017}} Also were adopted other service flags of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].Grechylo A. Ukrayinska Terytorialna Heraldyka. F.|format=PDF|url=http://www.history.org.ua/journal/1999/4/10.pdf|script-title=uk:Документи та матеряли: Про створення української національно-державної символіки у роки визвольної боротьби (1917-1920 рр.)|trans-title=Documents and materials: On the creation of Ukrainian national-state symbols during the battle for liberation (1917-1920)|language=uk|journal=Ukrainian Historical Journal|publisher=history.org.ua|location=Kyiv|volume=4|date=1999|issn=0130-5247|pages=115–121|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070705084455/http://www.history.org.ua/journal/1999/4/10.pdf|archive-date=July 5, 2007}} as an indication that the official flag was light blue–yellow.{{cite web|last=Chmyr|first=Mykola|url=http://vijsko.milua.org/Khoruhvy_HA.htm|script-title=uk:Українське військо у ХХ-ХХІ сторіччі: 'Командні хоругви' Галицької Армії (серпень 1919 р.)|trans-title=Ukrainian Army in the 20th-21st Century: 'Command banners' of the Galician Army (August 1919)|language=uk|website=vijsko.milua.org|date=2006|access-date=October 2, 2017}} Also were adopted other service flags of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]].Grechylo A. Ukrayinska Terytorialna Heraldyka. Lviv, 2010, pp. 98–118. {{ISBN|978-966-02-5259-2}} The official flag of [[Pavlo Skoropadsky]]'s [[Ukrainian State|Hetmanate]] also was light blue–yellow and became the same under [[Symon Petlura]]'s [[Directorate of Ukraine|Directorate]]. The flag of [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] was blue and yellow. The [[Free Territory|anarchist free-soviets]] that existed during the [[Ukrainian War of Independence|civil war]] used the black flag. @@ -224,7 +224,7 @@ ===Attempts to revive Soviet flags=== -On 21 April 2011 the [[Verkhovna Rada]] adopted a law which allows to raise the [[Victory Banner]] on the Victory Day.[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/short/2011/04/21/36767/ Rada enforced raising red flags on the May 9 (РАДА ЗОБОВ'ЯЗАЛА ВИВІШУВАТИ ЧЕРВОНІ ПРАПОРИ НА 9 ТРАВНЯ)]. ''Ukrayinska Pravda''. {{cite news |url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/259775.html |title= Rada bans Communist, Nazi propaganda in Ukraine |work= [[Interfax-Ukraine]] |date= 9 April 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}}

[http://www.dw.de/ukraine-lawmakers-ban-communist-and-nazi-propaganda/a-18372853 Ukraine lawmakers ban 'Communist and Nazi propaganda'], [[Deutsche Welle]] (9 April 2015) ==Flag of the head of state== Throughout the history of [[Ukraine]], various [[List of heads of state of Ukraine|heads of state]] have used different flags. The designs differ according to the historical era they were used in and in accordance with the political scene in [[Ukraine]] at the time. The first flag to be used by a [[List of heads of state of Ukraine|head of state of Ukraine]] was that of [[Pavlo Skoropadskyi]]. The current design, the flag of the [[President of Ukraine]], was adopted in 1991.

-There is also criticism in regards to color.<ref name=grechylo/> In 2013, scholar Dmytro Malakov argued that [[sky blue]] is the correct color, and that, according to [[Rule of tincture|rules of heraldry]], [[dark blue]] should not be used.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_sino-zhovtij-prapor-ce-znuschannya-nad-ukrajinskoyu-tradicieyu/508746 |trans-title=The dark blue and yellow flag is a mockery of Ukrainian tradition |title=Синьо-жовтий прапор – це знущання над українською традицією |work=[[Gazeta.ua]] |date=July 25, 2013 |first=Olga |last=Skorokhod |language=uk}}</ref> The head of the Ukrainian Heraldry Society has pointed out that it is not [[heraldry]], but rather [[vexillology]], that studies flags.<ref name=grechylo/>
+There is also criticism in regards to color.<ref name=grechylo/> In 2013, scholar Dmytro Malakov argued that [[sky blue]] is the correct color, and that, according to [[Rule of tincture|rules of heraldry]], [[Dark blue (color)|dark blue]] should not be used.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_sino-zhovtij-prapor-ce-znuschannya-nad-ukrajinskoyu-tradicieyu/508746 |trans-title=The dark blue and yellow flag is a mockery of Ukrainian tradition |title=Синьо-жовтий прапор – це знущання над українською традицією |work=[[Gazeta.ua]] |date=July 25, 2013 |first=Olga |last=Skorokhod |language=uk}}</ref> The head of the Ukrainian Heraldry Society has pointed out that it is not [[heraldry]], but rather [[vexillology]], that studies flags.<ref name=grechylo/>
 
 The flag is almost identical to that of the Austrian state of [[Lower Austria]] and the flag of German city of [[Chemnitz]], but both of those flags have a darker shade of blue.The flag also similar to the [[Malaysia]] state of [[Flag and coat of arms of Perlis|Perlis]], but has a reversed arrangement of colours with darker shades of blue and yellow as well as a different flag ratio.

-The roots of Ukrainian national symbols come from pre-Christian times when yellow and blue prevailed in traditional ceremonies, reflecting fire and water.<ref name=Saprykov>{{cite web|url=http://geraldika.ru/symbols/3334|script-title=ru:Флаг Украины|trans-title=Flag of Ukraine|language=ru|first=V.|last=Saprykov|website=geraldika.ru|date=May 30, 2003|access-date=October 2, 2017}}</ref> The most solid proof of yellow and blue colours could be traced as far as the [[Battle of Grunwald]], in which militia formations from various lands of the [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]] participated.
+The roots of Ukrainian national symbols come from pre-Christian times when yellow and blue prevailed in traditional ceremonies, reflecting fire and water.<ref name=Saprykov>{{cite web|url=http://geraldika.ru/symbols/3334|script-title=ru:Флаг Украины|trans-title=Flag of Ukraine|language=ru|first=V.|last=Saprykov|website=geraldika.ru|date=May 30, 2003|access-date=October 2, 2017}}</ref> The most solid proof of yellow and blue colours could be traced as far as the [[Battle of Grunwald]], in which militia formations from various lands of the [[Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth]] participated.
 
 Yellow–blue, red-black, crimson-olive and especially raspberry colour banners were widely used by [[Cossack]]s between the 16th and 18th centuries. These were not the only possible combinations, since normally Cossacks would fly their [[hetman]]'s banners, which were similar to the coats of arms of the nobility. Also, yellow and blue were the colours common on coats of arms in [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]]. In fact, the coat of arms of [[Lviv]] to this day remains a golden lion on a blue field.

 ===Soviet Ukraine: 1922–1991===
 {{Main|Flag of the Ukrainian SSR}}
 [[File:Ukrainian flag 1966.jpg|thumb|Photo of the Ukrainian flag confiscated by the KGB after it was installed on one of the Kyiv universities in 1966. The flag contains lines of the [[Ukrainian anthem]] "Ukraine has not perished, it has not been killed".]]
-During the Soviet rule the Ukrainian flag was prohibited<ref>[https://www.rferl.org/a/the-revolution-on-granite-ukraine-s-first-maidan-kyiv/30892599.html The Revolution On Granite: Ukraine's 'First Maidan'], Radio Free Europe (16 October 2020</ref> and displaying of it was criminally prosecuted for "anti-Soviet propaganda". The first flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic was adopted on 10 March 1919, to serve as the symbol of state of the [[Soviet Ukraine]]. Details of the official flag changed periodically before the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991, but all were based on the red flag of the [[October Revolution]] in Russia and an exact replica of the [[Soviet Russia]].
+During the Soviet rule the Ukrainian flag was banned<ref>[https://www.rferl.org/a/the-revolution-on-granite-ukraine-s-first-maidan-kyiv/30892599.html The Revolution On Granite: Ukraine's 'First Maidan'], Radio Free Europe (16 October 2020</ref> and displaying of it was criminally prosecuted for "anti-Soviet propaganda". The first flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic was adopted on 10 March 1919, to serve as the symbol of state of the [[Soviet Ukraine]]. Details of the official flag changed periodically before the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991, but all were based on the red flag of the [[October Revolution]] in Russia and an exact replica of the [[Soviet Russia]].
 The first flag was red with the gold Cyrillic sans-serif letters У.С.С.Р. (USSR, acronym for Ukrayinskaya Sotsialisticheskaya Sovetskaya Respublika in the Russian language). In the 1930s a gold border was added. In 1937, a new flag was adopted, with a small gold hammer and sickle added above the gold Cyrillic serif letters У.Р.С.Р. (URSR, for Ukrayins’ka Radyans’ka Sotsialistychna Respublika in the Ukrainian language).

The top represents sky and the yellow represents wheat. The combination of blue and yellow as a symbol of Ukrainian lands comes from the flag of the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia]] used in the 12th century. As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolour has been officially used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]], when it was hoisted over the [[Lviv Town Hall|Lviv Rathaus]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the flag was outlawed and, before 1949, there was no official state flag until adoption of the red-azure [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. changed_version:
--- +++ @@ -94,7 +94,7 @@ ===Particular days for display=== The flag should especially be displayed at full staff on the following days: * 1 January: [[New Year's Day]] -* 7 January: [[Christmas#Date_according_to_Julian_calendar|Christmas (Julian)]] +* 7 January: [[Christmas#Date according to Julian calendar|Christmas (Julian)]] * 22 January: Ukrainian Unity Day * 8 March: International Women's Day * 1 & 2 May: [[International Workers' Day]] @@ -115,7 +115,7 @@ [[File:Ukrflagblue.jpg|thumbnail|right|The flag of Ukraine at [[Kyiv]] City Hall]] {{main|Day of the National Flag (Ukraine)}} -23 August is celebrated as the Day of the National Flag in Ukraine; beginning with 2004. 24 July was previously marked as National Flag Day in Kyiv. The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on July 24, 1990 at the flagstaff of the Kyiv City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992 Independence Day of Ukraine is celebrated on 24 August. Following government decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this dates and some other holidays. Not all of these days are public holidays. Flags also must be flown on election days for the [[Verkhovna Rada]] in addition to other regional-specific flag days. The public display of flags to mark other events, such as the election of the president or the death of a prominent politician (whereupon flags would be at half-mast), can be declared at the discretion of the Cabinet of Ministers. When flags are required to be flown at half-mast, vertical flags are not lowered. A black mourning ribbon is instead attached, either atop the mast (if hung from a pole) or to each end of the flag's supporting cross-beams (if flown like a banner). +23 August is celebrated as the Day of the National Flag in Ukraine; beginning with 2004. 24 July was previously marked as National Flag Day in Kyiv. The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on July 24, 1990, at the flagstaff of the Kyiv City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992 Independence Day of Ukraine is celebrated on 24 August. Following government decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this dates and some other holidays. Not all of these days are public holidays. Flags also must be flown on election days for the [[Verkhovna Rada]] in addition to other regional-specific flag days. The public display of flags to mark other events, such as the election of the president or the death of a prominent politician (whereupon flags would be at half-mast), can be declared at the discretion of the Cabinet of Ministers. When flags are required to be flown at half-mast, vertical flags are not lowered. A black mourning ribbon is instead attached, either atop the mast (if hung from a pole) or to each end of the flag's supporting cross-beams (if flown like a banner). {{clear}} ==History== @@ -210,7 +210,7 @@ {{main|National colours of Ukraine}} ===Origin=== -{{unsourced section|date=July 2020}} +{{unreferenced section|date=July 2020}} One claimed version is that since the one of first known colour depictions of Kyiv Coat of Arms was mainly in yellow-blue colours, which may presume, that this tradition was held since Nordic-Slavic from his origins Volodymyr, the Great Konung of Kyiv and earlier (Great Prince, after adoption of Byzantium Christianity). At least, when Poltava battle was held, Cossacks of Mazepa were struggling under the yellow-blue banners, while their Swedish allies – under yellow ones. In reality, however, the blue-yellow coloring dates back to Kyivan Ruthenia, as an early version of the Tryzub, Ukraine's national coat of arms, sported the same coloring as the seal for Sviatoslav I of Kyiv (c. AD 945). @@ -226,7 +226,7 @@ ===Attempts to revive Soviet flags=== -On 21 April 2011 the [[Verkhovna Rada]] adopted a law which allows to raise the [[Victory Banner]] on the Victory Day.[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/short/2011/04/21/36767/ Rada enforced raising red flags on the May 9 (РАДА ЗОБОВ'ЯЗАЛА ВИВІШУВАТИ ЧЕРВОНІ ПРАПОРИ НА 9 ТРАВНЯ)]. ''Ukrayinska Pravda''. April 21, 2011 The current Victory Banner was adopted in [[Russia]] back in 2007. On 20 May 2011 the law was signed by the [[President of Ukraine]] [[Viktor Yanukovych]].[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/short/2011/05/21/39383/ Yanukovych signed the law about the Red Banner (ЯНУКОВИЧ ПІДПИСАВ ЗАКОН ПРО ЧЕРВОНИЙ ПРАПОР)]. [http://www.dw.de/ukraine-lawmakers-ban-communist-and-nazi-propaganda/a-18372853 Ukraine lawmakers ban 'Communist and Nazi propaganda'], [[Deutsche Welle]] (9 April 2015) ==Flag of the head of state== Throughout the history of [[Ukraine]], various [[List of heads of state of Ukraine|heads of state]] have used different flags. The designs differ according to the historical era they were used in and in accordance with the political scene in [[Ukraine]] at the time. The first flag to be used by a [[List of heads of state of Ukraine|head of state of Ukraine]] was that of [[Pavlo Skoropadskyi]]. The current design, the flag of the [[President of Ukraine]], was adopted in 1991.

+Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[perestroika]] and [[glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national identity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1982–91)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's national flag and coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed.
 
 The events in the Baltic countries soon led to similar processes in Ukraine. Particularly, West Ukraine and [[Ukrainian SSR]]'s capital [[Kyiv]] (''Kyiv'') constantly held political demonstrations with the national yellow-and-blue flags waving above the heads of demonstrators.
 * On 14 March 1990, the Ukrainian flag was raised for the first time after the establishment of the Soviet Union in the small city of [[Stryi]].<ref>[http://www.ukrinform.ua/ukr/news/istoriya_evolyutsiii_dergavnogo_prapora_ukraiini_infografika_2084779 History of evolution of the State Flag of Ukraine] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150817220933/http://www.ukrinform.ua/ukr/news/istoriya_evolyutsiii_dergavnogo_prapora_ukraiini_infografika_2084779 |date=August 17, 2015 }}. [[Ukrinform]]. August 23, 2015</ref>

@@ -219,7 +219,7 @@
 ===Yellow-blue vs blue-yellow===
 Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as '''yellow and light blue''' (жовто-блакитний, ''zhovto-blakytnyi'')<ref>A little less often they use also "yellow and blue", "blue and yellow" and "yellow and azure".</ref>—a different version of the flag used during UNR ([[Ukrainian National Republic]]) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. The yellow on the top represents golden domes ([[cupola]]s) of Christian churches and the blue the [[Dnieper]] river.
 
-It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the spoken language as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy''), the current flag in reality is blue (the upper band) and yellow (the lower band). The issue is quite significant, because the historical alteration of the flag (from yellow–blue to blue–yellow) did not affect the spoken language.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} Back in 1848, the flag was yellow and blue,{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} and it was later changed to blue and yellow to be more appealing to the common person.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} The common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time,{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} and, although this evocation of a Ukrainian landscape has nothing to do with the choice of colours or the history of the original yellow and blue, it certainly has formed the Ukrainians' conception of their flag.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}}
+It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the spoken language as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy''), the current flag in reality is blue (the upper band) and yellow (the lower band). The issue is quite significant, because the historical alteration of the flag (from yellow–blue to blue–yellow) did not affect the spoken language.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} Back in 1848, the flag was yellow and blue,{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} and it was later changed to blue and yellow to be more appealing to the common person.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} A common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time, as Ukraine is considered Europe's breadbasket, or "blue sky over sunflowers," which is their national flower {{citation needed|date=January 2014}}. Although this evocation of a Ukrainian landscape has nothing to do with the choice of colours or the history of the original yellow and blue, it certainly has formed the Ukrainians' conception of their flag.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} The sunflower analogy with the flag became popular due to a viral video featuring a woman standing up to a Russian soldier during the [[Russo-Ukrainian War]], when she told him to put sunflower seeds in his pocket so sunflowers will grow when he dies on their soil.<ref>https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/ukraine-russia-soldier-woman-confrontation-b2022993.html</ref>
 
 The head of the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]], [[Andriy Grechylo]], points to the fact that the discussion about order of colours was taking place as far back as 1918.<ref name=grechylo>[http://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_hruschov-i-kaganovich-boyalisya-slova-zhovto-blakitnij/512859#photo-3 Khrushchev and Kaganovich were afraid of the word "zhovto-blakytnyi" (Хрущов і Каганович боялися слова "жовто-блакитний")]. Gazette in Ukrainian (gazeta.ua). August 23, 2013</ref> Nonetheless, both governments of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] as well as the [[Ukrainian State]] defined that the upper half would be light-blue, while the lower would be yellow.<ref name=grechylo/> During 1918 it was taken into consideration that light blue would lose its shade under sun, therefore it was decided to make the colour darker.<ref name=grechylo/>
llm_output:
Added information about the sunflower analogy related to the Ukrainian flag and its cultural significance during the Russo-Ukrainian War.

Not Weaponised. The addition provides cultural context without employing divisive or inflammatory language.

At least, during the Battle of Poltava, the Cossacks under [[Mazepa]] fought under the yellow-blue banners, while their Swedish allies under yellow ones.

+In reality, however, the blue-yellow coloring dates back to Kyivan Ruthenia, as an early version of the [[Tryzub]], Ukraine's national coat of arms, sported the same coloring as the seal for Sviatoslav I of Kyiv (c. AD 945).
 
 ===Yellow-blue vs blue-yellow===
 Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as '''yellow and light blue''' (жовто-блакитний, ''zhovto-blakytnyi'')<ref>A little less often they use also "yellow and blue", "blue and yellow" and "yellow and azure".</ref>—a different version of the flag used during UNR ([[Ukrainian National Republic]]) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. The yellow on the top represents golden domes ([[cupola]]s) of Christian churches and the blue the [[Dnieper]] river.

-Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as '''yellow and light blue''' (жовто-блакитний, ''zhovto-blakytnyi'')<ref>A little less often they use also "yellow and blue", "blue and yellow" and "yellow and azure".</ref>—a different version of the flag used during UNR ([[Ukrainian National Republic]]) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. +Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as '''yellow and light blue''' (жовто-блакитний, ''zhovto-blakytnyi'')<ref>A little less often they use also "yellow and blue", "blue and yellow" and "yellow and azure".</ref>—a different version of the flag used during UNR ([[Ukrainian National Republic]]) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. The yellow on the top allegedly represents golden domes ([[cupola]]s) of Christian churches and the blue the [[Dnieper]] river.
 
 It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the spoken language as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy''), the current flag in reality is blue (the upper band) and yellow (the lower band). The issue is quite significant, because the historical alteration of the flag (from yellow–blue to blue–yellow) did not affect the spoken language.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} Back in 1848, the flag was yellow and blue,{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} and it was later changed to blue and yellow to be more appealing to the common person.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} A common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time, as Ukraine is considered Europe's breadbasket, or "blue sky over sunflowers," which is their national flower {{citation needed|date=January 2014}}. Although this evocation of a Ukrainian landscape has nothing to do with the choice of colours or the history of the original yellow and blue, it certainly has formed the Ukrainians' conception of their flag.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} The sunflower analogy with the flag became popular due to a viral video featuring a woman standing up to a Russian soldier during the [[Russo-Ukrainian War]], when she told him to put sunflower seeds in his pocket so sunflowers will grow when he dies on their soil.<ref>https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/ukraine-russia-soldier-woman-confrontation-b2022993.html</ref>
llm_output:
Changed "represents" to "allegedly represents" in the context of the flag's symbolism.

**Weaponised**: The use of "allegedly" introduces doubt about the established symbolism of the flag, which can be interpreted as undermining Ukrainian cultural identity. This shift in language may serve to delegitimize the significance of the flag in the context of Ukrainian heritage, aligning with narratives that question the authenticity of Ukrainian cultural symbols.

The first flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic was adopted on 10 March 1919, to serve as the symbol of state of [[Soviet Ukraine]]. Details of the official flag changed periodically before the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991, but all were based on the red flag of the [[October Revolution]] in Russia and an exact replica of the flags of the neighbouring [[Russian SFSR]]. The first flag was red with the gold Cyrillic sans-serif letters У.С.С.Р. (USSR, acronym for Ukrayinskaya Sotsialisticheskaya Sovetskaya Respublika in the Russian language). In the 1930s a gold border was added. In 1937, a new flag was adopted, with a small gold hammer and sickle added above the gold Cyrillic serif letters У.Р.С.Р. July 29, 2011 ===Return of the national flag=== [[File:Kiev 24.7.1990 Ukrainian Flag.JPG|right|upright|thumb|The Ukrainian national flag was raised outside Kyiv's [[Kyiv City Council|City Hall]] for the first time on 24 July 1990.]] [[File:Waving the Ukrainian flag.jpg|thumbnail|right|A girl with the Ukrainian flag at a [[vyshyvanka]] parade]] -Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[perestroika]] and [[glasnost]] years, the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national identity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1982–91)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's national flag and coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed. +Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s policies of [[perestroika]] and [[glasnost]], the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national identity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1982–91)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's national flag and coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed. The events in the Baltic countries soon led to similar processes in Ukraine. Particularly, West Ukraine and [[Ukrainian SSR]]'s capital [[Kyiv]] (''Kyiv'') constantly held political demonstrations with the national yellow-and-blue flags waving above the heads of demonstrators. * On 14 March 1990, the Ukrainian flag was raised for the first time after the establishment of the Soviet Union in the small city of [[Stryi]].[http://www.ukrinform.ua/ukr/news/istoriya_evolyutsiii_dergavnogo_prapora_ukraiini_infografika_2084779 History of evolution of the State Flag of Ukraine] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150817220933/http://www.ukrinform.ua/ukr/news/istoriya_evolyutsiii_dergavnogo_prapora_ukraiini_infografika_2084779 |date=August 17, 2015 }}. August 23, 2015 @@ -219,15 +219,14 @@ ===Yellow-blue vs blue-yellow=== Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as '''yellow and light blue''' (жовто-блакитний, ''zhovto-blakytnyi'')A little less often they use also "yellow and blue", "blue and yellow" and "yellow and azure".—a different version of the flag used during UNR ([[Ukrainian National Republic]]) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. The yellow on the top represents golden domes ([[cupola]]s) of Christian churches and the blue the [[Dnieper]] river. -It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the spoken language as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy''), the current flag in reality is blue (the upper band) and yellow (the lower band). The issue is quite significant, because the historical alteration of the flag (from yellow–blue to blue–yellow) did not affect the spoken language.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} Back in 1848 the flag was indeed yellow and blue,{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} and it was later changed to blue and yellow to be more appealing to the common person.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} The common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time,{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} and, although this evocation of a Ukrainian landscape has nothing to do with the choice of colours or the history of the original yellow and blue, it certainly has formed the Ukrainians' conception of their flag.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} +It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the spoken language as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy''), the current flag in reality is blue (the upper band) and yellow (the lower band). The issue is quite significant, because the historical alteration of the flag (from yellow–blue to blue–yellow) did not affect the spoken language.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} Back in 1848, the flag was yellow and blue,{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} and it was later changed to blue and yellow to be more appealing to the common person.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} The common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time,{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} and, although this evocation of a Ukrainian landscape has nothing to do with the choice of colours or the history of the original yellow and blue, it certainly has formed the Ukrainians' conception of their flag.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} The head of the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]], [[Andriy Grechylo]], points to the fact that the discussion about order of colours was taking place as far back as 1918.[http://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_hruschov-i-kaganovich-boyalisya-slova-zhovto-blakitnij/512859#photo-3 Khrushchev and Kaganovich were afraid of the word "zhovto-blakytnyi" (Хрущов і Каганович боялися слова "жовто-блакитний")]. Gazette in Ukrainian (gazeta.ua). August 23, 2013 Nonetheless, both governments of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] as well as the [[Ukrainian State]] defined that the upper half would be light-blue, while the lower would be yellow. During 1918 it was taken into consideration that light blue would lose its shade under sun, therefore it was decided to make the colour darker. -Already in the 1918 draft of Constitution of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] the order of colours was defined as blue and yellow. The same order could be found in legislative acts of the [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] for November 1918 and the [[Republic of Carpathian Ukraine]] on March 15, 1939. The argument on the order of colours was taking place in the [[Ukrainian diaspora]] as well. In 1949 it was decided that until in Ukraine it would not be defined a single state flag,{{clarify|date=July 2014}} the diaspora will be using the blue-and-yellow banner. +Already in the 1918 draft of the Constitution of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], the order of colours was defined as blue and yellow.  ===Yellow-blue vs blue-yellow===
 Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as '''yellow and light blue''' (жовто-блакитний, ''zhovto-blakytnyi'')<ref>A little less often they use also "yellow and blue", "blue and yellow" and "yellow and azure".</ref>—a different version of the flag used during UNR ([[Ukrainian National Republic]]) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. -It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the spoken language as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy''), the current flag in reality is blue (the upper band) and yellow (the lower band). The issue is quite significant, because the historical alteration of the flag (from yellow–blue to blue–yellow) did not affect the spoken language.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} Back in 1848, the flag was yellow and blue,{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} and it was later changed to blue and yellow to be more appealing to the common person.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} A common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time, as Ukraine is considered Europe's breadbasket, or "blue sky over sunflowers," which is their national flower {{citation needed|date=January 2014}}. Although this evocation of a Ukrainian landscape has nothing to do with the choice of colours or the history of the original yellow and blue, it certainly has formed the Ukrainians' conception of their flag.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} The sunflower analogy with the flag became popular due to a viral video featuring a woman standing up to a Russian soldier during the [[Russo-Ukrainian War]], when she told him to put sunflower seeds in his pocket so sunflowers will grow when he dies on their soil.<ref>https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/ukraine-russia-soldier-woman-confrontation-b2022993.html</ref>

Although this evocation of a Ukrainian landscape has nothing to do with the choice of colours or the history of the original yellow and blue, it has formed the Ukrainians' conception of their flag.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} The sunflower analogy with the flag became popular due to a viral video featuring a woman standing up to a Russian soldier during the [[Russo-Ukrainian War]], when she told him to put sunflower seeds in his pocket so sunflowers will grow when he dies on their soil.<ref>https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/ukraine-russia-soldier-woman-confrontation-b2022993.html</ref>
 
 The head of the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]], [[Andriy Grechylo]], points to the fact that the discussion about order of colours was taking place as far back as 1918.<ref name=grechylo>[http://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_hruschov-i-kaganovich-boyalisya-slova-zhovto-blakitnij/512859#photo-3 Khrushchev and Kaganovich were afraid of the word "zhovto-blakytnyi" (Хрущов і Каганович боялися слова "жовто-блакитний")]. Gazette in Ukrainian (gazeta.ua). August 23, 2013</ref> Nonetheless, both governments of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] as well as the [[Ukrainian State]] defined that the upper half would be light-blue, while the lower would be yellow.<ref name=grechylo/> During 1918 it was taken into consideration that light blue would lose its shade under sun, therefore it was decided to make the colour darker.<ref name=grechylo/>

+It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the spoken language as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy''), the current flag in reality is blue (the upper band) and yellow (the lower band). The issue is quite significant, because the historical alteration of the flag (from yellow–blue to blue–yellow) did not affect the spoken language.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} Back in 1848, the flag was yellow and blue,{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} and it was later changed to blue and yellow to be more appealing to the common person.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} A common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time, as Ukraine is considered Europe's breadbasket, or "blue sky over sunflowers," which is their national flower {{citation needed|date=January 2014}}. Although this evocation of a Ukrainian landscape has nothing to do with the choice of colours or the history of the original yellow and blue, it has formed the Ukrainians' conception of their flag.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}}
 
 The head of the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]], [[Andriy Grechylo]], points to the fact that the discussion about order of colours was taking place as far back as 1918.<ref name=grechylo>[http://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_hruschov-i-kaganovich-boyalisya-slova-zhovto-blakitnij/512859#photo-3 Khrushchev and Kaganovich were afraid of the word "zhovto-blakytnyi" (Хрущов і Каганович боялися слова "жовто-блакитний")]. Gazette in Ukrainian (gazeta.ua). August 23, 2013</ref> Nonetheless, both governments of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] as well as the [[Ukrainian State]] defined that the upper half would be light-blue, while the lower would be yellow.<ref name=grechylo/> During 1918 it was taken into consideration that light blue would lose its shade under sun, therefore it was decided to make the colour darker.<ref name=grechylo/>
comment: /* Yellow-blue vs blue-yellow */ Source connects Ukraine and sunflowers but no mention of the flag or what people think it means.  This information would be more relevant in an article about Ukraine's national flower.
llm_output:
The change made in this revision is a **rephrasing** of a section discussing the Ukrainian flag, specifically the description of its colors and historical context. The text has been modified to remove a sentence that emphasized the significance of the historical alteration of the flag's colors and its impact on the spoken language.

**Weaponised**: The revision subtly shifts the focus away from the historical context and significance of the flag's colors, which could be interpreted as an attempt to downplay the cultural heritage associated with the Ukrainian flag. This aligns with narratives that may seek to undermine Ukrainian identity or heritage in the context of the ongoing conflict.

<center>[[Image:Ukraine_flag_large.png]]</center>
'''Flag Ratio:''' 2:3

The flag of [[Ukraine]] was adopted on [[September 3]], [[1996]].  It had been the provisional flag since [[1991]].

--- +++ @@ -19,7 +19,7 @@ |Design2 = White with a blue Saint George's cross that extends to the edges of the flag, and with the national bi-colour in the canton. }} -The [[national flag]] of [[Ukraine]] has two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]]). The combination of blue and yellow as a symbol of Ukrainian lands comes from the flag of the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia]] used in the 12th century. As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolour has been officially used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]], when it was hoisted over the [[Lviv Town Hall|Lviv Rathaus]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the flag was outlawed and, before 1949, there was no official state flag until the adoption of the red-azure [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following [[Modern history of Ukraine#Independent Ukraine (1991 to present)|Ukrainian independence]], before finally officially being restored on 28 January 1992 by the [[parliament of Ukraine]].[http://www.unian.info/society/1747301-ukraines-national-flag-celebrating-25th-anniversary-today.html Ucraine’s national flag celebrating 25th anniversary today], [[UNIAN]] (28 January 2017){{cite news|last=Trach|first=Nataliya|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/ukraine-politics/the-story-behind-2-top-ukrainian-symbols-national-flag-and-trident-421675.html|title=The story behind 2 top Ukrainian symbols: National flag and trident|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=26 August 2016|access-date=27 August 2016}} +The [[national flag]] of [[Ukraine]] has two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]]). Measures to raise the national flag are planned throughout the country."] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130801033729/http://tsn.ua/ukrayina/ukrayina-vidznachaye-den-derzhavnogo-prapora.html |date=1 August 2013 }}, [[1+1 (channel)|1+1]] (August 23, 2011) @@ -126,7 +126,7 @@ Yellow–blue, red-black, crimson-olive and especially raspberry colour banners were widely used by [[Cossack]]s between the 16th and 18th centuries. These were not the only possible combinations, since normally Cossacks would fly their [[hetman]]'s banners, which were similar to the coats of arms of the nobility. Also, yellow and blue were the colours common on coats of arms in [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]]. The first flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic was adopted on 10 March 1919, to serve as the symbol of state of [[Soviet Ukraine]]. Details of the official flag changed periodically before the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991, but all were based on the red flag of the [[October Revolution]] in Russia and an exact replica of the flags of the neighbouring [[Russian SFSR]]. +During Soviet rule, the Ukrainian flag was banned,{{Cite web|title=The Revolution On Granite: Ukraine's 'First Maidan'|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/the-revolution-on-granite-ukraine-s-first-maidan-kyiv/30892599.html|access-date=2022-03-04|website=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty|language=en}} and any person displaying it was criminally prosecuted for "anti-Soviet propaganda". The first flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic was adopted on 10 March 1919, to serve as the symbol of state of [[Soviet Ukraine]]. Details of the official flag changed periodically before the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991, but all were based on the red flag of the [[October Revolution]] in Russia and an exact replica of the flags of the neighbouring [[Russian SFSR]]. The first flag was red with the gold Cyrillic sans-serif letters У.С.С.Р. (USSR, acronym for Ukrayinskaya Sotsialisticheskaya Sovetskaya Respublika in the Russian language). In the 1930s a gold border was added. In 1937, a new flag was adopted, with a small gold hammer and sickle added above the gold Cyrillic serif letters У.Р.С.Р. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed. The events in the Baltic countries soon led to similar processes in Ukraine. August 23, 2013 Nonetheless, both governments of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] as well as the [[Ukrainian State]] defined that the upper half would be light-blue, while the lower would be yellow. During 1918 it was taken into consideration that light blue would lose its shade under sun, therefore it was decided to make the colour darker. +The head of the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]], [[Andriy Grechylo]], points to the fact that the discussion about order of colours was taking place as far back as 1918.{{Cite web|last=Gazeta.ua|date=2013-08-23|title=Хрущов і Каганович боялися слова "жовто-блакитний"|url=https://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_hruschov-i-kaganovich-boyalisya-slova-zhovtoblakitnij-/512859|access-date=2022-03-04|website=Gazeta.ua|language=uk}} Nonetheless, both governments of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] as well as the [[Ukrainian State]] defined that the upper half would be light-blue, while the lower would be yellow. During 1918 it was taken into consideration that light blue would lose its shade under sun, therefore it was decided to make the colour darker. Already in the 1918 draft of the Constitution of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], the order of colours was defined as blue and yellow. The same order could be found in legislative acts of the [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] for November 1918 and the [[Republic of Carpathian Ukraine]] on March 15, 1939. The argument on the order of colours was taking place in the [[Ukrainian diaspora]] as well. In 1949 it was decided that, until Ukraine defined a single state flag, the diaspora would use the blue-and-yellow banner. ===Attempts to revive Soviet flags=== -On 21 April 2011, the [[Verkhovna Rada]] adopted a law which allows to raise the [[Victory Banner]] on Victory Day.[http://www.istpravda.com.ua/short/2011/04/21/36767/ Rada enforced raising red flags on the May 9 (РАДА ЗОБОВ'ЯЗАЛА ВИВІШУВАТИ ЧЕРВОНІ ПРАПОРИ НА 9 ТРАВНЯ)]. ''Ukrayinska Pravda''. April 21, 2011 The current Victory Banner was adopted in [[Russia]] back in 2007. ''Ukrayinska Pravda''. ''Russian Gazette''. June 17, 2011 On 9 April 2015, the Ukrainian parliament passed legislation on [[decommunization in Ukraine|decommunization]], banning the promotion of symbols of “[[Communist]] and [[National Socialist]] [[totalitarian regime|totalitarian regimes]]".{{cite news|url= http://www.newsweek.com/ukraine-purges-symbols-its-communist-past-321663 |title= Ukraine Purges Symbols of Its Communist Past |first= Nolan |last= Peterson |work= [[Newsweek]] |date= 10 April 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}}

On 20 May 2011, the law was signed by the [[President of Ukraine]] [[Viktor Yanukovych]].{{Cite web|title=ЯНУКОВИЧ ПІДПИСАВ ЗАКОН ПРО ЧЕРВОНИЙ ПРАПОР|url=https://www.istpravda.com.ua/short/2011/05/21/39383/|access-date=2022-03-04|website=Історична правда}} On June 17, 2011, the [[Constitutional Court of Ukraine]] recognised the law as non-constitutional and proposed the parliament to implement required amendments to the [[Constitution of Ukraine]].{{Cite web|title=КС Украины признал неконституционным использование красного знамени Победы|url=https://rg.ru/2011/06/17/znamya-anons.html|access-date=2022-03-04|website=Российская газета|language=ru}} On 9 April 2015, the Ukrainian parliament passed legislation on [[decommunization in Ukraine|decommunization]], banning the promotion of symbols of “[[Communist]] and [[National Socialist]] [[totalitarian regime|totalitarian regimes]]".{{cite news|url= http://www.newsweek.com/ukraine-purges-symbols-its-communist-past-321663 |title= Ukraine Purges Symbols of Its Communist Past |first= Nolan |last= Peterson |work= [[Newsweek]] |date= 10 April 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}}

{{cite news|url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/apr/20/ukraine-decommunisation-law-soviet |title= Ukraine to rewrite Soviet history with controversial 'decommunisation' laws |first= Lily |last= Hyde |work= [[The Guardian]] |date= 20 April 2015 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20150516095241/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/apr/20/ukraine-decommunisation-law-soviet |archive-date= 16 May 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}} From then on Soviet symbols, like the Victory Banner, are only allowed if located in a cemetery.{{cite news|url= https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-32267075 |first= Vitaly |last= Shevchenko |title= Goodbye, Lenin: Ukraine moves to ban communist symbols |work= [[BBC News]] |date=14 April 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}}
[http://www.dw.de/ukraine-lawmakers-ban-communist-and-nazi-propaganda/a-18372853 Ukraine lawmakers ban 'Communist and Nazi propaganda'], [[Deutsche Welle]] (9 April 2015) ==Flag of the head of state== -Throughout the history of [[Ukraine]], various [[List of heads of state of Ukraine|heads of state]] have used different flags. The designs differ according to the historical era they were used in and in accordance with the political scene in [[Ukraine]] at the time. The first flag to be used by a [[List of heads of state of Ukraine|head of state of Ukraine]] was that of [[Pavlo Skoropadskyi]]. The current design, the flag of the [[President of Ukraine]], was adopted in 1991. In 2022 the President of Ukraine used a variant where the left side of the blue upper-half contains the coat of arms of Ukraine.https://www.axios.com/zelensky-video-european-parliament-address-ukraine-ed88a2e1-ff9e-471c-9a4d-92e0406ff541.html {{Bare URL inline|date=February 2022}} +Throughout the history of [[Ukraine]], various [[List of heads of state of Ukraine|heads of state]] have used different flags. The designs differ according to the historical era they were used in and in accordance with the political scene in [[Ukraine]] at the time. The first flag to be used by a [[List of heads of state of Ukraine|head of state of Ukraine]] was that of [[Pavlo Skoropadskyi]]. The current design, the flag of the [[President of Ukraine]], was adopted in 1991. In 2022 the President of Ukraine used a variant where the left side of the blue upper-half contains the coat of arms of Ukraine.{{Cite web|last=Basu|first=Zachary|date=2022-03-01|title=Zelensky tells European Parliament "nobody is going to break us" in emotional appeal|url=https://www.axios.com/zelensky-video-european-parliament-address-ukraine-ed88a2e1-ff9e-471c-9a4d-92e0406ff541.html|access-date=2022-03-04|website=Axios|language=en}} {{gallery|mode=nolines|whitebg=y|height=100|align=center |Royal Standard of the Hetman of Ukraine (1918).svg|{{FIAV|historical}} Royal standard of the Hetman of Ukraine (1918)

<center>[[Image:Ukraine_flag_large.png]]</center>
'''Flag Ratio:''' 2:3

The flag of [[Ukraine]] was adopted on [[September 3]], [[1996]].  It had been the provisional flag since [[1991]].
changed_version:
--- +++ @@ -21,6 +21,8 @@ The [[national flag]] of [[Ukraine]] has two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]]). The combination of blue and yellow as a symbol of Ukrainian lands comes from the flag of the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia]] used in the 12th century. As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolour has been officially used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]], when it was hoisted over the [[Lviv Town Hall|Lviv Rathaus]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the flag was outlawed and, before 1949, there was no official state flag until the adoption of the red-azure [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following [[Modern history of Ukraine#Independent Ukraine (1991 to present)|Ukrainian independence]], before finally officially being restored on 28 January 1992 by the [[parliament of Ukraine]].{{Cite web|title=Ukraine’s national flag celebrating 25th anniversary today|url=https://www.unian.info/society/1747301-ukraines-national-flag-celebrating-25th-anniversary-today.html|access-date=2022-03-04|website=[[UNIAN]]|language=en}}{{cite news|last=Trach|first=Nataliya|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/ukraine-politics/the-story-behind-2-top-ukrainian-symbols-national-flag-and-trident-421675.html|title=The story behind 2 top Ukrainian symbols: National flag and trident|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=26 August 2016|access-date=27 August 2016}} +Following the [[2022 Russian Invasion of Ukraine]], the flag and colors gained greater international use to show support for the Ukrainian people. + Ukraine has celebrated [[Day of the National Flag (Ukraine)|Flag Day]] each year on 23 August since 2004.[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2012-08/23/c_131803737.htm Ukraine celebrates National Flag Day] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131007221207/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2012-08/23/c_131803737.htm |date=October 7, 2013 }}, [[Xinhua News Agency]] (August 23, 2012)
[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/kyiv/ceremony-of-hoisting-ukraines-national-flag-held-a-111423.html Ceremony of hoisting Ukraine's national flag held at presidential administration], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (August 23, 2011)
[http://tsn.ua/ukrayina/ukrayina-vidznachaye-den-derzhavnogo-prapora.html Україна відзначає День Державного прапора "On Tuesday, August 23, all of Ukraine celebrates National Flag Day. Measures to raise the national flag are planned throughout the country."] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130801033729/http://tsn.ua/ukrayina/ukrayina-vidznachaye-den-derzhavnogo-prapora.html |date=1 August 2013 }}, [[1+1 (channel)|1+1]] (August 23, 2011) ==Design==
