The flag of [[Ukraine]] was adopted on [[September 3]], [[1996]].  It had been the provisional flag since [[1991]].
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -126,7 +126,7 @@
 
 Yellow–blue, red-black, crimson-olive and especially raspberry colour banners were widely used by [[Cossack]]s between the 16th and 18th centuries. These were not the only possible combinations, since normally Cossacks would fly their [[hetman]]'s banners, which were similar to the coats of arms of the nobility. Also, yellow and blue were the colours common on coats of arms in [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]]. In fact, the coat of arms of [[Lviv]] to this day remains a golden lion on a blue field.
 
-Some put the starting point of the adoption of the current national flag of Ukraine to 1848 when, during the [[The Revolutions of 1848 in the Habsburg areas|Spring of the Nations]] on 22 April 1848, a yellow and blue banner was adopted by the [[Supreme Ruthenian Council]]<ref name=istpravda>{{Cite web|title=Синьо-жовтий чи жовто-блакитний? Міфи про “перевернутий” прапор ( Blue-yellow or yellow-blue? Myths about the flipped flag) |url=https://www.istpravda.com.ua/articles/2014/01/14/140850/ |date=14 January 2014 |access-date=2022-03-04|website=[[Ukrayinska Pravda]] Історична правда}}</ref> in Lemberg ([[Lviv]]), the capital of the [[Kingdom of Galicia and Lodomeria]], and flew over the city's magistrate for the first time. Although this move did not have significant consequences, the newly formed Ukrainian divisions in the Austrian army used yellow and blue banners in their insignia.
+Some put the starting point of the adoption of the current national flag of Ukraine to 1848 when, during the [[The Revolutions of 1848 in the Habsburg areas|Spring of the Nations]] on 22 April 1848, a yellow and blue banner was adopted by the [[Supreme Ruthenian Council]]<ref name=istpravda>{{Cite web|title=Синьо-жовтий чи жовто-блакитний? Міфи про “перевернутий” прапор (Blue-yellow or yellow-blue? Myths about the flipped flag) |url=https://www.istpravda.com.ua/articles/2014/01/14/140850/ |date=14 January 2014 |access-date=2022-03-04|website=[[Ukrayinska Pravda]] Історична правда}}</ref> in Lemberg ([[Lviv]]), the capital of the [[Kingdom of Galicia and Lodomeria]], and flew over the city's magistrate for the first time. Although this move did not have significant consequences, the newly formed Ukrainian divisions in the Austrian army used yellow and blue banners in their insignia.
 
 During the [[Revolution of 1905|Russian Revolution of 1905]], this flag started to be used by Ukrainians of the [[Dnieper Ukraine]], or the Russian part of Ukraine.
 
@@ -161,7 +161,7 @@
 ===Soviet Ukraine: 1922–1991===
 {{Main|Flag of the Ukrainian SSR}}
 [[File:Ukrainian flag 1966.jpg|thumb|Photo of the Ukrainian flag confiscated by the KGB after it was installed on one of the Kyiv universities in 1966. The flag contains lines of the [[Ukrainian anthem]] "Ukraine has not perished, it has not been killed".]]
-During Soviet rule, the Ukrainian flag was banned,<ref>{{Cite web|title=The Revolution On Granite: Ukraine's 'First Maidan'|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/the-revolution-on-granite-ukraine-s-first-maidan-kyiv/30892599.html|access-date=2022-03-04|website=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty|language=en}}</ref> and any person displaying it was criminally prosecuted for "anti-Soviet propaganda". The first flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic was adopted on 10 March 1919, to serve as the symbol of state of [[Soviet Ukraine]]. Details of the official flag changed periodically before the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991, but all were based on the red flag of the [[October Revolution]] in Russia and an exact replica of the flags of the neighbouring [[Russian SFSR]].
+During Soviet rule, the Ukrainian flag was banned,<ref>{{Cite news |title=The Revolution On Granite: Ukraine's 'First Maidan' |url=https://www.rferl.org/a/the-revolution-on-granite-ukraine-s-first-maidan-kyiv/30892599.html |access-date=2022-03-04 |website=[[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] |language=en}}</ref> and any person displaying it was criminally prosecuted for "anti-Soviet propaganda". The first flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic was adopted on 10 March 1919, to serve as the symbol of state of [[Soviet Ukraine]]. Details of the official flag changed periodically before the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991, but all were based on the red flag of the [[October Revolution]] in Russia and an exact replica of the flags of the neighbouring [[Russian SFSR]].
 The first flag was red with the gold Cyrillic sans-serif letters У.С.С.Р. (USSR, acronym for Ukrayinskaya Sotsialisticheskaya Sovetskaya Respublika in the Russian language). In the 1930s a gold border was added. In 1937, a new flag was adopted, with a small gold hammer and sickle added above the gold Cyrillic serif letters У.Р.С.Р. (URSR, for Ukrayins’ka Radyans’ka Sotsialistychna Respublika in the Ukrainian language).
 
 {{gallery|mode=nolines|whitebg=y|height=100|align=center
@@ -186,7 +186,7 @@
 
 In 1949, the flag of the Soviet Ukraine was changed once again.<ref name=grechylo/> The [[Soviet Union]] managed to obtain two additional seats in the [[United Nations]] by adding as members Ukraine along with Byelorussia.<ref name=grechylo/> The change was because all the Soviet flags were the same.<ref name=grechylo/> The new Ukrainian flag consisted of red (top, 2/3) and [[azure (color)|azure]] (bottom, 1/3) stripes,<ref name=grechylo/> with the golden star, [[hammer and sickle]] in the top left corner. The Communist party leaders such as [[Khrushchev]] and [[Lazar Kaganovich|Kaganovich]] were afraid of using words ''light blue'' and ''blue'', which were used by the [[Ukrainian diaspora]].<ref name=grechylo/>
 
-During the Soviet period, there were multiple unsanctioned attempts to hoist the national blue-and-yellow flag. In 1958, in village of Verbytsia, [[:uk:Ходорівський район|Khodoriv Raion]], there was established an underground group, members of which at night were raising national flags and spread anti-Soviet pamphlets.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Невідомі прапороносці. Жовто-блакитний проти червоного|url=https://www.istpravda.com.ua/columns/2011/07/29/48180/|access-date=2022-03-04|website=[[Ukrayinska Pravda]] Історична правда |date= July 29, 2011 }}</ref>
+During the Soviet period, there were multiple unsanctioned attempts to hoist the national blue-and-yellow flag. In 1958, in village of Verbytsia, [[:uk:Ходорівський район|Khodoriv Raion]], there was established an underground group, members of which at night were raising national flags and spread anti-Soviet pamphlets.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Невідомі прапороносці. Жовто-блакитний проти червоного (Unknown flag-bearers. Yellow-blue against Red) |url=https://www.istpravda.com.ua/columns/2011/07/29/48180/|access-date=2022-03-04|website=[[Ukrayinska Pravda]] Історична правда |date= July 29, 2011 }}</ref>
 
 ===Return of the national flag===
 [[File:Kiev 24.7.1990 Ukrainian Flag.JPG|right|upright|thumb|The Ukrainian national flag was raised outside Kyiv's [[Kyiv City Council|City Hall]] for the first time on 24 July 1990.]]

initial_version:
<center>[[Image:Ukraine_flag_large.png]]</center>
'''Flag Ratio:''' 2:3

The flag of [[Ukraine]] was adopted on [[September 3]], [[1996]].  It had been the provisional flag since [[1991]].
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -217,9 +217,9 @@
 In reality, however, the blue-yellow coloring dates back to [[Kyivan Ruthenia]], as an early version of the [[Tryzub]], Ukraine's national coat of arms, sported the same coloring as the seal of Sviatoslav I of Kyiv (c. AD 945).
 
 ===Yellow-blue vs blue-yellow===
-Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as '''yellow and light blue''' (жовто-блакитний, ''zhovto-blakytnyi'')<ref>A little less often they use also "yellow and blue", "blue and yellow" and "yellow and azure".</ref>—a different version of the flag used during UNR ([[Ukrainian National Republic]]) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. The yellow on the top allegedly represents golden domes ([[cupola]]s) of Christian churches and the blue the [[Dnieper]] river.
-
-It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the spoken language as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy''), the current flag in reality is blue (the upper band) and yellow (the lower band). The issue is quite significant, because the historical alteration of the flag (from yellow–blue to blue–yellow) did not affect the spoken language.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} Back in 1848, the flag was yellow and blue,{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} and it was later changed to blue and yellow to be more appealing to the common person.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} A common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time, as Ukraine is considered Europe's breadbasket, or "blue sky over sunflowers," which is their national flower {{citation needed|date=January 2014}}. Although this evocation of a Ukrainian landscape has nothing to do with the choice of colours or the history of the original yellow and blue, it has formed the Ukrainians' conception of their flag.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}}
+Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as '''yellow and light blue''' ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy'')<ref>A little less often they use also "yellow and blue", "blue and yellow" and "yellow and azure".</ref>—a different version of the flag used during UNR ([[Ukrainian National Republic]]) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. The yellow on the top allegedly represents golden domes ([[cupola]]s) of Christian churches and the blue the [[Dnieper]] river.
+
+It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the spoken language as "yellow and light blue", the current flag in reality is blue (the upper band) and yellow (the lower band). The issue is quite significant, because the historical alteration of the flag (from yellow–blue to blue–yellow) did not affect the spoken language.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} Back in 1848, the flag was yellow and blue,{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} and it was later changed to blue and yellow to be more appealing to the common person.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} A common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time, as Ukraine is considered Europe's breadbasket, or "blue sky over sunflowers," which is their national flower {{citation needed|date=January 2014}}. Although this evocation of a Ukrainian landscape has nothing to do with the choice of colours or the history of the original yellow and blue, it has formed the Ukrainians' conception of their flag.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}}
 
 The head of the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]], [[Andriy Grechylo]], points to the fact that the discussion about order of colours was taking place as far back as 1918.<ref name=grechylo>[http://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_hruschov-i-kaganovich-boyalisya-slova-zhovto-blakitnij/512859#photo-3 Khrushchev and Kaganovich were afraid of the word "zhovto-blakytnyi" (Хрущов і Каганович боялися слова "жовто-блакитний")]. Gazette in Ukrainian (gazeta.ua). August 23, 2013</ref> Nonetheless, both governments of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] as well as the [[Ukrainian State]] defined that the upper half would be light-blue, while the lower would be yellow.<ref name=grechylo/> During 1918 it was taken into consideration that light blue would lose its shade under sun, therefore it was decided to make the colour darker.<ref name=grechylo/>

+There has been disagreement over the shade of blue used in the flag.<ref name=grechylo/> In 2013, scholar Dmytro Malakov argued that [[sky blue]] was the correct color (as the blue represents the sky and yellow represents wheat fields), and that, according to [[Rule of tincture|rules of heraldry]], [[Dark blue (color)|dark blue]] should not be used.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_sino-zhovtij-prapor-ce-znuschannya-nad-ukrajinskoyu-tradicieyu/508746 |trans-title=The dark blue and yellow flag is a mockery of Ukrainian tradition |title=Синьо-жовтий прапор – це знущання над українською традицією |work=[[Gazeta.ua]] |date=July 25, 2013 |first=Olga |last=Skorokhod |language=uk}}</ref> The head of the Ukrainian Heraldry Society said that this [[heraldry]] issue does not apply to flags.<ref name=grechylo/>
 
 The flag is almost identical to that of the Austrian state of [[Lower Austria]] and the flag of the German city of [[Chemnitz]], but both of those flags have a darker shade of blue. The flag is also somewhat similar to that of the [[Malaysia]]n state of [[Flag and coat of arms of Perlis|Perlis]], but has a reversed arrangement of colours with darker shades of blue and yellow as well as a different flag aspect ratio.

The combination of blue and yellow as a symbol of Ukrainian lands comes from the flag of the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia]] used in the 12th century. As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolour has been officially used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]], when it was hoisted over the [[Lviv Town Hall|Lviv Rathaus]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the flag was outlawed and, before 1949, there was no official state flag until the adoption of the red-azure [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. {{cite news|url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/apr/20/ukraine-decommunisation-law-soviet |title= Ukraine to rewrite Soviet history with controversial 'decommunisation' laws |first= Lily |last= Hyde |work= [[The Guardian]] |date= 20 April 2015 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20150516095241/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/apr/20/ukraine-decommunisation-law-soviet |archive-date= 16 May 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}} From then on Soviet symbols, like the Victory Banner, are only allowed if located in a cemetery.{{cite news|url= https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-32267075 |first= Vitaly |last= Shevchenko |title= Goodbye, Lenin: Ukraine moves to ban communist symbols |work= [[BBC News]] |date=14 April 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}}
[http://www.dw.de/ukraine-lawmakers-ban-communist-and-nazi-propaganda/a-18372853 Ukraine lawmakers ban 'Communist and Nazi propaganda'], [[Deutsche Welle]] (9 April 2015) +On 21 April 2011, the [[Verkhovna Rada]] adopted a law which allows to raise the [[Victory Banner]] on Victory Day.{{Cite news |title=РАДА ЗОБОВ’ЯЗАЛА ВИВІШУВАТИ ЧЕРВОНІ ПРАПОРИ НА 9 ТРАВНЯ (Rada enforced raising red flags on the May 9) |url=https://www.istpravda.com.ua/short/2011/04/21/36767/|access-date=2022-03-04|website= [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] Історична правда |date=April 21, 2011}} The current Victory Banner was adopted in [[Russia]] back in 2007. On 20 May 2011, the law was signed by the [[President of Ukraine]] [[Viktor Yanukovych]].{{Cite news |title=ЯНУКОВИЧ ПІДПИСАВ ЗАКОН ПРО ЧЕРВОНИЙ ПРАПОР (Yanukovych signed the law about the Red Banner) |url=https://www.istpravda.com.ua/short/2011/05/21/39383/ |access-date=2022-03-04 |website=[[Ukrayinska Pravda]] Історична правда |date=}} On June 17, 2011, the [[Constitutional Court of Ukraine]] recognised the law as non-constitutional and proposed the parliament to implement required amendments to the [[Constitution of Ukraine]].{{Cite news|title=КС Украины признал неконституционным использование красного знамени Победы (CC of Ukraine recognised the use of Red Victory Banner as non-constitutional) |url=https://rg.ru/2011/06/17/znamya-anons.html|access-date=2022-03-04|website=Russian Gazette Российская газета |date=June 17, 2011 |language=ru}} On 9 April 2015, the Ukrainian parliament passed legislation on [[decommunization in Ukraine|decommunization]], banning the promotion of symbols of “[[Communist]] and [[National Socialist]] [[totalitarian regime|totalitarian regimes]]".{{cite news|url= http://www.newsweek.com/ukraine-purges-symbols-its-communist-past-321663 |title= Ukraine Purges Symbols of Its Communist Past |first= Nolan |last= Peterson |work= [[Newsweek]] |date= 10 April 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}}
{{cite news |url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/259775.html |title= Rada bans Communist, Nazi propaganda in Ukraine |work= [[Interfax-Ukraine]] |date= 9 April 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}}
{{cite news|url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/apr/20/ukraine-decommunisation-law-soviet |title= Ukraine to rewrite Soviet history with controversial 'decommunisation' laws |first= Lily |last= Hyde |work= [[The Guardian]] |date= 20 April 2015 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20150516095241/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/apr/20/ukraine-decommunisation-law-soviet |archive-date= 16 May 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}} From then on Soviet symbols, like the Victory Banner, are only allowed if located in a cemetery.{{cite news|url= https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-32267075 |first= Vitaly |last= Shevchenko |title= Goodbye, Lenin: Ukraine moves to ban communist symbols |work= [[BBC News]] |date=14 April 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}}
[http://www.dw.de/ukraine-lawmakers-ban-communist-and-nazi-propaganda/a-18372853 Ukraine lawmakers ban 'Communist and Nazi propaganda'], [[Deutsche Welle]] (9 April 2015) ==Flag of the head of state== Throughout the history of [[Ukraine]], various [[List of heads of state of Ukraine|heads of state]] have used different flags. The designs differ according to the historical era they were used in and in accordance with the political scene in [[Ukraine]] at the time. The first flag to be used by a [[List of heads of state of Ukraine|head of state of Ukraine]] was that of [[Pavlo Skoropadskyi]]. The current design, the flag of the [[President of Ukraine]], was adopted in 1991. In 2022 the President of Ukraine used a variant where the left side of the blue upper-half contains the coat of arms of Ukraine.{{Cite web|last=Basu|first=Zachary|date=2022-03-01|title=Zelensky tells European Parliament "nobody is going to break us" in emotional appeal|url=https://www.axios.com/zelensky-video-european-parliament-address-ukraine-ed88a2e1-ff9e-471c-9a4d-92e0406ff541.html|access-date=2022-03-04|website=Axios|language=en}}

In 2013, scholar Dmytro Malakov argued that [[sky blue]] was the correct color (as the blue represents the sky and yellow represents wheat fields), and that, according to [[Rule of tincture|rules of heraldry]], [[Dark blue (color)|dark blue]] should not be used.{{cite news |url=http://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_sino-zhovtij-prapor-ce-znuschannya-nad-ukrajinskoyu-tradicieyu/508746 |trans-title=The dark blue and yellow flag is a mockery of Ukrainian tradition |title=Синьо-жовтий прапор – це знущання над українською традицією |work=[[Gazeta.ua]] |date=July 25, 2013 |first=Olga |last=Skorokhod |language=uk}} The head of the Ukrainian Heraldry Society said that this [[heraldry]] issue does not apply to flags. +There has been disagreement over the shade of blue used in the flag. changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -19,7 +19,7 @@
 |Design2 = White with a blue Saint George's cross that extends to the edges of the flag, and with the national bi-colour in the canton.
 }}
 
-The [[national flag]] of [[Ukraine]] has two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]]). The combination of blue and yellow as a symbol of Ukrainian lands comes from the flag of the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia]] used in the 12th century. As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolour has been officially used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]], when it was hoisted over the [[Lviv Town Hall|Lviv Rathaus]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the flag was outlawed and, before 1949, there was no official state flag until the adoption of the red-azure [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following [[Modern history of Ukraine#Independent Ukraine (1991 to present)|Ukrainian independence]], before finally officially being restored on 28 January 1992 by the [[parliament of Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Ukraine’s national flag celebrating 25th anniversary today|url=https://www.unian.info/society/1747301-ukraines-national-flag-celebrating-25th-anniversary-today.html|access-date=2022-03-04|website=[[UNIAN]]|language=en}}</ref><ref name="Symbolsx2">{{cite news|last=Trach|first=Nataliya|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/ukraine-politics/the-story-behind-2-top-ukrainian-symbols-national-flag-and-trident-421675.html|title=The story behind 2 top Ukrainian symbols: National flag and trident|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=26 August 2016|access-date=27 August 2016}}</ref>
+The [[national flag]] of [[Ukraine]] has two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow.<ref>[[s:Constitution of Ukraine, 2004#Article 20|Article 20]])</ref> The combination of blue and yellow as a symbol of Ukrainian lands comes from the flag of the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia]] used in the 12th century. As a national flag, the blue and yellow bicolour has been used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]], when it was hoisted over [[Lviv Town Hall]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the [[flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]] was used and the bicolour flag was outlawed. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following [[Modern history of Ukraine#Independent Ukraine (1991 to present)|Ukrainian independence]], before officially being restored on 28 January 1992 by the [[Parliament of Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Ukraine’s national flag celebrating 25th anniversary today|url=https://www.unian.info/society/1747301-ukraines-national-flag-celebrating-25th-anniversary-today.html|access-date=2022-03-04|website=[[UNIAN]]|language=en}}</ref><ref name="Symbolsx2">{{cite news|last=Trach|first=Nataliya|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/ukraine-politics/the-story-behind-2-top-ukrainian-symbols-national-flag-and-trident-421675.html|title=The story behind 2 top Ukrainian symbols: National flag and trident|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=26 August 2016|access-date=27 August 2016}}</ref>
 
 Following the [[2022 Russian Invasion of Ukraine]], the flag and colours gained greater international use to show support for the Ukrainian people.
llm_output:
Removed some details about the flag's history and rephrased sentences for conciseness.

Not Weaponised. The changes made are primarily stylistic and do not introduce or remove any politically charged language or narratives related to cultural heritage.

Eventually, it was agreed to use the blue–yellow flag until the issue was resolved in the independent Ukraine. @@ -199,7 +199,7 @@ * On 14 March 1990, the Ukrainian flag was raised for the first time after the establishment of the Soviet Union in the small city of [[Stryi]]. {{Cite web|title=History of evolution of the State Flag of Ukraine |url=http://www.ukrinform.ua/ukr/news/istoriya_evolyutsiii_dergavnogo_prapora_ukraiini_infografika_2084779 |work=[[Ukrinform]] |date=August 23, 2015|access-date=2022-03-04|language=uk}} {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150817220933/http://www.ukrinform.ua/ukr/news/istoriya_evolyutsiii_dergavnogo_prapora_ukraiini_infografika_2084779 |date=August 17, 2015 }} * On 20 March 1990, the town council of [[Ternopil]] voted upon the usage and re-establishment of the yellow-and-blue flag and the [[Coat of arms of Ukraine|''tryzub'']] as well as the national anthem ''[[Ukraine's glory has not perished|Shche ne vmerla Ukrainy]]''. On the same day, the yellow-and-blue national flag was flown for the first time in about 80 years on a governmental building in Kyiv, replacing the then official [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|red-azure flag]] of the Ukrainian SSR. * On 28 April 1990, the oblast council (''oblasna rada'') of [[Lviv Oblast|Lviv]] also allowed the use of the national symbols of Ukraine within the Oblast. -* On 29 April 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown from the Ternopil city theater's flagstaff without the [[Flag of the Soviet Union|official flag of the Soviet Union]] hanging above it. +* On 29 April 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown from the Ternopil city theatre's flagstaff without the [[flag of the Soviet Union]] hanging above it. * After 24 July 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown for the first time over an official governmental building of the [[Kyiv City Council]] on the ''[[Maidan Nezalezhnosti]]'' square of the ''[[Khreshchatyk|Khreschatyk]]'' street.{{Cite news |date=2012-07-24 |title=22 роки тому в Києві офіційно підняли синьо-жовтий прапор (Twenty two years ago in Kyiv officially was raised the blue-yellow flag) |url=https://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/politics/2012/07/120724_flag_ukraine_history_kyiv_as |access-date=2022-03-04 |website=BBC News Україна |language=uk}} * After the declaration of independence of Ukraine on 24 August 1991, the national yellow-and-blue flag flew for the first time over the [[Verkhovna Rada|Ukrainian Parliament (''Verkhovna Rada'')]] building on 4 September 1991. @@ -228,7 +228,7 @@ Already in the 1918 draft of the Constitution of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], the order of colours was defined as blue and yellow. The same order could be found in legislative acts of the [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] for November 1918 and the [[Republic of Carpathian Ukraine]] on 15 March 1939. The argument on the order of colours was taking place in the [[Ukrainian diaspora]] as well. In 1949 it was decided that, until Ukraine defined a single state flag, the diaspora would use the blue-and-yellow banner. ===Attempts to revive Soviet flags=== -On 21 April 2011, the [[Verkhovna Rada]] adopted a law which allows to raise the [[Victory Banner]] on Victory Day.{{Cite news |title=РАДА ЗОБОВ’ЯЗАЛА ВИВІШУВАТИ ЧЕРВОНІ ПРАПОРИ НА 9 ТРАВНЯ (Rada enforced raising red flags on the May 9) |url=https://www.istpravda.com.ua/short/2011/04/21/36767/|access-date=2022-03-04|website= [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] Історична правда |date=April 21, 2011}} The current Victory Banner was adopted in [[Russia]] back in 2007. On 20 May 2011, the law was signed by the [[President of Ukraine]] [[Viktor Yanukovych]].{{Cite news |title=ЯНУКОВИЧ ПІДПИСАВ ЗАКОН ПРО ЧЕРВОНИЙ ПРАПОР (Yanukovych signed the law about the Red Banner) |url=https://www.istpravda.com.ua/short/2011/05/21/39383/ |access-date=2022-03-04 |website=[[Ukrayinska Pravda]] Історична правда |date=}} On 17 June 2011, the [[Constitutional Court of Ukraine]] recognised the law as non-constitutional and proposed the parliament to implement required amendments to the [[Constitution of Ukraine]].{{Cite news|title=КС Украины признал неконституционным использование красного знамени Победы (CC of Ukraine recognised the use of Red Victory Banner as non-constitutional) |url=https://rg.ru/2011/06/17/znamya-anons.html|access-date=2022-03-04|website=Russian Gazette Российская газета |date=June 17, 2011 |language=ru}} On 9 April 2015, the Ukrainian parliament passed legislation on [[decommunization in Ukraine|decommunization]], banning the promotion of symbols of “[[Communist]] and [[National Socialist]] [[totalitarian regime|totalitarian regimes]]".{{cite news|url= http://www.newsweek.com/ukraine-purges-symbols-its-communist-past-321663 |title= Ukraine Purges Symbols of Its Communist Past |first= Nolan |last= Peterson |work= [[Newsweek]] |date= 10 April 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}}

 }}
 
-The [[national flag]] of [[Ukraine]] has two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow.<ref>[[s:Constitution of Ukraine, 2004#Article 20|Article 20]])</ref> The combination of blue and yellow as a symbol of Ukrainian lands comes from the flag of the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia]] used in the 12th century. As a national flag, the blue and yellow bicolour has been used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]], when it was hoisted over [[Lviv Town Hall]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the [[flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]] was used and the bicolour flag was outlawed. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following [[Modern history of Ukraine#Independent Ukraine (1991 to present)|Ukrainian independence]], before officially being restored on 28 January 1992 by the [[Parliament of Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Ukraine’s national flag celebrating 25th anniversary today|url=https://www.unian.info/society/1747301-ukraines-national-flag-celebrating-25th-anniversary-today.html|access-date=2022-03-04|website=[[UNIAN]]|language=en}}</ref><ref name="Symbolsx2">{{cite news|last=Trach|first=Nataliya|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/ukraine-politics/the-story-behind-2-top-ukrainian-symbols-national-flag-and-trident-421675.html|title=The story behind 2 top Ukrainian symbols: National flag and trident|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=26 August 2016|access-date=27 August 2016}}</ref>
+The '''flag of Ukraine''' is the [[national flag]] of [[Ukraine]] which has two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow.<ref>[[s:Constitution of Ukraine, 2004#Article 20|Article 20]])</ref> The combination of blue and yellow as a symbol of Ukrainian lands comes from the flag of the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia]] used in the 12th century. As a national flag, the blue and yellow bicolour has been used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]], when it was hoisted over [[Lviv Town Hall]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the [[flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]] was used and the bicolour flag was outlawed. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following [[Modern history of Ukraine#Independent Ukraine (1991 to present)|Ukrainian independence]], before officially being restored on 28 January 1992 by the [[Parliament of Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Ukraine’s national flag celebrating 25th anniversary today|url=https://www.unian.info/society/1747301-ukraines-national-flag-celebrating-25th-anniversary-today.html|access-date=2022-03-04|website=[[UNIAN]]|language=en}}</ref><ref name="Symbolsx2">{{cite news|last=Trach|first=Nataliya|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/ukraine-politics/the-story-behind-2-top-ukrainian-symbols-national-flag-and-trident-421675.html|title=The story behind 2 top Ukrainian symbols: National flag and trident|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=26 August 2016|access-date=27 August 2016}}</ref>
 
 Following the [[2022 Russian Invasion of Ukraine]], the flag and colours gained greater international use to show support for the Ukrainian people.

 {{main|Day of the National Flag (Ukraine)}}
 
-23 August is celebrated as the Day of the National Flag in Ukraine; beginning with 2004. 24 July was previously marked as National Flag Day in Kyiv. The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on 24 July 1990, at the flagstaff of the Kyiv City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992 Independence Day of Ukraine is celebrated on 24 August. Following government decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this dates and some other holidays. Not all of these days are public holidays. Flags also must be flown on election days for the [[Verkhovna Rada]]  in addition to other regional-specific flag days. The public display of flags to mark other events, such as the election of the president or the death of a prominent politician (whereupon flags would be at half-mast), can be declared at the discretion of the Cabinet of Ministers. When flags are required to be flown at half-mast, vertical flags are not lowered. A black mourning ribbon is instead attached, either atop the mast (if hung from a pole) or to each end of the flag's supporting cross-beams (if flown like a banner).
+23 August is celebrated as the Day of the National Flag in Ukraine; beginning with 2004. 24 July was previously marked as National Flag Day in Kyiv. The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on 24 July 1990, at the flagstaff of the Kyiv City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992 Independence Day of Ukraine is celebrated on 24 August. Following government decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this dates and some other holidays. Not all of these days are public holidays. Flags also must be flown on election days for the [[Verkhovna Rada]] in addition to other regional-specific flag days. The public display of flags to mark other events, such as the election of the president or the death of a prominent politician (whereupon flags would be at half-mast), can be declared at the discretion of the Cabinet of Ministers. When flags are required to be flown at half-mast, vertical flags are not lowered. A black mourning ribbon is instead attached, either atop the mast (if hung from a pole) or to each end of the flag's supporting cross-beams (if flown like a banner).

-Both blue–yellow and yellow–blue flags were widely used during the [[Ukraine after the Russian Revolution|Ukrainian struggle for independence]] in 1917. For the first time in the [[Russian Empire]] the blue-yellow flag was flown on 25 March 1917 in [[Petrograd]] during a 20,000-strong mass [[Demonstration (protest)|demonstration]].<ref name=istpravda/> On the territory of the Russian Ukraine ([[Little Russia]]) the national flag of Ukraine was flown for the first time in [[Kyiv]] on 29 March 1917 by soldiers.<ref name=istpravda/> On 1 April 1917, Kyiv saw a 100,000-strong demonstration that carried over 320 national flags.<ref name=istpravda/> After the demonstrations, similar demonstrations with Ukrainian flags took place across the whole [[Russian Empire]], even going beyond the Ukrainian ethnic lands.<ref name=istpravda/> Numerous famous Ukrainian politicians wrote their recollection about the April 1 demonstration such as [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] and [[Serhiy Yefremov]], stating that there were blue-and-yellow flags, while [[Dmytro Doroshenko]] claimed that there were yellow-and-blue.<ref name=istpravda/> The blue-yellow flag was flown at the First Ukrainian Military Congress on 18 May 1917.<ref name=istpravda/>
+Both blue–yellow and yellow–blue flags were widely used during the [[Ukraine after the Russian Revolution|Ukrainian struggle for independence]] in 1917. For the first time in the [[Russian Empire]] the blue-yellow flag was flown on 25 March 1917 in [[Petrograd]] during a 20,000-strong mass [[Demonstration (protest)|demonstration]].<ref name=istpravda/> On the territory of the Russian Ukraine ([[Little Russia]]) the national flag of Ukraine was flown for the first time in [[Kyiv]] on 29 March 1917 by soldiers.<ref name=istpravda/> On 1 April 1917, Kyiv saw a 100,000-strong demonstration that carried over 320 national flags.<ref name=istpravda/> After the demonstrations, similar demonstrations with Ukrainian flags took place across the whole [[Russian Empire]], even going beyond the Ukrainian ethnic lands.<ref name=istpravda/> Numerous famous Ukrainian politicians wrote their recollection about the 1 April demonstration such as [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] and [[Serhiy Yefremov]], stating that there were blue-and-yellow flags, while [[Dmytro Doroshenko]] claimed that there were yellow-and-blue.<ref name=istpravda/> The blue-yellow flag was flown at the First Ukrainian Military Congress on 18 May 1917.<ref name=istpravda/>
 
 There are reliable sources that indicate that the official flag that was declared by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in 1918 is blue–yellow. Some sources mention that the yellow–blue was adopted by [[Tsentralna Rada]] on 22 March 1918.<ref>[http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=32027&cat_id=31295 State Symbols of Ukraine], [[Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine]], website.</ref> Other sources point out that no hard proof of a decision exists.<ref name=istpravda/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://vexillography.narod.ru/ukraine/unr.htm |script-title=ru:Флаги Украинской Народной Республики |trans-title=Flags of the Ukrainian People's Republic |language=ru |publisher=vexillography.narod.ru |date=July 14, 2002 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050228081927/http://vexillography.narod.ru/ukraine/unr.htm |archive-date=February 28, 2005}}</ref> Instead, they refer to the decision on the Fleet Flag, which was set to be light blue–yellow<ref>{{cite journal|last=Rozovyk|first=D. +In reality, however, the blue-yellow colouring dates back to [[Kyivan Ruthenia]], as an early version of the [[Tryzub]], Ukraine's national coat of arms, sported the same colouring as the seal of [[Sviatoslav I]] of Kyiv (c. AD 945).
 
 ===Yellow-blue vs blue-yellow===
 Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy'')<ref>A little less often they use also "yellow and blue", "blue and yellow" and "yellow and azure".</ref>—a different version of the flag used during UNR ([[Ukrainian National Republic]]) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. -Although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the spoken language as "yellow and light blue", the current flag in reality is blue (the upper band) and yellow (the lower band). +Although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the spoken language as "yellow and light blue", the current flag in reality is blue (the upper band) and yellow (the lower band).  The head of the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]], [[Andriy Grechylo]], points to the fact that the discussion about order of colours was taking place as far back as 1918.<ref name=grechylo>{{Cite news|last=Gazeta.ua|title=Хрущов і Каганович боялися слова "жовто-блакитний" (Khrushchev and Kaganovich were afraid of the word "zhovto-blakytnyi") |url=https://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_hruschov-i-kaganovich-boyalisya-slova-zhovtoblakitnij-/512859 |date=23 August 2013 |access-date=2022-03-04|website=Gazeta.ua|language=uk}}</ref> Nonetheless, both governments of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] as well as the [[Ukrainian State]] defined that the upper half would be light-blue, while the lower would be yellow.<ref name=grechylo/> During 1918 it was taken into consideration that light blue would lose its shade under sun, therefore it was decided to make the colour darker.<ref name=grechylo/>

 ===Display at half-staff===
 The flag is displayed at half-staff (half-mast in naval usage) as a sign of respect or mourning. Nationwide, this action is proclaimed by the president. Half-mast means the flag is flown two-thirds of the way up the flagpole with at least the height of the flag between the top of the flag and the top of the flagpole. Black ribbons indicate mourning on banners that can't be lowered to half-mast.

-23 August is celebrated as the Day of the National Flag in Ukraine since 2004. 24 July was previously marked as National Flag Day in Kyiv. The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on 24 July 1990, at the flagstaff of the Kyiv City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992, the [[Independence Day of Ukraine]] is celebrated on 24 August. Following government decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this dates and some other holidays; not all of these days are public holidays. Flags also must be flown on election days for the [[Verkhovna Rada]] in addition to other regional-specific flag days. The public display of flags to mark other events, such as the election of the president or the death of a prominent politician (whereupon flags would be at half-mast), can be declared at the discretion of the Cabinet of Ministers. When flags are required to be flown at half-mast, vertical flags are not lowered. A black mourning ribbon is instead attached, either atop the mast (if hung from a pole) or to each end of the flag's supporting cross-beams (if flown like a banner).
+23 August has been celebrated as the Day of the National Flag in Ukraine since 2004. 24 July was previously marked as National Flag Day in Kyiv. The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on 24 July 1990, at the flagstaff of the Kyiv City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992, the [[Independence Day of Ukraine]] is celebrated on 24 August. Following government decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this dates and some other holidays; not all of these days are public holidays. Flags also must be flown on election days for the [[Verkhovna Rada]] in addition to other regional-specific flag days. The public display of flags to mark other events, such as the election of the president or the death of a prominent politician (whereupon flags would be at half-mast), can be declared at the discretion of the Cabinet of Ministers. When flags are required to be flown at half-mast, vertical flags are not lowered. A black mourning ribbon is instead attached, either atop the mast (if hung from a pole) or to each end of the flag's supporting cross-beams (if flown like a banner).

The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on 24 July 1990, at the flagstaff of the Kyiv City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992 Independence Day of Ukraine is celebrated on 24 August. Following government decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this dates and some other holidays. Not all of these days are public holidays. Flags also must be flown on election days for the [[Verkhovna Rada]] in addition to other regional-specific flag days. The public display of flags to mark other events, such as the election of the president or the death of a prominent politician (whereupon flags would be at half-mast), can be declared at the discretion of the Cabinet of Ministers. When flags are required to be flown at half-mast, vertical flags are not lowered. A black mourning ribbon is instead attached, either atop the mast (if hung from a pole) or to each end of the flag's supporting cross-beams (if flown like a banner). +23 August is celebrated as the Day of the National Flag in Ukraine since 2004. 24 July was previously marked as National Flag Day in Kyiv. The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on 24 July 1990, at the flagstaff of the Kyiv City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992, the [[Independence Day of Ukraine]] is celebrated on 24 August. Following government decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this dates and some other holidays; not all of these days are public holidays. Flags also must be flown on election days for the [[Verkhovna Rada]] in addition to other regional-specific flag days. The public display of flags to mark other events, such as the election of the president or the death of a prominent politician (whereupon flags would be at half-mast), can be declared at the discretion of the Cabinet of Ministers. When flags are required to be flown at half-mast, vertical flags are not lowered. A black mourning ribbon is instead attached, either atop the mast (if hung from a pole) or to each end of the flag's supporting cross-beams (if flown like a banner). {{clear}} ==History==

changed_version:
--- +++ @@ -21,7 +21,7 @@ The [[national flag]] of [[Ukraine]] has two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow ([[Constitution of Ukraine]], [[s:Constitution of Ukraine#Article 20|Article 20]]). The combination of blue and yellow as a symbol of Ukrainian lands comes from the flag of the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia]] used in the 12th century. As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolour has been officially used since the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]], when it was hoisted over the [[Lviv Town Hall|Lviv Rathaus]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the flag was outlawed and, before 1949, there was no official state flag until the adoption of the red-azure [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following [[Modern history of Ukraine#Independent Ukraine (1991 to present)|Ukrainian independence]], before finally officially being restored on 28 January 1992 by the [[parliament of Ukraine]].{{Cite web|title=Ukraine’s national flag celebrating 25th anniversary today|url=https://www.unian.info/society/1747301-ukraines-national-flag-celebrating-25th-anniversary-today.html|access-date=2022-03-04|website=[[UNIAN]]|language=en}}{{cite news|last=Trach|first=Nataliya|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/ukraine-politics/the-story-behind-2-top-ukrainian-symbols-national-flag-and-trident-421675.html|title=The story behind 2 top Ukrainian symbols: National flag and trident|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=26 August 2016|access-date=27 August 2016}} -Following the [[2022 Russian Invasion of Ukraine]], the flag and colors gained greater international use to show support for the Ukrainian people. +Following the [[2022 Russian Invasion of Ukraine]], the flag and colours gained greater international use to show support for the Ukrainian people. Ukraine has celebrated [[Day of the National Flag (Ukraine)|Flag Day]] each year on 23 August since 2004.[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2012-08/23/c_131803737.htm Ukraine celebrates National Flag Day] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131007221207/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2012-08/23/c_131803737.htm |date=October 7, 2013 }}, [[Xinhua News Agency]] (August 23, 2012)
[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/kyiv/ceremony-of-hoisting-ukraines-national-flag-held-a-111423.html Ceremony of hoisting Ukraine's national flag held at presidential administration], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (August 23, 2011)
[http://tsn.ua/ukrayina/ukrayina-vidznachaye-den-derzhavnogo-prapora.html Україна відзначає День Державного прапора "On Tuesday, August 23, all of Ukraine celebrates National Flag Day. Measures to raise the national flag are planned throughout the country."] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130801033729/http://tsn.ua/ukrayina/ukrayina-vidznachaye-den-derzhavnogo-prapora.html |date=1 August 2013 }}, [[1+1 (channel)|1+1]] (August 23, 2011)

initial_version:
<center>[[Image:Ukraine_flag_large.png]]</center>
'''Flag Ratio:''' 2:3

The flag of [[Ukraine]] was adopted on [[September 3]], [[1996]].  It had been the provisional flag since [[1991]].
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -221,7 +221,7 @@
 
 It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the spoken language as "yellow and light blue", the current flag in reality is blue (the upper band) and yellow (the lower band). The issue is quite significant, because the historical alteration of the flag (from yellow–blue to blue–yellow) did not affect the spoken language.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} Back in 1848, the flag was yellow and blue,{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} and it was later changed to blue and yellow to be more appealing to the common person.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} A common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time, as Ukraine is considered Europe's breadbasket, or "blue sky over sunflowers," which is their national flower {{citation needed|date=January 2014}}. Although this evocation of a Ukrainian landscape has nothing to do with the choice of colours or the history of the original yellow and blue, it has formed the Ukrainians' conception of their flag.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}}
 
-The head of the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]], [[Andriy Grechylo]], points to the fact that the discussion about order of colours was taking place as far back as 1918.<ref name=grechylo>{{Cite news|last=Gazeta.ua|date=2013-08-23|title=Хрущов і Каганович боялися слова "жовто-блакитний" (Khrushchev and Kaganovich were afraid of the word "zhovto-blakytnyi") |url=https://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_hruschov-i-kaganovich-boyalisya-slova-zhovtoblakitnij-/512859 |date=August 23, 2013 |access-date=2022-03-04|website=Gazeta.ua|language=uk}}</ref> Nonetheless, both governments of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] as well as the [[Ukrainian State]] defined that the upper half would be light-blue, while the lower would be yellow.<ref name=grechylo/> During 1918 it was taken into consideration that light blue would lose its shade under sun, therefore it was decided to make the colour darker.<ref name=grechylo/>
+The head of the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]], [[Andriy Grechylo]], points to the fact that the discussion about order of colours was taking place as far back as 1918.<ref name=grechylo>{{Cite news|last=Gazeta.ua|title=Хрущов і Каганович боялися слова "жовто-блакитний" (Khrushchev and Kaganovich were afraid of the word "zhovto-blakytnyi") |url=https://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_hruschov-i-kaganovich-boyalisya-slova-zhovtoblakitnij-/512859 |date=23 August 2013 |access-date=2022-03-04|website=Gazeta.ua|language=uk}}</ref> Nonetheless, both governments of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] as well as the [[Ukrainian State]] defined that the upper half would be light-blue, while the lower would be yellow.<ref name=grechylo/> During 1918 it was taken into consideration that light blue would lose its shade under sun, therefore it was decided to make the colour darker.<ref name=grechylo/>
 
 Already in the 1918 draft of the Constitution of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], the order of colours was defined as blue and yellow.<ref name=grechylo/> The same order could be found in legislative acts of the [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] for November 1918 and the [[Republic of Carpathian Ukraine]] on March 15, 1939.<ref name=grechylo/> The argument on the order of colours was taking place in the [[Ukrainian diaspora]] as well.<ref name=grechylo/> In 1949 it was decided that, until Ukraine defined a single state flag, the diaspora would use the blue-and-yellow banner.<ref name=grechylo/>

 ===Stamps===
 [[File:Marka3.jpg|thumbnail|"Freedom for Ukraine" cinderella stamp, featuring the Ukrainian flag with a gold fringe and a gold [[Coat of arms of Ukraine|coat of arms]] on top of the flag pole]]
-The flag did not appear on Ukrainian official postal stamp issues until the 1992 was released, depicting the flag with state coat of arms. Since that time the flag has frequently appeared on stamps. [[Cinderella stamp]]s of the [[Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists]] were printed outside Ukraine during the Soviet period and served patriotic purposes.
+The flag did not appear on Ukrainian official postal stamp issues until 1992, where they depicted the flag with the state coat of arms. Since that time the flag has frequently appeared on stamps. [[Cinderella stamp]]s of the [[Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists]] were printed outside Ukraine during the Soviet period and served patriotic purposes.
 
 ===Decoration===
 Traditionally, the flag may be decorated with a [[gold (color)|golden]] [[Fringe (trim)|fringe]] surrounding the perimeter of the flag, as long as it does not deface the flag proper. The beginning of this tradition was the [[flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. The ''[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia]]'' shows a flag decorated with a gold star. Ceremonial displays of the flag, such as those in parades or on indoor posts, often use a fringe to enhance the beauty of the flag. No specific law governs the legality of this fringe. Traditionally, the [[Ukrainian Ground Forces|Army]], [[National Guard of Ukraine|Guard]], [[Ukrainian Navy|Navy]] and [[Ukrainian Air Force|Air Force]] use a fringed flag for [[military parade|parades]], [[colour guard]]s and indoor displays, while the [[President of Ukraine|Office of the President]] and local authorities use a fringed flag for all purposes.

 ===Origin===

-One claimed version is that, since one of the first known coloured depictions of the Coat of Arms of Kyiv was mainly in yellow-blue colours, this tradition may have existed since the time of the Nordic-Slavic [[Grand Prince of Kyiv]] [[Volodymyr the Great]]. AD 945). During the 1709 [[Battle of Poltava]], the Cossacks under [[Mazepa]] fought under the yellow-blue banners, while their Swedish allies were under yellow ones.
+One claimed version is that, since one of the first known coloured depictions of the Coat of Arms of Kyiv was mainly in yellow-blue colours, this tradition may have existed since the time of the Nordic-Slavic [[Grand Prince of Kyiv]] [[Volodymyr the Great]]. However, the blue-yellow colouring dates back to [[Kyivan Ruthenia]], as an early version of the ''[[Tryzub]]'', Ukraine's national coat of arms, sported the same colouring as the seal of [[Sviatoslav I]] of Kyiv (c. AD 945). During the 1709 [[Battle of Poltava]], the Cossacks following [[Mazepa]] fought under yellow-blue banners, while their Swedish allies were under yellow ones.
 
 ===Yellow-blue vs blue-yellow===
 Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy'')<ref>A little less often they use also "yellow and blue", "blue and yellow" and "yellow and azure".</ref>—a different version of the flag used during UNR ([[Ukrainian National Republic]]) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. The yellow on the top allegedly represents golden domes ([[cupola]]s) of Christian churches and the blue the [[Dnieper]] river.

 The flag is almost identical to that of the Austrian state of [[Lower Austria]] and the flag of the German city of [[Chemnitz]], but both of those flags have a darker shade of blue. The flag is also somewhat similar to that of the [[Malaysia]]n state of [[Flag and coat of arms of Perlis|Perlis]], but has a reversed arrangement of colours with darker shades of blue and yellow as well as a different flag aspect ratio.

 ===Decoration===
-Traditionally, the flag may be decorated with a [[gold (color)|golden]] [[Fringe (trim)|fringe]] surrounding the perimeter of the flag, as long as it does not deface the flag proper. The beginning of this tradition was the [[flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. The ''[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia]]'' shows a flag decorated with a gold star. Ceremonial displays of the flag, such as those in parades or on indoor posts, often use a fringe to enhance the beauty of the flag. No specific law governs the legality of this fringe. Traditionally, the [[Ukrainian Ground Forces|Army]], [[National Guard of Ukraine|Guard]], [[Ukrainian Navy|Navy]] and [[Ukrainian Air Force|Air Force]] use a fringed flag for [[military parade|parades]], [[color guard]]s and indoor displays, while the [[President of Ukraine|Office of the President]] and local authorities use a fringed flag for all purposes.

@@ -118,7 +118,7 @@
 [[File:Ukrflagblue.jpg|thumbnail|right|The flag of Ukraine at [[Kyiv]] City Hall]]
 {{main|Day of the National Flag (Ukraine)}}
 
-23 August is celebrated as the Day of the National Flag in Ukraine; beginning with 2004. 24 July was previously marked as National Flag Day in Kyiv. The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on July 24, 1990, at the flagstaff of the Kyiv City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992 Independence Day of Ukraine is celebrated on 24 August. Following government decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this dates and some other holidays. Not all of these days are public holidays. Flags also must be flown on election days for the [[Verkhovna Rada]]  in addition to other regional-specific flag days. The public display of flags to mark other events, such as the election of the president or the death of a prominent politician (whereupon flags would be at half-mast), can be declared at the discretion of the Cabinet of Ministers. When flags are required to be flown at half-mast, vertical flags are not lowered. A black mourning ribbon is instead attached, either atop the mast (if hung from a pole) or to each end of the flag's supporting cross-beams (if flown like a banner).
+23 August is celebrated as the Day of the National Flag in Ukraine; beginning with 2004. 24 July was previously marked as National Flag Day in Kyiv. The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on 24 July 1990, at the flagstaff of the Kyiv City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992 Independence Day of Ukraine is celebrated on 24 August. Following government decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this dates and some other holidays. Not all of these days are public holidays. Flags also must be flown on election days for the [[Verkhovna Rada]]  in addition to other regional-specific flag days. The public display of flags to mark other events, such as the election of the president or the death of a prominent politician (whereupon flags would be at half-mast), can be declared at the discretion of the Cabinet of Ministers. When flags are required to be flown at half-mast, vertical flags are not lowered. A black mourning ribbon is instead attached, either atop the mast (if hung from a pole) or to each end of the flag's supporting cross-beams (if flown like a banner).

 Both blue–yellow and yellow–blue flags were widely used during the [[Ukraine after the Russian Revolution|Ukrainian struggle for independence]] in 1917. For the first time in the [[Russian Empire]] the blue-yellow flag was flown on 25 March 1917 in [[Petrograd]] during a 20,000-strong mass [[Demonstration (protest)|demonstration]].<ref name=istpravda/> On the territory of the Russian Ukraine ([[Little Russia]]) the national flag of Ukraine was flown for the first time in [[Kyiv]] on 29 March 1917 by soldiers.<ref name=istpravda/> On 1 April 1917, Kyiv saw a 100,000-strong demonstration that carried over 320 national flags.<ref name=istpravda/> After the demonstrations, similar demonstrations with Ukrainian flags took place across the whole [[Russian Empire]], even going beyond the Ukrainian ethnic lands.<ref name=istpravda/> Numerous famous Ukrainian politicians wrote their recollection about the April 1 demonstration such as [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] and [[Serhiy Yefremov]], stating that there were blue-and-yellow flags, while [[Dmytro Doroshenko]] claimed that there were yellow-and-blue.<ref name=istpravda/> The blue-yellow flag was flown at the First Ukrainian Military Congress on 18 May 1917.<ref name=istpravda/>

The flag of the [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] was blue-yellow. The stateless [[Free Territory]], which existed during the [[Ukrainian War of Independence]], used the black flag.
 
@@ -178,7 +178,7 @@
 ===Interbellum Ukraine===
 The Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists is a Ukrainian political organisation which as a movement originally was created in 1929 in Western Ukraine (at the time interwar Poland). For a long time, the OUN did not officially have its own flag; however, during the Hungarian and Polish aggression against the [[Republic of Carpathian Ukraine]] in 1939, Carpathian Sich, a militarised wing of the OUN, adopted its flag from the OUN's emblem – a golden nationalistic trident on a blue background. The flag was finalised and officially adopted by the organisation only in 1964 at the 5th Assembly of Ukrainian Nationalists.
 
-The Ukrainian Insurgent Army was a Ukrainian nationalist paramilitary and later partisan army that engaged in a series of guerrilla conflicts during World War II against Nazi Germany, the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, and both Underground and Communist Poland. The group was the military wing of the Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists — Bandera faction (the OUN-B), originally formed in Volyn in the spring and summer of 1943. Its official date of creation is October 14, 1942, during the day of the Intercession of the Theotokos feast. The battle flag of the UPA was a 2:3 ratio red-and-black banner. The flag continues to be a symbol of the Ukrainian nationalist movement. The colours of the flag symbolise 'Ukrainian red blood spilled on Ukrainian black earth'.
+The Ukrainian Insurgent Army was a Ukrainian nationalist paramilitary and later partisan army that engaged in a series of guerrilla conflicts during World War II against Nazi Germany, the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, and both Underground and Communist Poland. The group was the military wing of the Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists — Bandera faction (the OUN-B), originally formed in Volyn in the spring and summer of 1943. Its official date of creation is 14 October  1942. The battle flag of the UPA was a 2:3 ratio red-and-black banner. The flag continues to be a symbol of the Ukrainian nationalist movement. The colours of the flag symbolise 'Ukrainian red blood spilled on Ukrainian black earth'.

-In 1949, the flag of the Soviet Ukraine was changed once again.<ref name=grechylo/> The [[Soviet Union]] managed to obtain two additional seats in the [[United Nations]] by adding as members Ukraine along with Byelorussia.<ref name=grechylo/> The change was because all the Soviet flags were the same.<ref name=grechylo/> The new Ukrainian flag consisted of red (top, 2/3) and [[azure (color)|azure]] (bottom, 1/3) stripes,<ref name=grechylo/> with the golden star, [[hammer and sickle]] in the top left corner. The Communist party leaders such as [[Khrushchev]] and [[Lazar Kaganovich|Kaganovich]] were afraid of using words ''light blue'' and ''blue'', which were used by the [[Ukrainian diaspora]].<ref name=grechylo/>
+In 1949, the flag of the Soviet Ukraine was changed once again.<ref name=grechylo/> The [[Soviet Union]] managed to obtain two additional seats in the [[United Nations]] by adding as members Ukraine along with Byelorussia.<ref name=grechylo/> The change was because all the Soviet flags were the same.<ref name=grechylo/> The new Ukrainian flag consisted of red (top, 2/3) and [[azure (color)|azure]] (bottom, 1/3) stripes,<ref name=grechylo/> with the golden star, [[hammer and sickle]] in the top left corner. The Communist party leaders such as [[Khrushchev]] and [[Lazar Kaganovich|Kaganovich]] were afraid of using words 'light blue' and 'blue', which were used by the [[Ukrainian diaspora]].<ref name=grechylo/>
 
 During the Soviet period, there were multiple unsanctioned attempts to hoist the national blue-and-yellow flag. In 1958, in village of Verbytsia, [[:uk:Ходорівський район|Khodoriv Raion]], there was established an underground group, members of which at night were raising national flags and spread anti-Soviet pamphlets.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Невідомі прапороносці. Жовто-блакитний проти червоного (Unknown flag-bearers. Yellow-blue against Red) |url=https://www.istpravda.com.ua/columns/2011/07/29/48180/|access-date=2022-03-04|website=[[Ukrayinska Pravda]] Історична правда |date= July 29, 2011 }}</ref>
 
@@ -214,21 +214,21 @@
 
 ===Origin===
 {{unreferenced section|date=July 2020}}
-One claimed version is that, since one of the first known colored depictions of the Coat of Arms of Kyiv was mainly in yellow-blue colors, this tradition may have existed since the time of the Nordic-Slavic [[Grand Prince of Kyiv]] [[Volodymyr the Great]]. At least, during the Battle of Poltava, the Cossacks under [[Mazepa]] fought under the yellow-blue banners, while their Swedish allies under yellow ones.
-
-In reality, however, the blue-yellow coloring dates back to [[Kyivan Ruthenia]], as an early version of the [[Tryzub]], Ukraine's national coat of arms, sported the same coloring as the seal of Sviatoslav I of Kyiv (c. AD 945).
+One claimed version is that, since one of the first known coloured depictions of the Coat of Arms of Kyiv was mainly in yellow-blue colours, this tradition may have existed since the time of the Nordic-Slavic [[Grand Prince of Kyiv]] [[Volodymyr the Great]]. At least, during the Battle of Poltava, the Cossacks under [[Mazepa]] fought under the yellow-blue banners, while their Swedish allies under yellow ones.
+
+In reality, however, the blue-yellow colouring dates back to [[Kyivan Ruthenia]], as an early version of the [[Tryzub]], Ukraine's national coat of arms, sported the same colouring as the seal of Sviatoslav I of Kyiv (c. AD 945).
 
 ===Yellow-blue vs blue-yellow===
-Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as '''yellow and light blue''' ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy'')<ref>A little less often they use also "yellow and blue", "blue and yellow" and "yellow and azure".</ref>—a different version of the flag used during UNR ([[Ukrainian National Republic]]) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. The yellow on the top allegedly represents golden domes ([[cupola]]s) of Christian churches and the blue the [[Dnieper]] river.
-
-It has to be noted that although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the spoken language as "yellow and light blue", the current flag in reality is blue (the upper band) and yellow (the lower band). The issue is quite significant, because the historical alteration of the flag (from yellow–blue to blue–yellow) did not affect the spoken language.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} Back in 1848, the flag was yellow and blue,{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} and it was later changed to blue and yellow to be more appealing to the common person.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} A common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time, as Ukraine is considered Europe's breadbasket, or "blue sky over sunflowers," which is their national flower {{citation needed|date=January 2014}}. Although this evocation of a Ukrainian landscape has nothing to do with the choice of colours or the history of the original yellow and blue, it has formed the Ukrainians' conception of their flag.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}}
+Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy'')<ref>A little less often they use also "yellow and blue", "blue and yellow" and "yellow and azure".</ref>—a different version of the flag used during UNR ([[Ukrainian National Republic]]) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. The yellow on the top allegedly represents golden domes ([[cupola]]s) of Christian churches and the blue the [[Dnieper]] river.
+
+Although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the spoken language as "yellow and light blue", the current flag in reality is blue (the upper band) and yellow (the lower band). The issue is quite significant, because the historical alteration of the flag (from yellow–blue to blue–yellow) did not affect the spoken language.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} Back in 1848, the flag was yellow and blue,{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} and it was later changed to blue and yellow to be more appealing to the common person.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} A common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was invented around that time, as Ukraine is considered Europe's breadbasket, or "blue sky over sunflowers," which is their national flower {{citation needed|date=January 2014}}. Although this evocation of a Ukrainian landscape has nothing to do with the choice of colours or the history of the original yellow and blue, it has formed the Ukrainians' conception of their flag.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}}
 
 The head of the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]], [[Andriy Grechylo]], points to the fact that the discussion about order of colours was taking place as far back as 1918.<ref name=grechylo>{{Cite news|last=Gazeta.ua|title=Хрущов і Каганович боялися слова "жовто-блакитний" (Khrushchev and Kaganovich were afraid of the word "zhovto-blakytnyi") |url=https://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_hruschov-i-kaganovich-boyalisya-slova-zhovtoblakitnij-/512859 |date=23 August 2013 |access-date=2022-03-04|website=Gazeta.ua|language=uk}}</ref> Nonetheless, both governments of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] as well as the [[Ukrainian State]] defined that the upper half would be light-blue, while the lower would be yellow.<ref name=grechylo/> During 1918 it was taken into consideration that light blue would lose its shade under sun, therefore it was decided to make the colour darker.<ref name=grechylo/>
 
-Already in the 1918 draft of the Constitution of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], the order of colours was defined as blue and yellow.<ref name=grechylo/> The same order could be found in legislative acts of the [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] for November 1918 and the [[Republic of Carpathian Ukraine]] on March 15, 1939.<ref name=grechylo/> The argument on the order of colours was taking place in the [[Ukrainian diaspora]] as well.<ref name=grechylo/> In 1949 it was decided that, until Ukraine defined a single state flag, the diaspora would use the blue-and-yellow banner.<ref name=grechylo/>
+Already in the 1918 draft of the Constitution of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], the order of colours was defined as blue and yellow.<ref name=grechylo/> The same order could be found in legislative acts of the [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] for November 1918 and the [[Republic of Carpathian Ukraine]] on 15 March 1939.<ref name=grechylo/> The argument on the order of colours was taking place in the [[Ukrainian diaspora]] as well.<ref name=grechylo/> In 1949 it was decided that, until Ukraine defined a single state flag, the diaspora would use the blue-and-yellow banner.<ref name=grechylo/>
 
 ===Attempts to revive Soviet flags===
-On 21 April 2011, the [[Verkhovna Rada]] adopted a law which allows to raise the [[Victory Banner]] on Victory Day.<ref>{{Cite news |title=РАДА ЗОБОВ’ЯЗАЛА ВИВІШУВАТИ ЧЕРВОНІ ПРАПОРИ НА 9 ТРАВНЯ (Rada enforced raising red flags on the May 9) |url=https://www.istpravda.com.ua/short/2011/04/21/36767/|access-date=2022-03-04|website= [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] Історична правда |date=April 21, 2011}}</ref> The current Victory Banner was adopted in [[Russia]] back in 2007. On 20 May 2011, the law was signed by the [[President of Ukraine]] [[Viktor Yanukovych]].<ref>{{Cite news |title=ЯНУКОВИЧ ПІДПИСАВ ЗАКОН ПРО ЧЕРВОНИЙ ПРАПОР (Yanukovych signed the law about the Red  ==Flag of the head of state==
 Throughout the history of [[Ukraine]], various [[List of heads of state of Ukraine|heads of state]] have used different flags. The designs differ according to the historical era they were used in and in accordance with the political scene in [[Ukraine]] at the time. The first flag to be used by a [[List of heads of state of Ukraine|head of state of Ukraine]] was that of [[Pavlo Skoropadskyi]]. The current design, the flag of the [[President of Ukraine]], was adopted in 1991. In 2022 the President of Ukraine used a variant where the left side of the blue upper-half contains the yellow [[Coat of arms of Ukraine|Tryzub]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Basu|first=Zachary|date=2022-03-01|title=Zelensky tells European Parliament "nobody is going to break us" in emotional appeal|url=https://www.axios.com/zelensky-video-european-parliament-address-ukraine-ed88a2e1-ff9e-471c-9a4d-92e0406ff541.html|access-date=2022-03-04|website=Axios|language=en}}</ref>

<center>[[Image:Ukraine_flag_large.png]]</center>
'''Flag Ratio:''' 2:3

The flag of [[Ukraine]] was adopted on [[September 3]], [[1996]].  It had been the provisional flag since [[1991]].
changed_version:
--- +++ @@ -19,7 +19,7 @@ |Design2 = White with a blue Saint George's cross that extends to the edges of the flag, and with the national bi-colour in the canton. }} -The the [[national flag]] of [[Ukraine]] has equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow.[[s:Constitution of Ukraine, 2004#Article 20|Article 20]]) The combination of blue and yellow as a symbol of Ukrainian lands comes from the flag of the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia]] used in the 12th century. As a national flag, the blue and yellow bicolour has been used since the [[Revolutions of 1848|1848 Spring of Nations]], when it was hoisted over [[Lviv Town Hall]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the [[flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]] was used and the bicolour flag was outlawed. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following [[Modern history of Ukraine#Independent Ukraine (1991 to present)|Ukrainian independence]], before officially being restored on 28 January 1992 by the [[Parliament of Ukraine]].{{Cite web|title=Ukraine’s national flag celebrating 25th anniversary today|url=https://www.unian.info/society/1747301-ukraines-national-flag-celebrating-25th-anniversary-today.html|access-date=2022-03-04|website=[[UNIAN]]|language=en}}{{cite news|last=Trach|first=Nataliya|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/ukraine-politics/the-story-behind-2-top-ukrainian-symbols-national-flag-and-trident-421675.html|title=The story behind 2 top Ukrainian symbols: National flag and trident|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=26 August 2016|access-date=27 August 2016}} +The [[national flag]] of [[Ukraine]] has equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow.[[s:Constitution of Ukraine, 2004#Article 20|Article 20]]) The combination of blue and yellow as a symbol of Ukrainian lands comes from the flag of the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia]] used in the 12th century. As a national flag, the blue and yellow bicolour has been used since the [[Revolutions of 1848|1848 Spring of Nations]], when it was hoisted over [[Lviv Town Hall]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]]. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the [[flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]] was used and the bicolour flag was outlawed. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following [[Modern history of Ukraine#Independent Ukraine (1991 to present)|Ukrainian independence]], before officially being restored on 28 January 1992 by the [[Parliament of Ukraine]].{{Cite web|title=Ukraine’s national flag celebrating 25th anniversary today|url=https://www.unian.info/society/1747301-ukraines-national-flag-celebrating-25th-anniversary-today.html|access-date=2022-03-04|website=[[UNIAN]]|language=en}}{{cite news|last=Trach|first=Nataliya|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/ukraine-politics/the-story-behind-2-top-ukrainian-symbols-national-flag-and-trident-421675.html|title=The story behind 2 top Ukrainian symbols: National flag and trident|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=26 August 2016|access-date=27 August 2016}} Ukraine has celebrated the [[Day of the National Flag (Ukraine)|Day of the National Flag]] on 23 August since 2004.[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2012-08/23/c_131803737.htm Ukraine celebrates National Flag Day] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131007221207/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2012-08/23/c_131803737.htm |date=October 7, 2013 }}, [[Xinhua News Agency]] (August 23, 2012)
[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/kyiv/ceremony-of-hoisting-ukraines-national-flag-held-a-111423.html Ceremony of hoisting Ukraine's national flag held at presidential administration], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (August 23, 2011)
[http://tsn.ua/ukrayina/ukrayina-vidznachaye-den-derzhavnogo-prapora.html Україна відзначає День Державного прапора "On Tuesday, August 23, all of Ukraine celebrates National Flag Day. Measures to raise the national flag are planned throughout the country."] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130801033729/http://tsn.ua/ukrayina/ukrayina-vidznachaye-den-derzhavnogo-prapora.html |date=1 August 2013 }}, [[1+1 (channel)|1+1]] (August 23, 2011)

 There has been disagreement over the shade of blue used in the flag.<ref name=grechylo/> In 2013, scholar Dmytro Malakov argued that [[sky blue]] was the correct colour, and that, according to [[Rule of tincture|rules of heraldry]], [[Dark blue (color)|dark blue]] should not be used.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_sino-zhovtij-prapor-ce-znuschannya-nad-ukrajinskoyu-tradicieyu/508746 |trans-title=The dark blue and yellow flag is a mockery of Ukrainian tradition |title=Синьо-жовтий прапор – це знущання над українською традицією |work=[[Gazeta.ua]] |date=July 25, 2013 |first=Olga |last=Skorokhod |language=uk}}</ref> The head of the Ukrainian Heraldry Society said that this [[heraldry]] issue does not apply to flags.<ref name=grechylo/>
 
-The flag is similar to that of the Austrian state of [[Lower Austria]] and the flag of the German city of [[Chemnitz]], but both of those flags have a darker shade of blue. +The flag is similar to that of the Austrian state of [[Lower Austria]] and the flag of the German city of [[Chemnitz]], but both of those flags have a darker shade of blue. The flag is also somewhat similar to that of the Malaysian state of [[Flag and coat of arms of Perlis|Perlis]], but has a reversed arrangement of colours with darker shades of blue and yellow as well as a different flag aspect ratio.
 
 ==Protocol and use==
 {{more citations needed|section|date=August 2017}}<!--only Legal status section has citations-->
@@ -147,7 +147,7 @@
 
 There are reliable sources that indicate that the official flag that was declared by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in 1918 is blue–yellow.
