F.|url=http://www.history.org.ua/journal/1999/4/10.pdf|script-title=uk:Документи та матеряли: Про створення української національно-державної символіки у роки визвольної боротьби (1917-1920 рр.)|trans-title=Documents and materials: On the creation of Ukrainian national-state symbols during the battle for liberation (1917-1920)|language=uk|journal=Ukrainian Historical Journal|publisher=history.org.ua|location=Kyiv|volume=4|date=1999|issn=0130-5247|pages=115–121|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070705084455/http://www.history.org.ua/journal/1999/4/10.pdf|archive-date=July 5, 2007}}</ref> as an indication that the official flag was light blue–yellow.<ref>{{cite web|last=Chmyr|first=Mykola|url=http://vijsko.milua.org/Khoruhvy_HA.htm|script-title=uk:Українське військо у ХХ-ХХІ сторіччі: 'Командні хоругви' Галицької Армії (серпень 1919 р.)|trans-title=Ukrainian Army in the 20th-21st Century: 'Command banners' of the Galician Army (August 1919)|language=uk|website=vijsko.milua.org|date=2006|access-date=October 2, 2017}}</ref> There were also several adoptions of other service flags of the Ukrainian People's Republic.<ref>Grechylo A. Ukrayinska Terytorialna Heraldyka. Lviv, 2010, pp. 98–118. {{ISBN|978-966-02-5259-2}}</ref>

The flag of the [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] was blue-yellow. The stateless [[Free Territory]], which existed during the [[Ukrainian War of Independence]], used the [[Anarchist_symbolism#Black_flag|black flag]].

The flag of the [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] was blue-yellow. The stateless [[Makhnovshchina]] (Free Territory), which existed during the [[Ukrainian War of Independence]], used the [[Anarchist_symbolism#Black_flag|black flag]].
 
 Among Ukrainian immigrant organisations, there were proponents of both blue–yellow and yellow–blue flags. Eventually, it was agreed to use the blue–yellow flag until the issue was resolved in the independent Ukraine.

@@ -215,7 +215,7 @@
 
 ===Origin===
 {{unreferenced section|date=July 2020}}
-One claimed version is that, since one of the first known coloured depictions of the Coat of Arms of Kyiv was mainly in yellow-blue colours, this tradition may have existed since the time of the Nordic-Slavic [[Grand Prince of Kyiv]] [[Volodymyr the Great]]. However, the blue-yellow colouring dates back to [[Kyivan Ruthenia]], as an early version of the ''[[Tryzub]]'', Ukraine's national coat of arms, sported the same colouring as the seal of [[Sviatoslav I]] of Kyiv (c. AD 945). During the 1709 [[Battle of Poltava]], the Cossacks following [[Mazepa]] fought under yellow-blue banners, while their Swedish allies were under yellow ones. Some Cossacs and nobelmen had also coats of arms in yellow- blue color <ref>{{Cite web |last=Vannier |first=Alexis |date=24 Aug 2021 |title=« CHTCHE NE VMERLA UKRAÏNY » : HISTOIRE DU DRAPEAU DE L’UKRAINE |url=https://www.taurillon.org/chtche-ne-vmerla-ukrainy-histoire-du-drapeau-de-l-ukraine?lang=fr |access-date=16 March 2022 |website=taurillon.org |language=fr}}</ref>.
+One claimed version is that, since one of the first known coloured depictions of the Coat of Arms of Kyiv was mainly in yellow-blue colours, this tradition may have existed since the time of the Nordic-Slavic [[Grand Prince of Kyiv]] [[Volodymyr the Great]]. However, the blue-yellow colouring dates back to [[Kyivan Ruthenia]], as an early version of the ''[[Tryzub]]'', Ukraine's national coat of arms, sported the same colouring as the seal of [[Sviatoslav I]] of Kyiv (c. AD 945). During the 1709 [[Battle of Poltava]], the Cossacks following [[Mazepa]] fought under yellow-blue banners, while their Swedish allies were under yellow ones. Some Cossacs and nobelmen had also coats of arms in yellow- blue color.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Vannier |first=Alexis |date=24 Aug 2021 |title=« CHTCHE NE VMERLA UKRAÏNY » : HISTOIRE DU DRAPEAU DE L’UKRAINE |url=https://www.taurillon.org/chtche-ne-vmerla-ukrainy-histoire-du-drapeau-de-l-ukraine?lang=fr |access-date=16 March 2022 |website=taurillon.org |language=fr}}</ref>
 
 ===Yellow-blue vs blue-yellow===
 Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy'')<ref>A little less often they use also "yellow and blue", "blue and yellow" and "yellow and azure".</ref>—a different version of the flag used during UNR ([[Ukrainian National Republic]]) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. The yellow on the top allegedly represents golden domes ([[cupola]]s) of Christian churches and the blue the [[Dnieper]] river.

The change made in this revision is the removal of the word "two" from the phrase "two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow," which now reads "equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow." Additionally, the phrase "the blue and yellow bicolour has been used since the 1848 Spring of Nations" was altered to "the blue and yellow bicolour has been used since the 1848 Spring of Nations," removing the reference to "Revolutions of 1848." 

**Weaponised**: The revision subtly alters the emphasis on the historical significance of the flag's colors and their usage, which can be interpreted as an attempt to downplay the flag's historical context and its association with national identity. This could be seen as an effort to reshape narratives around Ukrainian cultural symbols in a politically sensitive environment.

The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following [[Modern history of Ukraine#Independent Ukraine (1991 to present)|Ukrainian independence]], before officially being restored on 28 January 1992 by the [[Parliament of Ukraine]].{{Cite web|title=Ukraine’s national flag celebrating 25th anniversary today|url=https://www.unian.info/society/1747301-ukraines-national-flag-celebrating-25th-anniversary-today.html|access-date=2022-03-04|website=[[UNIAN]]|language=en}}{{cite news|last=Trach|first=Nataliya|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/ukraine-politics/the-story-behind-2-top-ukrainian-symbols-national-flag-and-trident-421675.html|title=The story behind 2 top Ukrainian symbols: National flag and trident|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=26 August 2016|access-date=27 August 2016}} Ukraine has celebrated the [[Day of the National Flag (Ukraine)|Day of the National Flag]] on 23 August since 2004.[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2012-08/23/c_131803737.htm Ukraine celebrates National Flag Day] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131007221207/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2012-08/23/c_131803737.htm |date=October 7, 2013 }}, [[Xinhua News Agency]] (August 23, 2012)
[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/kyiv/ceremony-of-hoisting-ukraines-national-flag-held-a-111423.html Ceremony of hoisting Ukraine's national flag held at presidential administration], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (August 23, 2011)
[http://tsn.ua/ukrayina/ukrayina-vidznachaye-den-derzhavnogo-prapora.html Україна відзначає День Державного прапора "On Tuesday, August 23, all of Ukraine celebrates National Flag Day. Measures to raise the national flag are planned throughout the country."] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130801033729/http://tsn.ua/ukrayina/ukrayina-vidznachaye-den-derzhavnogo-prapora.html |date=1 August 2013 }}, [[1+1 (channel)|1+1]] (August 23, 2011)

The original sentence "The '''flag of Ukraine''' has equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow." was modified to "The [[national flag]] of [[Ukraine]] ({{lang-uk|Прапор України|Prapor Ukrainy}}) consists of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow."

initial_version:
<center>[[Image:Ukraine_flag_large.png]]</center>
'''Flag Ratio:''' 2:3

The flag of [[Ukraine]] was adopted on [[September 3]], [[1996]].  It had been the provisional flag since [[1991]].
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -192,9 +192,12 @@
 During the Soviet period, there were multiple unsanctioned attempts to hoist the national blue-and-yellow flag. In 1958, in village of Verbytsia, [[:uk:Ходорівський район|Khodoriv Raion]], there was established an underground group, members of which at night were raising national flags and spread anti-Soviet pamphlets.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Невідомі прапороносці. Жовто-блакитний проти червоного (Unknown flag-bearers. Yellow-blue against Red) |url=https://www.istpravda.com.ua/columns/2011/07/29/48180/|access-date=2022-03-04|website=[[Ukrayinska Pravda]] Історична правда |date= July 29, 2011 }}</ref>
 
 ===Return of the national flag===
+{{see also|Protests against the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine}}
 [[File:Kiev 24.7.1990 Ukrainian Flag.JPG|right|upright|thumb|The Ukrainian national flag was raised outside Kyiv's [[Kyiv City Council|City Hall]] for the first time on 24 July 1990.]]
 [[File:Waving the Ukrainian flag.jpg|thumbnail|right|A girl with the Ukrainian flag at a [[vyshyvanka]] parade]]
 Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s policies of [[perestroika]] and [[glasnost]], the individual Soviet republics had strengthened their sense of national identity, which led to the [[History of the Soviet Union (1982–91)|Collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This concerned the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. These efforts were accompanied with attempts to restore the respective historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's national flag and coat of arms as the state symbol. The Parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed.
+
+[[File:We Stand with Ukraine protest in Helsinki, Finland, 2022 February - 07.jpg|thumb|Right|250px|An [[Protests against the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine|anti-war]] protest in [[Helsinki]] condemning the Russian invasion.]]
 
 The events in the Baltic countries soon led to similar processes in Ukraine. Particularly, West Ukraine and [[Ukrainian SSR]]'s capital [[Kyiv]] constantly held political demonstrations with the national yellow-and-blue flags waving above the heads of demonstrators.
 * On 14 March 1990, the Ukrainian flag was raised for the first time after the establishment of the Soviet Union in the small city of [[Stryi]].<ref> {{Cite web|title=History of evolution of the State Flag of Ukraine |url=http://www.ukrinform.ua/ukr/news/istoriya_evolyutsiii_dergavnogo_prapora_ukraiini_infografika_2084779 |work=[[Ukrinform]] |date=August 23, 2015|access-date=2022-03-04|language=uk}} {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150817220933/http://www.ukrinform.ua/ukr/news/istoriya_evolyutsiii_dergavnogo_prapora_ukraiini_infografika_2084779 |date=August 17, 2015 }} </ref>
@@ -209,6 +212,8 @@
 |Flag of Ukraine (Soviet shades).svg|Flag of Post-Soviet Ukraine used from 8 September 1991 to 28 January 1992 (blue-yellow) 
 |Flag of Ukraine (1992-2006).svg|Flag of Ukraine used from 1992–2006
 }}
+
+The usage of the Ukrainian national flag has been gaining popularity in recent years. At the onset of the [[2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine]], many places all over the world with landmarks lighting up the colors of the Ukrainian flag while some cities raised the Ukrainian flag in solidarity.<ref> https://www.collingwoodtoday.ca/town-of-blue-mountains/town-raises-ukrainian-flag-in-support-and-solidarity-for-the-people-of-ukraine-5167910</ref><ref> https://www.euronews.com/2022/02/25/in-many-capital-cities-official-buildings-turned-blue-and-yellow-in-solidarity-with-ukrain</ref>
 
 ==Flag controversies and criticism==
 {{main|National colours of Ukraine}}
llm_output:
Added references to the protests against the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine and the global solidarity shown through the display of the Ukrainian flag.

Weaponised: Not Weaponised. The changes reflect a historical context and current events without employing divisive or inflammatory language.

changed_version:

+++ 
@@ -173,15 +173,18 @@
 |Flag of Ukrainian SSR.svg|{{FIAV|historical}} 1949–1991
 }}
 
-===Interbellum Ukraine===
+===Interbellum and Reichskommissariat Ukraine===
 The Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists is a Ukrainian political organisation which as a movement originally was created in 1929 in Western Ukraine (at the time interwar Poland). For a long time, the OUN did not officially have its own flag; however, during the Hungarian and Polish aggression against the [[Republic of Carpathian Ukraine]] in 1939, Carpathian Sich, a militarised wing of the OUN, adopted its flag from the OUN's emblem – a golden nationalistic trident on a blue background. The flag was finalised and officially adopted by the organisation only in 1964 at the 5th Assembly of Ukrainian Nationalists.
 
 The Ukrainian Insurgent Army was a Ukrainian nationalist paramilitary and later partisan army that engaged in a series of guerrilla conflicts during World War II against Nazi Germany, the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, and both Underground and Communist Poland. The group was the military wing of the Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists — Bandera faction (the OUN-B), originally formed in Volyn in the spring and summer of 1943. Its official date of creation is 14 October 1942. The battle flag of the UPA was a 2:3 ratio red-and-black banner. The flag continues to be a symbol of the Ukrainian nationalist movement. The colours of the flag symbolise 'Ukrainian red blood spilled on Ukrainian black earth'.
+
+Between the period of 1941–1944, the flag of [[Nazi Germany]] was used to represent [[Reichskommissariat Ukraine]], a civilian government under Nazi occupation. 
 
 {{gallery|mode=nolines|whitebg=y|height=100|align=center
 |OUN-r Flag 1941.svg|Flag of the [[Ukrainian Insurgent Army]] and [[Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists|Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists (of Bandera)]]
 |OUN-M-03.svg|Flag of the [[Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists|Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists (of Melnyk)]]
 |Flag of Ukraine.svg|{{FIAV|historical}} Flag of [[Carpatho-Ukraine]] and the 1941 [[Ukrainian National Government (1941)|Ukrainian National Government]]
+|Flag of German Reich (1935–1945).svg|{{FIAV|historical}} Flag of [[Reichskommissariat Ukraine]] used from 1941–1944
 }}
 
 In 1949, the flag of the Soviet Ukraine was changed once again.<ref name=grechylo/> The [[Soviet Union]] managed to obtain two additional seats in the [[United Nations]] by adding as members Ukraine along with Byelorussia.<ref name=grechylo/> The change was because all the Soviet flags were the same.<ref name=grechylo/> The new Ukrainian flag consisted of red (top, 2/3) and [[azure (color)|azure]] (bottom, 1/3) stripes,<ref name=grechylo/> with the golden star, [[hammer and sickle]] in the top left corner. The Communist party leaders such as [[Khrushchev]] and [[Lazar Kaganovich|Kaganovich]] were afraid of using words 'light blue' and 'blue', which were used by the [[Ukrainian diaspora]].<ref name=grechylo/>
llm_output:

The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following [[Modern history of Ukraine#Independent Ukraine (1991 to present)|Ukrainian independence]], before officially being restored on 28 January 1992 by the [[Parliament of Ukraine]].{{Cite web|title=Ukraine’s national flag celebrating 25th anniversary today|url=https://www.unian.info/society/1747301-ukraines-national-flag-celebrating-25th-anniversary-today.html|access-date=2022-03-04|website=[[UNIAN]]|language=en}}{{cite news|last=Trach|first=Nataliya|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/ukraine-politics/the-story-behind-2-top-ukrainian-symbols-national-flag-and-trident-421675.html|title=The story behind 2 top Ukrainian symbols: National flag and trident|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=26 August 2016|access-date=27 August 2016}} Ukraine has celebrated the [[Day of the National Flag (Ukraine)|Day of the National Flag]] on 23 August since 2004.[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2012-08/23/c_131803737.htm Ukraine celebrates National Flag Day] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131007221207/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2012-08/23/c_131803737.htm |date=October 7, 2013 }}, [[Xinhua News Agency]] (August 23, 2012)
[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/kyiv/ceremony-of-hoisting-ukraines-national-flag-held-a-111423.html Ceremony of hoisting Ukraine's national flag held at presidential administration], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (August 23, 2011)
[http://tsn.ua/ukrayina/ukrayina-vidznachaye-den-derzhavnogo-prapora.html Україна відзначає День Державного прапора "On Tuesday, August 23, all of Ukraine celebrates National Flag Day. Measures to raise the national flag are planned throughout the country."] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130801033729/http://tsn.ua/ukrayina/ukrayina-vidznachaye-den-derzhavnogo-prapora.html |date=1 August 2013 }}, [[1+1 (channel)|1+1]] (August 23, 2011)

+Both blue–yellow and yellow–blue flags were widely used during the [[Ukraine after the Russian Revolution|Ukrainian struggle for independence]] in 1917. -The roots of Ukrainian national symbols come from pre-Christian times when yellow and blue prevailed in traditional ceremonies, reflecting fire and water.<ref name=Saprykov>{{cite web|url=http://geraldika.ru/symbols/3334|script-title=ru:Флаг Украины|trans-title=Flag of Ukraine|language=ru|first=V.|last=Saprykov|website=geraldika.ru|date=May 30, 2003|access-date=October 2, 2017}}</ref> The most solid proof of yellow and blue colours could be traced as far as the [[Battle of Grunwald]], in which militia formations from various lands of the [[Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth]] participated.
+The roots of Ukrainian national symbols come from pre-Christian times when yellow and blue prevailed in traditional ceremonies, reflecting fire and water.<ref name=Saprykov>{{cite web|url=http://geraldika.ru/symbols/3334|script-title=ru:Флаг Украины|trans-title=Flag of Ukraine|language=ru|first=V.|last=Saprykov|website=geraldika.ru|date=May 30, 2003|access-date=October 2, 2017}}</ref> The most solid proof of yellow and blue colours can be traced back as far as the [[Battle of Grunwald]] in 1410, in which militia formations from various lands of the [[Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth]] participated.
 
 Yellow–blue, red-black, crimson-olive and especially raspberry colour banners were widely used by [[Cossack]]s between the 16th and 18th centuries. These were not the only possible combinations, since normally Cossacks would fly their [[hetman]]'s banners, which were similar to the coats of arms of the nobility. Also, yellow and blue were the colours common on coats of arms in [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]]. In fact, the coat of arms of [[Lviv]] to this day remains a golden lion on a blue field.

 ===Interbellum and Reichskommissariat Ukraine===
 The Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists is a Ukrainian political organisation which as a movement originally was created in 1929 in Western Ukraine (at the time interwar Poland). For a long time, the OUN did not officially have its own flag; however, during the Hungarian and Polish aggression against the [[Republic of Carpathian Ukraine]] in 1939, Carpathian Sich, a militarised wing of the OUN, adopted its flag from the OUN's emblem – a golden nationalistic trident on a blue background. The flag was finalised and officially adopted by the organisation only in 1964 at the 5th Assembly of Ukrainian Nationalists.
 
-The Ukrainian Insurgent Army was a Ukrainian nationalist paramilitary and later partisan army that engaged in a series of guerrilla conflicts during World War II against Nazi Germany, the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, and both Underground and Communist Poland. The group was the military wing of the Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists — Bandera faction (the OUN-B), originally formed in Volyn in the spring and summer of 1943. Its official date of creation is 14 October 1942. The battle flag of the UPA was a 2:3 ratio red-and-black banner. The flag continues to be a symbol of the Ukrainian nationalist movement. The colours of the flag symbolise 'Ukrainian red blood spilled on Ukrainian black earth'.
+The Ukrainian Insurgent Army was a Ukrainian nationalist paramilitary and later partisan army that during World War II [[Collaboration in German-occupied Ukraine|collaborated with Nazi Germany]], and engaged in a series of guerrilla conflicts against Nazi Germany, the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, and both Underground and Communist Poland. The group was the military wing of the Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists — Bandera faction (the OUN-B), originally formed in Volyn in the spring and summer of 1943. Its official date of creation is 14 October 1942. The battle flag of the UPA was a 2:3 ratio red-and-black banner. The flag continues to be a symbol of the Ukrainian nationalist movement. The colours of the flag symbolise 'Ukrainian red blood spilled on Ukrainian black earth'.

 ==Flag controversies and criticism==
 {{main|National colours of Ukraine}}
 
 ===Origin===
 {{unreferenced section|date=July 2020}}
-One claimed version is that, since one of the first known coloured depictions of the Coat of Arms of Kyiv was mainly in yellow-blue colours, this tradition may have existed since the time of the Nordic-Slavic [[Grand Prince of Kyiv]] [[Volodymyr the Great]]. However, the blue-yellow colouring dates back to [[Kyivan Ruthenia]], as an early version of the ''[[Tryzub]]'', Ukraine's national coat of arms, sported the same colouring as the seal of [[Sviatoslav I]] of Kyiv (c. AD 945). During the 1709 [[Battle of Poltava]], the Cossacks following [[Mazepa]] fought under yellow-blue banners, while their Swedish allies were under yellow ones. Some Cossacs and nobelmen had also coats of arms in yellow- blue color.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Vannier |first=Alexis |date=24 Aug 2021 |title=« CHTCHE NE VMERLA UKRAÏNY » : HISTOIRE DU DRAPEAU DE L’UKRAINE |url=https://www.taurillon.org/chtche-ne-vmerla-ukrainy-histoire-du-drapeau-de-l-ukraine?lang=fr |access-date=16 March 2022 |website=taurillon.org |language=fr}}</ref>
+One claimed version is that, since one of the first known coloured depictions of the Coat of Arms of Kyiv was mainly in yellow-blue colours, this tradition may have existed since the time of the Nordic-Slavic [[Grand Prince of Kyiv]] [[Volodymyr the Great]]. However, the blue-yellow colouring dates back to [[Kyivan Ruthenia]], as an early version of the ''[[Tryzub]]'', Ukraine's national coat of arms, sported the same colouring as the seal of [[Sviatoslav I]] of Kyiv (c. AD 945). During the 1709 [[Battle of Poltava]], the Cossacks following [[Mazepa]] fought under yellow-blue banners, while their Swedish allies were under yellow ones. Some Cossacks and noblemen had coats of arms in yellow and blue.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Vannier |first=Alexis |date=24 Aug 2021 |title=« CHTCHE NE VMERLA UKRAÏNY » : HISTOIRE DU DRAPEAU DE L’UKRAINE |url=https://www.taurillon.org/chtche-ne-vmerla-ukrainy-histoire-du-drapeau-de-l-ukraine?lang=fr |access-date=16 March 2022 |website=taurillon.org |language=fr}}</ref>
 
 ===Yellow-blue vs blue-yellow===
 Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy'')<ref>A little less often they use also "yellow and blue", "blue and yellow" and "yellow and azure".</ref>—a different version of the flag used during UNR ([[Ukrainian National Republic]]) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. The yellow on the top allegedly represents golden domes ([[cupola]]s) of Christian churches and the blue the [[Dnieper]] river.

changed_version:

@@ -176,7 +176,7 @@
 ===Interbellum and Reichskommissariat Ukraine===
 The Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists is a Ukrainian political organisation which as a movement originally was created in 1929 in Western Ukraine (at the time interwar Poland). For a long time, the OUN did not officially have its own flag; however, during the Hungarian and Polish aggression against the [[Republic of Carpathian Ukraine]] in 1939, Carpathian Sich, a militarised wing of the OUN, adopted its flag from the OUN's emblem – a golden nationalistic trident on a blue background. The flag was finalised and officially adopted by the organisation only in 1964 at the 5th Assembly of Ukrainian Nationalists.
 
-The Ukrainian Insurgent Army was a Ukrainian nationalist paramilitary and later partisan army that during World War II [[Collaboration in German-occupied Ukraine|collaborated with Nazi Germany]], and engaged in a series of guerrilla conflicts against Nazi Germany, the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, and both Underground and Communist Poland. The group was the military wing of the Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists — Bandera faction (the OUN-B), originally formed in Volyn in the spring and summer of 1943. Its official date of creation is 14 October 1942. The battle flag of the UPA was a 2:3 ratio red-and-black banner. The flag continues to be a symbol of the Ukrainian nationalist movement. The colours of the flag symbolise 'Ukrainian red blood spilled on Ukrainian black earth'.
+The [[Ukrainian Insurgent Army]] was a Ukrainian nationalist paramilitary and later partisan army that engaged in a series of guerrilla conflicts during World War II against Nazi Germany, the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, and both Underground and Communist Poland. The group was the military wing of the Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists — Bandera faction (the OUN-B), originally formed in Volyn in the spring and summer of 1943. Its official date of creation is 14 October 1942. The battle flag of the UPA was a 2:3 ratio red-and-black banner. The flag continues to be a symbol of the Ukrainian nationalist movement. The colours of the flag symbolise 'Ukrainian red blood spilled on Ukrainian black earth'.
 
 {{gallery|mode=nolines|whitebg=y|height=100|align=center
 |OUN-r Flag 1941.svg|Flag of the [[Ukrainian Insurgent Army]] and [[Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists|Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists (of Bandera)]]

The flag of [[Ukraine]] was adopted on [[September 3]], [[1996]].  It had been the provisional flag since [[1991]].
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -222,8 +222,6 @@
 ===Yellow-blue vs blue-yellow===
 Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy'')<ref>A little less often they use also "yellow and blue", "blue and yellow" and "yellow and azure".</ref>—a different version of the flag used during UNR ([[Ukrainian National Republic]]) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. The yellow on the top allegedly represents golden domes ([[cupola]]s) of Christian churches and the blue the [[Dnieper]] river.
 
-Although most Ukrainians identify their flag in the spoken language as "yellow and light blue", the current flag in reality is blue (the upper band) and yellow (the lower band). The issue is quite significant, because the historical alteration of the flag (from yellow–blue to blue–yellow) did not affect the spoken language.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} Back in 1848, the flag was yellow and blue,{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} and it was later changed to blue and yellow to be more appealing to the common person.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} A common explanation of "blue sky above yellow field of wheat" was logically given around that time, as Ukraine is considered Europe's breadbasket, or "blue sky over sunflowers," which is their national flower.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}}
-
 The head of the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]], [[Andriy Grechylo]], points to the fact that the discussion about order of colours was taking place as far back as 1918.<ref name=grechylo>{{Cite news|last=Gazeta.ua|title=Хрущов і Каганович боялися слова "жовто-блакитний" (Khrushchev and Kaganovich were afraid of the word "zhovto-blakytnyi") |url=https://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_hruschov-i-kaganovich-boyalisya-slova-zhovtoblakitnij-/512859 |date=23 August 2013 |access-date=2022-03-04|website=Gazeta.ua|language=uk}}</ref> Nonetheless, both governments of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] as well as the [[Ukrainian State]] defined that the upper half would be light-blue, while the lower would be yellow.<ref name=grechylo/> During 1918 it was taken into consideration that light blue would lose its shade under sun, therefore it was decided to make the colour darker.<ref name=grechylo/>
 
 Already in the 1918 draft of the Constitution of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], the order of colours was defined as blue and yellow.<ref name=grechylo/> The same order could be found in legislative acts of the [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] for November 1918 and the [[Republic of Carpathian Ukraine]] on 15 March 1939.<ref name=grechylo/> The argument on the order of colours was taking place in the [[Ukrainian diaspora]] as well.<ref name=grechylo/> In 1949 it was decided that, until Ukraine defined a single state flag, the diaspora would use the blue-and-yellow banner.<ref name=grechylo/>
comment: /* ===Yellow-blue vs blue-yellow=== */  Removed paragraph; been unsourced since 2014. It's been 8 years.
llm_output:
Removed a paragraph discussing the historical context and significance of the Ukrainian flag's color order.

Not Weaponised. The removal of unsourced content does not inherently promote or undermine any cultural narrative.

+One claimed version is that, since one of the first known coloured depictions of the Coat of Arms of Kyiv was mainly in yellow-blue colours, this tradition may have existed since the time of the Nordic-Slavic [[Grand Prince of Kyiv]] [[Volodymyr the Great]]. However, the blue-yellow colouring dates back to [[Kyivan Ruthenia]], as an early version of the ''[[Tryzub]]'', Ukraine's national coat of arms, sported the same colouring as the seal of [[Sviatoslav I]] of Kyiv (c. AD 945). During the 1709 [[Battle of Poltava]], the Cossacks following [[Mazepa]] fought under yellow-blue banners, while their Swedish allies were under yellow ones. Some Cossacs and nobelmen had also coats of arms in yellow- blue color <ref>{{Cite web |last=Vannier |first=Alexis |date=24 Aug 2021 |title=« CHTCHE NE VMERLA UKRAÏNY » : HISTOIRE DU DRAPEAU DE L’UKRAINE |url=https://www.taurillon.org/chtche-ne-vmerla-ukrainy-histoire-du-drapeau-de-l-ukraine?lang=fr |access-date=16.03.2022 |website=taurillon.org |language=fr}}</ref>.
 
 ===Yellow-blue vs blue-yellow===
 Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy'')<ref>A little less often they use also "yellow and blue", "blue and yellow" and "yellow and azure".</ref>—a different version of the flag used during UNR ([[Ukrainian National Republic]]) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. The yellow on the top allegedly represents golden domes ([[cupola]]s) of Christian churches and the blue the [[Dnieper]] river.

In the table below the colours are given according to the technical specification DSTU 4512:2006:{{cite web |title=ДСТУ 4512:2006 — Вікіджерела |url=https://uk.wikisource.org/wiki/ДСТУ_4512:2006 |website=uk.wikisource.org |publisher=Wikimedia |access-date=9 March 2022 |language=uk}} -[[File:Flag of Ukraine (Ratio).svg|175px|right]] -{| class="wikitable" style="width:60%; background:#f9f9f9; border:1px solid #aaa; border-collapse:collapse; white-space:nowrap; text-align:left;" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="2" border="1" -|- style="text-align: center; background: #eee" -! Rubcov |author3=A. Gorpinchenko |author4=W. Sinel'nikova |author5=G. Docenko |author6=O. Kupko |author7=I. Potapenko |author8=E. Ershova |title=State Flag of Ukraine. DSTU 4512:2006 |publisher=State Standards of Ukraine |location=[[Kyiv]] |date=September 2006 | page=7}} -|- -| [[RAL colour standard|RAL]] -| 5019 Azure -| 1023 Gold (golden) -|- -| [[RGB color model]] -| 0, 87, 183{{Cite web|url=https://www.pantone.com/color-finder/2935-C|title=PANTONE® 2935 C - Find a Pantone Color | Quick Online Color Tool | Pantone|website=www.pantone.com}} -| 255, 215, 0{{Cite web|url=https://www.pantone.com/color-finder/Yellow-012-C|title=PANTONE® Yellow 012 C - Find a Pantone Color | Quick Online Color Tool | Pantone|website=www.pantone.com}} -|- -| [[CMYK]] -| 100, 63, 0, 2 -| 0, 2, 100, 0 -|- -| [[Hex triplet|HEX]] -| #0057b7 -| #ffd700 -|- -| [[Websafe]] -| #0066cc -| #ffcc00 -|} - -There has been disagreement over the shade of blue used in the flag. In 2013, scholar Dmytro Malakov argued that [[sky blue]] was the correct colour, and that, according to [[Rule of tincture|rules of heraldry]], [[Dark blue (color)|dark blue]] should not be used.{{cite news |url=http://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_sino-zhovtij-prapor-ce-znuschannya-nad-ukrajinskoyu-tradicieyu/508746 |trans-title=The dark blue and yellow flag is a mockery of Ukrainian tradition |title=Синьо-жовтий прапор – це знущання над українською традицією |work=[[Gazeta.ua]] |date=July 25, 2013 |first=Olga |last=Skorokhod |language=uk}} The head of the Ukrainian Heraldry Society said that this [[heraldry]] issue does not apply to flags. - -The flag is similar to that of the Austrian state of [[Lower Austria]], the German city of [[Chemnitz]], and the Hungarian city of [[Pécs]], but all of those flags have a darker shade of blue. The flag is also somewhat similar to that of the Malaysian state of [[Flag and coat of arms of Perlis|Perlis]], but has a reversed arrangement of colours with darker shades of blue and yellow as well as a different flag aspect ratio. - -==Protocol and use== -{{more citations needed|section|date=August 2017}} - -===Legal status=== - -Article 20 of the Constitution of Ukraine states the following, citing: "the State Flag of Ukraine is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow colour." ({{lang-uk|"Державний Прапор України — стяг із двох рівновеликих горизонтальних смуг синього і жовтого кольорів."}}).{{Cite book|url=https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine|title=Constitution of Ukraine}}{{cite web |url=http://zakon4.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/254%D0%BA/96-%D0%B2%D1%80 |script-title=uk:Конституція України |language=uk |website=Верховна Рада України}} - -===Vertical flags=== -[[File:Hanging flag of Ukraine.svg|thumb|upright=0.25|Hanging version of the Ukrainian flag]] - -In addition to the normal horizontal format, many public buildings, such as the [[Verkhovna Rada]], use vertical flags. Most town halls fly their town flag together with the national flag in this way; some town flags in Ukraine exist only in vertical form. The proportions of these vertical flags are not specified. When hung like a banner or draped, the blue band should be on the left. When flown from a vertical flagpole, the blue band must face the mast. - -===Stamps=== -[[File:Marka3.jpg|thumbnail|"Freedom for Ukraine" cinderella stamp, featuring the Ukrainian flag with a gold fringe and a gold [[Coat of arms of Ukraine|coat of arms]] on top of the flag pole]] -The flag did not appear on Ukrainian official postal stamp issues until 1992, when they depicted the flag with the state coat of arms. Since then the flag has frequently appeared on stamps. [[Cinderella stamp]]s of the [[Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists]] were printed outside Ukraine during the Soviet period and served patriotic purposes. - -===Decoration=== -Traditionally, the flag may be decorated with a [[gold (color)|golden]] [[Fringe (trim)|fringe]] surrounding the perimeter of the flag, as long as it does not deface the flag proper. The beginning of this tradition was the [[flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. The ''[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia]]'' shows a flag decorated with a gold star. Ceremonial displays of the flag, such as those in parades or on indoor posts, often use a fringe to enhance the beauty of the flag. No specific law governs the legality of this fringe. Traditionally, the [[Ukrainian Ground Forces|Army]], [[National Guard of Ukraine|Guard]], [[Ukrainian Navy|Navy]] and [[Ukrainian Air Force|Air Force]] use a fringed flag for [[military parade|parades]], [[colour guard]]s and indoor displays, while the [[President of Ukraine|Office of the President]] and local authorities use a fringed flag for all purposes. - -===Places of continuous display=== -[[File:28160-Lviv.jpg|thumbnail|The Ukrainian flag flying on the [[Lviv Theatre of Opera and Ballet]] with the statue of Glory]] -Ukrainian flags are customly displayed continuously at certain locations. -* [[Maidan Nezalezhnosti]], main square of [[Kyiv]], traditional place for political rallies, including for large-scale radical protest campaigns ([[Orange Revolution]] and [[Euromaidan]]) -* [[Presidential Administration Building (Kyiv)|Presidential Administration Building]], [[Verkhovna Rada building]] and [[Budynok Uryadu]] -* [[Kyiv City Council]] -* [[Lviv High Castle]] -* [[Vernadsky Research Base]] -* At [[State Border Guard Service of Ukraine]] sites -* National, regional and local government buildings -* [[Diplomatic missions of Ukraine|Ukrainian embassies and consulates]] - -===Particular days for display=== -The flag should especially be displayed at full staff on the following days: -* 1 January: [[New Year's Day]] -* 7 January: [[Christmas#Date according to Julian calendar|Christmas (Julian)]] -* 22 January: Ukrainian Unity Day -* 8 March: International Women's Day -* 1 & 2 May: [[International Workers' Day]] -* 9 May: Victory Day over Nazism -* 28 June: Constitution Day -* 23 August: Flag Day -* 24 August: Independence Day -* 21 November: Day of Dignity and Freedom -* 6 December: Armed Forces Day -* 25 December: Christmas (Gregorian/Neo-Julian) - -===Display at half-staff=== -The flag is displayed at half-staff (half-mast in naval usage) as a sign of respect or mourning. Nationwide, this action is proclaimed by the president. Half-mast means the flag is flown two-thirds of the way up the flagpole with at least the height of the flag between the top of the flag and the top of the flagpole. Black ribbons indicate mourning on banners that can't be lowered to half-mast. -* 4th Saturday of November: [[Holodomor Memorial Day]] -* Other historical cases: mass victims of accidents, [[War in Donbass]] and [[Euromaidan]]; [[Death and state funeral of Lech and Maria Kaczyński]], [[Funeral of Pope John Paul II]] and [[11 September attacks]]. - -==Flag Day== -[[File:Ukrflagblue.jpg|thumbnail|right|The flag of Ukraine at [[Kyiv]] City Hall]] -{{main|Day of the National Flag (Ukraine)}} - -23 August has been celebrated as the Day of the National Flag in Ukraine since 2004. 24 July was previously marked as National Flag Day in Kyiv. The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on 24 July 1990, at the flagstaff of the Kyiv City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992, the [[Independence Day of Ukraine]] is celebrated on 24 August. Following government decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this dates and some other holidays; not all of these days are public holidays. Flags also must be flown on election days for the [[Verkhovna Rada]] in addition to other regional-specific flag days. The public display of flags to mark other events, such as the election of the president or the death of a prominent politician (whereupon flags would be at half-mast), can be declared at the discretion of the Cabinet of Ministers. When flags are required to be flown at half-mast, vertical flags are not lowered. A black mourning ribbon is instead attached, either atop the mast (if hung from a pole) or to each end of the flag's supporting cross-beams (if flown like a banner). -{{clear}} - -==History== -[[File:Flag colors.jpg|thumb|Typical agricultural landscape of Ukraine in the [[Kherson Oblast]]]] -[[File:Ilja Jefimowitsch Repin - Reply of the Zaporozhian Cossacks - Yorck.jpg|thumb|left|225px|Cossack flags depicted in ''[[Reply of the Zaporozhian Cossacks]]'' by [[Ilya Repin]], 1880–1891]] -The roots of Ukrainian national symbols come from pre-Christian times when yellow and blue prevailed in traditional ceremonies, reflecting fire and water.{{cite web|url=http://geraldika.ru/symbols/3334|script-title=ru:Флаг Украины|trans-title=Flag of Ukraine|language=ru|first=V.|last=Saprykov|website=geraldika.ru|date=May 30, 2003|access-date=October 2, 2017}} The most solid proof of yellow and blue colours can be traced back as far as the [[Battle of Grunwald]] in 1410, in which militia formations from various lands of the [[Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth]] participated. - -Yellow–blue, red-black, crimson-olive and especially raspberry colour banners were widely used by [[Cossack]]s between the 16th and 18th centuries. These were not the only possible combinations, since normally Cossacks would fly their [[hetman]]'s banners, which were similar to the coats of arms of the nobility. Also, yellow and blue were the colours common on coats of arms in [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]]. In fact, the coat of arms of [[Lviv]] to this day remains a golden lion on a blue field. - -Some put the starting point of the adoption of the current national flag of Ukraine to 1848 when, during the [[The Revolutions of 1848 in the Habsburg areas|Spring of the Nations]] on 22 April 1848, a yellow-and-blue banner was adopted by the [[Supreme Ruthenian Council]]{{Cite web|title=Синьо-жовтий чи жовто-блакитний? Міфи про “перевернутий” прапор (Blue-yellow or yellow-blue? Myths about the flipped flag) |url=https://www.istpravda.com.ua/articles/2014/01/14/140850/ |date=14 January 2014 |access-date=2022-03-04|website=[[Ukrayinska Pravda]] Історична правда}} in Lemberg ([[Lviv]]), the capital of the [[Kingdom of Galicia and Lodomeria]], and flew over the city's magistrate for the first time. Although this move did not have significant consequences, the newly formed Ukrainian divisions in the Austrian army used yellow-and-blue banners in their insignia. - -During the [[Revolution of 1905|Russian Revolution of 1905]], this flag was used by Ukrainians of the [[Dnieper Ukraine]], or the Russian part of Ukraine. - -{{gallery items|width=180|class=center -|[[File:Alex K Halych-Volhynia-flag.svg|180x100px]]|{{FIAV|reconstructed}} Flag of the [[Kingdom of Ruthenia]] -|[[File:Alex K Grundwald flags 1410-05.svg|180x100px]]|{{FIAV|reconstructed}} Flags of the [[Ruthenian Voivodeship|Ruthenian lands]] during the [[Battle of Grunwald]], 1410 -|[[File:Flag of the Zaporizhian Sich.svg|180x100px|border]]|{{FIAV|normal}}{{FIAV|twosided}} Banner of the [[Zaporizhian Sich]] before 1775 -|[[File:Flag of the Cossack Hetmanat.svg|180x100px]]|{{FIAV|normal}} Flag of the coat of arms of the Cossack Hetmanate (1649–1764) -|[[File:Alex K Chornomorske Kozacke Viysko-03.svg|180x100px]]|{{FIAV|historical}} Flag of the [[Black Sea Cossack Host]] in 1803 -|[[File:Flag of the Ruthenian National Guard from Yavoriv.png|190x100px|border]]|{{FIAV|historical}} Flag of Ruthenian National Guard in 1848 -|[[File:Flag of Ukraine.svg|180x100px|border]]|{{FIAV|noflag}} Variant of the national flag since 1848 -}} - -===Early independence: 1917–1921=== -[[File:Богуш Шіппіх - Згинуть наші вороженьки, як роса на сонці (1917).png|thumbnail|UPR flag with the blue and yellow flag, [[Ukrainian War of Independence]], 1918]] -[[File:Украинская галицкая армия флаг.jpg|thumbnail|left|[[Ukrainian Galician Army]] troops with the blue and yellow flag, 1918]] -Both blue–yellow and yellow–blue flags were widely used during the [[Ukraine after the Russian Revolution|Ukrainian struggle for independence]] in 1917. For the first time in the [[Russian Empire]] the blue-yellow flag was flown on 25 March 1917 in [[Petrograd]] during a 20,000-strong mass [[Demonstration (protest)|demonstration]]. On the territory of Ukraine the national flag was flown for the first time in [[Kyiv]] on 29 March 1917 by soldiers. On 1 April 1917, Kyiv saw a 100,000-strong demonstration that carried over 320 national flags. After the demonstrations, similar demonstrations with Ukrainian flags took place across the whole [[Russian Empire]], even going beyond the Ukrainian ethnic lands. Numerous famous Ukrainian politicians wrote their recollection about the 1 April demonstration such as [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] and [[Serhiy Yefremov]], stating that there were blue-and-yellow flags, while [[Dmytro Doroshenko]] claimed that there were yellow-and-blue. The blue-yellow flag was flown at the First Ukrainian Military Congress on 18 May 1917. - -There are reliable sources that indicate that the official flag that was declared by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] in 1918 is blue–yellow. Some sources mention that the yellow–blue was adopted by [[Tsentralna Rada]] on 22 March 1918.[http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=32027&cat_id=31295 State Symbols of Ukraine], [[Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine]], website. Since then the flag has frequently appeared on stamps. Since then, the flag has frequently appeared on stamps. [[Cinderella stamp]]s of the [[Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists]] were printed outside Ukraine during the Soviet period for patriotic purposes. ===Decoration=== -Traditionally, the flag may be decorated with a [[gold (color)|golden]] [[Fringe (trim)|fringe]] surrounding the perimeter of the flag, as long as it does not deface the flag proper. The beginning of this tradition was the [[flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. The ''[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia]]'' shows a flag decorated with a gold star. Ceremonial displays of the flag, such as those in parades or on indoor posts, often use a fringe to enhance the beauty of the flag. No specific law governs the legality of this fringe. Traditionally, the [[Ukrainian Ground Forces|Army]], [[National Guard of Ukraine|Guard]], [[Ukrainian Navy|Navy]] and [[Ukrainian Air Force|Air Force]] use a fringed flag for [[military parade|parades]], [[colour guard]]s and indoor displays, while the [[President of Ukraine|Office of the President]] and local authorities use a fringed flag for all purposes. +Traditionally, the flag may be decorated with a [[gold (color)|golden]] [[Fringe (trim)|fringe]] surrounding the perimeter of the flag, as long as it does not deface the flag proper. The tradition began with the [[flag of the Ukrainian SSR]]. In addition, the ''[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia]]'' shows a flag decorated with a gold star. Ceremonial displays of the flag, such as those in parades or on indoor posts, often use a fringe to enhance the allure of the flag. No specific law governs the use of the fringe. Traditionally, the [[Ukrainian Ground Forces|Army]], [[National Guard of Ukraine|Guard]], [[Ukrainian Navy|Navy]] and [[Ukrainian Air Force|Air Force]] use a fringed flag for [[military parade|parades]], [[colour guard]]s and indoor displays, while the [[President of Ukraine|Office of the President]] and local authorities use a fringed flag on all occasions. ===Places of continuous * National, regional and local government buildings * [[Diplomatic missions of Ukraine|Ukrainian embassies and consulates]] ===Particular days for display=== -The flag should especially be displayed at full staff on the following days: +In particular, the flag should be displayed at full staff on the following days: * 1 January: [[New Year's Day]] * 7 January: [[Christmas#Date according to Julian calendar|Christmas (Julian)]] * 22 January: Ukrainian Unity Day @@ -108,15 +108,15 @@ * 25 December: Christmas (Gregorian/Neo-Julian) ===Display at half-staff=== -The flag is displayed at half-staff (half-mast in naval usage) as a sign of respect or mourning. Nationwide, this action is proclaimed by the president. Half-mast means the flag is flown two-thirds of the way up the flagpole with at least the height of the flag between the top of the flag and the top of the flagpole. Black ribbons indicate mourning on banners that can't be lowered to half-mast. +The flag is displayed at [[Half-mast|half-staff]] (or half-mast) as a sign of respect or [[mourning]]. When done nationwide, such a step is proclaimed by the president. Half-mast means flying a flag two-thirds of the way up a flagpole; the top of the flag must be at least a flag's height from the top of the flagpole. Black ribbons indicate mourning on banners that can't be lowered to half-mast. * 4th Saturday of November: [[Holodomor Memorial Day]] -* Other historical cases: mass victims of accidents, [[War in Donbass]] and [[Euromaidan]]; [[Death and state funeral of Lech and Maria Kaczyński]], [[Funeral of Pope John Paul II]] and [[11 September attacks]]. +* Other historical cases: mass victims of accidents, [[War in Donbass]] and [[Euromaidan]]; [[death and state funeral of Lech and Maria Kaczyński]], [[funeral of Pope John Paul II]] and [[11 September attacks]]. ==Flag Day== [[File:Ukrflagblue.jpg|thumbnail|right|The flag of Ukraine at [[Kyiv]] City Hall]] {{main|Day of the National Flag (Ukraine)}} -23 August has been celebrated as the Day of the National Flag in Ukraine since 2004. 24 July was previously marked as National Flag Day in Kyiv. The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on 24 July 1990, at the flagstaff of the Kyiv City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992, the [[Independence Day of Ukraine]] is celebrated on 24 August. Following government decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this dates and some other holidays; not all of these days are public holidays. Flags also must be flown on election days for the [[Verkhovna Rada]] in addition to other regional-specific flag days. The public display of flags to mark other events, such as the election of the president or the death of a prominent politician (whereupon flags would be at half-mast), can be declared at the discretion of the Cabinet of Ministers. When flags are required to be flown at half-mast, vertical flags are not lowered. A black mourning ribbon is instead attached, either atop the mast (if hung from a pole) or to each end of the flag's supporting cross-beams (if flown like a banner). +The Day of the National Flag in Ukraine is celebrated on 23 August; it began in 2004. Previously, 24 July was National Flag Day in Kyiv. The first ceremonial raising of the yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag in modern times took place on 24 July 1990, at the flagstaff of the Kyiv City Council, two years before the flag was officially adopted as the National flag. Since 1992, the [[Independence Day of Ukraine]] has been celebrated on 24 August. Following a government decree, the flag must be flown from public buildings on this date and certain other holidays; not all are public holidays. Flags must also be flown on parliamentary election days and regional-specific flag days. The public display of flags to mark other events, such as the election of the president or the death of a prominent politician (whereupon flags are flown at half-mast), can be declared at the discretion of the [[Cabinet of ministers of Ukraine|Cabinet of Ministers]]. When flags are flown at half-mast, vertical flags are not lowered.  {{unreferenced section|date=July 2020}}
 One claimed version is that, since one of the first known coloured depictions of the Coat of Arms of Kyiv was mainly in yellow-blue colours, this tradition may have existed since the time of the Nordic-Slavic [[Grand Prince of Kyiv]] [[Volodymyr the Great]]. However, the blue-yellow colouring dates back to [[Kyivan Ruthenia]], as an early version of the ''[[Tryzub]]'', Ukraine's national coat of arms, sported the same colouring as the seal of [[Sviatoslav I]] of Kyiv (c. AD 945). During the 1709 [[Battle of Poltava]], the Cossacks following [[Mazepa]] fought under yellow-blue banners, while their Swedish allies were under yellow ones. Some Cossacks and noblemen had coats of arms in yellow and blue.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Vannier |first=Alexis |date=24 Aug 2021 |title=" CHTCHE NE VMERLA UKRAÏNY " : HISTOIRE DU DRAPEAU DE L'UKRAINE |url=https://www.taurillon.org/chtche-ne-vmerla-ukrainy-histoire-du-drapeau-de-l-ukraine?lang=fr |access-date=16 March 2022 |website=taurillon.org |language=fr}}</ref>
 
-===Yellow-blue vs blue-yellow===
+===Yellow-blue versus blue-yellow===
 Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy'')<ref>A little less often they use also "yellow and blue", "blue and yellow" and "yellow and azure".</ref>—a different version of the flag used during UNR ([[Ukrainian National Republic]]) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. The yellow on the top allegedly represents golden domes ([[cupola]]s) of Christian churches and the blue the [[Dnieper]] river.
 
 The head of the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]], [[Andriy Grechylo]], points to the fact that the discussion about order of colours was taking place as far back as 1918.<ref name=grechylo>{{Cite news|last=Gazeta.ua|title=Хрущов і Каганович боялися слова "жовто-блакитний" (Khrushchev and Kaganovich were afraid of the word "zhovto-blakytnyi") |url=https://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_hruschov-i-kaganovich-boyalisya-slova-zhovtoblakitnij-/512859 |date=23 August 2013 |access-date=2022-03-04|website=Gazeta.ua|language=uk}}</ref> Nonetheless, both governments of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] as well as the [[Ukrainian State]] defined that the upper half would be light-blue, while the lower would be yellow.<ref name=grechylo/> During 1918 it was taken into consideration that light blue would lose its shade under sun, therefore it was decided to make the colour darker.<ref name=grechylo/>

However, the blue-yellow colouring dates back to [[Kyivan Ruthenia]], as an early version of the ''[[Tryzub]]'', Ukraine's national coat of arms, sported the same colouring as the seal of [[Sviatoslav I]] of Kyiv (c. AD 945). During the 1709 [[Battle of Poltava]], the Cossacks following [[Mazepa]] fought under yellow-blue banners, while their Swedish allies were under yellow ones. Some Cossacks and noblemen had coats of arms in yellow and blue.{{Cite web |last=Vannier |first=Alexis |date=24 Aug 2021 |title=" CHTCHE NE VMERLA UKRAÏNY " : HISTOIRE DU DRAPEAU DE L'UKRAINE |url=https://www.taurillon.org/chtche-ne-vmerla-ukrainy-histoire-du-drapeau-de-l-ukraine?lang=fr |access-date=16 March 2022 |website=taurillon.org |language=fr}} ===Yellow-blue vs blue-yellow=== Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy'')A little less often they use also "yellow and blue", "blue and yellow" and "yellow and azure".—a different version of the flag used during UNR ([[Ukrainian National Republic]]) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. The yellow on the top allegedly represents golden domes ([[cupola]]s) of Christian churches and the blue the [[Dnieper]] river. @@ -227,7 +227,7 @@ Already in the 1918 draft of the Constitution of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], the order of colours was defined as blue and yellow. The same order could be found in legislative acts of the [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] for November 1918 and the [[Republic of Carpathian Ukraine]] on 15 March 1939. The argument on the order of colours was taking place in the [[Ukrainian diaspora]] as well. In 1949 it was decided that, until Ukraine defined a single state flag, the diaspora would use the blue-and-yellow banner. ===Attempts to revive Soviet flags=== -On 21 April 2011, the [[Verkhovna Rada]] passed a law allowing the [[Victory Banner (Soviet Union)|Victory Banner]] to be raised on Victory Day.{{Cite news |title=РАДА ЗОБОВ’ЯЗАЛА ВИВІШУВАТИ ЧЕРВОНІ ПРАПОРИ НА 9 ТРАВНЯ (Rada enforced raising red flags on the May 9) |url=https://www.istpravda.com.ua/short/2011/04/21/36767/|access-date=2022-03-04|website= [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] Історична правда |date=April 21, 2011}} The current Victory Banner was adopted in [[Russia]] in 2007. On 20 May 2011, the law was signed by the [[President of Ukraine]] [[Viktor Yanukovych]].{{Cite news |title=ЯНУКОВИЧ ПІДПИСАВ ЗАКОН ПРО ЧЕРВОНИЙ ПРАПОР (Yanukovych signed the law about the Red Banner) |url=https://www.istpravda.com.ua/short/2011/05/21/39383/ |access-date=2022-03-04 |website=[[Ukrayinska Pravda]] Історична правда |date=}} On 17 June 2011, the [[Constitutional Court of Ukraine]] recognised the law as unconstitutional and proposed that the parliament implement required amendments to the [[Constitution of Ukraine]].{{Cite news|title=КС Украины признал неконституционным использование красного знамени Победы (CC of Ukraine recognised the use of Red Victory Banner as non-constitutional) |url=https://rg.ru/2011/06/17/znamya-anons.html|access-date=2022-03-04|website=Russian Gazette Российская газета |date=June 17, 2011 |language=ru}} On 9 April 2015, the Ukrainian parliament passed legislation on [[decommunization in Ukraine|decommunization]], banning the promotion of symbols of “[[Communist]] and [[National Socialist]] [[totalitarian regime]]s".{{cite news|url= http://www.newsweek.com/ukraine-purges-symbols-its-communist-past-321663 |title= Ukraine Purges Symbols of Its Communist Past |first= Nolan |last= Peterson |work= [[Newsweek]] |date= 10 April 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}}
{{cite news |url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/259775.html |title= Rada bans Communist, Nazi propaganda in Ukraine |work= [[Interfax-Ukraine]] |date= 9 April 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}}
{{cite news|url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/apr/20/ukraine-decommunisation-law-soviet |title= Ukraine to rewrite Soviet history with controversial 'decommunisation' laws |first= Lily |last= Hyde |work= [[The Guardian]] |date= 20 April 2015 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20150516095241/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/apr/20/ukraine-decommunisation-law-soviet |archive-date= 16 May 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}} Since then, Soviet symbols, like the Victory Banner, have only been allowed in cemeteries.{{cite news|url= https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-32267075 |first= Vitaly |last= Shevchenko |title= Goodbye, Lenin: Ukraine moves to ban communist symbols |work= [[BBC News]] |date=14 April 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}}
[http://www.dw.de/ukraine-lawmakers-ban-communist-and-nazi-propaganda/a-18372853 Ukraine lawmakers ban 'Communist and Nazi propaganda'], [[Deutsche Welle]] (9 April 2015) +On 21 April 2011, the [[Verkhovna Rada]] passed a law allowing the [[Victory Banner (Soviet Union)|Victory Banner]] to be raised on Victory Day.{{Cite news |title=РАДА ЗОБОВ'ЯЗАЛА ВИВІШУВАТИ ЧЕРВОНІ ПРАПОРИ НА 9 ТРАВНЯ (Rada enforced raising red flags on the May 9) |url=https://www.istpravda.com.ua/short/2011/04/21/36767/|access-date=2022-03-04|website= [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] Історична правда |date=April 21, 2011}} The current Victory Banner was adopted in [[Russia]] in 2007. On 20 May 2011, the law was signed by the [[President of Ukraine]] [[Viktor Yanukovych]].{{Cite news |title=ЯНУКОВИЧ ПІДПИСАВ ЗАКОН ПРО ЧЕРВОНИЙ ПРАПОР (Yanukovych signed the law about the Red Banner) |url=https://www.istpravda.com.ua/short/2011/05/21/39383/ |access-date=2022-03-04 |website=[[Ukrayinska Pravda]] Історична правда |date=}} On 17 June 2011, the [[Constitutional Court of Ukraine]] recognised the law as unconstitutional and proposed that the parliament implement required amendments to the [[Constitution of Ukraine]].{{Cite news|title=КС Украины признал неконституционным использование красного знамени Победы (CC of Ukraine recognised the use of Red Victory Banner as non-constitutional) |url=https://rg.ru/2011/06/17/znamya-anons.html|access-date=2022-03-04|website=Russian Gazette Российская газета |date=June 17, 2011 |language=ru}} On 9 April 2015, the Ukrainian parliament passed legislation on [[decommunization in Ukraine|decommunization]], banning the promotion of symbols of “[[Communist]] and [[National Socialist]] [[totalitarian regime]]s".{{cite news|url= http://www.newsweek.com/ukraine-purges-symbols-its-communist-past-321663 |title= Ukraine Purges Symbols of Its Communist Past |first= Nolan |last= Peterson |work= [[Newsweek]] |date= 10 April 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}}
{{cite news |url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/259775.html |title= Rada bans Communist, Nazi propaganda in Ukraine |work= [[Interfax-Ukraine]] |date= 9 April 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}}
{{cite news|url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/apr/20/ukraine-decommunisation-law-soviet |title= Ukraine to rewrite Soviet history with controversial 'decommunisation' laws |first= Lily |last= Hyde |work= [[The Guardian]] |date= 20 April 2015 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20150516095241/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/apr/20/ukraine-decommunisation-law-soviet |archive-date= 16 May 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}} Since then, Soviet symbols, like the Victory Banner, have only been allowed in cemeteries.{{cite news|url= https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-32267075 |first= Vitaly |last= Shevchenko |title= Goodbye, Lenin: Ukraine moves to ban communist symbols |work= [[BBC News]] |date=14 April 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}}
[http://www.dw.de/ukraine-lawmakers-ban-communist-and-nazi-propaganda/a-18372853 Ukraine lawmakers ban 'Communist and Nazi propaganda'], [[Deutsche Welle]] (9 April 2015) ==Flag of the head of state== Throughout the history of [[Ukraine]], various [[List of heads of state of Ukraine|heads of state]] have used different flags. The designs differ according to the historical era during which they were used and the political situation in [[Ukraine]] at the time. [[Pavlo Skoropadskyi]] was the first [[List of leaders of Ukraine|Ukrainian head of state]] to use a flag. The current design, the flag of the [[President of Ukraine]], was adopted in 1999. In 2022, the President of Ukraine used a variant in which the left side of the blue upper-half contains the yellow ''[[Coat of arms of Ukraine|Tryzub]]''.{{Cite web|last=Basu|first=Zachary|date=2022-03-01|title=Zelensky tells European Parliament "nobody is going to break us" in emotional appeal|url=https://www.axios.com/zelensky-video-european-parliament-address-ukraine-ed88a2e1-ff9e-471c-9a4d-92e0406ff541.html|access-date=2022-03-04|website=Axios|language=en}}

Not Weaponised. The changes do not introduce any weaponisation terms or narratives; they simply clarify historical details about the flag without altering the underlying message or context.

<center>[[Image:Ukraine_flag_large.png]]</center>
'''Flag Ratio:''' 2:3

The flag of [[Ukraine]] was adopted on [[September 3]], [[1996]].  It had been the provisional flag since [[1991]].
changed_version:
--- +++ @@ -19,7 +19,9 @@ |Design2 = White with a blue Saint George's cross that extends to the edges of the flag, with the national bicolour in the canton. }} -The '''Flag of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|Прапор України|Prapor Ukrainy}}) consists of equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow.[[s:Constitution of Ukraine, 2004#Article 20|Article 20]]) As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolour has been used since the [[Revolutions of 1848|1848 Spring of Nations]], when it was hoisted over [[Lviv Town Hall]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], just before [[World War II]] it was also adopted by [[Carpatho-Ukraine]] in March 1939. When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the [[flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]] was used and the bicolour flag was outlawed. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following [[Modern history of Ukraine#Independent Ukraine (1991 to present)|Ukrainian independence]], before officially being restored on 28 January 1992 by the [[Parliament of Ukraine]].{{Cite web|title=Ukraine's national flag celebrating 25th anniversary today|url=https://www.unian.info/society/1747301-ukraines-national-flag-celebrating-25th-anniversary-today.html|access-date=2022-03-04|website=[[UNIAN]]|language=en}}{{cite news|last=Trach|first=Nataliya|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/ukraine-politics/the-story-behind-2-top-ukrainian-symbols-national-flag-and-trident-421675.html|title=The story behind 2 top Ukrainian symbols: National flag and trident|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=26 August 2016|access-date=27 August 2016}} +The '''Flag of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|Прапор України|Prapor Ukrainy}}) consists of equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow.[[s:Constitution of Ukraine, 2004#Article 20|Article 20]]) As a [[national flag]], the blue and yellow bicolour has been used since the [[Revolutions of 1848|1848 Spring of Nations]], when it was hoisted over [[Lviv Town Hall]]. It was officially adopted as a state flag for the first time in 1918 by the short-lived [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] and subsequently used by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], just before [[World War II]] it was also adopted by [[Carpatho-Ukraine]] in March 1939. + +When Ukraine was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the [[flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]] was used and the bicolour flag was outlawed. The blue and yellow flag was provisionally adopted for official ceremonies in September 1991 following [[Modern history of Ukraine#Independent Ukraine (1991 to present)|Ukrainian independence]], before officially being restored on 28 January 1992 by the [[Parliament of Ukraine]].{{Cite web|title=Ukraine's national flag celebrating 25th anniversary today|url=https://www.unian.info/society/1747301-ukraines-national-flag-celebrating-25th-anniversary-today.html|access-date=2022-03-04|website=[[UNIAN]]|language=en}}{{cite news|last=Trach|first=Nataliya|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/ukraine-politics/the-story-behind-2-top-ukrainian-symbols-national-flag-and-trident-421675.html|title=The story behind 2 top Ukrainian symbols: National flag and trident|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=26 August 2016|access-date=27 August 2016}} Ukraine has celebrated the [[Day of the National Flag (Ukraine)|Day of the National Flag]] on 23 August since 2004.[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2012-08/23/c_131803737.htm Ukraine celebrates National Flag Day] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131007221207/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2012-08/23/c_131803737.htm |date=October 7, 2013 }}, [[Xinhua News Agency]] (August 23, 2012)
[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/kyiv/ceremony-of-hoisting-ukraines-national-flag-held-a-111423.html Ceremony of hoisting Ukraine's national flag held at presidential administration], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (August 23, 2011)
[http://tsn.ua/ukrayina/ukrayina-vidznachaye-den-derzhavnogo-prapora.html Україна відзначає День Державного прапора "On Tuesday, August 23, all of Ukraine celebrates National Flag Day. Measures to raise the national flag are planned throughout the country."] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130801033729/http://tsn.ua/ukrayina/ukrayina-vidznachaye-den-derzhavnogo-prapora.html |date=1 August 2013 }}, [[1+1 (channel)|1+1]] (August 23, 2011)

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -191,7 +191,6 @@
 During the Soviet period, multiple unsanctioned attempts to hoist the national blue-and-yellow flag were made. In 1958, an underground group was established in the village of Verbytsia, [[:uk:Ходорівський район|Khodoriv Raion]]; its members raised national flags and spread anti-Soviet pamphlets under cover of darkness.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Невідомі прапороносці. Жовто-блакитний проти червоного (Unknown flag-bearers. Yellow-blue against Red) |url=https://www.istpravda.com.ua/columns/2011/07/29/48180/|access-date=2022-03-04|website=[[Ukrayinska Pravda]] Історична правда |date= July 29, 2011 }}</ref>
 
 ===Return of the national flag===
-{{see also|Protests against the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine}}
 [[File:Kiev 24.7.1990 Ukrainian Flag.JPG|right|upright|thumb|The Ukrainian national flag was raised outside Kyiv's [[Kyiv City Council|City Hall]] for the first time on 24 July 1990.]]
 [[File:Waving the Ukrainian flag.jpg|thumbnail|right|A girl with the Ukrainian flag at a [[vyshyvanka]] parade]]
 Under the influence of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s policies of [[perestroika]] and [[glasnost]], individual Soviet republics gained a strengthened sense of national identity, leading to the [[collapse of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. This was particularly true for the three [[Baltic states]] and [[West Ukrainian National Republic|Western Ukraine]], which were the last territories annexed into Soviet Union. The national awakening was accompanied by attempts to restore historical national symbols. In 1988, the [[List of Lithuanian rulers#Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic (1940–1941 and 1944–1990)|Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR]] [[Coat of arms of Lithuania#History|re-established]] Lithuania's national flag and coat of arms as the state symbol. The parliaments of [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]] soon followed suit.
llm_output:
Removed the reference to "Protests against the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine".

Not Weaponised. The change appears to be a removal of a specific reference that may not directly contribute to a weaponised narrative, but rather reflects an editorial decision regarding relevance.
