The argument on the order of colours was taking place in the [[Ukrainian diaspora]] as well. In 1949 it was decided that, until Ukraine defined a single state flag, the diaspora would use the blue-and-yellow banner. ===Attempts to revive Soviet flags=== -On 21 April 2011, the [[Verkhovna Rada]] passed a law allowing the [[Victory Banner (Soviet Union)|Victory Banner]] to be raised on Victory Day.{{Cite news |title=РАДА ЗОБОВ'ЯЗАЛА ВИВІШУВАТИ ЧЕРВОНІ ПРАПОРИ НА 9 ТРАВНЯ (Rada enforced raising red flags on the May 9) |url=https://www.istpravda.com.ua/short/2011/04/21/36767/|access-date=2022-03-04|website= [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] Історична правда |date=April 21, 2011}} The current Victory Banner was adopted in Russia in 2007. On 20 May 2011, the law was signed by the [[President of Ukraine]] [[Viktor Yanukovych]].{{Cite news |title=ЯНУКОВИЧ ПІДПИСАВ ЗАКОН ПРО ЧЕРВОНИЙ ПРАПОР (Yanukovych signed the law about the Red Banner) |url=https://www.istpravda.com.ua/short/2011/05/21/39383/ |access-date=2022-03-04 |website=[[Ukrayinska Pravda]] Історична правда |date=}} On 17 June 2011, the [[Constitutional Court of Ukraine]] recognised the law as unconstitutional and proposed that the parliament implement required amendments to the [[Constitution of Ukraine]].{{Cite news|title=КС Украины признал неконституционным использование красного знамени Победы (CC of Ukraine recognised the use of Red Victory Banner as non-constitutional) |url=https://rg.ru/2011/06/17/znamya-anons.html|access-date=2022-03-04|website=Russian Gazette Российская газета |date=June 17, 2011 |language=ru}} On 9 April 2015, the Ukrainian parliament passed legislation on [[decommunization in Ukraine|decommunization]], banning the promotion of symbols of “[[Communist]] and [[National Socialist]] [[totalitarian regime]]s".{{cite news|url= http://www.newsweek.com/ukraine-purges-symbols-its-communist-past-321663 |title= Ukraine Purges Symbols of Its Communist Past |first= Nolan |last= Peterson |work= [[Newsweek]] |date= 10 April 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}}
{{cite news |url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/259775.html |title= Rada bans Communist, Nazi propaganda in Ukraine |work= [[Interfax-Ukraine]] |date= 9 April 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}}
{{cite news|url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/apr/20/ukraine-decommunisation-law-soviet |title= Ukraine to rewrite Soviet history with controversial 'decommunisation' laws |first= Lily |last= Hyde |work= [[The Guardian]] |date= 20 April 2015 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20150516095241/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/apr/20/ukraine-decommunisation-law-soviet |archive-date= 16 May 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}} Since then, Soviet symbols, like the Victory Banner, have only been allowed in cemeteries.{{cite news|url= https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-32267075 |first= Vitaly |last= Shevchenko |title= Goodbye, Lenin: Ukraine moves to ban communist symbols |work= [[BBC News]] |date=14 April 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}}

On 20 May 2011, the law was signed by the [[President of Ukraine]] [[Viktor Yanukovych]].{{Cite news |title=ЯНУКОВИЧ ПІДПИСАВ ЗАКОН ПРО ЧЕРВОНИЙ ПРАПОР (Yanukovych signed the law about the Red Banner) |url=https://www.istpravda.com.ua/short/2011/05/21/39383/ |access-date=2022-03-04 |website=[[Ukrayinska Pravda]] Історична правда |date= 21 May 2011 |language=uk}} On 17 June 2011, the [[Constitutional Court of Ukraine]] recognised the law as unconstitutional and proposed that the parliament implement required amendments to the [[Constitution of Ukraine]].{{Cite news|title=КС Украины признал неконституционным использование красного знамени Победы (CC of Ukraine recognised the use of Red Victory Banner as non-constitutional) |url=https://rg.ru/2011/06/17/znamya-anons.html|access-date=2022-03-04|website=Russian Gazette Российская газета |date=June 17, 2011 |language=ru}} On 9 April 2015, the Ukrainian parliament passed legislation on [[decommunization in Ukraine|decommunization]], banning the promotion of symbols of “[[Communist]] and [[National Socialist]] [[totalitarian regime]]s".{{cite news|url= http://www.newsweek.com/ukraine-purges-symbols-its-communist-past-321663 |title= Ukraine Purges Symbols of Its Communist Past |first= Nolan |last= Peterson |work= [[Newsweek]] |date= 10 April 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}}
{{cite news |url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/259775.html |title= Rada bans Communist, Nazi propaganda in Ukraine |work= [[Interfax-Ukraine]] |date= 9 April 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}}
{{cite news|url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/apr/20/ukraine-decommunisation-law-soviet |title= Ukraine to rewrite Soviet history with controversial 'decommunisation' laws |first= Lily |last= Hyde |work= [[The Guardian]] |date= 20 April 2015 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20150516095241/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/apr/20/ukraine-decommunisation-law-soviet |archive-date= 16 May 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}} Since then, Soviet symbols, like the Victory Banner, have only been allowed in cemeteries.{{cite news|url= https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-32267075 |first= Vitaly |last= Shevchenko |title= Goodbye, Lenin: Ukraine moves to ban communist symbols |work= [[BBC News]] |date=14 April 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}}{{cite news|url= https://www.dw.de/ukraine-lawmakers-ban-communist-and-nazi-propaganda/a-18372853 |title= Ukraine lawmakers ban 'Communist and Nazi propaganda' |work= [[Deutsche Welle]] |date=9 April 2015 |archive-date= 1 October 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151001180213/https://www.dw.com/en/ukraine-lawmakers-ban-communist-and-nazi-propaganda/a-18372853 |url-status=live |access-date= 11 February 2023}} ==Flag of the head of state== Throughout the history of [[Ukraine]], various [[List of heads of state of Ukraine|heads of state]] have used different flags. The designs differ according to the historical era they were used in and in accordance with the political scene in [[Ukraine]] at the time. The first flag to be used by a [[List of heads of state of Ukraine|head of state of Ukraine]] was that of [[Pavlo Skoropadskyi]]. The current design, the flag of the [[President of Ukraine]], was adopted in 1999. In 2022 the President of Ukraine used a variant where the left side of the blue upper-half contains the yellow ''[[Coat of arms of Ukraine|Tryzub]]''.{{Cite web|last=Basu|first=Zachary|date=2022-03-01|title=Zelensky tells European Parliament "nobody is going to break us" in emotional appeal|url=https://www.axios.com/zelensky-video-european-parliament-address-ukraine-ed88a2e1-ff9e-471c-9a4d-92e0406ff541.html|access-date=2022-03-04|website=Axios|language=en}}

The flag of [[Ukraine]] was adopted on [[September 3]], [[1996]].  It had been the provisional flag since [[1991]].
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -69,7 +69,7 @@
 ==Protocol and use==
 {{more citations needed|section|date=August 2017}}<!--only Legal status section has citations-->
 
-Article 20 of the [[Constitution of Ukraine]] states that "the State Flag of Ukraine is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow colour." ({{lang-uk|"Державний Прапор України — стяг із двох рівновеликих горизонтальних смуг синього і жовтого кольорів."}}).<ref name="constitution_article">{{Cite book|url=https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine|title=Constitution of Ukraine}}</ref><ref name=constitution_official_uk>{{cite web |url=http://zakon4.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/254%D0%BA/96-%D0%B2%D1%80 |script-title=uk:Конституція України |language=uk |website=Верховна Рада України}}</ref>
+Article 20 of the [[Constitution of Ukraine]] states that "the State Flag of Ukraine is a banner of two equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow colour." ({{lang-uk|"Державний Прапор України — стяг із двох рівновеликих горизонтальних смуг синього і жовтого кольорів."|link=no}}).<ref name="constitution_article">{{Cite book|url=https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine|title=Constitution of Ukraine}}</ref><ref name=constitution_official_uk>{{cite web |url=http://zakon4.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/254%D0%BA/96-%D0%B2%D1%80 |script-title=uk:Конституція України |language=uk |website=Верховна Рада України}}</ref>
 
 [[File:Hanging flag of Ukraine.svg|thumb|upright=0.25|Hanging version of the Ukrainian flag]]
 In addition to the normal horizontal format, many public buildings, such as the [[Verkhovna Rada]], use vertical flags. Most town halls fly their town flag together with the national flag in this way; some town flags in Ukraine exist only in vertical form. The proportions of these vertical flags are not specified<!-- (commented out until supporting evidence can be found), although a ratio of 5:2 is the most common-->. When hung like a banner or draped, the blue band should be on the left. When flown from a vertical flagpole, the blue band must face the mast.
@@ -215,7 +215,7 @@
 One claimed version is that, since one of the first known coloured depictions of the [[Coat of Arms of Kyiv]] was mainly in yellow-blue colours, this tradition may have existed since the time of the Nordic-Slavic [[Grand Prince of Kyiv]] [[Volodymyr the Great]]. However, the blue-yellow colouring dates back to [[Kievan Rus’]], as an early version of the ''[[Tryzub]]'', Ukraine's national coat of arms, sported the same colouring as the seal of [[Sviatoslav I]] of Kyiv (c. AD 945). During the 1709 [[Battle of Poltava]], the Cossacks following [[Mazepa]] fought under yellow-blue banners, while their Swedish allies were under yellow ones. Some Cossacks and noblemen had coats of arms in yellow and blue.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Vannier |first=Alexis |date=24 Aug 2021 |title=" CHTCHE NE VMERLA UKRAÏNY " : HISTOIRE DU DRAPEAU DE L'UKRAINE |url=https://www.taurillon.org/chtche-ne-vmerla-ukrainy-histoire-du-drapeau-de-l-ukraine?lang=fr |access-date=16 March 2022 |website=taurillon.org |language=fr}}</ref>
 
 ===Yellow-blue versus blue-yellow===
-Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy'')<ref>A little less often they use also "yellow and blue", "blue and yellow" and "yellow and azure".</ref>—a different version of the flag used during UNR ([[Ukrainian National Republic]]) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. The yellow on the top allegedly represents golden domes ([[cupola]]s) of Christian churches and the blue the [[Dnieper]] river.
+Ukrainians commonly refer to the flag as "yellow and light blue" ({{lang-uk|жовто-блакитний|link=no}}, ''zhovto-blakytnyy'')<ref>A little less often they use also "yellow and blue", "blue and yellow" and "yellow and azure".</ref>—a different version of the flag used during UNR ([[Ukrainian National Republic]]) years (1917–1921) with yellow on the top and blue on the bottom. The yellow on the top allegedly represents golden domes ([[cupola]]s) of Christian churches and the blue the [[Dnieper]] river.
 
 The head of the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]], [[Andriy Grechylo]], points to the fact that the discussion about order of colours was taking place as far back as 1918.<ref name=grechylo>{{Cite news|last=Gazeta.ua|title=Хрущов і Каганович боялися слова "жовто-блакитний" (Khrushchev and Kaganovich were afraid of the word "zhovto-blakytnyi") |url=https://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_hruschov-i-kaganovich-boyalisya-slova-zhovtoblakitnij-/512859 |date=23 August 2013 |access-date=2022-03-04|website=Gazeta.ua|language=uk}}</ref> Nonetheless, both governments of the Ukrainian People's Republic as well as the Ukrainian State defined that the upper half would be light-blue, while the lower would be yellow.<ref name=grechylo/> During 1918 it was taken into consideration that light blue would lose its shade under sun, therefore it was decided to make the colour darker.<ref name=grechylo/>

The yellow on the top allegedly represents golden domes ([[cupola]]s) of Christian churches and the blue the [[Dnieper]] river. -The head of the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]], [[Andriy Grechylo]], points to the fact that the discussion about order of colours was taking place as far back as 1918.{{Cite news|last=Gazeta.ua|title=Хрущов і Каганович боялися слова "жовто-блакитний" (Khrushchev and Kaganovich were afraid of the word "zhovto-blakytnyi") |url=https://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_hruschov-i-kaganovich-boyalisya-slova-zhovtoblakitnij-/512859 |date=23 August 2013 |access-date=2022-03-04|website=Gazeta.ua|language=uk}} Nonetheless, both governments of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] as well as the [[Ukrainian State]] defined that the upper half would be light-blue, while the lower would be yellow. During 1918 it was taken into consideration that light blue would lose its shade under sun, therefore it was decided to make the colour darker. - -Already in the 1918 draft of the Constitution of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], the order of colours was defined as blue and yellow. The same order could be found in legislative acts of the [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] for November 1918 and the [[Republic of Carpathian Ukraine]] on 15 March 1939. The argument on the order of colours was taking place in the [[Ukrainian diaspora]] as well. In 1949 it was decided that, until Ukraine defined a single state flag, the diaspora would use the blue-and-yellow banner. +The head of the [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]], [[Andriy Grechylo]], points to the fact that the discussion about order of colours was taking place as far back as 1918.{{Cite news|last=Gazeta.ua|title=Хрущов і Каганович боялися слова "жовто-блакитний" (Khrushchev and Kaganovich were afraid of the word "zhovto-blakytnyi") |url=https://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_hruschov-i-kaganovich-boyalisya-slova-zhovtoblakitnij-/512859 |date=23 August 2013 |access-date=2022-03-04|website=Gazeta.ua|language=uk}} Nonetheless, both governments of the Ukrainian People's Republic as well as the Ukrainian State defined that the upper half would be light-blue, while the lower would be yellow. During 1918 it was taken into consideration that light blue would lose its shade under sun, therefore it was decided to make the colour darker. + +Already in the 1918 draft of the Constitution of the Ukrainian People's Republic, the order of colours was defined as blue and yellow. The same order could be found in legislative acts of the [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] for November 1918 and the [[Republic of Carpathian Ukraine]] on 15 March 1939. The argument on the order of colours was taking place in the [[Ukrainian diaspora]] as well. In 1949 it was decided that, until Ukraine defined a single state flag, the diaspora would use the blue-and-yellow banner. ===Attempts to revive Soviet flags=== On 21 April 2011, the [[Verkhovna Rada]] passed a law allowing the [[Victory Banner (Soviet Union)|Victory Banner]] to be raised on Victory Day.{{Cite news |title=РАДА ЗОБОВ'ЯЗАЛА ВИВІШУВАТИ ЧЕРВОНІ ПРАПОРИ НА 9 ТРАВНЯ (Rada enforced raising red flags on the May 9) |url=https://www.istpravda.com.ua/short/2011/04/21/36767/|access-date=2022-03-04|website= [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] Історична правда |date=April 21, 2011}} The current Victory Banner was adopted in [[Russia]] in 2007. On 20 May 2011, the law was signed by the [[President of Ukraine]] [[Viktor Yanukovych]].{{Cite news |title=ЯНУКОВИЧ ПІДПИСАВ ЗАКОН ПРО ЧЕРВОНИЙ ПРАПОР (Yanukovych signed the law about the Red Banner) |url=https://www.istpravda.com.ua/short/2011/05/21/39383/ |access-date=2022-03-04 |website=[[Ukrayinska Pravda]] Історична правда |date=}} On 17 June 2011, the [[Constitutional Court of Ukraine]] recognised the law as unconstitutional and proposed that the parliament implement required amendments to the [[Constitution of Ukraine]].{{Cite news|title=КС Украины признал неконституционным использование красного знамени Победы (CC of Ukraine recognised the use of Red Victory Banner as non-constitutional) |url=https://rg.ru/2011/06/17/znamya-anons.html|access-date=2022-03-04|website=Russian Gazette Российская газета |date=June 17, 2011 |language=ru}} On 9 April 2015, the Ukrainian parliament passed legislation on [[decommunization in Ukraine|decommunization]], banning the promotion of symbols of “[[Communist]] and [[National Socialist]] [[totalitarian regime]]s".{{cite news|url= http://www.newsweek.com/ukraine-purges-symbols-its-communist-past-321663 |title= Ukraine Purges Symbols of Its Communist Past |first= Nolan |last= Peterson |work= [[Newsweek]] |date= 10 April 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}}
{{cite news |url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/259775.html |title= Rada bans Communist, Nazi propaganda in Ukraine |work= [[Interfax-Ukraine]] |date= 9 April 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}}
{{cite news|url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/apr/20/ukraine-decommunisation-law-soviet |title= Ukraine to rewrite Soviet history with controversial 'decommunisation' laws |first= Lily |last= Hyde |work= [[The Guardian]] |date= 20 April 2015 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20150516095241/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/apr/20/ukraine-decommunisation-law-soviet |archive-date= 16 May 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}} Since then, Soviet symbols, like the Victory Banner, have only been allowed in cemeteries.{{cite news|url= https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-32267075 |first= Vitaly |last= Shevchenko |title= Goodbye, Lenin: Ukraine moves to ban communist symbols |work= [[BBC News]] |date=14 April 2015 |access-date= 17 May 2015}}

 The [[national flag]] of [[Ukraine]] ({{lang-uk|Прапор України|Prapor Ukrayiny|link=yes}}) consists of equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow.
 
-The blue and yellow bicolour first appeared during the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]] in [[Lviv|Lemberg]], then part of the [[Austrian Empire]]. It was adopted as a state flag for the first time in the aftermath of the [[Russian Revolution]] by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], the [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] and the [[Ukrainian State]]. It was also later adopted by [[Carpatho-Ukraine]] in March 1939. When [[Ukraine]] was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the bicolour was banned and it used [[flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]] which featured a [[red flag]] along with the azure bottom with a golden [[hammer and sickle]] and a golden bordered [[red star]] on top. During the [[dissolution of the Soviet Union]], the bicolour gradually returned in use before officially being adopted again on 28 January 1992 by the [[Verkhovna Rada|Ukrainian parliament]].
+The blue and yellow bicolour first appeared during the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]] in [[Lviv|Lemberg]], then part of the [[Austrian Empire]]. It was adopted as a state flag for the first time in the aftermath of the [[Russian Revolution]] by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], the [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] and the [[Ukrainian State]]. It was also later adopted by [[Carpatho-Ukraine]] in March 1939. When [[Ukraine]] was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the bicolour was banned and it used the [[flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]] which featured a [[red flag]] along with the azure bottom with a golden [[hammer and sickle]] and a golden-bordered [[red star]] on top. During the [[dissolution of the Soviet Union]], the bicolour gradually returned in use before officially being adopted again on 28 January 1992 by the [[Verkhovna Rada|Ukrainian parliament]].
 
 Ukraine has celebrated the [[Day of the National Flag (Ukraine)|Day of the National Flag]] on 23 August since 2004.

 ===Soviet Ukraine: 1922–1991===
 {{Main|Flag of the Ukrainian SSR}}
-[[File:Ukrainian flag 1966.jpg|thumb|Photo of the Ukrainian flag confiscated by the KGB after it was flown in one of the Kyiv universities in 1966. The flag contains lines of the [[Ukrainian anthem]]: "Ukraine has not perished, it has not been killed".]]
+[[File:Ukrainian flag 1966.jpg|thumb|Photo of the Ukrainian flag confiscated by the KGB after it was flown in one of the Kyiv universities in 1966. The flag contains lines alluding to the [[Ukrainian anthem]]: "Ukraine has not perished, it has not been killed".]]
 During Soviet rule, the Ukrainian flag was banned,<ref>{{Cite news |title=The Revolution On Granite: Ukraine's 'First Maidan' |url=https://www.rferl.org/a/the-revolution-on-granite-ukraine-s-first-maidan-kyiv/30892599.html |access-date=2022-03-04 |website=[[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] |language=en}}</ref> and anyone displaying it could be criminally prosecuted for "anti-Soviet propaganda". The first flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic was adopted on 10 March 1919, to serve as the symbol of state of [[Soviet Ukraine]]. Details of the official flag changed periodically before the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991, but all were based on the red flag of the [[October Revolution]] in Russia and an exact replica of the flags of the neighbouring [[Russian SFSR]].
 The first flag was red with the gold Cyrillic sans-serif letters У.С.С.Р. (USSR, acronym for Ukrayinskaya Sotsialisticheskaya Sovetskaya Respublika in the [[Russian language]]). In the 1930s, a gold border was added to the flag. In 1937, a new flag was adopted, with a small gold hammer and sickle added above the gold Cyrillic serif У.Р.С.Р. (URSR, for Ukrayins’ka Radyans’ka Sotsialistychna Respublika in the Ukrainian language).

-The [[national flag]] of [[Ukraine]] ({{lang-uk|Прапор України|Prapor Ukrayiny|link=no}}) consists of equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow.
+The [[national flag]] of [[Ukraine]] ({{lang-uk|Прапор України|Prapor Ukrayiny|link=yes}}) consists of equally sized horizontal bands of blue and yellow.
 
 The blue and yellow bicolour first appeared during the 1848 [[Revolutions of 1848|Spring of Nations]] in [[Lviv|Lemberg]], then part of the [[Austrian Empire]]. It was adopted as a state flag for the first time in the aftermath of the [[Russian Revolution]] by the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], the [[West Ukrainian People's Republic]] and the [[Ukrainian State]]. It was also later adopted by [[Carpatho-Ukraine]] in March 1939. When [[Ukraine]] was part of the [[Soviet Union]], the bicolour was banned and it used [[flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]] which featured a [[red flag]] along with the azure bottom with a golden [[hammer and sickle]] and a golden bordered [[red star]] on top. During the [[dissolution of the Soviet Union]], the bicolour gradually returned in use before officially being adopted again on 28 January 1992 by the [[Verkhovna Rada|Ukrainian parliament]].

 There has been disagreement over the shade of blue used in the flag. In 2013, scholar Dmytro Malakov argued that [[sky blue]] was the correct colour, and that, according to [[Rule of tincture|rules of heraldry]], [[Dark blue (color)|dark blue]] should not be used.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_sino-zhovtij-prapor-ce-znuschannya-nad-ukrajinskoyu-tradicieyu/508746 |trans-title=The dark blue and yellow flag is a mockery of Ukrainian tradition |title=Синьо-жовтий прапор – це знущання над українською традицією |work=[[Gazeta.ua]] |date=July 25, 2013 |first=Olga |last=Skorokhod |language=uk}}</ref> The [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]] stated that this [[heraldry]] issue does not apply to flags.<ref name=grechylo/>
 
-The flag is similar to that of the [[States of Austria|Austrian state]] of [[Lower Austria]], the [[Germany|German]] city of [[Chemnitz]], historical [[Kingdom of Dalmatia]] (now Croatia) and the [[Hungary|Hungarian]] city of [[Pécs]], but all of those flags have a darker shade of blue. The flag is also somewhat similar to that of the [[States and federal territories of Malaysia|Malaysian state]] of [[Flag and coat of arms of Perlis|Perlis]] and the [[England|English]] county of [[Flag of County Durham|Durham]] (without the cross), but has a reversed colour arrangement, darker shades of blue and yellow, and a different [[aspect ratio]].
+The flag is similar to that of the [[States of Austria|Austrian state]] of [[Lower Austria]], the [[Germany|German]] city of [[Chemnitz]], historical [[Kingdom of Dalmatia]] (now Croatia) and the [[Hungary|Hungarian]] city of [[Pécs]], but all of those flags have a darker shade of blue. The flag is also somewhat similar to that of the [[States and federal territories of Malaysia|Malaysian state]] of [[Flag and coat of arms of Perlis|Perlis]] and the [[England|English]] county of [[Flag of County Durham|Durham]] (without the cross), but has a reversed colour arrangement, lighter shades of blue and yellow, and a different [[aspect ratio]].

 There has been disagreement over the shade of blue used in the flag. In 2013, scholar Dmytro Malakov argued that [[sky blue]] was the correct colour, and that, according to [[Rule of tincture|rules of heraldry]], [[Dark blue (color)|dark blue]] should not be used.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://gazeta.ua/articles/history/_sino-zhovtij-prapor-ce-znuschannya-nad-ukrajinskoyu-tradicieyu/508746 |trans-title=The dark blue and yellow flag is a mockery of Ukrainian tradition |title=Синьо-жовтий прапор – це знущання над українською традицією |work=[[Gazeta.ua]] |date=July 25, 2013 |first=Olga |last=Skorokhod |language=uk}}</ref> The [[Ukrainian Heraldry Society]] stated that this [[heraldry]] issue does not apply to flags.<ref name=grechylo/>
 
-The flag is similar to that of the [[States of Austria|Austrian state]] of [[Lower Austria]], the [[Germany|German]] city of [[Chemnitz]], historical [[Kingdom of Dalmatia]] (now Croatia) and the [[Hungary|Hungarian]] city of [[Pécs]], but all of those flags have a darker shade of blue. The flag is also somewhat similar to that of the [[States and federal territories of Malaysia|Malaysian state]] of [[Flag and coat of arms of Perlis|Perlis]], but has a reversed colour arrangement, darker shades of blue and yellow, and a different [[aspect ratio]].
+The flag is similar to that of the [[States of Austria|Austrian state]] of [[Lower Austria]], the [[Germany|German]] city of [[Chemnitz]], historical [[Kingdom of Dalmatia]] (now Croatia) and the [[Hungary|Hungarian]] city of [[Pécs]], but all of those flags have a darker shade of blue. The flag is also somewhat similar to that of the [[States and federal territories of Malaysia|Malaysian state]] of [[Flag and coat of arms of Perlis|Perlis]] and the [[England|English]] county of [[Flag of County Durham|Durham]] (without the cross), but has a reversed colour arrangement, darker shades of blue and yellow, and a different [[aspect ratio]].

 ===Display at half-staff===
 The flag is displayed at [[Half-mast|half-staff]] (or half-mast) as a sign of respect or [[mourning]]. When done nationwide, such a step is proclaimed by the president. Half-mast means flying a flag two-thirds of the way up a flagpole; the top of the flag must be at least a flag's height from the top of the flagpole. Black ribbons indicate mourning on banners that can't be lowered to half-mast.

 The events in the Baltic countries soon led to similar patterns in Ukraine. -* On 14 March 1990, the Ukrainian flag was raised for the first time since the establishment of the Soviet Union in the small city of [[Stryi]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=History of evolution of the State Flag of Ukraine |url=http://www.ukrinform.ua/ukr/news/istoriya_evolyutsiii_dergavnogo_prapora_ukraiini_infografika_2084779 |work=[[Ukrinform]] |date=August 23, 2015|access-date=2022-03-04|language=uk}} {{Cite web |url=http://www.ukrinform.ua/ukr/news/istoriya_evolyutsiii_dergavnogo_prapora_ukraiini_infografika_2084779 |title=Archived copy |access-date=23 August 2015 |archive-date=17 August 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150817220933/http://www.ukrinform.ua/ukr/news/istoriya_evolyutsiii_dergavnogo_prapora_ukraiini_infografika_2084779 |url-status=bot: unknown }}</ref>
+* On 14 March 1990, the Ukrainian flag was raised for the first time since the establishment of the Soviet Union in the small city of [[Stryi]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=History of evolution of the State Flag of Ukraine |url=http://www.ukrinform.ua/ukr/news/istoriya_evolyutsiii_dergavnogo_prapora_ukraiini_infografika_2084779 |work=[[Ukrinform]] |date=August 23, 2015|access-date=2022-03-04|language=uk}} {{Cite web |url=http://www.ukrinform.ua/ukr/news/istoriya_evolyutsiii_dergavnogo_prapora_ukraiini_infografika_2084779 |title=Укрінформ - актуальні новини України та світу |access-date=23 August 2015 |archive-date=17 August 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150817220933/http://www.ukrinform.ua/ukr/news/istoriya_evolyutsiii_dergavnogo_prapora_ukraiini_infografika_2084779 |url-status=bot: unknown }}</ref>
 * On 20 March 1990, the [[Ternopil]] town council voted on the use and re-establishment of the yellow-and-blue flag and the [[Coat of arms of Ukraine|''tryzub'']] and ''[[Ukraine's glory has not perished|Shche ne vmerla Ukrainy]]'' national anthem. The same day, the yellow-and-blue national flag was flown for the first time in 80 years on a governmental building in Kyiv, replacing the then-official [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|red-azure flag]] of the Ukrainian SSR.
 * On 28 April 1990, the [[Lviv Oblast|Lviv]] oblast council (''oblasna rada'') also allowed the use of the national symbols of Ukraine within the Oblast.
 * On 29 April 1990, the yellow-and-blue flag was flown from the Ternopil city theatre's flagstaff without the [[flag of the Soviet Union]] hanging above it.

 ==Flag of the head of state==
-Throughout the history of [[Ukraine]], various [[List of heads of state of Ukraine|heads of state]] have used different flags. The designs differ according to the historical era they were used in and in accordance with the political scene in [[Ukraine]] at the time. The first flag to be used by a [[List of heads of state of Ukraine|head of state of Ukraine]] was that of [[Pavlo Skoropadskyi]]. The current design, the flag of the [[President of Ukraine]], was adopted in 1999. In 2022 the President of Ukraine used a variant where the left side of the blue upper-half contains the yellow ''[[Coat of arms of Ukraine|Tryzub]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Basu|first=Zachary|date=2022-03-01|title=Zelensky tells European Parliament "nobody is going to break us" in emotional appeal|url=https://www.axios.com/zelensky-video-european-parliament-address-ukraine-ed88a2e1-ff9e-471c-9a4d-92e0406ff541.html|access-date=2022-03-04|website=Axios|language=en}}</ref>

@@ -91,24 +91,23 @@
 
 ===Particular days for display===
 In particular, the flag should be displayed at full staff on the following days:
-* 1 January: [[New Year's Day]] (День нового року)
-* 7 January: [[Christmas#Date according to Julian calendar|Christmas (Julian)]] (Різдво (Юліан))
-* 22 January: Ukrainian Unity and Freedom Day (День Соборності та Свободи України)
-* 8 March: [[International Women's Day]] (Міжнародний жіночий день)
-* 1 & 2 May: [[International Workers' Day|Labor Day]] (День праці)
-* 8 May: [[Victory Day over Nazism in World War II]] (День перемоги над нацизмом у Другій світовій війні)
-* 9 May: [[Europe Day]] (День Європи)
-* 28 June: Constitution Day (День Конституції)
-* 23 August: [[Day of the National Flag (Ukraine)|Day of the National Flag]] (День державного прапора)
-* 24 August: [[Independence Day of Ukraine|Independence Day]] (День Незалежності)
-* 13 October: Defenders of Ukraine Day (День захисника України)
-* 21 November: Day of Dignity and Freedom (День Гідності та Свободи)
-* 6 December: Armed Forces Day (День збройних сил)
-* 25 December: Christmas (Gregorian/Neo-Julian) (Різдво (григоріанський/нео-юліанський))
+* 1 January: [[New Year's Day]]
+* 7 January: [[Christmas#Date according to Julian calendar|Christmas (Julian)]]
+* 22 January: Ukrainian Unity and Freedom Day
+* 8 March: International Women's Day
+* 1 & 2 May: [[International Workers' Day]]
+* 9 May: Victory Day over Nazism
+* 28 June: Constitution Day
+* 23 August: Flag Day
+* 24 August: Independence Day
+* 13 October: Defenders of Ukraine Day
+* 21 November: Day of Dignity and Freedom
+* 6 December: Armed Forces Day
+* 25 December: Christmas (Gregorian/Neo-Julian)
 
 ===Display at half-staff===
 The flag is displayed at [[Half-mast|half-staff]] (or half-mast) as a sign of respect or [[mourning]]. When done nationwide, such a step is proclaimed by the president. Half-mast means flying a flag two-thirds of the way up a flagpole; the top of the flag must be at least a flag's height from the top of the flagpole. Black ribbons indicate mourning on banners that can't be lowered to half-mast.
-* 4th Saturday of November: [[Holodomor Memorial Day]] (День пам'яті жертв голодоморів)
+* 4th Saturday of November: [[Holodomor Memorial Day]]
 * Other historical cases: mass victims of accidents, [[Russo-Ukrainian War]] and [[Euromaidan]]; [[death and state funeral of Lech and Maria Kaczyński]], [[funeral of Pope John Paul II]] and [[11 September attacks]].
 
 ==Flag Day==

**Not Weaponised**: The changes appear to be a simplification of the text rather than an attempt to alter the cultural narrative or weaponize cultural heritage. The removal of translations does not inherently promote a specific political agenda or narrative.

@@ -158,7 +158,7 @@
 
 ===Soviet Ukraine: 1922–1991===
 {{Main|Flag of the Ukrainian SSR}}
-[[File:Ukrainian flag 1966.jpg|thumb|Photo of the Ukrainian flag confiscated by the KGB after it was flown in one of the Kyiv universities in 1966. The flag contains lines alluding to the [[Ukrainian anthem]]: "Ukraine has not perished, it has not been killed".]]
+[[File:Ukrainian flag 1966.jpg|thumb|Photo of the Ukrainian flag confiscated by the KGB after it was flown in one of the Kyiv universities in 1966. The flag contains lines alluding to the [[Ukrainian anthem]]: "Ukraine has not perished, it has not been killed yet".]]
 During Soviet rule, the Ukrainian flag was banned,<ref>{{Cite news |title=The Revolution On Granite: Ukraine's 'First Maidan' |url=https://www.rferl.org/a/the-revolution-on-granite-ukraine-s-first-maidan-kyiv/30892599.html |access-date=2022-03-04 |website=[[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] |language=en}}</ref> and anyone displaying it could be criminally prosecuted for "anti-Soviet propaganda". The first flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic was adopted on 10 March 1919, to serve as the symbol of state of [[Soviet Ukraine]]. Details of the official flag changed periodically before the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991, but all were based on the red flag of the [[October Revolution]] in Russia and an exact replica of the flags of the neighbouring [[Russian SFSR]].
 The first flag was red with the gold Cyrillic sans-serif letters У.С.С.Р. (USSR, acronym for Ukrayinskaya Sotsialisticheskaya Sovetskaya Respublika in the [[Russian language]]). In the 1930s, a gold border was added to the flag. In 1937, a new flag was adopted, with a small gold hammer and sickle added above the gold Cyrillic serif У.Р.С.Р. (URSR, for Ukrayins’ka Radyans’ka Sotsialistychna Respublika in the Ukrainian language).
